HEADLINE: Newark Gives Travel Agents a Peek at the Future of Tourism

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Aug. 8

 BODY:
This is not a place that immediately leaps to mind when people think of tourism destinations.
But when 40 travel agents showed up here tonight for the beginning of a two-day tour of Newark's neighborhoods, parks and partly revitalized downtown, they got an intriguing glimpse of something that probably could not have happened at another time in the last four decades: the selling of Newark. 
 The gathering, known in the tourism business as "a mystery tour" in which the visiting agents are given only a general idea of what they will be seeing, is the first time in the memory of city officials and local tourism experts that the city has so aggressively sought its share of an estimated $7.5 billion annual tourist market in northern New Jersey.
It was an effort that would not have been possible until now in a city whose image has long been defined by the devastating riots of 1967.
Indeed, along with a recent advertising campaign organized by a consortium of business and civic groups to promote the city to corporations looking for office space, the tour was part of Newark's efforts to capitalize on a thriving economy and a pervasive sense of opportunity.
"The idea that we are the capital of bad inner cities is gone," said Councilwoman Gayle Chaneyfield-Jenkins, a member of the City Council's newly energized tourism committee, which is co-sponsoring the tour with the Gateway Tourism Council and the New Jersey chapter of the American Society of Travel Agents.
"The view here is that we are one of the great cities -- not the prettiest, because we have our warts, but not the ugliest either," she said. "It's like a house that is being remodeled but isn't quite there. But it's good enough to invite guests in."
Mark Shapiro, the president of the New Jersey chapter of the travel agents group, said that at first the idea of Newark was "a tough sell" to a busload of savvy travel agents.
"Their first reaction," he said, "was 'Are you out of your mind?' But now they are very excited."
Today's tour comes on the heels of the advertising campaign unveiled this summer by corporate leaders. It began with a six-week print campaign featuring full-page testimonials from new and longtime business leaders in the city telling of advantages like the transportation network, nearby airport, fiber optics infrastructure and office rents that are a fraction of the Manhattan rents just a 15-minute train ride away.
Dan Gales, executive director of Connection-Newark, the private economic development group that helped organize the campaign, said that the goal was to demonstrate that changes in Newark were real and not just public relations hype.
To that end, the campaign stresses things that are already completed in the city and plays down such things as a proposed downtown sports arena for the New Jersey Nets and New Jersey Devils, the construction that just began on the regional headquarters of the credit-card giant M.B.N.A., and the newly opened Starbucks.
"We are trying to demonstrate that Newark is more than just the promise of future activity or things that we think will happen," said William Freeman, the president for public communications of Verizon and one of the business leaders behind the ad campaign. "We want to show businesses and others thinking about locating here that they aren't pioneers and that the pioneering has already been done."
The group is still assessing the impact of the print ad campaign, which ended in late June, as it prepares to run a similar ad campaign on television. A Web site set up for businesses interested in Newark received 30,000 to 40,000 hits a week during the campaign, which ran from May 28 to July 5. It featured ads in The Star Ledger, The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and local ethnic papers. Before the ads ran, the site received about 5,000 hits a week.
As they began their tour this evening at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, many of the travel agents did sound a bit like wary pioneers while others with memories of a long-ago Newark were just glad that someone was giving them a reason to think about returning.
"I live an hour away but never came to Newark because, frankly, there wasn't much reason," said Ralph Ferrara of Schneider Travel Service in Butler, N.J. "I'm very anxious now to see why I should come here."
After a reception tonight at the Newark Museum, the tour will take many of the travel agents tomorrow to Branch Brook Park, a sprawling area designed by Frederick Law Olmstead that has more cherry blossoms than Washington's Tidal Basin. They will visit the Basilica of the Sacred Heart, rebuilt residential areas like Society Hill in the Central Ward where the 1967 riots began, and stalwart older communities like Forest Heights with its hardy Victorian houses. They will visit the home of the New Jersey Historical Society and tour the minor-league baseball park Riverfront Stadium and one of the newly renovated downtown office buildings that is attracting lawyers and high-tech businesses.
For Claudette Jones of Voyager Travel in Trenton, the tour was "a great, great opportunity" to sample the improvements in the city that she has heard about. For Salvatore Castoria, of A Better Trip in Matawan, N.J., the "bad outweighed the good in Newark" for a long time, but the tour gave him a chance to learn a lot of positive things about the city.
"You're not going to go here instead of Miami Beach," Aland Landesman said, "but for a day or two while visiting the region it's fine."
Richard Copland, the incoming president of the American Society of Travel Agents, who runs Hillside Travel in the Bronx, was impressed mostly by the $187 million New Jersey Performing Arts Center, which he said was among the attractions that could help Newark attract some of the "spillover" tourism from New York, which is bursting at the seams with tourists.
"There's a lot of money out there now, and people who travel want options like a baseball game, entertainment, restaurants," Mr. Copland said. "Five years ago you wouldn't come here and would be talking instead about the poverty and drug addiction of Newark. But that has changed, and I'm impressed."
But some Newark travel agents, like Lorraine Lavender of Grand Travel Inc., were less convinced of the city's appeal. Many of the amenities that tourists seek were not here in abundance, she said, adding that greater economic development and the influx of more businesses was necessary before the city could be a true tourist destination.
"When 6 o'clock comes, they are like cattle leaving," she said, referring to people who work in many of the city's office buildings.
But Kevin Jenkins, the husband of Councilwoman Chaneyfield-Jenkins, said there was ample recent history of urban turnarounds to give him confidence that Newark's efforts to sell itself to business as well as tourism had a shot at success.
"They said it was wishful thinking in Cleveland, in Baltimore and Boston," he said. "Look at those places. Who's dreaming?"

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE RECORD;
An Ally of Big Business Balances a Friend of the Earth

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
At a Democratic fund-raiser last month at the Upper West Side duplex apartment of the singer Paul Simon, Vice President Al Gore was introduced by Connecticut's senators, Christopher J. Dodd and Joseph I. Lieberman.
After some preliminary remarks about the strength of the economy and the old ideas of Republicans, Mr. Gore began to bash big oil and big insurance companies, a staple nowadays of his stump speech. 
 "We need to give the medical decisions back to the doctors, and take them away from the accountants and the H.M.O.'s and the insurance companies," he declared.
The moment Mr. Gore uttered the words "insurance companies," several of the people in Mr. Simon's living room snickered loudly. Insurance is to Connecticut what oil is to Oklahoma, what automobiles are to Michigan, what tobacco is to Kentucky. And Mr. Lieberman has been a staunch ally of the industry.
Indeed, on a broad array of issues, Mr. Lieberman is perceived as a business-friendly Democrat. On some issues, including those that affect the insurance industry, he has been much more of a business ally than Mr. Gore. This could help the Democratic ticket in its fund-raising and in reassuring corporate leaders who are nervous about Mr. Gore's environmental views.
For example, Mr. Lieberman is one of a handful of Democrats who support legislation to limit the amount of damages that can be collected from lawsuits. Such legislation has been at the top of corporate America's Washington wish list for more than a decade. Insurance companies have led the battle in favor it. Trial lawyers, among the Democratic Party's biggest contributors, have led the fight against the limits on damages. Mr. Lieberman has always been on the side of the insurance business. Mr. Gore has always been with the lawyers.
"We consider Mr. Lieberman a friend of the insurance industry," said Jack Dolan, a spokesman for the American Council of Life Insurance.
By the same token, Mr. Lieberman has regularly voted for increases in the Pentagon's budget. Two major defense contractors, the General Dynamics Corporation and the United Technologies Corporation, have plants in Connecticut that employ thousands of workers.
Mr. Lieberman has been an ally of other companies that Mr. Gore has blasted in recent speeches, including pharmaceutical companies. Several, including the Bayer Corporation, the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company and Pfizer Inc., have operations in Connecticut. In 1997, when the Senate was considering legislation to reauthorize the Food and Drug Administration, Mr. Lieberman was among the few Democrats who voted on the side of the drug industry on important amendments.
Mr. Lieberman has been rewarded for this support with campaign donations. The Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan organization that tracks campaign money, reported today that Mr. Lieberman had received more money from the insurance interests for his Senate race this year than any other senator ($197,419), and more from pharmaceutical interests ($91,150) than any other senator except Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, who is chairman of the Finance Committee's subcommittee on health. Mr. Lieberman has also received nearly $100,000 from political action committees and individuals connected to defense contractors.
It is not surprising that Mr. Lieberman has been a standard bearer for important industries in his state. A politician who did not do that would not last very long in office.
But as Democrats go, Mr. Lieberman has been quite friendly to business generally, something that could reassure corporate interests that have been tepid about Mr. Gore. Frank Coleman, a spokesman for the United States Chamber of Commerce, said that in his two terms in the Senate, Mr. Lieberman had voted on the side of business interests more than almost any other Democrat.
Mr. Lieberman is a vigorous supporter of international trade, a position similar to Mr. Gore's but different from many Democrats, and he is one of the few Democrats in the Senate who favors a reduction in the capital gains tax.
In Silicon Valley, Mr. Lieberman is hailed as the senator who saved stock options.
In 1994, accounting rulemakers considered changing the accounting procedures for stock options in a way that would have reduced the reported profits of companies that granted options to executives and other employees. It was one of the first Congressional issues to attract lobbying from executives in Silicon Valley.
First, Mr. Lieberman pushed through the Senate a nonbinding resolution that denounced the Financial Accounting Standards Board, the arbiter of accounting procedures, for trying to change the rules. Then he introduced legislation to restrict the authority of the board. After that, the board backed down.
In part for his role in the options fight, the American Electronic Association, a trade group of technology companies, named Mr. Lieberman to the "high-tech legislative hall of fame." Mr. Gore considers the high-tech community an important constituency and has held many fund-raising events and meetings with its executives.
Mr. Lieberman's record in support of business interests could help Democratic fund-raising for the fall campaign.
"Senator Lieberman's record on fiscal responsibility and issues with regard to business generally has been very strong, very moderate and ought to be very attractive to the business community," said Joel Jankowsky, who heads the lobbying arm of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld, a Washington law firm.
There is a business constituency that remains nervous about Mr. Lieberman: Hollywood. Entertainment executives, one of the Democratic Party's most important cash constituencies, are nervous about his embrace of the V-chip and his alliance with William J. Bennett, the former education secretary under President Ronald Reagan, in denouncing excessive violence and sex in movies, television and music. But that will not stop entertainment executives from organizing lavish parties for the Democratic ticket next week at the Democratic convention in Los Angeles.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 12, 2000, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An editorial on Wednesday about Texas executions erred in saying that the Supreme Court has ruled that executing minors under age 16 violates the Constitution. In 1988, in a 5-to-4 decision overturning an Oklahoma statute, four justices agreed that executing a person who was 15 years old at the time a crime was committed would be unconstitutional; a fifth justice concurred on narrower grounds.

HEADLINE: No Lectures or Teachers, Just Software

BYLINE: By JOSHUA GREEN

 BODY:
THE red phone on your desk rings in the middle of the night. The voice you hear is that of the White House chief of staff, alerting you to a crisis in the Eastern European country of Krasnovia. You're needed at the White House, pronto. "We'll send a limo," he says, and hangs up. After an emergency meeting with the president, you're given a classified intelligence report and access to the country's foremost diplomats, policy analysts and military leaders. You are to submit a report in time for a presidential address that evening. The president is waiting to act on your recommendation.
This is high school, circa 2010. 
 The scene is from an interactive software course, Crisis in Krasnovia, that its creator, Roger C. Schank, believes will revolutionize how children are taught.
"Software is going to replace classes as we know them," said Dr. Schank, director of the Institute for Learning Sciences at Northwestern University. After a career studying artificial intelligence at Stanford and Yale, Dr. Schank has shifted his sights from teaching computers to teaching students. In 1995, he founded Cognitive Arts, a company that is exploring commercial uses of software-based teaching.
A critic of traditional teaching methods, Dr. Schank wants to use technology to overhaul the entire educational system. "The computer is our Trojan mouse," he said. "It allows us to get our foot in the door to do something radical and difficult."
Through the Institute for Learning Sciences and Cognitive Arts, Dr. Schank and his staff have developed more than 100 programs, many of them, like Krasnovia, purely for learning research. But the company has also created courses for clients like Arthur Andersen, the Environmental Protection Agency and the United States Air Force.
Dr. Schank is marketing his courses to universities and believes they will be attracted by the potential savings and by the program's academic pedigree. In May, Cognitive Arts announced it would join with Columbia University to develop 80 software-based courses that correspond directly to existing Columbia courses. In June, Harvard Business School said it would begin offering pre-enrollment software courses designed by Cognitive Arts to students who had been accepted for enrollment.
Dr. Schank's programs combine the look of high-tech video games with a Mission Impossible-style narrative. A course in biology, for instance, might challenge students to stop a worldwide virus outbreak; an economics course might have them play the role of adviser to the chairman of the Federal Reserve; a physics course might entail building a rocket and landing it on the moon. In essence, each software course is like an elaborate choose-your-own-ending novel.
The aim is to get students to delve into a course's volumes of academic information, including hours of videotape of experts in a field related to the program. Students running Krasnovia, for example, can draw on video advice from Thomas Boyatt, a former ambassador, and Bruce Laingen, an American diplomat who was held hostage in Iran and is president of the American Academy of Diplomacy.
Rather than subject students to full-blown lectures, Dr. Schank breaks the video into snippets that address only the question at hand. He believes students learn more effectively through this piecemeal approach, which he calls "just in time" learning.
"The value of the computer is that it allows kids to learn by doing," he said. "People don't learn by being talked at. They learn when they attempt to do something and fail. Learning happens when they try to figure out why."
Bald, bearded and powerfully built, Dr. Schank's appearance and demeanor suggest Marlon Brando in the movie "Apocalypse Now." His professional reputation is somewhat similar. His brusque manner and outspoken criticism of those he disagrees with have alienated some colleagues and earned him the reputation of iconoclast. But his success in designing teaching software has made him a much sought after figure among businesses, military clients and universities.
His company puts extraordinary effort into creating software courses, each of which can take up to a year to design and can cost up to $1 million. Video is an important component of Dr. Schank's program. After interviewing professors, his staff develops a story, writes a script, hires professional actors and begins filming. Cognitive Arts even arranged the use of CNN footage of the Bosnian conflict to lend the aura of authenticity to Crisis in Krasnovia.
The programs allow students to progress at their own pace. Dr. Schank says the semester system is badly outdated, a view he also holds for most tests, which foster only temporary memorization, he says. His programs require students to write detailed reports on what they have learned. A student who cuts corners does not finish the course, and the failing grade is delivered in the spirit of a video game. In Krasnovia, for instance, an incomplete report would draw a mock newscast in which commentators ridicule the president's address. Students must then go back and improve their work.
These multimedia simulations differ radically from current online offerings. "When you look at online courses now, what do you see?" Dr. Schank said. "Text online with a quiz. We're not taking a lecture and putting it on screen. We're restructuring these courses into goal-based scenarios that will get kids excited."
Dr. Schank says that such courses will render traditional classes -- and many professors -- obsolete. "The idea of one professor for one class is ancient," he said. "New technology is going to give every student access to the best professors in the world."
But many academics dismiss Dr. Schank's prediction that traditional teaching methods will soon become obsolete and question software learning's pedagogic value. "Education depends on relationships between people," said David F. Noble, a history professor at York University in Toronto and a critic of online learning. "Interactive is not the same as interpersonal. What Schank doesn't recognize is that teaching is not just about relaying knowledge."
Others warn against accepting radical new technology without pause. "The American university system is a highly functional institution," said Phil Agre, an associate professor of information studies at the University of California at Los Angeles. "The danger is that we will apply overly simplistic ideas about technology and tear apart the institution before we really know what we're doing."
Another assessment of the value of Dr. Schank's work is offered by Prof. Howard Nusbaum, chairman of the psychology department at the University of Chicago. "Schank's idea in principal is a very sound one," Professor Nusbaum said. "But in the case of software learning, its success or failure will depend on implementation more than theory."
Several of the country's top universities are experimenting with ways to implement new technology-based teaching methods. Seymour Papert, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Media Laboratory, was among the first to advocate computers as teaching tools.
"The world is changing so fast that the concept of schools teaching people what they need to know is no longer viable," Dr. Papert said. "We're moving into a time when people need to know how to learn things they weren't taught in school. Second, we now have the technology to let kids learn better. This will not just allow them to learn the same things better; it will teach kids to learn radical new things at all ages."
Mitchel Resnick, another professor at M.I.T.'s Media Laboratory, said: "Computers offer kids multiple ways to learn, where in the past there was only one way. Ultimately, you want kids to have a tool chest of different options they can bring to bear when solving problems."
But new technology also threatens to exacerbate current inequities. Dr. Resnick worries that the so-called digital divide will not be one of access to computers but a "fluency gap" between those able to use them for learning and those who merely use them to play games.
Dr. Schank does not think his programs will be a victim of the digital divide. He believes that poorer schools are likely to benefit first from his programs. Top high schools "don't want this -- their kids get into Harvard," he said.
"But poorer schools," he continued, "aren't going to turn down a college level software course that's endorsed by Columbia."
Dr. Schank pointed to the example of the Daniel Jenkins Academy, a public high school in Polk County, Fla., a poor district that will switch to online teaching this fall. Students will gather in classrooms where they will take Web-based classes on computers. They will be taught remotely by teachers working from their homes. Dr. Schank suggested that once disadvantaged students began outperforming those from better schools, many long-held assumptions about teaching will go the way of the slide rule.
"We have a whole country of people who agree on education, and they're all wrong," he said with characteristic bluntness. "School just isn't that relevant anymore. We'll make it relevant. We're trying to overthrow the system."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES;
Crude Oil Prices Rise Sharply After a Report on Inventories

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices surged past $30 a barrel yesterday after an industry report showed that United States inventories were at their lowest levels since 1976.
The report, released after the market closed on Tuesday, heightened concerns about potential supply shortages later this year. Oil inventory levels remain low even though OPEC has increased output twice this year. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has increased production by more than two million barrels a day, or 2.7 percent of worldwide output. 
 "The decline in distillate is very scary because this is when you build inventory for winter," said Bill O'Grady, director of fundamental futures research at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. "If you don't get caught up by the middle of September, you usually don't get caught up."
Crude oil for September delivery rose $1.23, or 4.2 percent, to $30.35 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It was the highest closing price since July 20. Oil prices are up 43 percent from a year ago.
The American Petroleum Institute reported that supplies dropped 2.1 million barrels, to 282.6 million, as a 17 percent rise in imports could not offset near-record demand from refiners. Distillate fuel inventories also fell, with heating oil supplies now 39 percent below levels a year ago.
The Energy Department released its own inventory estimates yesterday, pegging United States crude oil supplies slightly higher, up 1.3 million barrels, to 285.4 million.
"The D.O.E.'s are probably a little more realistic, but still not very comforting," Mr. O'Grady said of the figures.
Most analysts had expected crude oil inventories to rebound, after dropping nine million barrels in the previous week.
In London, Brent crude oil for September settlement rose 97 cents, or 3.4 percent, to $29.87 a barrel on the International Petroleum Exchange. Prices are up 46 percent from a year ago.
"The A.P.I. numbers have pulled the market up," said Simon Stanley, a trader with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in London. "But I don't think they were bullish enough to justify this sort of increase."
In other energy trading in New York, heating oil for September delivery rose 3.71 cents, or 4.7 percent, to 83.54 cents a gallon. Prices are 51 percent higher than a year ago, though well below a nine-year high of $1 reached on Jan. 31.

HEADLINE: Fewer Inflation Alarms in New Fed Survey

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
The economy has slowed, dampening demand and keeping consumer prices in check, the Federal Reserve said today in its latest regional economic survey.
"Easing demand appears to be restraining price increases," said the Fed report, commonly known as the beige book. "District reports suggest consumer spending, manufacturing and construction were slightly softer than in the last report." 
 While labor markets "continue to be very tight" and energy costs have risen, retailers and other businesses are not passing along those costs to consumers in the form of higher prices, "partly because of competitive pressures," the Fed said.
The report suggests that the central bank's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee will not need to raise interest rates to slow the economy at its next meeting, on Aug. 22. The Fed has raised the overnight bank lending rate to 6.5 percent, a nine-year high, in six steps since June 1999.
The report is far less alarmist than previous regional reports, and it will form the basis of the committee's discussion about the state of the economy. The report noted slowdowns or stable growth in virtually every major sector of the economy, including the consumer sector.
The Fed did note that businesses were having difficulty finding workers, with "severe" shortages in the Boston and Kansas City districts. The problem of finding workers was keeping some companies from growing in the districts around Atlanta, Dallas, St. Louis and Richmond, Va.
"A staffing service contact in the Chicago area said that meeting its customers' needs for workers was 'like torture,' " the Fed report said. Fast-food chains in St. Louis are offering their employees free meals, regular pay increases and profit sharing, the Fed said.
The lack of available workers has been a Fed concern for more than a year. Previous Fed surveys on the economy have noted that wages were rising, although with no clear effect on consumer prices.
In the Fed's view, the job market picture appears to be improving. The pool of available workers, after falling steadily since 1996, has stabilized in the last seven months, hovering between 9.8 million and 10.3 million. And the Labor Department said last week that the unemployment rate stayed at 4 percent in July as the economy lost 108,000 jobs.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
I.M.F. Expects Investments in Emerging Countries to Decline

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Private investment in Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe will drop during the next year as investors seek safe havens because of concern the United States economy and stock market will slump, the International Monetary Fund predicted in a report released today.
"The tight link between the performance of emerging and U.S. asset markets has tempered our optimistic outlook for emerging markets financing," the fund said in its first quarterly report on investments in emerging markets. "We expect overall financing flows to moderate in coming quarters." 
 A decline of almost 30 percent in the Nasdaq composite index from March through May prompted investors to pull out of stock and bond markets in economies from South Africa and Russia to Argentina and Indonesia.
That pullout forced developing nations to cut back on the sale of new bonds. Total new bond sales totaled $15.5 billion in April through June -- less than half that issued the previous three months and "comparable to the crisis quarters of 1997," the fund said.
"Only those that really needed to raise money did so, often damaging returns," the report said. Argentina topped that list, selling $2.6 billion in new bonds.
As concern about United States interest rate increases eased in June, equity markets in countries like Argentina and Indonesia and bonds in Turkey and Russia rebounded, the fund's report said.
"A decisive decoupling of emerging from U.S. markets is unlikely," the report said. It predicted that more investors were likely to keep their money in safe markets or in cash, particularly if an expected slowdown in the American economy becomes a so-called hard landing.
As a result of the United States slowdown, investors are shunning developing economies, even though growth in the countries where those markets are based is largely improving, the fund report said.
The poor performance of those markets "was due to the external environment," the report concluded. And that environment was set by markets in richer nations, it said.
Companies eager to issue new equity or countries seeking to sell new bonds, it said, will have to endure "choppy conditions and exploit windows of opportunity."
In the last quarter, the $5.7 billion initial public offering of China Unicom accounted for more than half the total $11.1 billion new equity issues from emerging markets.
The fund also found that investors were changing their analyses of these more risky equity markets, as they begin to invest based on specific industries, not just overall political considerations
. The fund did not forecast how much investment in emerging markets would drop in the next year.

HEADLINE: Gordon Spivack, 71, Antitrust Lawyer and Ex-Justice Official

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Gordon B. Spivack, a prominent antitrust lawyer and former senior Justice Department official, died at his home in New Haven on Sunday. He was 71.
The cause was colon cancer, said Stephen M. Hudspeth, head of the litigation department at Coudert Brothers, the New York City law firm where Mr. Spivack was a senior partner from 1986 until his death. 
 As a lawyer for Coudert and earlier for the firm of Lord, Day & Lord, now defunct, Mr. Spivack's roster of clients included some of the nation's biggest companies, including Cargill, Chevron and Union Carbide. He also represented the Coca-Cola Company for decades, defending the company's often-challenged relationship with bottlers and distributors, and spent much of the 1980's successfully defending Fischbach & Moore, a big electrical contractor, against bid-rigging charges.
Mr. Spivack's move from Lord, Day to Coudert in 1986 played a small but influential role in the evolution of New York's legal profession from a clubby business ruled by tradition into a more open industry. As a government lawyer in the 1950's and 1960's, Mr. Spivack won cases that brought fines and jail time to executives at large corporations including General Electric and Westinghouse.
Born in New Haven, Mr. Spivack graduated from Yale in 1950. After graduation he joined the United States Army, becoming a sergeant first class in the Army's medical corps. Mr. Spivack returned to New Haven in 1952 to enroll in Yale Law School, from which he graduated first in the class of 1955.
That year, when Herbert Brownell Jr. was attorney general, Mr. Spivack joined the Justice Department's antitrust division. Mr. Spivack was the government's lead lawyer when it sued executives at G.E. and Westinghouse in 1960, accusing them of fixing the price of large electrical generators.
In 1965, Mr. Spivack became the department's director of operations, supervising 350 trial lawyers. But in 1967 he returned to Yale Law School as a professor of antitrust law and civil procedure.
"Antitrust was his lifeblood," said Mr. Hudspeth, who was a student of Mr. Spivack. "He lived the antitrust law and believed it was a cornerstone of our democratic polity and of our economic freedom."
In 1970, Mr. Brownell was a partner at Lord, Day and that year he lured Mr. Spivack out of academia to start Lord, Day's antitrust group (though Mr. Spivack taught at Yale at night until 1978). He remained there for more than 15 years, while serving on the President's Commission for Revision of Antitrust Law and Procedures in the late 1970's.
But in 1986, Mr. Spivack took himself, 17 other lawyers and all of his clients to Coudert.
Tellingly, perhaps, Mr. Spivack changed firms because he wanted seven of his associates made into partners and Lord, Day agreed to promote only two.
"To me it's insane to tell people who are highly qualified, 'Go find some other firm because we got some fixed ratio between partners and associates,' " Mr. Spivack said at the time. "I thought I did owe it to these people. Since my own firm did not recognize this, I went looking for someone who did."
At that time, the Spivack defection was perhaps the biggest ever from a major Manhattan law firm, and it helped usher in an era in which much of New York's legal community turned its back on many traditional ways of doing business. Lord, Day itself could not make the transition and closed its doors in 1994.
Mr. Spivack is survived by his wife, Dolores T., of New Haven; a brother, Irving, of Woodbridge, Conn.; two sons, Michael D., of Miami, and Paul S., of New York; and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
An investment bank drops the traditional.

BYLINE: By Bernard Stamler 

 BODY:
THEY don't sell consumer goods. Although they are financial institutions, they don't have street-level branches, tellers or A.T.M.'s. Many people have no idea what they do, and few people will ever interact directly with one.
So just how do you advertise an investment bank? 
 Traditionally, the answer was simple: with "tombstones," the somber boxes in the financial press that announce this big deal or that, complete or in the works. But that was before the Internet economy and its lucrative initial public offerings changed everything, inspiring heightened competition among the players in a once buttoned-down industry. Nowadays, extensive display and broadcast ad campaigns have become the norm.
The latest to join the fray: Robertson Stephens, the San Francisco-based investment banking arm of the FleetBoston Financial Corporation. In an industry dominated by old-line giants like Goldman, Sachs & Company, it is determined to make its mark. Or, at the very least, to carve out its niche.
The company was founded in 1978, not far from Silicon Valley and at about the same time that the high-technology industry there began to blossom. (It was acquired by FleetBoston's predecessor, the BankBoston Corporation, in 1998.) Lately, its revenues have risen sharply, from $360 million in 1998 to $970 million last year to "nearly a billion" so far this year, according to Allen Olivo, its chief marketing officer. Because Robertson Stephens has specialized for years in bringing technology companies to market, with clients like the E*Trade Group, the online investment firm, it is, he said, "the first investment bank to focus on the new economy."
But how can that translate into an advantage over bigger Wall Street-based Johnny-come-latelies? The idea is to build brand, said Mr. Olivo, who has been involved in branding before with companies like Amazon .com and Apple Computer, where he was senior director for marketing communications during the "Think Different" days of the late 1990's. Robertson Stephens was in Silicon Valley, literally and figuratively, before anyone else, he said, and because of that has "knowledge that gives us a unique perspective in a global growth economy."
Hence an unconventional new campaign devised by Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., that breaks today in The New York Times and other newspapers. "Thanks, old economy," proclaim the double-page spreads, words floating on an otherwise blank background. "We'll take it from here."
The ad is intended to "say something, but quietly," said the account director, Trish Adams, and to stress that Robertson Stephens's "culture is a little different from other investment banks." Future print ads, also featuring one-line statements will follow, she said, in publications like The Wall Street Journal, Industry Standard and Fast Company. And, like today's example, they will feature one-line statements -- "headlines," Ms. Adams called them -- that will be more like philosophical statements than hard-sell slogans.
The 30-second Robertson Stephens television spots -- all of them apparently filmed in double or triple time -- also aim to be unconventional in their message, she said, without delving too far into the substance of what, exactly, an investment bank does. In one of them, for example, an off-camera announcer muses about America's westward migration and the fact that there is "still so much more to be done." "It's not time to settle down," he intones as a freighter scoots by the Golden Gate Bridge, waves lapping nearby and San Francisco's skyline barely visible in the distance. "It never is."
In another spot, the same voice asks if "you really think that all the technology in the world can erase economic truths that have held for hundreds of years?" And as clouds speed over the tops of buildings in San Francisco's financial district, shot from a camera looking up at times at nearly a 90-degree angle, he answers the question himself: "So do we. Ladies and gentlemen, this time it's different."
The commercials will run primarily on Bloomberg television, CNBC and CNNfn, Ms. Adams said, beginning this week and continuing through at least the end of the year. And the lack of substance in them and in print is deliberate, she said; for now, the idea is to say "who they are and what they stand for," with respect to Robertson Stephens. Advertising with "more content will be rotated in later," Ms. Adams said.
Neither she nor Mr. Olivo would disclose the size of the Robertson Stephens effort, although the trade press put the figure at $25 million when Wieden & Kennedy was awarded the account back in May. And while Mr. Olivo hopes that the campaign will result in increased business for the firm, that will be only one of the benchmarks by which its success will be gauged, he said. There are other more intangible measures as well.
"Our target is multifaceted," he said, involving, among other things, "recruiting, as we grow in size, and geographically," as well as "getting better known by the public" and wielding "greater influence in the general conversation about the industry."
"We don't want to be the next Goldman, Sachs or Morgan Stanley," Mr. Olivo said. "We're just trying to become the most influential investment bank in the new economy."

SECTION: Section C; Page 8; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 915 words

HEADLINE: Extent of Telephone Strike May Have Surprised Target

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
As Verizon Communications prepares to enter its fifth day of bargaining with its striking unions, the question arises: Has Verizon received more than it bargained for with this strike?
The walkout by 86,000 workers of Verizon, the nation's largest telecommunications employer, has developed into one of the largest and most unruly strikes in years, raising questions about the company's preparation for the contract talks and its handling of the walkout. 
 Management was distracted for the first six months of the year by the completion of the merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE, which created the newly named Verizon. And then the company was eager to embark on a huge advertising and promotional campaign to establish the new Verizon brand. Did those distractions lead the company's management to underestimate the unions' intent to transform the Aug. 5 contract deadline into a point of reference for organized labor's future in high-technology companies?
"I think there probably was a certain amount of arrogance here on management's part," said Neil Bernstein, a professor of law at Washington University in St. Louis who also works as a labor arbitrator. "Telephone companies have generally not been overly concerned about strikes, mainly because their services are so automated."
The company denies that it underestimated the challenge of reaching a new contract. "No company ever wants a strike, and we most certainly did everything we could to prevent one," said Eric Rabe, Verizon's spokesman. "Sometimes it's just necessary to get eyeball to eyeball on issues."
Instead of a token walkout like the two-day strike by Bell Atlantic's unions two years ago, Verizon has received a mounting public relations problem.
The company's customers in the 12 Eastern states and Washington, where the strike is taking place, are unable to reach directory assistance. And regionwide, requests for repairs have swelled to 82,000, compared with 36,000 at this time last month.
Negotiations between Verizon and the two unions representing its employees, the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, deteriorated yesterday, reducing chances for a quick resolution, according to people close to the talks.
And on the picket lines, tension has increased between management and strikers. The unions said yesterday that nine picketers had been hit by managers' vehicles in separate incidents, but that none were hospitalized. Verizon said that union members had thrown bottles, rocks and eggs at managers trying to enter company buildings.
So far, 24 union members throughout the region have been arrested during the strike, according to the company.
A profit warning from the company on Tuesday sent shares in Verizon down more than 12 percent, and yesterday they fell an additional 3.7 percent, to $40.50 a share. Since June, shares in Verizon, the nation's largest provider of local telephone and wireless service, have fallen nearly 30 percent, to a two-year low.
The company's woes come amid a nationwide advertising campaign that began on Aug. 1, using actors including James Earl Jones to make people more aware of the new name, which is pronounced vah-RISE-un. And even as chances of a strike mounted before the deadline of 12:01 a.m. last Sunday set by the union, Verizon chose to proceed with its advertising plans.
"This is clearly not the association you want to build as you launch a new brand," said Martin Tipping, director of naming at Landor Associates, a corporate identity consulting company. "At least people are learning how to pronounce the name."
According to people involved in the talks, an indication of Verizon's handling of the negotiations came in the minutes leading up to the deadline. Only then did Verizon make concessions to one of the unions' main demands, which would allow them to organize in the company's fast-growing wireless division.
By that time, though, it was too late to avoid a strike. While Verizon had also made wage and benefit concessions that the unions found satisfactory, other issues remained stumbling blocks. They included the use of nonunion contractors and the relocation of some work in response to the merger or changing corporate priorities.
Labor experts say it appears Verizon did not correctly gauge the unions' readiness to turn the strike opportunity into a sounding board for labor's place in the new economy.
"This strike is pivotal because the unions are confronting changes produced by rapid technological advances," said Richard Hurd, professor of labor issues at Cornell University.
The unions are not emerging from the strike with their image unscathed. One union member was arrested today for harrassing a Verizon manager at a company building in Manhattan. And the New York City Police Department has been investigating the possibility that strikers have been involved in numerous acts of vandalism that have knocked out telephone service in some parts of the city.
In Manhattan yesterday, five police officers from the Midtown South Precinct who were monitoring picket lines were doused with bird excrement and other waste dumped from the top of Verizon's 41-story headquarters building on the Avenue of the Americas at 42nd Street.
The officers were taken to Bellevue Hospital and treated for exposure to animal feces.
"We're not going to rule out management or strikers," said Sgt. Andrew McInnis, a spokesman for the police department.

HEADLINE: Layoffs May Be at a Record Low, Survey Finds

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
With the American economy enjoying its longest economic expansion on record, the number of permanent layoffs declined over the last three years, the government reported yesterday. The rate may now match the lowest in the 20-year history of the survey.
The new data also shows that women are now laid off virtually as often as men, closing a wide gap that had existed for most of the last 20 years. At the same time, the layoff rate for blacks rose. And the gap between the layoff rate for blacks compared with whites widened significantly over the last three years. The layoff rate for Hispanics, however, dropped sharply, falling below that of blacks. The differential between whites and Hispanics also narrowed. 
 During the three years ended with 1999, 3.3 million workers on the job for three years or more were laid off while 4.3 million workers on the job for less than three years lost their jobs, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported in its biennial job displacement survey. This compares with total layoffs of 8 million, 3.6 million of them on the job for three years or more, from 1995 to 1997. And that is down from a total of 8.4 million in the period from 1993 through 1995.
The decline in layoffs is more pronounced when calculated as a percentage of all employed workers. According to the bureau, that rate declined to 6.1 percent in the last three years, from 6.6 percent in 1995 through 1997 and 8 percent in 1993 through 1995. And this 6.1 percent may be near or even match the low for the survey, which goes back to 1979.
The first bureau survey was released in 1984. But because the way the survey was conducted was changed from five-year periods to three-year periods in the report released in 1994, it is difficult to make historical comparisons. Steve Hipple, the economist at the bureau who oversees the job displacement data, said that the rate of job layoffs was probably understated in the earlier data.
If this is the case, the 6.1 percent layoff rate from the last three years may actually be equal to the 5.5 percent rate reported for 1987 through 1989, the low point in the bureau's data.
But the decline in the layoff rate in the last three years was far less than in the preceding three years, when the rate for all workers 20 years and older fell 17.5 percent.
"It is not surprising that in a strong job market that job loss declined," said Henry Farber, an economist at Princeton University who studies job displacement data. He said that even with a strong economy, there would be layoffs as some industries shrink while others grow.
The lowest layoff rate, 5.7 percent, was for workers 45 to 54. Of all the displaced workers, nearly three-quarters had new jobs by the time the survey was taken in February. Nearly three-fifths of those laid off from wage and salary jobs found new jobs that paid the same or more.
While the layoff rate for blacks did increase to 7.3 percent, it is still significantly below the level earlier in the 1990's, when it was as high as 9.4 percent between 1991 and 1995. The increase in the difference between the layoff rate for blacks and whites ends six years of narrowing. In the three-year period from 1991 through 1993, the gap was 1.4 percentage points. It narrowed to 0.5 percentage point in the next three-year period and was 0.6 percentage point in 1995 though 1997.
Mr. Hipple could not say why the gap had widened again. He said that the existence of a gap was consistent with the fact that the unemployment rate for whites is lower than that for blacks. But he said that it was hard to tell whether this year's widening of the gap was a one-time event or not.
Mr. Farber, who has worked with the bureau's jobs data for years, could not comment in detail on the change in the layoff rates for blacks because he had not yet received the backup data on which yesterday's release was based. But he said "the black number is an interesting number and something to point out."
The layoff rate of Hispanics fell to 7 percent over the last three years from 8.8 percent. That is the lowest it has been since the the 1990-91 recession. The gap between the white and Hispanic layoff rate narrowed to 1 percentage point from 2.3 percentage points in the 1995-97 period.
The gap between the layoff rate for women and men has been narrowing over the last 20 years, with the biggest changes coming in times of strong job growth. In 1991-93, the gap was 7.4 percent for women and 8.8 percent for men. That narrowed to 7.6 percent for women and 8.4 percent for men in 1993-95, to 6.5 percent for women and 6.7 percent for men in 1995-97 and to 6.1 percent for women and 6 percent for men in the last three years.
"Women's jobs are concentrated in service industries and the risk of job losses in services industries has grown over time," Mr. Hipple said.

HEADLINE: Arrest of Banker in Graft Case Poses a Test of Bosnia's Resolve

BYLINE: By CARLOTTA GALL 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Aug. 8

 BODY:
The arrest of a prominent Bosnian banker and former government minister is being watched by foreign officials here as a test of the government's resolve to fight corruption.
The suspect, Alija Delimustafic, an owner of BH Banka, which collapsed two years ago owing foreign embassies and international organizations $15 million, was arrested on Friday night and charged with fraud and abusing his position. 
 But the case "is not just about money going missing," a foreign official here said.
"It is a very, very high-profile fraud case," the official said. "It's an important test case, and we want to see it succeed."
Local news media have hinted that the affair goes to the core of the Bosnian leadership in Sarajevo, some of whose members were Mr. Delimustafic's close colleagues in the war from 1992 to 1995. The government has been silent on the case.
Foreign officials here say corruption has reached such levels that the powerful vested interests of the governing parties are the major obstruction to democracy and development in Bosnia, as a recent report by the General Accounting Office said.
Mr. Delimustafic, 46, was arrested at the offices of his company Cenex, which ran the collapsed bank and still controls a trading company, supermarket chain and an insurance company. The well-connected businessman was interior minister in the early 90's. In the war, he was foreign trade minister of a collapsed country that had almost no trade and only the most tenuous links to the outside world.
According to Mirsad Bajraktarevic, head of the 120-member financial police unit that is investigating corruption in Bosnia, BH Banka collapsed with debts of $15 million. Some $900,000 of that total belonged to the United States Agency for International Development and represented operating funds and loan payments of its assistance programs to Bosnia, according to the General Accounting Office report. The Swiss Embassy has also acknowledged losing a significant sum.
None of the foreign creditors has retrieved money since the bank crashed, and they have pushed the government hard to investigate the case. Cenex has continued trading, and creditors have set their sights on its assets, particularly a shopping center on the southern edge of Sarajevo.
The center was probably built with some of the missing money, Mr. Bajraktarevic said in an interview. "And the bank made credits beyond its means," he said, adding that the credits were not insured.
Mr. Bajraktarevic's task has been to track the dealings of the bank over the last 10 years. He transferred the case to the prosecutor's office last month.
"It is very complex," he said. "Twenty people were involved in setting up the bank, and a lot of transfers were made out of the country, and Bosnia has not signed any international conventions."
PricewaterhouseCoopers has been brought in to audit the bank, he said.
The representative for the World Bank here, Elaine Patterson, noted that banks in transitional economies are fragile and crashes are to be expected before regulations are in place. But the World Bank, itself a victim of fraud in Bosnia, has pressed hard for a full investigation and pursuit of the banks' assets to pay back creditors.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Phone Strike Drags On As Contract Talks Continue
As Verizon Communications prepares to enter its fifth day of bargaining with its striking unions, the question arises: Has Verizon gotten more with this strike than it bargained for?
As the walkout by 86,000 workers of Verizon, the nation's largest telecommunications employer, has developed into one of the most unruly strikes in years, doubts are growing over the company's preparation for the contract talks and its handling of the strike. Page C8. 

'Dot-Com' Merger Excites Investors
Phone.com and Software.com, two relatively small, money-losing software companies, announced they were merging, and investors responded by adding $2.6 billion to their combined market values. The ".com" suffix in both companies' names is somewhat misleading, as neither does business through its Web site. C20.
 
DNA Used to Make Tiny Motors
A team of researchers at Bell Laboratories and Oxford University has fashioned molecular-sized motors out of the chemical that stores the genetic code, portending a possible role for DNA beyond biology. The development is part of an effort, still in its infancy, to harness DNA as a structural and electronic material that might one day be used to make ultra-tiny computers or mechanical devices, like a robot that could cruise through the bloodstream to repair an injury. C5.
 
Ex-Broker Accused of Murder Plot
Stuart Winkler, a former top executive for a small brokerage company in New Jersey who is awaiting trial on charges that he bilked investors of $100 million, was accused of hiring a fellow prisoner to kill the judge who has kept him behind bars since April. B3.
 
ABC to Reprimand Correspondent
ABC News executives said they would reprimand John Stossel, the news correspondent, for a report challenging the assumed benefits of organic food that was based in part on evidence that did not exist. The producer of the segment, David W. Fitzpatrick, is to be suspended without pay for one month. C20.
 
Advanced Micro Readies New Chip
Advanced Micro Devices plans to release details of its new 64-bit processor today, a chip that is intended to compete head on with Intel's forthcoming Itanium. Advanced Micro said it expected the new chip to help it gain sales in the workstation and server market. C20.
 
Barclays in Talks to Buy Lender
Britain's third largest bank, Barclays, said it was negotiating to acquire Woolwich, a leading British mortgage lender, for about 5.5 billion or $8.3 billion. Barclays, which only a few years ago was one of Britain's most troubled banks, has been on a tear over the last year under its chief executive, Matthew Barrett, who took the bank's top job about 10 months ago. C3.
 
Carmakers to Add Stability Systems
Ford Motor said it would offer computerized stability systems as an option on all of its sport utility vehicles and pickups by the 2005 model year to reduce the frequency of rollovers. General Motors responded by saying that the Cadillac Escalade full-sized sport utility vehicle will be equipped with the stability system as standard equipment this autumn. C4.
 
Report Suggests Brazilian Recovery
Brazil's economy grew 3.92 percent in the second quarter compared with the period a year earlier, the government said in a report, signaling that the recovery from a currency crisis in early 1999 was accelerating. C3.
 
Tracking Who Is Getting Richer
The rich are getting richer, and the poor are getting poorer, right? It will be a familiar refrain this election year. But what if increasing inequality is mostly a myth -- an artifact of misleading data and changing lifestyles? What if just about everyone is getting richer? Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE RACE FOR CONTRIBUTIONS;
Fund-Raisers for 2 Clintons Set for Eve of Convention

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. and JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore has for months been planning the Democratic National Convention as a coming-out party for his presidential campaign and a long-awaited opportunity to step out of President Clinton's imposing shadow.
But Bill and Hillary Clinton each intend to spend twice as much time in Los Angeles as the vice president, basking in the spotlight and raising millions of dollars for their own political projects. 
 By the end of the Democratic convention week, the Clintons will have raised far more money than the vice president -- $4 million anticipated for the first lady's New York Senate bid at a star-studded concert this Saturday night and at least $10 million for Mr. Clinton's presidential library at a brunch that Barbra Streisand will hold this Sunday at her compound in Malibu. Each of 50 couples at the brunch has committed at least $100,000, and some more than $1 million, to the president's library in Little Rock, Ark.
Ms. Streisand will also lend her cachet to Mr. Gore's campaign, headlining a concert at the Shrine Auditorium next Thursday that is expected to raise at least $2.5 million for the Democratic National Committee. Ms. Streisand will sing three songs.
Some Gore aides and senior Democratic fund-raisers are angry about the Clinton-heavy convention schedule, saying they are concerned the Clinton events will siphon off Hollywood money that would be better spent assisting the Gore-Lieberman ticket.
The stacked social calendar has also rankled some wealthy Southern California Democrats, who say they have been bombarded by invitations to fund-raisers and appeals for money. Finally, the political ailment known as "donor fatigue" may have hit Hollywood.
"This is Gore's convention, but there are two tributes to Clinton," said a Democratic strategist who insisted on anonymity. "It's embarrassing for the Gores to have this huge event for the president that will raise money for Hillary. This convention is not about her."
How can it be that three people who work in the same complex and whose careers have been intimately entwined for the past eight years seem unable to coordinate what should be one of the most important events of the Clinton era?
But, in fact, not only is there little coordination between the Gore presidential campaign and Mrs. Clinton's Senate campaign, but there is also competition between Mr. Gore and Mrs. Clinton for money and attention, most dramatically at the coming Democratic convention.
And for his part, the president is trying to balance the needs of both candidates, while burnishing his legacy and raising tens of millions of dollars for his presidential library.
The highly visible events spotlighting President Clinton and his wife in Los Angeles are not only troubling to the Gore forces because they drain money. They also put the Clintons at center stage just as the vice president and his ticket-mate are trying to occupy that territory and distance themselves from Mr. Clinton.
Even one adviser to Mrs. Clinton said today that it might have been inappropriate for the first lady to use Mr. Gore's nominating convention as a venue to raise money for her Senate campaign.
Several Gore allies said today that they were not worried about the money, but they acknowledged that the symbolism would be unmistakable: on the eve of Mr. Gore's national moment, all of Hollywood will turn out to honor Mr. Clinton, not once but twice.
Convention organizers had already faced a delicate balancing act in deciding a role for the Clintons. It was partly addressed when the president and first lady agreed to address the delegates at the Staples Center on the convention's opening night. Afterward, the president will be saluted by the Democratic Party's top donors at Paramount Studios; the Clintons will then leave Los Angeles on Tuesday morning.
But the competition over fund-raising demonstrates that the competition between the two camps is not fully resolved.
The headline event is Saturday night at a private Los Angeles estate. More than 1,400 people will attend a salute to the president, with the proceeds going to Mrs. Clinton's Senate campaign. Among the performers will be Paul Anka, Michael Bolton, Toni Braxton, Cher, Melissa Etheridge, Patti LaBelle, Brian McKnight, Diana Ross, Mark McGrath of Sugar Ray, Stevie Wonder and Luther Vandross. And there will be tributes on stage by Ted Danson, Michael Douglas, Whoopi Goldberg, Goldie Hawn, Angelica Huston, Jack Lemmon, Shirley MacLaine, Dylan McDermott, Rosa Parks, Gregory Peck, Jimmy Smits, Mary Steenburgen, John Travolta and Red Buttons.
The host of the Saturday night concert is Stan Lee, the comic book publishing icon and creator of Spider-Man. Aaron Tonken, a consultant for Stan Lee Media who recruited the talent, played down the talk in Los Angeles that the concert would overshadow Mr. Gore's own concert on Thursday night. But he also acknowledged that Mrs. Clinton was sensitive about the event.
"Mrs. Clinton's campaign office pushed very hard for me to help get as much talent as possible for the vice president's event," Mr. Tonken said. "She has been very sensitive and almost pushy for me to help the vice president."
Mr. Gore's event on Thursday night at the 6,000-seat Shrine Auditorium features a concert by Ms. Streisand, as well as appearances by Whoopi Goldberg, Baby Face, Boyz II Men and Gladys Knight. Tickets range from $150 to $20,000. A few $1,000 tickets are still unsold.
The Saturday night tribute to the president also caused some concern among members of the host committee, who scheduled the media party for the same night.
Garry South, a top political adviser to Gov. Gray Davis of California, acknowledged that there had been competing demands for entertainers to draw donors to Democratic fund-raisers. "Some competition for talent is inevitable," he said. "There's been some jostling here about the whole thing."
Mr. South said that aides to Mrs. Clinton called him several weeks ago to propose a major soft-money fund-raiser on Saturday night with top entertainment figures. He said he did not advise against it -- in fact, Governor Davis is a co-sponsor of the event -- but warned the Clinton campaign that she would be competing with numerous other fund-raising events during convention week.
"From a practical standpoint, I told them they'd have to do it in a way that doesn't distract from other activities, including the salute to President Clinton on Monday and the concert for Gore and the D.N.C. Thursday night," Mr. South said.
"We get this in California all the time," Mr. South said. "There are a zillion people coming out here all year long in ongoing and nonstop fund-raising activities."
He added, "All three events will come off smashingly and everybody will be happy as a clam and everybody will make a lot of clams."
A supporter of the Clintons complained that the Saturday night concert benefiting Mrs. Clinton's Senate campaign had "spun out of control," saying the organizers "don't care about Hillary and the president -- they are promoting themselves, and politically, this just hurts Hillary."
But a senior Gore adviser played down concerns about Mrs. Clinton's fund-raiser, saying: "We welcome the event for Hillary. If any of our fund-raisers think we are being hurt by her events, they are just wrong. The phones are ringing off the hook. We are doing great." The adviser, who refused to be identified, acknowledged that there had been "grumbling" among fund-raisers, but added that fund-raisers often complained about the hard task of raising money.
And Howard Wolfson, Mrs. Clinton's spokesman, also said his candidate was not draining resources from Mr. Gore. "Thanks to the very strong economy created under the Clinton-Gore administration, there is more than enough to go around," Mr. Wolfson said.
One generous Democratic contributor in the entertainment business turned down an invitation to the Sunday brunch at Ms. Streisand's home. He described the event to an aide as "a heavy ticket" requiring a donation of $100,000 to $1 million in a year when demand for political money was already intense.
He told the aide he might consider contributing to the library project next year or later, but felt he had done more than enough for the party this year.
After leaving Los Angeles on Tuesday morning, the president will travel to Michigan for an appearance with the vice president at a symbolic passing of the torch. Mr. Gore will then depart for Los Angeles.

PUB-DATE: August 10, 2000

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 529 words

HEADLINE: The Buchanan Coup Attempt

 BODY:
Eight years after the establishment of the Reform Party by Ross Perot, the party's machinery has apparently been seized -- or disabled -- by Patrick Buchanan, longtime scold on the Republican right. As a presidential candidate, Mr. Buchanan has little to offer the American public except the politics of resentment. But if he gets the Reform Party's presidential nomination this week, his tirades against free trade, affirmative action and abortion may draw votes away from Gov. George W. Bush, unless they help Mr. Bush by making him seem more moderate. In any case, it is enough to make one nostalgic for Mr. Perot, the eccentric Texas billionaire who founded the party.
Despite Mr. Perot's comical behavior, the Reform Party has drawn support from a wide range of well-intentioned Americans who wanted to elevate the tone of politics. For them it is especially unfortunate that Mr. Buchanan's takeover attempts have been less about issues than about getting his hands on the more than $12 million in federal campaign funds due the party because of Mr. Perot's past showings on the ballot. 
 Today the party opens its convention in Long Beach, Calif., where Mr. Buchanan says he expects to be nominated after working hard all year to take over the party organization state by state. Anti-Buchanan members are charging fraud, and contend that if they cannot stop his selection at the convention they will break off and form a separate Reform Party with its own nominee. A court battle over who gets the $12 million is considered likely.
The high-water mark of Mr. Perot's candidacy occurred in the spring of 1992, when it seemed plausible that he could actually beat President Bush and the Democratic challenger, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. But Mr. Perot's odd tactical reversals -- dropping out of the race suddenly and, just as suddenly, jumping back in -- and his paranoid-sounding charges of conspiracies against him and his family did him in. Nevertheless, he brought a certain truth-telling to the 1992 campaign, warning of the dangers of federal deficits, the power of special interests and what he said was declining American competitiveness abroad. In his 1996 race he was far less credible as a candidate.
The only policy that Mr. Buchanan has picked up from the old Perot campaign is opposition to trade agreements. His moralizing and demands for anti-abortion laws run counter to the libertarian streak of many Reform Party members, including Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota.
When Mr. Buchanan walked out of the Republican Party last fall, Governor Bush lamented his loss to the G.O.P. In fact, the party was fortunate to be rid of his nasty brand of nativism and his divisive rants about cultural war and the "Israeli lobby." In these generally prosperous economic times, it is fair enough for Mr. Buchanan to try to call attention to the problems of those not benefiting from the boom. But it is doubtful that his flame-throwing attacks on his ever-changing list of foreign and domestic enemies will elevate the race this year. The Reform Party would do better to nominate a candidate appealing to idealism rather than the paranoid fringe.

HEADLINE: STUDY SAID TO FIND U.S. MISSILE SHIELD MIGHT INCITE CHINA

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
A highly classified intelligence report warns that deploying an American national missile defense could prompt China to expand its nuclear arsenal tenfold and lead Russia to place multiple warheads on ballistic missiles that now carry only one, according to officials who have reviewed it.
Although the report reaffirms what China and Russia have publicly said in opposition to the system, it offers a detailed analysis of how those two nations are likely to respond and suggests that the effects of an American decision to build a nuclear defense would ripple around the globe from Europe to South Asia, the officials said. 
 It warns that China would expand its relatively small arsenal of roughly 20 long-range nuclear missiles to a quantity large enough to overwhelm the limited defensive system that the Clinton administration is considering. One person who has seen the report said it estimated that China could deploy up to 200 warheads by 2015, prompting India and Pakistan to respond with their own buildups.
Although Russia's economy is unlikely to support a large buildup of its missile forces, officials said the report found that it could again deploy shorter-range missiles along its borders and resume adding multiple warheads to its ballistic missiles. That is something Russia agreed to stop as part of the second strategic arms control treaty, or Start 2, which it ratified this year.
The report, "Foreign Responses to U.S. National Missile Defense Deployment," underscores warnings by opponents here and abroad that the administration's proposal to build a limited defensive system could lead to a new arms race with Russia and, to a lesser extent, in Asia.
The report does not recommend for or against a national missile defense, but simply spells out potential consequences. Although it makes clear that some of those consequences could be dire, the study also underscores the emerging threat to the United States from the proliferation of ballistic missiles, which advocates have long cited as the rationale for building a system.
President Clinton, who received a copy in the last few days, has said he would make a decision on whether to go ahead with the system this year based on four criteria, including two covered by the report, the threat to and the effects on overall national security, including arms control. The other criteria are the cost and the technological feasibility.
This week, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said he would delay until at least next month making a recommendation to the president on the system. He cited "a number of difficult issues" that have to be resolved. The secretary, who has been briefed on the intelligence findings, is supposed to base his recommendation in part on the effects addressed in the report.
The report, which is expected to be sent to members of Congress on Thursday, is sure to fuel the debate over whether Mr. Clinton should approve the first steps toward a defensive shield or postpone the decision until the next administration. An official who has seen the report said it included assessments that critics and supporters of a missile defense would use "and make no one happy."
And it could affect the presidential campaign. Vice President Al Gore has largely embraced the adminstration stand of building a limited land-based system. The Republican candidate, George W. Bush, favors a broader system that could include sea- and space-based arms.
The report includes an annex that repeats the intelligence assessment last year that Iraq, Iran and North Korea could develop ballistic missiles capable of hitting the United States by 2015, the officials said. In fact, the threat from North Korea may be more imminent, despite a flurry of diplomatic activity by North Korea, the officials said.
Although North Korea has abided by a pledge that it made last year not to test its long-range missiles, it has continued building a three-stage missile that could hit the United States and could deploy it "in reasonably short order," one official said.
The report, a National Intelligence Estimate, represents the collective assessment of the nation's intelligence agencies, including the Central Intelligence Agency, the Defense Intelligence Agency and the State Department Bureau of Intelligence and Research. One senior official said the report did not intend to predict with certainty how China, Russia and other countries would respond, but rather simply laid out a range of responses.
Another official, arguing that the report did not necessarily undercut the case for a missile defense, said some of the findings represented worst-case scenarios. The report says, for example, that the Russians could withdraw from "an array of arms control treaties," especially if the United States went ahead without negotiating changes in the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972, which prohibits national missile defenses.
The official noted that although Russia had so far strongly resisted Washington's efforts to change the treaty, they have an interest in negotiating reductions in both countries' nuclear arsenals, because Russia can scarcely afford to maintain the 5,000 or so warheads that it has.
The report suggests that the Russians could accept a trade-off that would strictly limit the American defensive system to 100 interceptor missiles based in Alaska, as the administration has proposed building by 2007. But without an agreement, Russia could respond by increasing the warheads on each missile.

HEADLINE: 15 Awarded Highest Civilian Honor

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Presi dents hand out plenty of perks ambassadorships, invitations to state dinners and specially made boxes of M&M's bearing the presidential seal.
With just five months left in his term, and his opportunities for presenting awards dwindling, President Clinton today awarded 15 people with Presidential Medals of Freedom, the country's highest civilian honor. Some of the awards seemed to represent belated presidential thank-yous. Some clearly had a political twist. At least one was a consolation prize. 
In announcing the awards, Mr. Clinton said he had huddled with his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, who is running for the Senate in New York, to review the upstanding people from all walks of life nominated by aides and others.
The honorees included John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard economist, Msgr. George G. Higgins, a labor activist, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who is Mr. Clinton's envoy to Africa.
Although the selection process is cloaked in mystery, Mrs. Clinton perhaps had a role in advocating for Marian Wright Edelman, her first boss at the Children's Defense Fund; the Rev. Gardner C. Taylor, a prominent pastor from Brooklyn who has backed her campaign; and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the man she hopes to succeed in the Senate.
The award was a consolation prize for Gen. Wesley K. Clark, who was NATO's supreme commander during the bombing of Yugoslavia but who was passed over for the post of chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Now an investment banker, General Clark wore a suit instead of a uniform but still stood ramrod straight.
Mr. Clinton, over the course of his presidency, has handed out 83 of the gold medallions decorated with red, white and blue. There are no limits to the number of medals that can be awarded, and although the White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said this was the final medal ceremony of the year, he added, "The president always reserves the right to do something on a more ad-hoc basis near the end of the administration."
Mr. Clinton has always reached out to Republicans when presenting the awards. Bob Dole won the honor the year after he lost to Mr. Clinton in the 1996 presidential race. Former President Gerald R. Ford joined former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, in in 1999. This year, Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, won the award posthumously. Mr. Chafee died in October.
The other honorees were Simon Wiesenthal, the Holocaust survivor and Nazi hunter; Cruz Reynoso, a former judge from California who is vice chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights; George McGovern, a former Democratic presidential nominee; James Edward Burke, chairman of the Partnership for a Drug-Free America; Adm. William Crowe, a former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; Mildred Jeffrey, a labor activist; and Mathilde Krim, founder of the American Foundation for AIDS Research.
"It's the highest honor of my life," said Mr. McGovern said. "I treasure it even more than running for the presidency of the United States. If I had won, that would have been the greatest honor."
Then, of course, he would have been the one handing out medals.
