HEADLINE: No Rise in Child Abuse Seen in Welfare Shift

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
When Congress abolished welfare as a permanent safety net four years ago, there were alarming predictions about the prospect of an already overwhelmed foster care system's being flooded by a new wave of abused children. But according to the early findings of two studies, the changes do not appear to have had such dire effects across the country.
Confirmed cases of child abuse and neglect have fallen since 1996, the researchers involved in the studies say. Their conclusions are confirmed by federal statistics released yesterday reporting that there were 903,000 cases of child maltreatment in 1998, compared with 969,000 in 1996 and 1,019,000 in the peak year of 1993. 
 One study notes, too, that while data is limited, the number of children entering foster care has been stable or falling slightly in recent years, continuing the national decline that began slightly more than five years ago, after the worst period of crack cocaine addiction. In 1999, 3.30 children out of every 1,000 entered foster care, according to one study, down from 3.87 in 1994.
Perhaps no other forecast to stem from the 1996 welfare overhaul was as chilling as the predictions regarding foster care. At the time, some advocates for the poor and child welfare officials feared that the stress of losing benefits or the pressures of having to work for a welfare check would lead to a rise in child abuse and neglect.
But the latest findings suggest that since President Clinton signed the 1996 legislation placing strict time limits and work obligations on much of the country's welfare recipients, their children do not seem to have flooded into foster care.
That somewhat heartening picture comes at a time when children's overall well-being has improved slightly. Child poverty, infant mortality and birth rates for teenagers declined noticeably in the 1990's, a study released last month by the Federal Interagency Forum on Child and Family Statistics found.
"I don't think the picture is entirely rosy, but there is little evidence, if any, to suggest that there's a large population negatively affected," said Rob Geen, a senior research associate with the Urban Institute, a research organization based in Washington that is conducting a study of the impact of the welfare changes.
Researchers and policy analysts caution, however, that certain states and certain families show signs of trouble that deserve closer attention. There are, after all, many much less blunt ways of measuring possible damage to children other than foster care admissions -- from health conditions to juvenile delinquency.
"The concerns come in when you speak to individual workers and hear stories about specific families that have been affected by welfare reform," Mr. Geen said. "There are many of them, but they are not large enough or well documented enough to show up in the aggregate numbers."
The full and lasting impact of welfare changes on children and family well-being will most likely play out over the next several years, because different states are on different schedules for putting the law's changes into effect.
Some states imposed work requirements or time limits on welfare recipients before the 1996 federal laws took effect. In other states, time limits have not kicked in. Officials with the Urban Institute, as well as those with the Chapin Hall Center for Children at the University of Chicago, who have conducted a study of welfare families in Illinois, consequently warn that the snapshot they have so far developed is an early one.
For now, even if the most dire predictions do not appear to have been realized, how much of that can be attributed to the success of an overhaul of welfare remains imprecise. Other trends -- chiefly, the general economic health of the country, declining rates of child poverty, and unrelated changes in child welfare policies -- could also be responsible. Nor is it clear what would have happened to foster care caseloads in the absence of changes in welfare.
Some children, the researchers contend, may be getting by without welfare because their parents have found work. Some children who are being neglected may not show up on the radar of child welfare workers because their families are no longer on government assistance. Other at-risk families may be temporarily shielded by relatives and friends.
In raising concerns that foster care systems would be burdened by an influx of vulnerable children, advocates noted that poverty is the greatest single ingredient in the mistreatment or neglect of children. Many experts wondered, then, whether under a welfare overhaul more children would land in foster care and whether more of them would languish there for longer because judges might be reluctant to return children to homes with empty pantries.
"Nearly everyone we spoke with expected to see significant negative effects from welfare reform on child welfare," Mr. Geen said. "There's no evidence to suggest that there has been a substantial impact."
He adds, however, that there is scattered evidence of trouble that merits close examination. In some states, like Michigan, child neglect reports based on lack of supervision have spiked sharply. Mr. Geen said state child welfare workers told him they believed that the increase reflected, in part, new welfare-to-work requirements, with mothers now having to leave their children unattended. But the increase, Mr. Geen said, could be due to other changes.
Mr. Geen's report is based on aggregate data and interviews with 500 policymakers, welfare office workers, child welfare caseworkers, advocates and other experts in 12 states: Alabama, California, Colorado, Florida, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, New Jersey, New York, Texas, Washington and Wisconsin.
State by state figures will not be released until Mr. Geen's report is published later this year.
In Michigan, New Jersey, Texas and Washington, the number of child abuse and neglect investigations increased significantly from 1996 through 1998, the most recent year for which figures are available. Mr. Geen said state officials attributed those increases not to welfare changes, but to other factors in child welfare policies, like changes in screening policies. He said the number of substantiated cases declined in all but one of the 12 states in that same period.
In more than half of the 12, welfare workers filed more child neglect reports than in the past. But case workers who investigate those reports noted that many of the referrals were inappropriate, Mr. Geen said.
Meanwhile, the Chapin Hall study similarly concluded that child welfare indicators had not taken a turn for the worse since the welfare law changed. Neither abuse and neglect reports, nor the number of children coming into foster care, has gone up in Illinois since 1996, it found.
"That's not entirely due to the success of welfare reform," said Robert Goerge, associate director of Chapin Hall. "We have a very strong economy and that generally results in fewer reports of abuse and neglect and fewer children going into foster care."
At the same time, Illinois embarked on a major overhaul of its child welfare system, seeking to get more children into permanent homes and trying to prevent children from coming into the formal foster care system.
Therein lies the difficulty of understanding the impact of welfare policy changes on children's lives. The ebb and flow of foster care numbers is driven by everything from widely publicized incidents of child fatalities, like the Elisa Izquierdo case in New York City, which significantly drove up abuse reports, to crack cocaine addiction, which drove up foster care numbers to record levels in the early 1990's.
"We still don't have full information on whether requiring parents to go to work and threatening to cut off their aid actually improves the welfare of their children or prevents abuse and neglect," Mr. Goerge said. "But it is certainly the case that welfare reform hasn't made things worse."
The number of families on welfare has dropped by 50 percent since 1993, to 2,453,000 in September 1999, according to figures released recently by the federal Department of Health and Human Services. So far, many single mothers on welfare have found jobs and have seen some increase in their income, according to a study by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research organization in Washington. But since the new welfare laws took effect, the incomes of 1.8 million families have declined, to $8,400 a year on average, compared with $8,760 in 1995. The center has not specifically inquired what has happened to their children.
According to federal data, in New York State the welfare caseload has shrunk by one-third since 1993, to 279,692 families in September 1999, most of them in New York City. Of those who have left the rolls, city officials cannot say how many have found work. Nor is much known about the general well-being of their families, including their encounters with the city's child welfare agency.
Those who are left on the rolls, some social policy analysts say, may be the ones who are the most ill-prepared to make it on their own. They may be impeded by mental illness or substance abuse, or they may be victims of domestic violence -- the same conditions that may also place their children at greater risk of abuse and neglect. Their prospects may not be discerned until a year or two from now.
"People want to know the answers now," Mr. Geen said. "But everyone we spoke to said, 'Please come back in two years and we'll have a different story to tell you.' "

NEW YORK
 
MANHATTAN: WEST NILE MEETING URGED
A coalition of New York environmentalists, repeating their view yesterday that widespread pesticide spraying against the West Nile virus may threaten the public more than the virus itself, said they had asked to meet with Dr. Neal L. Cohen, New York City's health commissioner. "The overuse of toxic pesticides to combat this virus creates an insidious air of false security," said Adrienne Esposito, of the Citizens Campaign for the Environment. A Health Department spokeswoman said yesterday that Dr. Cohen had not yet received the request. Eric Lipton (NYT) 

MANHATTAN: FIRE DISRUPTS ELECTRICITY
A smoky electrical fire in a manhole on West 80th Street last night knocked out power to 59 customers, Consolidated Edison said. The cause of the fire at West 80th and Columbus Avenue, which started at 11:15 p.m. and burned some underground cables before being put out an hour later, was not clear, Con Ed and the Fire Department said. The utility did not know early this morning when service would be restored, said D. Joy Faber, a spokeswoman. Andy Newman (NYT)
 
BROOKLYN: STOP SIGN INSTALLED BEFORE PROTEST
One month after a 9-year-old boy was hit by a car and killed at the intersection and one day before a neighborhood protest was planned there, the Department of Transportation agreed to install a stop sign on 24th Avenue at 83rd Street in Brooklyn. Local residents and elected officials had lobbied for a sign for years. Carmine Santa Maria, president of the Bensonhurst West End Community Council, said the avenue from 86th Street to Stillwell Avenue had no lights or stop signs and had been the scene of many accidents. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)
 
QUEENS: PHONY DENTIST PLEADS GUILTY
A Kew Gardens man has pleaded guilty to posing as a dentist in Jamaica, Queens, and treating more than 100 Medicaid patients. Since last August, the man, Ramin Setarehshenas, had operated an office called Colosseum Dental and had examined teeth, taken X-rays and written prescriptions, according to Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer's office. Mr. Setarehshenas agreed to make $18,000 in restitution and faces up to four years in prison. Sentencing is scheduled for Oct. 17. (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: ACTIVIST MISSING IN INDONESIA
Human Rights Watch, a human rights group based in Manhattan, urged the Indonesian government yesterday to increase efforts to find a lawyer and activist from Queens who vanished five days ago in Sumatra. The group said it feared that the lawyer, Jafar Siddiq Hamzah, 35, might have been kidnapped by Indonesian military or paramilitary troops on Saturday. The group said Indonesia's regional military commander had denied any knowledge of Mr. Hamzah's whereabouts, and appeals by the United States Embassy in Jakarta to the government had yielded no results. (AP)
 
SCHENECTADY: TURBOTRAINS ARRIVE
The first of seven turbocharged Amtrak trains has been delivered to Amtrak by Super Steel Schenectady. The train, designed to travel 125 miles per hour on part of the route between Schenectady and New York City, is being inspected and tested before it goes into service this autumn. The second of the seven trains will be delivered to Amtrak in coming months and the rest completed by late 2002, said Lynn Bowersox, an Amtrak spokeswoman. (AP)
 
SYRACUSE: INDIAN LAND CLAIMS
Testimony is to resume next week in the second phase of the Cayuga Indian Nation's land claims trial, in which the tribe is seeking nearly $2 billion in interest. The money would be added to a $36.9 million award granted by a jury in February. Judge Neal McCurn of Federal District Court ruled in 1994 that New York illegally acquired 64,027 acres of reservation land in Cayuga and Seneca Counties in 1795 and 1807. An economist for the Cayugas plans to testify that the state should pay $1.74 billion in interest calculated back to 1795. The Justice Department's economist says the interest should be $527.5 million, while the state's expert economist plans to argue that New York should pay $12.1 million. at most. (AP)
 
CONNECTICUT
 
HARTFORD: SENTENCING IN UNDER-AGE SEX CASE A Superior Court judge on Tuesday agreed to reduce the sentence of a bus driver and self-proclaimed witch who was convicted of having sex with a 14-year-old boy. The woman, Kerri Lynn Patavino, 32, was convicted in 1997 for engaging in what was described as ritualistic sex with the boy while she was his bus driver at a Trumbull middle school. The judge cut the six-year sentence by a year after Ms. Patavino publicly apologized for the first time. She had previously denied the charges and had already served one year of her sentence. (NYT)
 
NEW JERSEY
 
TRENTON: MOST CRIMES FALL
Crime in New Jersey last year, with the exception of car theft, dropped about 6 percent from the year before, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman reported yesterday. Reports of murder dropped 11 percent, rape 13 percent, and domestic violence 1 percent. Motor vehicle theft, however, rose 1 percent. New Jersey's decline mirrors the national crime rate, which fell 7 percent last year. (NYT)
 
NEWARK: SUSPECT IN EARLIER ECSTASY ARREST
A college student charged last week in one of New Jersey's largest seizures of the drug Ecstasy had been arrested in New York City three weeks earlier on similar charges. On July 8, the student, Brian Juliano, 23, a senior at Monmouth University, was charged by police officers in Brooklyn with possession of 5,000 tablets of Ecstasy. He was free on bail when he was arrested at a New Jersey warehouse with, the police said, 45,000 doses of the drug, valued at $1.5 million. His lawyer said Mr. Juliano would plead not guilty in both cases. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)
 
GLASSBORO: SPRINKLERS AT COLLEGE DORMS
Spurred by a new state law and by the deaths of students in a fire at Seton Hall University, Rowan University has finished installing a new fire sprinkler system in time for fall classes. Rowan spent $1.9 million to install sprinklers in on-campus apartments and 17 dormitories, and spent nearly $143,000 on batteries for smoke detectors. In January, three students died in a Seton Hall University dormitory that had no sprinklers. A state law in July made such sprinklers necessary. (NYT)

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
John Wiley Leases Office in Hoboken

BYLINE: By Joseph P. Fried 

 BODY:
John Wiley & Sons, a leading publisher of scientific, medical and technical books based in Manhattan, has signed a lease for office space in Hoboken, N.J., where it plans to move its headquarters and 800 of its employees.
Wiley, whose headquarters have been at 605 Third Avenue, at 39th Street, since 1962, is to occupy eight floors of a 13-story office structure for which ground is to be broken next month, said Tony Cicatiello, a spokesman for SJP Properties, the developer. The building is one of two that SJP is constructing for a development called the Waterfront Corporate Center, part of a city plan to redevelop the Hoboken waterfront with office buildings, a hotel and housing. 
 The building Wiley is to occupy is expected to be completed in early 2002. Wiley's lease is for 400,000 square feet and has a 15-year term. A spokesman for the publishing house, Susan Spilka, declined to say what the rent would be.
With its business expanding, Wiley was seeking larger space, but was unable to find an affordable site in Manhattan, real estate specialists said. As part of an incentive package, the New Jersey Economic Development Authority approved a business employment incentive grant for Wiley that is expected to provide $7 million over the next 10 years. Ms. Spilka declined to say whether Wiley had asked the New York City government for economic benefits to remain in the city.
Among other major companies that have recently found office space across the Hudson is Chase Manhattan Bank, which said in June that it would move several thousand employees from Lower Manhattan to Jersey City but would retain its headquarters at 270 Park Avenue in Manhattan. Joseph P. Fried

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The rich may get richer, but numbers suggest the poor are doing better, too.

BYLINE: By Virginia Postrel; This column appears here every Thursday. Virginia Postrel is the editor at large of Reason magazine and the author of "The Future and Its Enemies: The Growing Conflict Over Creativity, Enterprise and Progress." Four economic analysts -- Ms. Postrel, Jeff Madrick, Alan B. Krueger and Hal R. Varian -- rotate as contributors.

 BODY:
THE rich are getting richer, and the poor are getting poorer, right? You'll hear that riff plenty this election year, if not from the major party candidates then from Ralph Nader and Pat Buchanan. It's a populist truism, Exhibit A in the case against the economy's recent dynamism.
But what if increasing inequality is mostly a myth -- an artifact of misleading data and changing lifestyles? What if just about everyone is getting richer? 
 In his new book, "The Fourth Great Awakening and the Future of Egalitarianism" (University of Chicago Press), the iconoclastic economic historian Robert W. Fogel makes just that case. Professor Fogel, of the University of Chicago, won the 1993 Nobel Prize for his revisionist empirical work on such topics as the economics of slavery and the development of the railroads. Here, he marshals data not just on income but on spending, time use, calorie consumption and health measures like life expectancy and height.
What he finds is good news indeed: a century of stunning material progress and improved physical well-being in the United States and the rest of the industrialized world. Poorer people have been the big winners. "In every measure that we have bearing on the standard of living, such as real income, homelessness, life expectancy, and height, the gains of the lower classes have been far greater than those experienced by the population as a whole, whose overall standard of living has also improved," Professor Fogel writes.
Most strikingly, technical and economic progress has bought us more time; we live longer, healthier lives and enjoy much more time to do what we want rather than what we must. In this, he notes, the poor have gained the most. A century ago, the lower your income, the more hours a year you worked to earn it -- a depressing prospect. Today, it's just the opposite.
Nowadays, the basics cost very little time. In 1880, for instance, covering a typical household's annual food bills cost 1,405 hours of labor, or about a half-year's wages back then, and those hours didn't include substantial unpaid time in the kitchen. A year's worth of food now costs a mere 260 hours of labor, and that price buys much greater variety and convenience, including a lot of restaurant meals.
One result is that Americans work many fewer hours each year. The free time of a typical working man has tripled over the last century. He now spends more time at leisure (not including sleeping, eating, commuting, chores and other basic activities) than at work. Women have enjoyed similar gains in leisure, mostly because they have a lot less housework.
Life expectancy, meanwhile, has increased 10 years just since 1950, mostly because people over 65 are living much longer. The age at which chronic problems like heart disease and arthritis set in keeps occurring later, and those ailments are less debilitating. This trend means many more active retirement years, which further adds to the huge increase in free time.
So what about the rising inequality we hear so much about? Professor Fogel argues that what looks like bad news over the last couple of decades mostly reflects individuals' different choices about how to use all this free time.
Take two men in the same occupation. One chooses to work long hours during middle age -- earning lots of overtime, advancing to the top corporate or partnership ranks or making it big in the start-up game -- so he can retire at 55. Another takes a more laid-back approach, avoiding the time commitments that would maximize his income and spending more time with his family and hobbies. He works until he's 65. Over the course of their lives, they may make about the same income. But in any given year, their incomes will be significantly different because of their choices about when to take their free time. This pattern intensifies when you add spouses pursuing similarly divergent choices.
In an appendix to Professor Fogel's book, Chulhee Lee, a former research associate at the University of Chicago and now an assistant professor at Seoul National University, presents evidence that increases in these sorts of variations account for much of what looks like a rise in income inequality from 1969 to 1989. Changes in how many heads of households and their spouses worked and how many hours they worked accounted for 54 percent of the rise in the spread between the highest 10 percent of household incomes and the lowest 10 percent. Changing wages, by contrast, accounted for less than 6 percent of the increase in the gap.
You might think these are signs of widespread, permanent unemployment among lower-income people. But Professor Lee found evidence to the contrary. As of 1994, 80 percent of those in the bottom 10 percent of incomes were spending more than they earned, an increase from about 53 percent in 1972-73. And the amount that 80 percent spent was about twice their incomes. Incomes look more lopsided, but the ratio of spending between the richest and poorest deciles has barely budged over time.
How can poor people spend significantly more than they earn? "You don't go to a bank and say, 'I'm very poor but worthy -- please give me some money,' " Professor Fogel said in an interview. Most likely, he said, they are using savings to finance either transient unemployment, which may be voluntary, or early retirement. Only a few of the poorest people stay poor over time, and the same is true for the richest, who tend to be at the peak of their earning years.
This evidence suggests that the apparent increase in inequality exists because more people with financial assets are taking breaks from work. That doesn't mean poverty has disappeared, of course, though its material hardships have lessened significantly. But it does suggest that identifying the real problems of the poor -- as most people understand that term -- requires a lot more nuance than aggregated income statistics provide. Focusing on snapshot inequality rather than on long-term life opportunities leads us to underestimate the country's enormous material progress and to overemphasize money as the solution to hard-core poverty.
Rather than worry about material inequality, Professor Fogel says, we should concern ourselves with the alienation that keeps a minority of the statistically poor from enjoying the self-realization our abundant time makes possible. Deciding what to do with that time, he argues, is something Americans of all income levels now face.
Today, he said: "People have the same problem that only the rich had, and that is, what do you do with your life? What is the good life? That was, from Socrates' time until the beginning of the 20th century, only an issue for the rich. Now it's becoming an issue for ordinary people. If you worked 3,000 hours a year, you didn't have a lot of time to wonder what to do with your life."

HEADLINE: Number in Prison Grows Despite Crime Reduction

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
After an eight-year drop in crime, the population of the nation's state and federal prisons grew last year at the lowest rate since 1979, 3.4 percent, the Justice Department reported yesterday.
The main reasons the prison population has increased even as crime has declined, the report said, are that the number of inmates returned to prison for parole violations increased, the length of the average sentence rose, and drug crimes, which are not included in the overall crime rate computed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, did not drop. 
 The number of inmates returned to prison after being released on parole during the 1990's grew by 54 percent, as parole agents became tougher about revoking parole for technical violations like failing a drug test. By contrast, the number of criminals sent to prison for new convictions rose only 7 percent.
The average length of time served was 28 months in 1998, up from 20 months in 1990, the report said, the result of tougher sentencing laws.
The report also found that the total number of Americans in all jails and prisons surpassed two million for the first time, reaching 2,026,596 at the end of 1999, the report said.
The report also found that Texas, which has been on a record-setting prison expansion under Gov. George W. Bush, the Republican presidential candidate, passed California as the state with the most prison inmates, though Texas has a much smaller population, 20 million people compared with 32 million in California. At the end of 1999, Texas had 163,190 inmates and California, 163,067.
In addition, the report said 9.4 percent of black men ages 25 to 29 were in state and federal prisons in 1999, almost 10 times the rate for white men in their late 20's, which was 1 percent. Among Hispanic males in their late 20's, 3.1 percent were in prison.
While the report highlighted the racial disparities in prison, it contradicted an assertion of advocates of prison and drug sentencing reform, who say most prisoners are locked up for drug arrests. In fact, the Justice Department found, people who had been convicted of violent crimes accounted for 51 percent of the increase in state prison populations from 1990 to 1998. Drug offenses accounted for 19 percent of the increase, property crimes accounted for 15 percent, and various other crimes accounted for 15 percent.
Altogether, in 1998, there were 545,200 state prison inmates serving time for violent offenses -- including murder, robbery, assault and rape -- compared with 242,900 for property crimes -- including burglary, auto theft and fraud -- and 236,800 for drug crimes.
Prisoners sentenced for drug crimes do predominate, the report said, in the federal system. Of the 108,925 federal inmates in 1998, 30,470 were sentenced for drug crimes, compared with 9,557 for violent crimes and 7,935 for property crimes.
Alfred Blumstein, a criminologist at Carnegie Mellon University, said a major finding of the study, written by Allen J. Beck of the Bureau of Justice Statistics, was that the continued growth of the prison population was driven by the huge increase in the number of parolees being returned to prison.
The report says most of those returning parolees have committed new crimes.
But Professor Blumstein said that the parole system had gotten tougher and that more parolees were being returned for violations like failing a monthly urine test for drugs.
The 3.4 percent increase in inmates in state and federal prisons in 1999 -- to 1.37 million -- was well below the average annual growth rate during the 1990's, of 6.5 percent, the new report said. The growth rate hit a high of 8.7 percent in 1994, well after the crime wave of the late 1980's and early 1990's began to decline in 1991, falling gradually for the rest of the decade.
There are 690 prisoners per 100,000 United States residents, according to The Sentencing Project, a nonprofit prison research and advocacy organization in Washington. That rate is six times that of Canada and Australia, which are both around 110 prisoners per 100,000 residents, the project said, and five times that of any country in the European Union.
One major issue that the Justice Department's study did not address was whether there was any relationship between growth in the incarceration rate and the drop in crime. Advocates of tougher prosecution and sentencing say the huge growth in imprisonment, with the incarceration rate quadrupling since 1980, has been largely responsible for the decrease in crime.
But Professor Blumstein said crime rates were also going up sharply in the late 1980's when prison population was increasing as well. Some other factors that must also be considered, he said, were the improved economy in the 1990's, better police tactics and the waning of the crack cocaine epidemic. 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: August 24, 2000, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 10 about a slowing in the increase of the nation's prison population misstated the number of federal inmates sentenced on various types of charges in 1998. The article substituted 1990 figures from the Justice Department report. Actually, of the 108,925 inmates in federal prisons in 1998, 63,011 (not 30,470) were charged with drug crimes, 12,656 (not 7,557) were charged with violent offenses and 8,627 (not 7,935) were charged with property crimes.

HEADLINE: AT THE MOVIES;
Cable Offshoot Branches Out

BYLINE: By Dave Kehr

 BODY:
As the new digital technologies continue to transform the movie business, established companies are looking for ways to protect their franchise while taking advantage of new opportunities. One example is IFC Films, an offshoot of the Independent Film Channel cable network, which was itself an offshoot of Bravo, the upscale cultural channel that started up in 1980.
Under the direction of Jonathan Sehring, the president of IFC Films, and Caroline Kaplan, the vice president for production and development, the company has branched out from creating programs for its parent network into producing full-length features for theatrical distribution. 
 With IFC's "Boys Don't Cry" winning an Oscar for the actress Hilary Swank and "Girlfight," a drama about a female boxer from Brooklyn, poised to become the indie hit of the fall season, it's been a good year for Mr. Sehring and Ms. Kaplan.
But they aren't resting on their laurels. They've just sprung another offshoot, teaming with the producers Gary Winick and John Sloss to create Independent Digital Entertainment, a k a InDigEnt.
"Right now it's five movies," Mr. Sehring said, "but it's going to be an ongoing series of movies done by filmmakers with pretty good casts, inspired by Dogma 95, but with a New York slant."
Dogma 95 is the semiserious movement spawned by the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier as a reaction against Hollywood inflation. The idea is to make digital video films quickly and cheaply, without recourse to fancy lighting, special effects or music. "We don't have the Dogma rules, other than the budget, which initially was to make 10 films for $100,000 each," Mr. Sehring said. "So for a million dollars we'll have a whole slate."
"Half of the revenue, from the first dollar, goes to the creative talent," he said, a radical departure from Hollywood accounting practices. "So a lot of pretty well-known actors, directors and writers are working for scale, because they're sharing revenue from the outset."
The initial projects are "Final," directed by Campbell Scott and starring Denis Leary and Hope Davis, and Ethan Hawke's "Last Word on Paradise," with Uma Thurman and Kevin Corrigan. "We're not into making made-for-cable movies," Mr. Sehring said. "When we make a movie, we want it to go out theatrically and we want it to go to pay television. We get the cable window after it runs on pay TV and we get the library rights."
Non-InDigEnt projects for the next year include "Waking Life," an animated feature directed by Richard Linklater ("Slacker"), and "Monsoon Wedding," a new film by Mira Nair ("Salaam Bombay!") currently shooting in India. "The one thing we are steadfast about is not having any creative control over a project," Mr. Sehring said, "which is why we've had a lot of world-class filmmakers come to work with us, from John Sayles and Steven Soderbergh early, to Rick and Mira now.
"We're involved when they want us to be involved, and if they don't want us, we stay away. Rick sometimes feels it's a bit disconcerting because he hasn't heard from us. He'll call in and say, 'Don't you want to know what's going on?' and we're like, 'Yeah, whenever you want to tell us.' We told you we'd leave you alone, and we're leaving you alone."
 
Donal Who?
When Donal Logue won the best actor award at January's Sundance Film Festival, for playing Dex, a pudgy Don Juan in Jenniphr Goodman's "Tao of Steve," he was hailed as a gifted newcomer -- an ambiguous compliment for this character actor who has appeared in almost 40 features since 1989.
"I remember people at Sundance asking, 'Is this your first movie?' " said Mr. Logue on a recent New York visit. "And I thought, that's cool. It's weird that you can work so much for 10 years and support yourself and get around and not appear on the radar anywhere. But then the times I did appear on the radar, I played parts so different from each other that people didn't put together that I was the same guy. And that's cool, too.
"I'm completely into that element of being unrecognizable to some degree from part to part to part. Like Jimmy, this weird cab driver guy that I did on MTV, to the gay cancer guy in 'The Band Played On,' to the vampire in 'Blade' whose hand gets cut off, to Dex in 'The Tao of Steve.' "
Mr. Logue, in fact, can currently be seen in three movies on New York screens: "Steve," for which he received warm reviews; "The Patriot," in which he has a supporting role (a Southern soldier who overcomes his racism); and "The Opportunists," a hangdog heist comedy opening today that finds Mr. Logue as a not-so-sharp security guard (review, Page 13).
"All of us want to hit the homer," Mr. Logue said. "But movies are sometimes made in the trenches, by the guys in the smaller parts. And sometimes you have more freedom, because you have less to carry so you can do wilder stuff. But at the same time I'm glad, now that I've had my chance to carry a movie, that people would respect it."
 
A Fable of Immigration
Speaking of "The Opportunists," the film is the work of Myles Connell, a 36-year-old Dublin native who now lives in Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. The film, on one level, is an ironic fable about immigration and the American dream. Its central character is Michael, a young Irishman (Peter McDonald) who turns up on the of his long-lost cousin Vic (Christopher Walken) in Sunnyside, Queens. Michael expects to find a prosperous businessman; instead he finds a safecracker on parole. Not to be dissuaded from his dream of riches, Michael pressures Vic into undertaking one last job.
"You see so many New York crime movies that are just fast cars and guns and people lying in pools of blood, and I just wanted to do something different, that was based more around a character who was just trying to make a go of it," Mr. Connell said.
"Vic to Michael is a little bit of a metaphor for his relationship to coming to America. For people who come here from different places, there's much more opportunity to get an education and so on here. You come to appreciate the things you get here that maybe you don't get at home. Michael is much more devious, but there's something of me in him.
"The old immigrant neighborhoods, and the way people stay for a generation or two and then disperse out into the rest of the country, were fascinating to me," Mr. Connell said. "I wanted to create, out of those neighborhoods, a sense of a village. I showed the movie in France, and a critic there said he thought it was a very bucolic film. I took it as a compliment."

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 33; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 1387 words

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
In Their Own Worlds: Giant Hybrids of Fact and Fantasy

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

DATELINE: NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Aug. 4

 BODY:
"Unnatural Science" at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art is a well-done exhibition. The first serious theme show to be organized in the vaulting refurbished factory spaces of Mass MOCA, which opened to the public last year, it is thoughtfully installed, coherent yet diverse, and presents most of its participants to good advantage.
It also has an eminently topical theme, given the computer-generated nature of almost everything, the regular advances in science and medicine, the constant refinements in digital imaging and the arrival of the genome era. Science and its technologies press in on us from all sides, and artists are bound to use them, adapting, mimicking, distorting and commenting upon them as they see fit. 
 The only thing missing is staying power. Too many of the artworks in this show stick to familiar strategies or are little more than elaborate, often beautifully executed illustrations of some scientific fact or fantasy. In one work, for example, it is possible to watch hundreds of little flags flutter in exactly the same speed and direction as the winds outside the building -- the kind of effect that looks great in a science museum or, even better, across wavy fields of grain. The show provides very few experiences that don't evaporate almost before you vacate Mass MOCA's handsomely renovated premises.
The sight of artists grappling with intractable materials or difficult thought is relatively rare here. The beautiful, abstruse paintings of Matthew Ritchie, with their meldings of creation myth, Big Bang theory and polytheism, offer some resistance, and also provide one of the show's few moments of color. (Catherine Chalmers's big color photographs of insects and reptiles instinctually enacting the food chain in action provide the other.)
But too often the show is about art for consumption's sake, works whose meanings are completely available either visually or with the help of an explanatory brochure. As with so many big shows lately, one begins to suspect that the museum theme show, once the litmus test of curatorial talent, is morphing into a no-brainer, and that art is doing its bit to help.
In these post-Conceptual times, when art is so overtly involved with narrative and subject matter reigns, it's getting easier and easier to come up with catchy, accessible, viewer-friendly art links -- art and fashion, film, religion or history. Add to this the institutionalization of Conceptual-oriented installation art and the ever-larger museum spaces being built to accommodate it. The result is festivalism, as Peter Schjeldahl aptly put it in The New Yorker last summer: big shows that present a succession of big, encompassing artworks quarantined in separate galleries, so that the viewer moves from one discrete experience of total immersion to the next.
"Unnatural Science" is a case of mini-festivalism. It contains only 14 works by 15 artists, but each has been given quantities of space and is seen pretty much in isolation. And each provides an "experience."
So it's telling to simply walk through this show and notice which experience holds your attention and which doesn't. There is plenty that is handsome and momentarily engaging. Gary Schneider's "Genetic Self-Portrait," with its greatly magnified black-and-white images of such details as a strand of the artist's hair or his DNA have a strange deathliness considering their extreme focus on life. In "Apparatus for the Distillation of Vague Intuitions," Eve Andree Laramee takes her usual chem-lab sculptures to mad-scientist extremes, covering two large tables with towering transparent edifices of glass beakers and coiling tubes, although there's a strong resemblance to an elegant window display.
And clearly intended as the exhibition's showstopper is Tim Hawkinson's "Uberorgan," which fills Mass MOCA's largest, football-field-size gallery with a dozen white plastic bladder-shaped balloons the size of small whales. Equipped with big telescoping horns made of cardboard and aluminum foil and triggered by a device similar to a player-piano roll, the balloons function as bagpipes, bleating out the notes of four Christian hymns in very low octaves. The economy of filling such a large space with so much sound and form using a relatively small amount of material is impressive. "Uberorgan" is definitely an experience, but the most lasting impression, as is usual with this artist, is one of boyish genius and industriousness.
There are numerous opportunities for total immersion here, but little that you dip into feels very new, unless you use narrative as the yardstick. Repeatedly generic visual strategies are used to convey less familiar subject matter -- that is, the words change, but the tunes don't.
Thus Michael Oatman's "Long Shadows: Henry Perkins and the Eugenics Survey of Vermont (Vermont Pure)" partakes of the lengthening tradition of the walk-in diorama re creation as practiced by Ilya Kabokov, Mark Dion, Barbara Bloom and other artists. Mr. Oatman, who has worked in the diorama format himself since the early 1990's, has assembled here the half-real, half-imagined office of Perkins -- the first director of the Robert Hull Fleming Museum of the University of Vermont -- whose zoological training found perverse expression in the racist pseudo-science of eugenics that sought to weed out "undesirable" genetic traits through sterilization.
The display is fastidiously detailed and fascinatingly creepy -- a kind of walk-in history lesson -- but its most powerful element is simple: a videotape of an actor giving a lecture whose racist ideas are drawn from Perkins's letters and eugenics propaganda. In one of the installation's many unnecessary touches, it is projected on a painting of a landscape.
Similarly, Lim Young-sun's "Room of the Host," adds capably but unexceptionally to the ever-expanding installation-art tradition of the darkened room in which the viewer is surrounded by mysterious lighted objects and strange sounds. (Practitioners of this genre range from regulars like Tatsuo Miyajima to one-time users like Serge Spitzer, who created an unaccountable stir at last year's Venice Biennale by lining up empty glasses in a huge darkened shed.) In this case the objects are small jars containing green fluid and little specimenlike resin casts that suggest skulls, bones, vertebrae and jellyfish that hang from the ceiling. Thomas Grunfeld's 1994 "Misfit (St. Bernhard)," a stuffed dog with a sheep's face, staves off complete Surrealist hokiness with a weird, saintly serenity, but may also have contributed to the craze for anatomically incorrect taxidermical jokes that currently afflicts sculpture.
The most impressive works in the show are two old standards. One is Peter Fischli and David Weiss's 30-minute 1987 film classic, "Der Lauf der Dinge" ("The Way Things Go"). A seemingly uninterrupted domino effect of chain reactions involving oozing foam, pendulums, balances, inclined planes, rolling objects of all kinds and occasional fireworks, it creates an effect of 70's Process Art in perpetual motion. Equally good is Steina Vasulka's 1993 video installation "Borealis," which captures the uncontrollable power of nature in constantly moving, spatially disorienting images of roaring water, breaking waves and moist, loudly crunching undergrowth. Ms. Vasulka's aggressive manipulation of her medium matches her subject. The wildness of nature, the weirdness of video and the susceptibility of human perception play a hallucinatory game of tag here, and the viewer struggles to keep up.
But these works are among the exceptions in an exhibition that suggests -- as Donald Judd once said of 80's painting -- that theme shows are becoming a form of musical comedy. The analogy conjures up not only the endless recycling of familiar conventions -- which I think was Judd's meaning -- but also a sequence of more or less pleasant entertainments in which each player executes a song-and-dance routine that works well with the other numbers and then exits gracefully, clearing the stage for the next performer.
 
"Unnatural Science" remains at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, 87 Marshall Street, North Adams, Mass., (413) 664-4481, through April 15. Information online: www.massmoca.org.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Decrease in Petroleum Costs Kept July Import Prices Level

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Prices of imported goods were unchanged in July as a decline in the cost of petroleum offset increases for autos and some raw materials, government figures showed today.
The steady import prices last month came after a 1.2 percent increase in June, the Labor Department said. Excluding petroleum, import costs rose 0.3 percent after an increase of 0.1 percent in June. 
 Falling import costs have helped keep inflation in check in recent years as companies paid less for raw materials and were unable to raise their prices when faced with international competition. That began to change in recent months, especially as rising oil costs began to feed through into the cost of other goods and services.
Compared with July 1999, import prices were 6.7 percent higher last month. Excluding oil, however, the year-over-year increase was just 1.6 percent. While that was the largest such increase since January 1996, import prices excluding fuel are still rising at a slower pace than they did the first five years of the nine-year-old economic expansion.
Federal Reserve policy makers will meet on Aug. 22, and some of them have signaled that they will hold the line on interest rates. The pace of inflation, excluding the effect of higher energy prices, is "pretty tame" and consumer spending is slowing, Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said today.
And though the economy may be cooling, jobs remain plentiful. A separate Labor Department report showed the four-week average for first-time claims for state unemployment benefits fell to 288,500 last week from 295,250 in the previous week. The four-week average was the lowest since the last week of May. For the week, claims rose 18,000, to a level of 293,000.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Ambivalence in China On Expanding Net Access

BYLINE: By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Aug. 10

 BODY:
China's unease with the Internet is growing as the country embraces the new medium to modernize its economy yet worries about the Web's spread beyond government control.
Just this week, the government-sponsored State Research Information Technology Company said it had hired a California company to help set up electronic commerce sites for thousands of government companies. And it claims to own China's first patented Wireless Application Protocol system, which could greatly expand Internet access in a country where cellular telephones vastly outnumber personal computers. 
 But even as the government pushes its own Internet ventures, it is trying to stamp out others that it sees as a potential political threat.
"Enemy forces at home and abroad are sparing no effort to use this battlefront to infiltrate us," said an editorial this week in the Communist Party's national newspaper, The People's Daily.
The warning followed renewed reports that local governments are establishing Internet surveillance units and tracking down people who use the Web to express political dissent or other nonconformist ideas. The government shut one such Web site, www.xinwenming.com, this week for posting "counterrevolutionary content," a euphemism that often means nothing more than criticism of the government. Police are searching for the Web site's organizers, according to the New York-based Human Rights in China group.
The government's deep ambivalence toward the Internet, which Beijing fears could be used to unite opposition to the Communist Party, has slowed the medium's development here. And it threatens to distort the new industry in much the way the planned economy distorted other industries in the past, favoring inefficient government-owned ventures over more creative private ones.
Already, the government's heavy hand has cast a pall over private Web ventures, which are relying on foreign investment to survive.
Regulations that make much of the foreign investment technically illegal and the inability of Internet companies to list their shares on China's stock market are scaring off venture capitalists who were still pumping money into the sector just a few weeks ago. Many of the tiny Internet companies started in the last year are running out of cash and closing.
Internet entrepreneurs say government interference has cost the industry hundreds of millions of dollars in investment capital that could have helped close the gap with the Internet of the West.
Had Beijing moved more quickly, the critics say, many Chinese Internet companies could have listed their shares on Nasdaq before that market tumbled in April and the American public's appetite for Internet plays waned.
Instead, Beijing dithered and by the time it began allowing Chinese companies to list abroad, the moment had passed. The shares of the last two Chinese Internet companies to list on Nasdaq, Netease.com and Sohu.com, are trading at about half of their initial offering prices. Other Chinese Internet stock offerings have been postponed.
China's state-owned ventures, meanwhile, are failing to generate much excitement among the venture capital community that has watched the Internet develop elsewhere.
"Many of the government initiatives which don't have a strong involvement with the private sector do face the risk of failure," said David Williams, a Hong Kong-based partner at the American venture capital firm Draper Fisher Jurvetson.
Despite its threatening talk and a few widely publicized arrests, Beijing appears to be failing in its efforts to control unauthorized information flows. The government estimates that 17 million people are connected to the Internet, and that number is doubling every six months while numerous Web sites are popping up each day.
For example, one popular Web site, www.homeway.com, which regularly posts unconfirmed news reports from the Hong Kong press, had reported for weeks that Li Jizhou, vice minister of public security, was in Beijing's Qincheng Prison awaiting trial for taking bribes worth millions of dollars. And the Web site of the Internet advocate Huang Qi, www.6-4tianwang.com, remains up, despite the arrest of Mr. Huang. He is facing charges of subversion after posting information about the 1989 massacre that ended pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square.

HEADLINE: Legislatures Of the World Call Congress 'The Rudest'

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 10

 BODY:
More than 170 speakers of legislatures around the world plan to meet here for the first time later this month to celebrate a little-noticed byproduct of the spread of democracy: the growth and strengthening of national parliaments.
To the chagrin of the organizers, however, no one from the United States Congress seems willing to attend. 
 Since 1996, the Republican-led Congress has failed to pay its dues to the group that organized the meeting, the Inter-Parliamentary Union, which Americans helped to found in 1889. An invitation to preside over part of the meeting was sent to J. Dennis Hastert, the Illinois Republican who is speaker of the House of Representatives. It has not been answered. No one can make it from the Senate side either, officials of the Inter-Parliamentary Union said.
"I think that they should be there," said Anders B. Johnsson, a Swede who is secretary general of the group. "I think the world wants them to be there. We've sent that message. But we haven't got a response. I think that's a shame."
Mr. Johnsson, an administrator based in Geneva, and Najma Heptullah, the speaker of India's upper house, who is now president of the parliamentary union, both tried to meet American legislators to persuade them to attend the meeting and play a part in strengthening the work of national legislatures. Ms. Heptullah waited in vain in New York for two weeks for an appointment with Mr. Hastert in Washington, union officials said.
An official on Mr. Johnsson's staff, frustrated by repeated snubs from Washington, called Congress "the rudest parliament in the world, without a doubt." He described the atmosphere on Capitol Hill as fortresslike and "run by aides who are the age of my children."
In Washington, John Feehery, the House speaker's spokesman, said that Mr. Hastert could not attend the meeting because he would be traveling in Colombia with President Clinton at the end of August. "This is the worst time of the year for us, toward the end of the August recess," he said. "This is a very contentious political year, and the speaker is going to be spending most of his time campaigning."
If Congress does not resume paying its dues, about $900,000 a year, it will be suspended from the Inter-Parliamentary Union in October and expelled next year, oddly, at a meeting scheduled to be held in Havana.
National legislatures have growing roles to play in a global age, parliamentary union officials and members say. Legislatures have the power to regulate the uses of national resources, and protect countries from exploitation in an era of economic globalization. They ratify treaties and debate international policies. Domestically, they can protect rights, raise tax revenues and guide social policies so that spending reaches the poor. Functioning legislatures aid development.
When Secretary General Kofi Annan travels abroad, said Santiago Romero-Perez, director of the Inter-Parliamentary Union's liaison office with the United Nations, "he makes it a point of visiting parliaments."
"This is not a chance happening," Mr. Romero added, "but a realization that the big commitments made during the 1990's really need a popular response. Parliaments have to legislate and appropriate the funds."
In Geneva, Mr. Johnsson said that many parliaments still needed work.
"If you look at the last decade -- the 1990's, the one that history will remember as a period of democratization in the world -- one country out of every four in the world changed its constitutional framework, its electoral law, its parliament." he said. "In all of those, there were two elements in common. One is that they introduced multiparty systems, and the other was that they introduced a stronger parliament with real legislative and oversight functions."
National parliaments, he said, are a natural link between the grass roots and the wider world, including the international economic institutions that have become targets of criticism in the third world.
"Many people in many parts of the world feel that they are completely disconnected from the real decision-making processes on the international scene," Mr. Johnsson said. "That is a great concern. If they don't feel that these are their processes and that they have an influence over them, then these processes may be destroyed. That we cannot afford."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
Two Big Online Toy Sellers to Merge Units

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Toys "R" Us and Amazon.com said yesterday that they were merging their online toy-sales units, an acknowledgment that selling toys on the Internet has been too hard for each of them alone.
Starting later this year, toysrus .com will direct users to a toy section of Amazon.com. Customers will be able to use their Amazon accounts to buy toys, books, tools and other merchandise in a single order that will be shipped in one box. 
 But Amazon's role will shift from being a store proprietor to being something more like a mall owner. Toys "R" Us will buy the inventory, set the prices, write the item descriptions and get credit for the revenue and any potential profits or losses. Toys "R" Us will pay Amazon to use its Internet site and to house the merchandise in its warehouses.
"This allows both of us to reach profitability in our toy businesses significantly sooner than we would have been able to," said Jeffrey P. Bezos, chief executive of Amazon.
The deal also helps each company avoid the more troubling aspects of its toy business.
Last Christmas season, Toys "R" Us was hit by myriad operating problems, from crashes on its Web site to an inability to deliver toys when promised. Amazon was able to satisfy customers, but did so at a big cost. It had ordered so many toys that it had to take a $39 million writedown on its unsold inventory, a huge number relative to its total sales of toys and children's merchandise of $95 million in the fourth quarter of last year.
Amazon has found toys a more difficult business than books and records. They are big and expensive to ship. They must be ordered, largely from Asia, six months ahead of time, forcing a retailer to predict children's whims. And unlike books, unwanted toys cannot be returned to manufacturers for credit.
Toys "R" Us will sell its three distribution centers, which analysts estimate it had spent $50 million to build. And Amazon will sell Toys "R" Us its inventory of toys. Neither company would say if a charge would be taken to cover those costs.
"We are getting better, but they are three years ahead of us and we would never catch up," said John Eyler, chief executive of Toys "R" Us.
Analysts praised Amazon for getting out of a tough business.
"They capitulated," said Lauren Levitan, with Robertson Stevens. "They needed to do something to mitigate their inventory risk and create a more predictable business for themselves."
The move is not without a cost to Amazon's image. "I am struck by the irony of the visionary poster boy for the new economy being mated with the poster child of eroding retail brands," Ms. Levitan said.
Peter Caruso, a retail analyst with Merrill Lynch, said the highlight of the deal was that the market for Toys "R" Us might not be eroding as fast as some had feared.
"This tells you the success Amazon had in books is not going to be repeated in other areas, and the Internet toy market is not going to be as large as everyone thought," he said. "That means that Toys 'R' Us is not going to be vulnerable sitting there with all those stores."
This vision of the toy market is vastly different from a year ago, when half a dozen companies were preparing to spend an estimated $200 million to promote online toy stores. Christmas proved to be a Waterloo for many of them, in fact. Toysmart, an online store backed by Walt Disney, failed, as did Red Rocket, a toy store owned by Viacom. And KBKids.com, controlled by KB Toys, the No. 2 store chain, has abandoned its plan for a public offering and has laid off 30 percent of its work force.
"This is great news for us," said Toby Lenk, the chief executive of eToys, the No. 1 online toy store. "Last year we had half a dozen competitors. Now our two remaining competitors are merging into one."
Mr. Lenk said he expected the steep price cutting of last year to be far less severe this Christmas. "A lot of the players doing the insane discounting are just not here anymore," he said.
Investors, however, were largely unmoved by the deal. Shares in Toys "R" Us closed unchanged at $17.375. Amazon shares slipped 43.75 cents, to $30.4375. Etoys dropped 9 cents, to $3.9375.
Under the arrangement with Amazon, online customers will no longer be able to return toys to stores, as Toys "R" Us customers have been able to do. Conversely, though, most will no longer have to pay sales tax.

HEADLINE: Soft, Cute and New on the Farm;
Far From Andes, Alpacas Turn Heads and Even Profits

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

DATELINE: BETHEL, N.Y.

 BODY:
Screech. Slam. Ooh. Ahh.
Edward F. Boyd and his family scarcely notice the noise anymore. They know the routine so well. First, there is the sudden glow of the brake lights on the vehicles heading past their 120-acre farm on a normally quiet back road in rural Sullivan County. Then comes the whine of the brakes and the thump of car doors slamming. Inevitably, a knot of curious visitors gathers at the pasture fence near the 200-year-old house. 
 "A lot of them take out cameras," said Mr. Boyd, "because they've never seen an alpaca before."
He was referring to the 80 quizzical, friendly looking, big-eyed creatures eyeing him meditatively on a recent afternoon, all of them sporting improbably long eyelashes and goofy topknots. Each resembled nothing so much as a teddy-bear-ish Bambi as drawn by Dr. Seuss.
Until very recently the alpaca was an exotic sight at county fairs and petting zoos in the metropolitan region. And the animals were profoundly unknown way out there in rustic crevices like Mr. Boyd's 120-acre former dairy spread, half a mile from what was once the site of the original Woodstock festival.
For a tiny but growing number of upstate farmers and entrepreneurs, however, these gentle, adaptable creatures are becoming not just a curiosity but a way of life: an avocation, a passionate cause and, more importantly, a profit center.
Officials in Sullivan County and the region see the alpaca farms, should their numbers grow, not only as a support to the local economy, but as an alternative to the exurban encroachment that is implacably transforming picturesque dairy farms into split-level tracts. "Alpacas are well suited to the land here," said Allan C. Scott, supervisor of the Town of Bethel, the largest in the county. "It's already a good thing for our economy, and I'm sure that raising alpacas could be an economic option for others in Sullivan County."
One of those others is Maria Herlinda Bravo, an entrepreneur who has established a herd of 340 alpacas on a 48-acre farm in Callicoon, N.Y., six miles northwest of Mr. Boyd.
"Alpacas thrive in the warm days and cool nights here," said Ms. Bravo, a former grocery-chain vice president, who in 1999 made her farm the headquarters of a vertically integrated international alpaca operation. She breeds the animals and shears the luxurious fleece for her fashion business, selling expensive scarves, sweaters, blankets and blouses through a catalog and on the Internet, under the name of Quintessence and Company.
Apart from Mr. Boyd and Ms. Bravo, alpaca herds have recently been established in Catskill, New Kingston and Walton. There are other New York herds in Hancock and Rome, and alpacas are being raised on Long Island and in Connecticut.
Mr. Boyd's son Brandon is president of the Mid-Atlantic Alpaca Association, which counts as its members 100 of the 140 alpaca owners in seven mid-Atlantic states (they are given to flaunting vehicle bumper stickers proclaiming "ALPACAS -- HAVE YOU HERD?").
But still: alpacas?
While some raise the animals as pets, the real draw is the silky, durable, water-resistant and highly insulative alpaca fleece, which has long been prized as the raw material for luxurious fabric.
Breeders say that depending on the color and the quality, fleece sells for $2 to $8 per ounce in the United States, primarily to artisanal weavers and knitters. Each animal produces five to eight pounds of fleece per year, enough for several sweaters.
While it can be lucrative to sell, alpaca can be even more lucrative to weave: a man's sweater can be made out of one pound of yarn worth about $40; it costs $100 in labor to weave, and can be sold for $400.
But Mr. Boyd and other herd owners breed alpacas for more than fleece: females sell for $12,500 to $40,000, and herd sires have fetched as much as $165,000. Owners command stud fees of $2,000 to $5,000 for their prize bulls.
These days 99 percent of the world's three million alpacas graze in the mountains of Bolivia, Chile and Peru. But in recent years, herds have been established in Canada, Australia, Japan, Britain, Israel, Italy and other countries.
In the United States, alpacas are being raised in every state, and the nation's alpaca herd is growing by about 22 percent a year, according to the Alpaca Registry in Kalispell, Mont. By July 31, there were 29,856 registered alpacas, up 2,145 percent over 1990, when there were 1,330. The number of owners has grown from 146, in 1991, to 2,919.
"We expect the number to double in another five years," said Ken Hobert, business manager of the Alpaca Owners and Breeders Association in Estes Park, Colo., which has 1,950 members. "We get 1,000 inquiries a month from people who want to know more about owning alpacas," he said of the registry's Web site, www.alpacainfo.com.
He said the scarcity of alpacas is based on their slow rate of reproduction, since females usually deliver one baby, called a cria, per year. Importing alpacas from South America is difficult and expensive, given quarantine restrictions, and the Alpaca Registry has been closed to newly imported alpacas since Dec. 31, 1998. Unregistered alpacas "have minimal breeding value, and are difficult to sell," Mr. Boyd said.
Eager to show off the superiority of their fleece, alpaca worshipers proffer research showing that alpaca fibers are stronger, lighter, warmer and softer than sheep's wool. Studies show that the semi-hollow alpaca fibers are finer than Angora rabbit fleece, mohair (from Angora goats) and cashmere goat fleece.
And unlike merino (sheep's wool), alpaca fleece is lanolin-free, and sold, therefore, to those who are allergic to wool.
Beyond this, breeders say alpacas are, in livestock patois, easy keepers, requiring minimal food, water, care and shelter, thanks to the extremes of heat and cold their ancestors endured in the Andes. They live 15 to 25 years and can weigh 150 to 175 pounds.
They are placid, have no incisors, horns, hooves or claws, and "they don't bite and they rarely kick, and when they do, they don't hurt each other -- because they have soft pads on their feet," said Mr. Boyd's farm manager, Jair Trujillo. "They don't cut up the pasture, either."
For these and other reasons, alpaca owners reject comparisons with the ostrich-farm scramble of the 1980's, when speculators expected windfall profits from the supposedly exploding ostrich market only to find that it was more of a novelty boomlet. "Ostriches are mean, dangerous and dirty," contended Mr. Boyd, "and they are nowhere as easy to handle as alpacas."
Ms. Bravo estimates that, given the slow alpaca reproductive rate, "it will take a long time to drive the price of breeding stock down."
She has placed a big bet on Sullivan County by putting in new buildings and paddocks to house her high-tech computer-monitored alpaca business, which employs six full-time workers, and features a two-story barn-cum-office-cum-laboratory equipped with ultrasound devices to monitor gestating alpaca females.
The hope for stability in alpaca prices is an important consideration in Sullivan County, where, because of low milk prices, more farms "are being lost every year," said Mr. Scott, a director of the Sullivan County Partnership, a consortium of organizations working to develop the county's economy.
Mr. Boyd, an alpaca proselytizer, said he welcomed competition. "There is plenty of room for more," said Mr. Boyd, a retired marketing manager for the Pepsi-Cola Company and American Home Products Corporation.
Mr. Boyd, 86, bought the farm in 1966, a decade after it supported dairy cows, "but I always wanted to use the property productively," he said. He finally got his wish in 1994 after seeing a televised report about an alpaca herd in Santa Fe, N.M. "I knew how to spell alpaca but didn't know any more than that."
He added, laughing, "Some people thought I had a soft cranium, but I saw the potential from the start." He suggested the alpaca avocation to his wife and four grown children. "After Dad suggested we buy them, we just looked at each other," recalled his 44-year-old son, Brandon, an entertainment lawyer in Manhattan. "Then we said: 'What is this? Can you eat them? Do they pull a plow?' Finally we thought, 'Maybe it will help to keep Dad busy.' "
In 1994 the senior Mr. Boyd bought his first three animals for $55,500, soon bought seven more, and found himself the proprietor of the Double E Alpaca Farm (the E's represent Ed Boyd and his wife, Edith).
As his herd increased, he began selling fleece to local spinners, and soon was selling animals and obtaining stud fees. "I started with a five-year plan, to make money, and we made it," said Mr. Boyd, adding that his alpacas were profitable for the first time in 1999, earning $50,000.
Along the way, Brandon Boyd said that he was converted. "There was just something about them that drew me in," he said. As he spoke, he stood near his father in the venerable dairy barn, where a throng of alpacas made the sound called "humming": a soothing ululation that sounds something like a happy kazoo.
"They are such gentle animals," Brandon said. "All I can say is that I've really become very gung-ho about alpacas."

HEADLINE: Tire Technology Has Bred Consistency and Compatibility

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
No one yet knows what caused a disproportionate number of Firestone tires to fail on Ford Explorers, or why many of the failed tires seem to have come from one Firestone plant in Decatur, Ill. But when it comes to tire design, manufacture and composition in general, experts are unanimous about one thing: Tires on the road today are safe, when they are used as intended.
"The general reason for tire failure is tire abuse by drivers, not tire manufacture," said Edward J. Wagner, a consultant in Louisville, Ky., who often serves as an expert witness -- both for and against tire companies -- in product liability lawsuits. Among other mistakes, consumers let their tires get low on air, or put the wrong size of tires on their vehicles. 
 In November, Consumer Reports studied six all-weather tires for sport utility vehicles -- none of them made by Firestone. It checked how well they braked, took corners, held the road in snow or rain and otherwise performed. "We've found no tires with dangerous performance attributes," said R. David Pittle, technical director of Consumer Reports. Even the lowest-ranked tire -- a Goodyear Wrangler RAF -- "ranked in the middle of good," he said.
That was not always the case, of course. When radial tires were introduced in the United States in the late 1970's, they brought their share of problems. Most were reinforced with fiberglass, which often broke. And many had sidewalls that bulged out, causing bumpy rides. One early radial, the Firestone 500, leaked air, making it the subject of one of the largest tire recalls in history.
Now, all tire manufacturers use durable steel belts. And most tires are made of sophisticated rubber compounds that can withstand heat and friction. "You almost can't buy a bad tire these days," said Robert Ulrich, editor of Modern Tire Dealer.
No one is suggesting that tires are commodities, differentiated only by advertising. Indeed, they are highly engineered products, with each company keeping its particular curing temperature, tread design and cocktail of rubber compounds a closely held trade secret.
Tires can be made up of as many as 200 different materials, from rubbers to plastics to steel, amalgamated into more than 30 components. Some parts, like the tread or sidewall, are visible. Others, like the steel belts for reinforcement, or the butyl rubber interliners to keep air from leaking, are on the inside. There are layers, called plies, of polyester, rayon and other materials. Most tires have high-tensile steel wires, called beads, that keep tires seated against the metal wheels.
Each line of tires has a slightly different tread designed for hugging the road better in wet weather, but all of them operate loosely on the principle that the placement or depth of grooves on the tire can keep the tire from accumulating water and hydroplaning. Similarly, manufacturers tinker with the makeup of rubber compounds to increase traction, and redesign treads to give a quieter ride.
Every tire represents tradeoffs. Put in a lot of carbon black to make the tire more resistant to cuts and it may have traction problems on wet pavements. Add silica to reduce resistance -- and thus increase fuel economy -- and there can be a static electricity buildup that causes a mild shock if you touch the car.
In Europe, some tire manufacturers have added extra nylon reinforcement to make tires more durable. Joan Claybrook, director of Public Citizen, the consumer rights group, has frequently suggested that American tire manufacturers do the same. But most American tire experts say the nylon does not add anything to tire performance.
But for the most part -- ad campaigns to the contrary -- tires are compatible, making it possible for consumers to replace one tire at a time with whatever brand they prefer.
All tires are manufactured to specifications laid out by the Tire and Rim Association, a trade group that decides the minimum and maximum amount of air the tire should hold and the size of car or load it should carry. The "DOT" stamp that appears on tires is a Department of Transportation certification that the tires conform to the association's standards and have passed its tests for resistance to puncture, endurance, stability and such.
"Every manufacturer makes their tires compatible expressly so consumers can move between Brand A and Brand B and Brand C," said William M. Hopkins, Goodyear's vice president for technical planning.
There have been cases of companies voluntarily recalling tires because the beads were cracking, or for other structural problems. But Marvin Bozarth, executive director of the International Tire and Rubber Association, says the vast majority of the recalls over the last 20 years were of tires that had been inadvertently mislabeled, not tires that had performed badly.
"There are small differences among tires, but there are no big differences," he said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: The Long, Costly Encore

 BODY:
Al Gore has got to be thinking "Get the hook." After all, Los Angeles is a show-business town, and Democrats from across the country are heading there for what is supposed to be Vice President Gore's show. But President and Mrs. Clinton are blatantly hogging the spotlight from Saturday until next Tuesday. As has so often been the case in the Clinton administration, the thirst for campaign money and other donations seems to be overriding both good manners and political prudence. The bottom line is that Mr. Gore does not get to be the star of his own show until it is half over, and by that time the Clintons will have decamped with millions of Democratic dollars.
By comparison, the last baton-passing by a two-term president was a model of grace and consideration. In 1988 Ronald Reagan zipped into New Orleans for 48 hours on a schedule adjusted to his vice president's political needs. Mr. Reagan gave one speech denouncing the Democrats and another asserting that George Bush was ready to lead, made a joint appearance with Mr. Bush at the airport and then winged off toward California. 
 The Clintons are heading for the Golden State too, but for them it is beach party time. A Saturday concert is supposed to raise $4 million for Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign. At Barbra Streisand's place in Malibu on Sunday, Mr. Clinton is expected to pull in $10 million for his presidential library.
It would be hard work to raise that kind of money later on for a facility in Arkansas, and that probably explains the president's willingness to compete with Mr. Gore for time and top billing among wealthy donors at the convention. But the president's insistent star turn misserves Mr. Gore in a way that goes beyond the financial. At this point in the campaign, the vice president needs to be seen as an independent force rather than a second banana who cannot even dictate the schedule of his own convention.
This competition for attention between two supposedly best buddies creates an odd setting for Mr. Clinton's speech to the convention on Monday. Will it be a full-throated campaign speech for Mr. Gore as a leader who deserves to be president in his own right and on his own merits? Or will it be Mr. Clinton's valedictory reminder that he created an economic boom that Mr. Gore is lucky to be running on?
As a historic footnote, it should be noted that Ronald Reagan wanted a third term too. But he didn't use his vice president's convention to remind everyone of that fact.
