HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
A Union-Created Group Attacks Bush on Health Care Issues

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

 BODY:
The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, through a group it created called American Family Voices, has joined the political advertising wars with a 30-second television spot titled "Invest." The advertisement takes George W. Bush to task for several decisions he has made as governor of Texas and tries to link them to large contributions to him and the Republican Party from the insurance, nursing home and drug industries. The slickly produced advertisement does not urge viewers to vote against Mr. Bush or for Vice President Al Gore, but asks them to call Mr. Bush's office or visit the sponsoring group's Web site. 

PRODUCER -- Axelrod & Associates.
ON THE SCREEN -- A hand-held camera pans the confetti-strewn floor of a darkened arena after the Republican convention. The camera pauses at posters that list the size of campaign contributions from various industries to Mr. Bush and Republican committees. The spot closes with text giving the telephone number of Mr. Bush's office in Austin, Tex., and the Web address of American Family Voices.
 
SCRIPT -- "The convention's over," a narrator says. "And look who won. The insurance industry; they've invested millions in George W. Bush, who vetoed a patients' bill of rights in Texas. Nursing home operators; they've given over a hundred thousand to Bush, who weakened nursing home laws in Texas, while patient complaints doubled. The big drug companies; they've kicked in millions for Bush, who joined them in opposing guaranteed Medicare prescription coverage. Tell Bush when special interests win, America's families lose."
 
ACCURACY -- The advertisement gives big numbers for industry contributions to Mr. Bush ($4.3 million from the insurance industry, $2.3 million from drug companies), but they include large soft-money donations to Republican Party committees and smaller donations to the Bush campaign. The advertisement's other assertions are based on newspaper articles and are oversimplified but not false, although Mr. Bush has not opposed Medicare prescription drug coverage but only insisted that the benefit not be fully financed by taxpayers.
 
SCORECARD -- With this spot, the labor movement and liberal interests are putting Mr. Bush and other Republicans on notice that they will conduct an aggressive negative campaign on economic issues this fall. Unions have budgeted millions of dollars for this and similar efforts that will support Democratic candidates around the country. JOHN M. BRODER

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATIC TEAM;
Standing With the Centrists In a Play for the New South

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore surrounded himself with centrist Democratic governors from Southern states today and delivered a stem-winding populist speech in an effort to demonstrate that the South was still in play in this year's election.
Alongside Mr. Gore, a Middle Tennessean and a Southern Baptist, stood his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, a Connecticut Yankee and an Orthodox Jew whose introduction to the South came in 1963 when he helped register black voters in Mississippi. 
 That would not have always been an alluring resume to many of the independent white Southerners whom Mr. Gore and Mr. Lieberman must capture in order to win states like Georgia this year. But the Democrats played up Mr. Lieberman's religion and his history today, calculating that the South had changed, that Mr. Lieberman's selection would excite minority voters, and that the ticket's centrism and religious faith might appeal to white Southerners.
At the rally in Centennial Olympic Park, Mr. Lieberman said he saw "how good our nation can be" when he watched his fellow student volunteers put their lives on the line to register voters in the 1960's.
"Today," Mr. Lieberman said, "I am so proud to stand before you as the first Jewish-American lucky enough to be a major party candidate for vice president of the United States. And when I look at Al Gore, the man who made it possible, and I think about the courage and character that went into making this decision, once again I see a glimpse of how good our nation can be."
The most recent polls, some of which are dated, show Mr. Gore trailing his Republican rival, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, in every Southern state except for his native Tennessee, and the race appears closer than expected there. But Gore campaign officials say Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Florida, North Carolina and Tennessee remain in play.
Republican strategists expressed confidence today that the resurgent appeal of statewide Democratic candidates in the South would not transfer to a national election, and that Mr. Gore would not replicate President Clinton's success in winning four Southern states in 1992 and 1996.
"It's difficult for national Democrats to convince Southern voters that they are similar to the moderate Democratic governors they have elected," said Q. Whitfield Ayres, a Republican pollster here.
Several of the Democratic governors disagreed, saying Mr. Lieberman's selection had been received warmly in their states.
"The values people had when I was growing up -- respect of marriage and family, respect of the Sabbath, that's what they see in Joe Lieberman," said Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina, who is completing his fourth term.
Gov. Roy Barnes of Georgia said the choice helped by demonstrating Mr. Gore's independence. "Look," he said, "we Southerners are not aliens from another planet. Attitudes have changed and the stereotype of the South of 50 years ago is not the South of today. And, remember, populism was born in the South."
Mr. Gore embraced that populist tradition today when he told the crowd he would raise the minimum wage, provide prescription drug benefits for the elderly, lower school class sizes and "take medical decisions away from bureaucrats who work for H.M.O.'s."
"Do you remember what it was like eight years ago?" he asked. Someone in the crowd answered, "Pitiful."
"Pitiful, you are exactly right," Mr. Gore said. "We had $300 billion annual budget deficits. That bunch had quadrupled the national debt in little over a decade. We were broke. High unemployment. We'd had the worst recession since the 1930's. We saw crime rising, families breaking up at a higher rate. All the problems were worse."
Mr. Gore said President Clinton and he had changed things, and reminded his audience that Mr. Bush said in his nomination acceptance speech that the Democrats had "coasted through prosperity" and taken the path of least resistance.
"I wish there had been less resistance," Mr. Gore said. "I cast the tie-breaking vote after all the ones on the other side voted no for the change that was so needed. I wish there had been less resistance when they shut down the government, not once but twice. I wish there had been less resistance when we brought about the changes that have now led to a dramatic transformation in our economy."
Mr. Lieberman said the accusations that the last eight years had been squandered were nonsense, saying, "If you're one of the people working in one of the 22 million jobs that have been created in this country since 1993, these haven't been squandered years."
Mr. Gore was joined today by Governors Donald Siegelman of Alabama and Paul E. Patton of Kentucky, along with Mr. Barnes and Mr. Hunt.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
On the Path to Create a School of Thought

BYLINE: By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
GREGORY JAVAN MILLS is talking about the collection he has spent 20 years assembling: 5,000 films starring black actors or made by black producers and directors. There is "Tamango," with Dorothy Dandridge as a slave who has a love affair with her master. There is "Joe's Bed-Stuy Barbershop: We Cut Heads," an early film by Spike Lee. There is "Harlem Rides the Range," an all-black western from the 1940's.
So what are the prized possessions in Mr. Mills's collection at the New York State Black Film Archive? 
 "I wouldn't call them possessions," he stammers, then begs, "You have to phrase it another way."
He is sitting in a film and video classroom in the Adam Clayton Powell State Office Building on 125th Street in Harlem. A Bell & Howell projector so old that it looks like an antique refrigerator, with a door that flaps open if it is not latched, sits on a coffee table. The machine was built for the military, it turns out. But it is not his prized possession. Finally, Mr. Mills decides that his prized possession is "the ability to steer this organization on the right path."
And there it is: unreconstituted artspeak, or rather, arts administrator-speak, that falls so easily from the tongues of the type of executive director whose job includes running the projector and making the popcorn. Mr. Mills talks as if he is writing a grant, or perhaps has written too many: careful, measured and heavy on what some might call truisms. "There's always room for improvement," he says after being asked if things are better for black artists now than in the 1970's.
At the Harlem Week 2000 Black Film Festival, which ends on Sunday, Mr. Mills is showing films that have not been screened in half a century or more. They are drawn from his archive, which he describes as the largest collection of black films. Mr. Mills's films are stored in the basement of the office building and in other places, including his apartment, the studio in Harlem where he has lived, alone, since he moved to Manhattan in the 1970's. "I'm like Duke Ellington: this is what I do, this is my family. Duke Ellington said, 'Music is my mistress.' "
But collecting movies was an ordeal at first. In the early 1980's, Mr. Mills would set up a table outside the New York Public Library, offering information about his organization. The idea was, once people came up to the table, they would slip some change into the donation jar. He ended up with more than money: he met film collectors from Brooklyn, who provided the reels for the first Black Film Festival, in 1985. The collaboration was, in Mr. Mills's terms, "an opportunity to bring Manhattan and Brooklyn together."
But the collectors did not volunteer to help him build a collection. "I would say, 'How do you get this stuff?' They would say, 'We got the connections.' "
MR. MILLS, 48, did not start off with much of an interest in film, although as a child in Winston-Salem, N.C., he loved Bette Davis. And he remembers overhearing his mother, a public-school dietitian, talk about Dorothy Dandridge's death (in 1965, at 42, of an overdose of prescription drugs). His father worked on cars. "I don't think I wanted to work in the cafeteria or be a mechanic," he says, "so I became an artist."
A painter, to be specific. He spent a few years in the Air Force (his "Peter Max period," he calls it; he painted a psychedelic mural for the noncommissioned officers' club at Ellsworth Air Force Base in South Dakota). Then, thanks to the G.I. Bill, he moved to New York and enrolled at the School of Visual Arts. He still quotes Oscar Wilde and Jimi Hendrix like an ardent student.
Here is something he says the professors did not teach him at the school: in the 1970's, New York galleries would not show "black art," and that included abstract paintings by a black artist, namely, him. Here is something they did teach him there: artists start schools of thought, like Bauhaus, the Ash Can School and Dada. So, at school, he decided to start a "school of thought for artists of color." One of his first projects was to help a fellow student whose photographs of children playing in Harlem had been declared "unaesthetic" at Visual Arts. His letters of protest led the administration to reconsider, and the student got the degree that had been hanging in the balance. A panel discussion on race and the arts, the first of many, followed.
In the early 80's, Mr. Mills saw a public television segment on Oscar Micheaux, who made films in the early 20's and 30's about black life and who was nicknamed the Midnight Rambler because he often rented white movie theaters after midnight to show his films. Mr. Mills knew nothing about the man.
That's the way of things. Know nothing, start a film festival. Fortunately, Mr. Mills and Ernest Steele, who became the archivist, found -- without the help of the Brooklyn collectors -- the Donnell Library Center in Midtown Manhattan, which houses the city's film archives. They spent days researching distributors and collectors and building a network of people who would alert them when rare prints came on the market.
In the 1980's, worried that the recession was hurting support of the arts in Harlem, he considered quitting. "I thought, 'Let's have an auction, sell off everything, everyone go back to their first love.' " Then another grant came through, and changed his mind.

HEADLINE: In the Oil-Rich Nigeria Delta, Deep Poverty and Grim Fires

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

DATELINE: OVIRI-COURT, Nigeria, Aug. 6

 BODY:
As the rain clattered on his aluminum roof, Akierou Awe sat in a gloomy corner of his mud-brick house and spoke softly of the fuel-pipeline explosion that killed three of his sons last month, not far from his village in this oil-soaked corner of Africa.
Fuel had been leaking from the pipeline at a spot deep in the bush, near a forest of rubber trees. Villagers had been scooping it up with jerrycans, washbasins and plastic bottles that they carried away in wheelbarrows, hoping to resell it for a few pennies above the official rate of 21 cents a quart. 
 Then perhaps a wheelbarrow knocked against another, causing a spark.
The explosion shook Mr. Awe's house early on the morning of July 10. The fire spread along a mile-long stretch of the pipeline, killing more than 300 people, including his sons Kingsley, 23; Tuesday, 22, and Gift, 20, all of whom tapped rubber trees for a living.
"Even as you see me now, I am no longer a full human being," Mr. Awe, 65, a retired civil servant, said, so softly that the rain nearly drowned out his words. "Gift attended secondary school and he was supposed to finish this year." A fourth son, Hope, 20, had been with his brothers but was not killed. Hope was still in the hospital, but his father did not know whether he would survive.
The Niger Delta of Nigeria, one of the world's top oil producers, has been the center of violent despair for years. A swampy patch of land, laced by tributaries of West Africa's great Niger River, it yields almost all of Nigeria's two million barrels a day of crude, most of which ends up at gas stations in the United States.
But because of this country's complicated history of ethnic politics, delta residents have remained stunningly and desperately poor. The residents are members of ethnic minorities; partly out of fear that Nigeria might break up one day, the Hausa-speaking northern generals who have ruled most of the time since independence have kept the oil-rich delta poor and weak.
And recently, in gruesome displays of that poverty, hundreds have been burned to death in at least five explosions as they tried to scoop up leaking fuel.
Perhaps more than any other country on the continent, Nigeria -- where one in six Africans live -- has focused attention on the problematic role of natural resources, which have enriched the African elite and Western businesses but slowed development.
Nigeria is the nightmare that loomed before World Bank officials who recently approved a $3.7 billion oil pipeline for Chad; it is a warning for tiny Equatorial Guinea, where oil started gushing four years ago.
Pipelines have exploded in many poor nations. The biggest explosions since the early 1980's occurred in 1984 in Brazil, where 508 were killed; in 1994 in Egypt, where there were 529 deaths; and in 1998 in Cameroon, where at 220 died.
But Nigeria leads by a wide margin: in the last two years, official figures indicate, more than 2,000 women, men and children have died in pipeline explosions. Many believe that the real figure is even higher.
What is more, while explosions elsewhere result from accidents, here the source is sabotage. Organized rings of thieves with knowledge of the pipelines, allied with corrupt government and military officials, are believed to siphon huge quantities of fuel with sophisticated equipment and trucks.
The leaks eventually attract jerrycan-grasping villagers, invariably the ones who end up being killed.
"Because of the level of grinding poverty in the Niger Delta, when there are these leaks, people see it as an opportunity to make some money despite the dangers," said Doifie Ola, director of Environmental Rights Action, a Lagos-based organization that monitors explosions. "Similar incidents are likely to keep recurring if nothing concrete is done."
Immediately after assuming power in May 1999, President Olusegun Obasanjo visited the delta. He raised great hopes among its seven million inhabitants, but little has been accomplished. A Niger Delta development bill has yet to become law.
In fact the most notable government action was the military's destruction of a town called Odi last November after residents killed 12 police officers. President Obasanjo later expressed regret for the attack on Odi, which many see as the single most startling violation of human rights during his term.
Port Harcourt, one of the two oil centers in the delta, had tentatively been on the itinerary of President Clinton, who is to visit Nigeria this month. But it is now unlikely he will come to the delta; he will very likely spend most of his visit in the capital, Abuja.
The delta is growing increasingly restive. Early this month, youths held hostage 165 workers associated with Shell, the biggest oil exporter, eventually releasing them. And vandalism of oil pipelines has risen sharply.
The targets are usually not the multinationals' pipelines, which carry crude oil for export, but lines connected to government-owned refineries that process crude in the delta and ship easy-to-resell gasoline or kerosene through a 3,250-mile network crisscrossing Nigeria.
The country's four oil refineries have long been the source of corruption: Gen. Sani Abacha, the former dictator, allowed them to deteriorate so severely that Nigeria found itself in the absurd position of importing gasoline -- through the general's middlemen -- from non-oil-producing nations.
Since General Abacha's death in June 1998, the refineries have been repaired, making the delivery network the target of thieves who siphon out fuel.
Some results have been grim. In October 1998, 1,082 people were killed, by official tally, in a huge explosion in Jesse, not far from here. A pipeline connected to a refinery in Warri, the second oil center of the delta, was punctured.
In 1999 government pipelines were sabotaged 497 times, according the state-run Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, which owns and operates the pipeline network. In the first three months of this year, the number had already reached 200.
In the first five months, $20 million was lost in stolen fuel and damage done to pipelines, the petroleum corporation estimates.
The state-run corporation fired some of its workers after villagers reported their involvement in the siphoning: they had employed soldiers to guard tankers that were driven along the pipelines to collect the fuel.
Jackson Gaius-Obaseki, managing director of the oil corporation, acknowledged the collusion at a news conference in Warri after visiting victims of the latest explosion, and said more dismissals were planned.
At another news conference, a corporation spokesman, Ndu Ughamadu, said that although villagers had been scooping up the fuel, they could not have been the ones to puncture it.
"Our engineers have told us that vandalization of oil pipelines takes a scientific process which ordinary villagers can't engage in," he said. "There must be well-placed people that have links with this pipeline vandalization. Where they have located a pipeline, they will perforate holes and quietly they will lay pipelines for up to one kilometer, where they siphon the fuel at will."
To reach the pipeline from here in Oviri-Court, one must quit a dirt road and hike a half-mile into the bush. Wooden planks remain on the muddy stretches to allow access to vehicles -- evidence, villagers said, that an organized ring had come here with a truck and equipment. A big hole had been dug, exposing the pipeline, which now lay underwater.
The explosion charred the trees in the area; their leafless black skeletons rise out of darkened water. The 300 bodies have been carried away. But the tools of the dead lay scattered around: washbasins, countless plastic bottles, jerrycans, a scorched bicycle, two wheelbarrows.
Adeje, a nearby village with no electricity, no tap water and no paved road, is typical of the Niger Delta -- in fact better off than villages accessible only by boat.
Timothy Oghoro, a community leader in his 70's, was one of many villagers who said they had reported the leaking pipeline to the local authorities.
But nothing had been done, Mr. Oghoro said, because the vandals were well connected and had siphoned the fuel under military escort.
"The police are not here to protect us," Mr. Oghoro said. "If the government wanted to protect us, they would employ people to man the pipeline. No one will go there."
Another local leader, David Okomore, 45, said he and the village chief, Benson Egberebo, 65, once videotaped a leaking pipeline.
"The soldiers pounced on us," he said. "The chief was taken to the police station and interrogated."
Mr. Okomore, one of the few college-educated men in the village, said two of his cousins, women aged 50 and 19, had been killed in the explosion. He had to identify their bodies, which were buried in a mass grave. "Because they were poor and uneducated," he said, "they were scooping the fuel."
Mr. Okomore foresees repercussions beyond the deaths: "Because of the explosion and the destruction, the farms we have won't produce anymore -- even the river has been polluted. There will be even less for the people to do here."
Surely, he added, the destruction will make more people hopeless. More will scoop for fuel. He is not counting on the government.
"When we ask for compensation," he said, "they harass us with soldiers. There's nothing we can do. We only live by the mercy of God now."

SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 641 words

HEADLINE: A Trap of Welfare And Child Abuse

BYLINE: By Patrick T. Murphy; Patrick T. Murphy, public guardian of Cook County, Illinois, is author of "Drowning in Hot Water," a novel.

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
I have represented abused and neglected children in court for decades, and, like many others in close contact with the child welfare system, I never bought the predictions that welfare reform would send more parents into the pathology of abuse. I thought the opposite, because I expected the birth rate for teenagers on welfare to go down once the system stopped encouraging births. That would mean fewer families under intense stress. 
 So when statistics reported this week showed that child abuse cases have gone down nationwide since the new welfare law was passed in 1996, I was surprised only at how quickly the decline had showed itself.
In Chicago, the number of abused and neglected children in the system has fallen by nearly half in the years since the old safety net was removed. A major reason is that there are fewer new cases of abuse. In New York, too, cases are decreasing, not increasing.
In the same years, birth rates for both white and African-American teenagers have also dropped substantially. Certainly, welfare reform is not the complete reason. A thriving economy has to have played a role in giving people an incentive to break old patterns, as has education reinforcing a deliberate message about irresponsible teenage behavior. Though I can't prove it, I believe welfare reform is just as important an ingredient.
Opponents of welfare reform ridiculed the notion that children were having children in order to get welfare. In the most literal sense, they were right. But children having children had become part of the culture surrounding many girls whose families were on welfare, and government support had allowed it to flourish. The girls having the babies were not equipped to see the consequences in their own lives or their children's.
A typical abuse case that I see now involves a woman in her early 20's who has between two and four children, usually by different fathers. She had her first child when she should have been reading "Macbeth" as a sophomore in high school and her second when she should have been reading "Hamlet" as a senior. The fathers have shirked all responsibility and disappeared. By the time the woman is in her 20's, she has four children and no involved man to help her. She turns to drugs as the only viable opportunity for a vacation. Or, as some argue, for self-medication.
We bring her to court on abuse charges, give her a counselor and ultimately return the children, whereupon she goes back to her bleak housing project, looks out the window and realizes that without an education and job opportunities, her future, and that of her children, is nonexistent. Her depression is based on reality. She ultimately turns back to drugs or liquor or both, and the children are abused or neglected again.
These cases began when our welfare system was still sending out an illusory promise to inexperienced girls that they and their children would be supported for the rest of their lives. The truth was that the support was absolutely minimal and could never be more than minimal.
A couple of years ago, one of our lawyers picked up a 14-year-old inner-city girl who had just delivered a baby at a Chicago hospital. On the way out, a social worker warned the girl that the next time she had a child, she should be more serious about prenatal care. Today, the girl would more likely have been warned that having children mortgaged her future and told about ways of controlling her fertility, from abstinence to abortion.
Has welfare reform worked? It's probably too early to tell. But the social worker's dismissive assumption about an inner-city girl's needs would not be so easy now. Nor could the girl so easily accept repeated early motherhood. I believe this fundamental change will translate into even fewer abused children needing my help a few years from now.

HEADLINE: Retail Plan for Armory Upsets School Advocates

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
A City Hall plan to rebuild the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx as a retail complex drew more than 200 protesters to the huge, fortress-like building yesterday, where they called for new school rooms instead of chain stores on the site.
Criticism of the City Hall proposal is growing from members of the Bronx clergy and the city's Democratic coalition in Congress, who say it ignores both a drastic need for classroom space in the northwest Bronx and the availability of federal school construction aid to provide it. 
 "The mayor would do well to listen to this community," said Representative Eliot L. Engel, the Bronx Democrat, who attended the rally. In an interview, he said the new retail complex proposed by City Hall "is the worst thing they could put here."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced the city's plan for the Kingsbridge Armory, a decrepit, 80-year-old structure that fills an entire block off Kingsbridge Road and Jerome Avenue, in his State of the City address in January.
Under the plan, $30 million in city financing has been set aside to repair the armory's massive roof, which engineers say could collapse. The city selected RD Management, a shopping mall developer based in Manhattan, to spend $80 million or more to renovate the rest of the building for use as a recreational complex, a multiplex and at least one chain store.
But almost a year before the mayor's announcement, the Northwest Bronx Community & Clergy Coalition, a neighborhood group that has long advocated housing and youth programs in the neighborhoods surrounding the armory site, approached the mayor's staff with a plan to devote at least part of it to public classrooms.
The group said it spent $50,000, using grants from foundations, to prepare architectural drawings showing how the armory could house 1,800 classroom seats, to be used by two or three public schools. It estimated the cost at $110 million.
"The need for classroom space is tremendous, and if we miss this opportunity it gets worse," said Ronn Jordon, a member of the Bronx group. District 10 in the Bronx is the third most crowded in the city, according to Board of Education records.
The Bronx group also approached City Hall with a suggestion for financing the project in part: a federal school construction program sponsored in 1998 by Representative Charles B. Rangel that would make as much as $60 million a year available to New York State to build schools in poor neighborhoods where businesses or private donors agree to pick up part of the cost.
"Armories are a gift, since we have to take advantage of existing structures," Mr. Rangel said. "It is so sad the mayor has blinders on."
But Michael Carey, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said the city had already given ample consideration to the proposal for schools at the armory site, and rejected the idea.
"It will take a tremendous amount of money to maintain this building," he said, "and its best custodian for the future is the private sector."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE LABOR EFFORT;
Finding Another Loophole, a New Secretive Group Springs Up

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Turning to a second legal loophole after another was closed, one of the nation's largest unions, a leading supporter of Vice President Al Gore, has quietly created a group that this week is televising an advertisement harshly critical of Gov. George W. Bush.
Neither the group's ad nor its Web site (www.checkforyourself.com) discloses its relationship with the union, the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, or Afscme. 
 Afscme provided $800,000 to start the organization, American Family Voices. In a news release and on its Web site, the group describes its mission as advocacy of "progressive policies, especially economic issues." It says its membership includes advocates for consumers, health care, education, children, the elderly, civil rights and labor.
The organization was created in July, after Congress closed a loophole in federal tax and election law known as Section 527, under which groups were able, with virtually no disclosure, to raise and spend unlimited sums to spread political messages. American Family Voices was instead chartered under Section 501(c)4, a longstanding provision in the tax code that allows it to engage in political activity with minimal financial disclosure.
Afscme, which has 1.3 million members, endorsed Vice President Gore last autumn, months before he sealed the Democratic presidential nomination.
The executive director of American Family Voices is Michael Lux, a longtime liberal campaigner who worked for two years in the Clinton White House and has been affiliated with People for the American Way.
The new effort makes organized labor the latest of a number of interests, as varied as the Sierra Club and the pharmaceutical industry, to set up independent groups to underwrite political advertising and other election-related activities.
Under its Section 501(c)4 tax status, American Family Voices is permitted to engage in political activities like polling, lobbying and issue advertising but is not permitted to advocate the election or defeat of individual candidates. Such groups must file public information returns with the Internal Revenue Service but are not required to disclose the sources of their income.
They are reminiscent of secretive groups set up under Section 527. Sam Wyly, for instance, a wealthy benefactor of Mr. Bush, created a group called Republicans for Clean Air that ran television advertisements during the primaries attacking the environmental record of the Texas governor's chief rival, Senator John McCain of Arizona.
In June, Congress passed legislation requiring Section 527 groups to disclose their major contributors and spending. American Family Voices was created after the legislation took effect on July 1, Mr. Lux said. As a result, it could not take advantage of the Section 527 nondisclosure loophole and will instead operate under the minimal-disclosure requirements of Section 501(c)4.
Mr. Lux said he had raised $700,000 in addition to the sum provided by Afscme and intended to use the money this fall to buy issue advertising in the presidential campaign and selected Congressional races. He declined to identify the group's other contributors, saying only that they were organizations and individuals who shared the union's policy agenda for working people.
The advertisement against Governor Bush, which is running this week in Philadelphia, Detroit, St. Louis and Washington, attacks him for vetoing patients' rights legislation, weakening nursing home regulations and opposing government-guaranteed prescription drug benefits under Medicare. It links his policies to large contributions from the insurance, nursing home and drug industries.
Afscme's president, Gerald McEntee, said in an interview that American Family Voices was one of a number of independent political efforts that the union would undertake this fall on issues of importance to working families, including health care, education, the environment and taxes.
Fred Wertheimer, an advocate of revisions in federal campaign law, said the union's hidden sponsorship of American Family Voices dramatized a longstanding problem in American politics.
"Closing the Section 527 secrecy loophole just solved one of the problems," Mr. Wertheimer said. "This is another example of interests' conducting blatant electioneering activities and hiding their donors. And it's a huge problem. This conduct is an evasion of the spirit of disclosure laws and will be a growing problem that will have to be solved just like the Section 527 groups were."

HEADLINE: U.S. Child Poverty Rate Fell as Economy Grew, But Is Above 1979 Level

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Child poverty rates fell significantly in many states in the current economic boom, but nationwide, and in all but a handful of states, child poverty is still higher than it was 20 years ago, according to a study released today by the National Center for Children in Poverty at Columbia University.
More than 13 million American children, 3 million more than in 1979, live in poverty. 
 Here in California, where 1 out of 6 of the nation's poor children live, child poverty has been particularly stubborn. According to the study, the child poverty rate soared by 90 percent from 1979 to 1993 as the Golden State was badly tarnished by recession, and declined only 14.9 percent in the next five years of economic growth.
The recent decline in California was encouraging but still lagged behind the rest of the nation, which saw a 17.1 percent decline after a 38.8 percent increase from 1979 to 1993.
Nationally, according to census data, the child poverty rate rose to 18.7 percent in 1998, the most current information available, from 16.2 percent in 1979. In New York, the rate is 24.2 percent, or nearly 1 in 4 children living in poverty, up from 18.9 percent in 1979.
Elected officials and advocates for children across the country cited low wages and high living costs as primary factors in the persistence of child poverty.
Deborah Leff, president and chief executive officer of America's Second Harvest, the nation's largest domestic hunger relief organization, said a family earning the minimum wage was "literally earning thousands of dollars under the poverty line," which in 1998 was $16,666 for a family of four and today is $17,050.
"You can get off welfare, work hard, play by the rules and still not be able to feed your family," Ms. Leff said.
Elie Ward, the executive director of Statewide Youth Advocacy, said poverty rates in New York had often been worse than the national ones because of the high cost of living that low-income workers face in New York City.
Gail Nayowith, executive director of the Citizens' Committee for Children of New York, said the level of child poverty in New York was affected by the city's many immigrants, who often work for very low wages and have large families.
The report does not say why some states, like Illinois and New Jersey, have seen significant reductions in child poverty rates since 1979, and others have seen increases or relatively minor declines.
Whether welfare reform has had any effect on child poverty rates is also unclear, said Julian Palmer, a spokesman for the children's poverty center.
But Robert Goerge, assistant director of the Chapin Center for Children at the University of Chicago, said Illinois' early welfare overhaul, with generous benefits, which began in 1993, helped explain why the state's children had risen out of poverty.
That program, for instance, allowed welfare recipients to continue receiving health benefits and food stamps while easing into full-time employment, long before other states allowed such a benefit.
"You can make more money and not get penalized," Mr. Goerge said.
Jacqueline Tencza, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Department of Human Services, said her state had used savings from cuts in welfare payments to help people who get off welfare.
For instance, Ms. Tencza said, $100 million that had previously been spent on welfare checks was shifted to subsidies for child care.
At $125 to $150 a week, child care often accounts for at least 40 percent of the take-home pay of a former welfare mother who has just joined the work force, Ms. Tencza said.
But in Georgia, where welfare caseloads have been reduced by more than half since 1997, the number of children in poverty rose more than 29 percent from 1993 to 1998, according to the study.
"I don't think anyone ever believed that the immediate result of welfare reform would be the reduction of poverty," said Michael L. Thurmond, commissioner of the Georgia Department of Labor and the architect of the state's welfare reform plan.
Poverty can take generations to overcome, Mr. Thurmond said.
In Los Angeles, poverty has dogged Zena Garcia and her children for years. But this year was going to be different. This year Mrs. Garcia was going to do something special for her son James's 12th birthday next Thursday. Maybe she would take him to the zoo or buy him one of those foldable scooters every child seems to zip by on. This year was going to be different because her husband, Manuel, 36, had a job.
"My husband is working as hard as he can, but it's still not enough to pay the bills," Mrs. Garcia, 43, said here the other day. "I haven't been able to pay the phone bill in two months, and they're about to cut it off. And on Friday, I have to make a choice: pay the gas bill or buy shoes for my daughter."
Her daughter, Virginia, is 6 and will start first grade in the fall. Mrs. Garcia knows what her choice will be. She is going to buy her daughter a pair of shoes. If the gas is shut off as a result, she said, "we'll deal with it."
"I want the same thing for my kids that every parent wants," she said.
Mr. Garcia works as a cook's assistant in a hospital, but has no steady hours and no benefits. He brings home $399 to $500 every two weeks. He has repeatedly applied for part-time or full-time status, which would provide crucial benefits.
"We're waiting and praying that it happens," Mrs. Garcia said.
Both Garcias, who were born in this country, completed a job training program in nearby Santa Monica at the St. Joseph Center, an organization that helps poor families. But so far Mrs. Garcia has not been able to find work and has returned to school to earn a high school equivalency diploma. As their case worker, Lupe Rojo, said, the Garcias are doing all they can to make it.
"It gets depressing," Mrs. Garcia said.
Her son lives in a home for troubled children. Mrs. Garcia talks to him every other day on the telephone, and that is why her phone bill is so high. She has not had the heart to tell him that he cannot go to the zoo or have a scooter.
"It's going to hurt," she said. "It's going to hurt me."
Her daughter has been pestering her about a scooter of her own. But seeing her mother near tears the other day, Virginia put a hand on Mrs. Garcia's shoulder and said, "Only get one, because I'll share mine with James."

HEADLINE: Crusading for Consumers All Around the Town

BYLINE: By EUN LEE KOH 

 BODY:
The boisterous cries on behalf of New York City's lowly consumers were heard from the Bronx to the Battery yesterday.
From the steps of City Hall to outside Madison Square Garden, city officials at separate news conferences championed consumer rights, wagging fingers at businesses that defraud or dupe their customers. 
 For the city's public advocate, Mark Green, the targets were the city's top three energy suppliers, which he accused of anticompetitive practices. For Assemblyman Jeffrey Klein of the Bronx, the cause was unsanitary supermarkets: he wants Gov. George E. Pataki to sign a bill that would make it easier for the state to shut down food stores that have failed inspections.
At Evergreen Videos, a small family-owned video store in Greenwich Village, the city's consumer affairs commissioner, Jane S. Hoffman, released a survey on the average price of a movie rental in the city. Ms. Hoffman said she chose the location because the store had one of the lowest rental prices in Manhattan.
And not to be outdone, the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, denounced the rising cost of entertainment, from movies to sports tickets. He singled out the Knicks, whose games can cost as much as $220 per person.
For the individual officials, it was business as usual, but for all of them to jump on the consumer-protection trolley on the same day?
"People say consumers need a voice -- hey, they had plenty today," said Steve Sigmund, a spokesman for Mr. Green.
Spokesmen for the officials said the sudden convergence of consumer advocacy was sheer coincidence.
"We didn't plan any of this to happen all at once," said Michael Schlank, a spokesman for Mr. Klein. "I guess we're all just concerned about the welfare of the people in this city."
Mr. Schlank said that the assemblyman had no choice but to schedule his news conference yesterday, because Mr. Klein planned to fly to Los Angeles this weekend for the Democratic National Convention.
But in hushed tones, some spokesmen for the officials said there were other reasons for the sudden surge in consumer interests.
"It's the summer, and news is slow," a spokeswoman said. "Friday's generally a bad day to break news because no one reads the Saturday papers, so Thursday it was. And consumer advocacy always gets everyone's wheels turning."
Regardless, the city officials put on their sternest faces and said "tsk, tsk" to consumer-unfriendly industries.
Mr. Vallone took up the cause of the average New Yorker who simply wants to see a movie or a basketball game.
"New York is becoming so expensive that many families can't afford to go to the movies or even out for ice cream," Mr. Vallone said. "It is unacceptable that during this economic boom, basic entertainment is beyond the reach of working people."
With furrowed brow, Mr. Klein released a list of what he called the city's 10 worst supermarkets, some of which he said had sold contaminated foods that included rat droppings.
Ms. Hoffman held up a copy of "Casablanca" as she told New Yorkers that renting a movie should not be "risky business." She warned New Yorkers to look out for unusually high late fees or exorbitant membership costs.
At City Hall, Mr. Green said that deregulation of energy suppliers had driven up costs for consumers.
"Because there is excessive demand and inadequate supply, deregulation has forced consumers and businesses to end up paying millions of extra dollars for power this summer," he said.

HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
BRONX: COCAINE SEIZED -- Federal agents yesterday announced the seizure of nearly 670 kilograms of cocaine in the Bronx on Saturday. They said that agents from the Drug Enforcement Administration and New York City police officers arrested three men and charged them with drug trafficking after searching a van and finding 50 kilograms of cocaine. The other 619 kilograms were discovered during a search of a nearby apartment. John Sullivan (NYT) 

MANHATTAN: VIRUS RESEARCH FINANCING CRITICIZED -- In a letter to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Senator Charles E. Schumer has complained that New York is not getting enough money to track the West Nile virus. He said that this year, the centers would distribute about $6.9 million nationwide for such monitoring, but that New York's share would be only $720,000, or about one-tenth of the total. The Centers for Disease Control did not return a phone call seeking comment yesterday. Meanwhile, the Suffolk County health commissioner, Clare B. Bradley, said that it was likely that "West Nile virus is present throughout Suffolk County." (AP)
 
MANHATTAN: MAN BEATEN AT HOME -- A man was badly beaten by a burglar at his home yesterday, the police said. The man's wife returned to their West 81st Street apartment at 6:50 p.m. and found her husband, Jack Kravitz, 57, beaten in the head and face, an investigator said. The attack is not thought to be linked to seven other violent burglaries on the Upper West Side, said Detective John Giammarino, a police spokesman. Mr. Kravitz was in critical condition at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. Andy Newman (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: WOMAN TELLS OF TRAIN ACCIDENT -- A woman who was thought to have jumped in front of a train that tore off her leg on July 31 has recovered consciousness and on Monday told detectives she was pushed onto the tracks by a robber, said Detective John Giammarino, a police spokesman. The woman, Buo Yu You, 55, of Delancey Street was hit by a J train at the Bowery station. Ms. You, who also suffered head injuries, was in stable condition at Bellevue Hospital Center last night, the authorities said. Andy Newman (NYT)
 
YAPHANK: ORGANIC GOLF COURSES -- Suffolk County has agreed to build two 18-hole public golf courses here without using pesticides. Robert L. Garfinkle, an assistant county attorney, said the courses would be among the first in the country to use organic methods from their inception. The action stems from a lawsuit brought by the Long Island Neighborhood Network of Massapequa, which said the original plans for the golf courses, which are to be built on public land, failed to comply with state environmental law. John Rather (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: MANY CASES, ONE TRIAL -- A judge ruled yesterday that she would hold one trial for a Manhattan man, Arohn Kee, charged with three murders and four rapes in Harlem, despite protests by the man's lawyers that he would not get a fair trial because of the complexity and volume of evidence. Justice Joan Sudolnik of State Supreme Court in Manhattan said asking witnesses to testify in four trials would be too much. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)
 
WHITE PLAINS: UNEMPLOYMENT BENEFITS SCHEME -- In the latest crackdown effort on those who illegally claim unemployment benefits, the Westchester County district attorney has accused 22 Westchester residents who have jobs of stealing a combined $78,000 in benefits from the State Labor Department. Each defendant faces up to four years in prison. The defendants allegedly collected benefits ranging from $1,711 to $9,490 between June 1997 and January of this year, said Jeanine F. Pirro, the district attorney. Al Baker (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: CHILDREN'S INSURANCE -- New York is among the states with the most success in enrolling children in the federal Children's Health Insurance Program, according to a new report from the Children's Defense Fund. With 453,000 enrollments in the government insurance program, New York is in fourth place, behind Alaska, Massachusetts and Maryland, the report found. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: NEW CHIEF FOR CABRINI HOSPITAL -- Paul J. Candino has been named president and chief executive of Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan, succeeding Jeffrey Frerichs, who resigned in July. Mr. Candino will continue as president and chief executive of Prism Network Inc., a corporation that specializes in developing health care systems for insurance companies. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)
 
BROOKLYN: CHARGES IN BANK ROBBERIES -- Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn charged 13 men yesterday with being part of a mob-connected robbery ring that broke into nearly 30 banks from Long Island to Florida between 1992 and 1999, stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars from vaults and deposit boxes. One man, George Ludwigsen of Boca Raton, Fla., is the younger brother of Chris Paciello, a Miami nightclub owner who is to go on trial next month on charges of bank robbery and murder. Alan Feuer (NYT)
 
CONNECTICUT
 
HARTFORD: DELAY URGED FOR TRIBAL RECOGNITION -- After two days of talks in Washington about the federal government's plan to recognize two Connecticut Indian tribes, the state attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, has urged the Interior Department to postpone its decision. Numerous questions remain about the tribe's claims, Mr. Blumenthal said. The Interior Department research used to determine whether the tribes, the Eastern Pequots and the Paucatuck Eastern Pequots, deserve formal recognition is flawed, he asserted. Tribal recognition carries several benefits, including potential casino ventures. The Bureau of Indian Affairs did not return a phone call seeking comment. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)
 
NEW JERSEY
 
TRENTON: UTILITY BILLS FOR THE POOR -- A group called New Jersey Citizen Action wants state regulators to allow utilities to charge low-income customers a fixed percentage of their income when they pay their utility bills. Poor people typically must devote 10 to 13 percent of their income to utilities, leading to more than 100,000 disconnections because of unpaid bills, the group said. Under the plan, low-income customers would pay 3 percent of their income. In return, the utilities would get some money instead of none and would keep families from using potentially dangerous alternatives like kerosene lamps. (NYT)

HEADLINE: Anarchism's Appeal

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Anarchism, the Creed That Won't Stay Dead" (Arts & Ideas pages, Aug. 5): 
 I applaud the anarchists' inclination to reject established political, economic and social order. The Republican Party's current slogan, "compassionate conservatism," is oxymoronic. The Democrats' claim to be the party of inclusion and diversity is often undermined by their choice of nominees for high office (Joseph I. Lieberman notwithstanding). And transnational institutions like the World Trade Organization seek to impose selfish economic standards without regard for the human costs.
But I draw the line at the neo-Luddite aversion to technological progress. Informed by creative, humanitarian ideals, technology can foster social justice. It is only when technology is left to global-business buccaneers and their fellow travelers that it becomes a tool for rapacious acquisition, consumption and other forms of self-indulgence.
 
STEVEN S. BERIZZI
Hartford, Aug. 11, 2000

HEADLINE: Seeking Out a Just Way To Make Amends for Slavery;
The Idea of Reparations for Blacks Is Gaining in Urgency, But a Knot of Questions Remain, Like: Which Blacks?

BYLINE: By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
In recent years the issue of reparations has exploded among nations wrestling with the past. Scholars are beginning to see the German payout of $60 billion to Jewish victims of the Holocaust, the United States decision to pay reparations to Japanese-Americans who were interned during World War II and even Japan's awkward efforts to settle with Korean "comfort women" as bedrocks of a new political landscape.
Elazar Barkan, the chairman of the cultural studies department at Claremont Graduate University in California, contends that since the end of the cold war, the West in particular has entered a neo-Enlightenment period of political morality in which restitution increasingly plays a leading role. Political language has shifted, he writes in "The Guilt of Nations"(W.W. Norton), from machtpolitik, the politics of power, to a shared belief among nations in the rights of individuals and groups. 
 Consent and cooperation have become the buzzwords of global relations, Mr. Barkan says, and agreement is now being achieved through negotiation rather than force. "Certainly the eagerness of leaders -- Clinton, Blair, Chirac, the pope -- to atone has been mocked," he said during a telephone interview. "But there is a growing sense that you have to do the right thing."
In this new era, Mr. Barkan and others argue, the issue of American reparations for slavery -- straitjacketed for decades in a kind of intellectual Bedlam -- is beginning to look sane. "For so long it was just ludicrous for black folk to even bring up the notion that they might be entitled to some just compensation," said Michael Eric Dyson, the Ida B. Wells Barnett professor of religious studies at De Paul University in Chicago. "It was simply crazy." But after so many successful reparations campaigns, including those for economic and cultural restitution to various American Indian tribes, the African-American case has gained momentum.
Every year since 1989, Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, has sponsored a bill to establish a commission to study reparations for slavery. It remains stuck in committee, but away from Capitol Hill other developments are having a significant impact on the national debate.
Black intellectuals like Randall Robinson, the president of TransAfrica, a lobbying group, and the author of "The Debt: What America Owes to Blacks," and the Harvard University professors Charles T. Ogletree and Henry Louis Gates Jr. have publicly supported reparations. Individual cities and towns are confronting their racist pasts: some, like Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland and Dallas, support Federal hearings on reparations while others, like Tulsa, Okla., Rosewood, Fla., and Elaine, Ark., are either considering or are paying monetary damages for past atrocities. As Mr. Dyson explains, "African-Americans themselves are beginning to be politicized around this debate."
Mr. Barkan writes that slavery remains "the most glaring example of an unaddressed historical injustice in the United States." He adds that this "stands in direct contrast with the public culture that embraces the concept of attempting to redress its imperfect past."
But opponents of reparations commonly argue that other examples of past imperfection are redressable in ways that slavery is not. In the case of the Japanese-Americans, the victims themselves were compensated for quantifiable, provable suffering at the hands of an identifiable perpetrator, the United States Government. With the descendants of slaves, this argument goes, the situation is entirely different.
It is, first of all, said to be impossible to determine the actual present-day effect of slavery -- to trace the impact of slavery on, for example, today's overwhelming incarceration rate among black males, or to calculate all those generations of lost or artificially depressed wages. Not to mention the quagmire of determining who should be compensated. All blacks? Only those who demonstrate direct linkage to a slave? Should those of mixed race be included? Or what about Oprah?
Supporters of reparations find this line of argument irrelevant. "The way I look at historical crimes or historical injustices is do the victims still suffer, whether it is the victim or the victim's descendants," Mr. Barkan says. "Another issue that's been raised is, 'Why should I pay for it, I didn't do it?' It is a foolish argument. No one is responsible personally for any wrongdoing. But just to stop the action doesn't mean to have paid for the past. The perpetrator is very clear. It's the identity of the U.S. The U.S. as an entity is responsible."
Scott L. Malcomson, the author of the forthcoming "One Drop of Blood: The American Misadventure of Race" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux) points out that whites have been distancing themselves from moral culpability for slavery since as far back as the Revolutionary period. Thomas Jefferson, for instance, argued that it was the British who were to blame. Even so, many abolitionists at the time supported their own form of reparations: the establishment of a colony in Africa for freed slaves.
Although Mr. Barkan writes in "The Guilt of Nations" that national identity is a result of history, "for better and for worse," and therefore we "should pay our historical debts," Wendy Kaminer, a fellow at the Radcliffe Public Policy Center, recently argued the opposite point. Writing in American Prospect magazine, she said that the campaign for reparations "reflects some of the premises of the aristocracy it attacks." She continued: "It allows the past to define our entitlements in the present; it relies on a belief in the justice of inheritance. . . . If equality is a birthright, you don't have to purchase it with the sufferings of your ancestors, any more than you should be able to purchase privileges with your ancestors' achievements."
Indeed, just how the past should be used is at the crux of the debate. Ian Buruma, who has written extensively about the legacies of World War II, contends that the quest for reparations tends to mire the petitioners in the very victimization for which they seek payment, as well as encouraging a never-ending flood of restitution-seekers. "If every group that feels a historical wrong wants compensation, how far back do you go?" he asked in an interview. "It becomes problematic."
As ethnic groups in the United States and elsewhere have assimilated, Mr. Buruma went on, they have tended to replace their cultural identities with the residue of past discrimination. This leads, in his view, to resentment, which undermines the possibility of mutual understanding between groups.
"Instead of identifying as an American entitled to freedoms and rights and all men created equal," he said of African-Americans seeking reparations, "you are born into an aggrieved group deserving compensation. Then that's your whole identity and you can never get out of it."
For some, the argument against reparations is simply that any kind of compensation would be wholly inappropriate and inadequate recompense, not just for slavery but also for the entire array of racial injustices that trailed in slavery's wake. As the sociologist Glenn C. Loury wrote recently in The New York Times: "Who can say what the out-of-wedlock birth rate for blacks would be, absent chattel slavery? How does one calculate the cost of inner-city ghettos, of poor education, of the stigma of perceived racial inferiority? The severity of slavery's 'injury' is far more profound than any cash transfer will be able to reverse."
But for proponents, the word reparations can cover a host of interventions, from cash payments -- the current equivalent of, say, 40 acres and a mule -- to a direct, official apology from the President. Some argue that affirmative action policies already in place should be considered sufficient, though Mr. Barkan responds that affirmative action aims at fixing present injustices rather than compensating for past ones.
Mr. Robinson and Mr. Ogletree, among others, have suggested that reparations be used to finance social and economic development programs for the benefit of all black Americans. In another development, a lawyer named Deadria Farmer-Paellmann is compiling evidence for lawsuits against a dozen companies that she says demonstrably benefited from the slave trade. Among them are Providence Bank, a precursor of the FleetBoston Financial Corporation, and the Aetna Insurance Company of Hartford.
Ultimately, though, many proponents of reparations see the issue as a moral one that cannot be dismissed because the practicalities seem byzantine at the moment. "I think it's part of the social contract of justice in America," Mr. Dyson said, "that if black people have done what they've done and have been treated the way they've been treated, then they deserve what they deserve. And we can argue about what that dessert should look like, but it ain't come yet."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Share Prices Post Gains on Encouraging Economic Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday as blue-chip issues surged on encouraging economic data. Concerns over the possiblity of a second-half earnings slowdown kept technology stocks from broader gains.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 119.04 points, or 1.1 percent, to 11,027.80. Yesterday was the first time since April that the index had crossed the 11,000 threshold. 
 Broader stock indicators were also higher.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 11.59 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,471.84, and the Nasdaq composite index was up 29.48 points, or 0.8 percent, to 3,789.47, having recovered from a loss of 60 points earlier in the session.
Analysts said a pattern had emerged recently in which investors reacted to daily news, causing markets to fluctuate from session to session.
"The market is kind of directionless," said John Caldwell, director of portfolio strategies for McDonald Investments in Cleveland. "People seem to be grasping, looking for some fundamental issue to hang their hat on.".
Yesterday, for example, blue-chip investors were encouraged by an inflation report that showed that producer prices remained virtually the same in July after a huge jump in June caused by soaring energy costs.
Among the sectors helping push the Dow higher were tobacco, banking, drugs and health care. Philip Morris rose 2 3/8, to 31, after an analyst at Goldman, Sachs said its stock could rise 50 to 60 percent this year. And the investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers closed up 6 3/4, 132 5/8, on positive inflation data.
Technology stocks fell in early trading but recovered. Dell Computer was punished after it announced earnings that beat Wall Street's targets but apparently disappointed the high expectations of investors. The company failed to live up to projected revenue growth figures. Its shares fell 4 1/16, to 37 11/16.
 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Fall
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices fell for the first time in four days yesterday after a rise in retail sales in July led to concern that the economy might not be slowing enough to stave off another interest rate increase this year by the Federal Reserve.
The most active 10-year note fell 7/32, to 99 24/32, as its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.78 percent from 5.75. The current 30-year bond fell 12/32, to 107 25/32, while its yield rose to 5.70 percent from 5.68.

SECTION: Section A; Page 15; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1390 words

HEADLINE: Journal;
Al Gore's Chicken Soup

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
So righteous, so brave, so bold. The verdict is in: Al Gore is the best thing to happen to the Jews since Oskar Schindler.
Such has been the ecstatic cry of the media bloviators once the vice president showed the guts, the courage and, yes (all together now!), the chutzpah to select a Jew -- an Orthodox Jew, yet -- as his running mate. Never mind that Alan Greenspan and Robert Rubin have been far more powerful than any vice president, Jewish or not, will ever be. Never mind that the also-rans on Mr. Gore's uninspiring list of potential running mates were of unambiguously lesser caliber than Joseph Lieberman. 
 No matter. For a political press desperate for a new story line, here it is: The Republicans may have Charlton Heston, but in the newly daring Mr. Gore the Democrats at last have their own Moses, who just might lead them to the Promised Land in November after all. According to one account, a presidential candidate considered "dull, cautious and incapable of stirring emotional loyalty even among his own supporters" has with this surprise pick jump-started his idling campaign. (Actually, the quote comes from The Times in July 1984, after Walter Mondale anointed Geraldine Ferraro, but it can stand for the collective wisdom of August 2000.)
Yes, Mr. Gore made his choice in defiance of lethal anti-Jewish bigots on the American fringe, from Sacramento to Crown Heights to cyberspace. And yes, polls say that 12 percent of the country is still anti-Semitic. But doesn't Pat Buchanan have those votes sewed up anyway?
I defer to a recent Hebrew school grad in my household, 16-year-old Simon: "Gore gets to prove himself risky by doing something completely unrisky -- picking a middle-of-the-road candidate like himself." His opinion was echoed by another Jew I canvassed, Woody Allen, who finds the fact that "people are knocked out of their chairs" by Mr. Lieberman's nomination "ridiculous." He adds: "It's an embarrassment for the country that it took to the year 2000" for a Jew to be on the ticket. "Everyone is saying how tolerant the country is -- they settle for so little!"
If anything, all the self-congratulatory talk this week about the tolerance of Jews is more unsettling than cheering, once it becomes clear how little many non-Jews know about us. The constant refrain -- "Could a Jewish vice president wage war on his Sabbath?" -- has never been asked so vociferously of devout Christians who might have to leave church if bombs dropped on a Sunday. "I go to an Orthodox synagogue, and do you know how many beepers go off?" says a laughing Abraham Foxman of B'nai B'rith's Anti-Defamation League, noting all the Jewish doctors who, apparently unbeknownst to most Americans, actually do whip off their prayer shawls when called upon to save lives.
Conservative Republicans, meanwhile, seem to think that one size yarmulke fits all -- that all Orthodox Jews, Mr. Lieberman included, can be patronizingly stereotyped as cultural reactionaries with views closer to Jerry Falwell's than Mr. Gore's. Writing for The Wall Street Journal, Peggy Noonan celebrated Mr. Lieberman as a blood brother to such right-wing Orthodox Jews as Dr. Laura Schlessinger. Yet the Connecticut senator shares few of the views of the anti-gay, pro-life Dr. Laura (or others named by Ms. Noonan) and is in fact to the left of the Clinton-Gore administration on "don't ask, don't tell," which he feels should be scrapped so that gays can serve openly in the military. Mr. Lieberman's cultural conservatism mainly consists of throwing occasional self-promotional press conferences with William Bennett to rail impotently against Jerry Springer.
The beauty of the Lieberman nomination for Democrats is that it calls the Republicans' bluff on their new "inclusiveness." George W. Bush may have put minorities onstage in Philadelphia, but Mr. Gore put one on the ticket. Better still for the Democrats, compassionate conservatism has such a strict code of political correctness that the Bush forces, already criticized by Jewish groups for the governor's official declaration of a "Jesus Day" in Texas this year, will never dare pick on a Jewish candidate. When Mr. Lieberman eloquently defended a woman's right to choose a so-called partial birth abortion on "Larry King Live" this week, you didn't hear any of the usual Republican cries of "infanticide." Instead the G.O.P. tried to argue that Mr. Lieberman, who had a 95 percent voting record with the liberal Americans for Democratic Action last year, was a closet Republican. Now that's chutzpah.
But just as the press gives Mr. Gore excessively high marks for doing the politically expedient thing in picking Mr. Lieberman, so it oversells Mr. Lieberman's value to Mr. Gore. The conventional media wisdom that the first Democratic senator to moralize against Monicagate will now inoculate Mr. Gore from Clinton fatigue and Clinton sleaze is beside the point, even if it were true.
"We're not choosing a preacher, we're choosing a president," said Mr. Gore in 1988, when deflecting Jesse Jackson in the primaries. Despite the biblical pandering by both tickets this year, the same still holds. If puritanical preaching against Bill Clinton's sins is such a sure winner, why did the Bush campaign lock Henry Hyde in an attic in Philadelphia last week? Why, at the height of G.O.P. moralizing against Monicagate in 1998, did the Democrats gain seats in the election? The same Washington geniuses who predicted -- with stunning unanimity and inaccuracy -- that voters would punish Mr. Clinton's party in '98 predict the same fate for Mr. Gore this year. And they're probably wrong again. Now, as then, voters dislike sanctimonious public scolds, regardless of faith or party, as much as they dislike public scoundrels. Now, as then, they know when Mr. Clinton is on the ballot and when he is not, and don't regard all Democrats as his surrogates.
The real problem for Mr. Gore this year isn't Clinton fatigue -- it's Gore fatigue. And you feel it almost every time he opens his mouth. Whether in small groups or large, on the record or off, the hyper-cautious vice president has trouble speaking plainly and candidly when trying to further his views or his candidacy. Most Americans recognize that he is both far more experienced in and knowledgeable about government than Governor Bush. Few confuse his private life with Bill Clinton's. Polls show that Americans agree with Mr. Gore's positions on most issues and love the economy. But it all may be for naught for a candidate who not only tells you how to build a watch when you ask what time it is but is still talking after you've nodded off.
A classic example was Mr. Gore's appearance on "Meet the Press" last month. Asked by Tim Russert for his visceral reaction to the photo of Elian Gonzalez at gunpoint, the vice president fudged ("I wasn't there, I didn't see exactly what happened") and droned on in the impersonal legalese of Michael Dukakis's legendary debate flub. Simple requests for his judgments of Ralph Nader and Viktor Chernomyrdin yielded evasions like "I don't really know him personally" and "I have no idea." Did Mr. Gore agree with the Supreme Court Boy Scouts decision handed down more than two weeks earlier? "I haven't read the opinion." Worse, each of these non-answers was surrounded by yards of scripted boilerplate, obfuscation or equivocation, occasionally interrupted by attempts (thankfully foiled by Mr. Russert) to introduce charts. It's not good news for Democrats that Mr. Gore is said to be writing his own acceptance speech for next week.
Joseph Lieberman, himself something of a droning orator and equivocator (including on impeachment), couldn't solve this problem even were he Sammy Davis Jr. The best any vice-presidential candidate can do is no harm. Yet Abraham Foxman says that already some worried Jews are calling the Anti-Defamation League with "what if" questions, as in, "What if the ticket loses? Will Jews be the scapegoat?"
I wouldn't lose any sleep over it. If Mr. Gore loses, it's not going to be Mr. Lieberman's fault or Mr. Clinton's fault or some anti-Semitic cabal's fault but Mr. Gore's fault. And Mr. Lieberman will have proven himself the wisest guy on the ticket anyway, by not having given up his day job in the Senate to make the race.

HEADLINE: U.S., Seeing Threat of Disease, Halts Trade in Argentine Beef

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11

 BODY:
The United States and Argentina have temporarily halted trade in Argentine beef because of concerns of a possible outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease here.
In statements today, the two governments called the step precautionary and said the disease did not pose a long-term threat to the growing trade in one of Argentina's most popular exports. Nevertheless, the halt in shipments is more bad news for President Fernando de la Rua in his lagging efforts to pry Argentina out of a two-year recession. 
 Argentina's quota of beef sales to the United States is 20,000 tons a year and it is lobbying hard to increase the quota. The United States refused fresh Argentine beef until 1997, when the Agriculture Department lifted a ban linked to recurrent outbreaks of foot-and-mouth disease in the early part of the century.
Argentine beef has become a gastronomic fashion in much of the United States. Fed on grass rather than corn and allowed to roam on the pampas, Argentine cattle produce beef that is lean and tasty, if slightly chewy.
Nine days ago, Argentine officials found antibodies for foot-and-mouth disease in 10 head of cattle smuggled from neighboring Paraguay. Foot-and-mouth, rarely suffered by humans although they can be carriers, is a virus characterized by fever, weight loss and mouth blisters. As a precaution, the Argentine government ordered the slaughter of 3,000 head of cattle in northern Formosa, Corrientes and Entre Rios Provinces and suspended most exports of fresh beef, not only to the United States, but also to Canada, Venezuela, Central America and the Caribbean.
The government said the cattle with the antibodies were not actually sick.
After Argentina took action, the United States Department of Agriculture put a "temporary hold" on fresh, chilled or frozen Argentine beef. Cooked and canned beef imports will still be allowed in.
Agriculture Secretary Antonio Berhongaray said today that his government took Washington's action in stride. "There is no inclination on the part of the United States to prohibit the import of Argentine beef," Mr. Berhongaray said. "This was a move that was anticipated."
In a brief statement today, the American Embassy praised Argentina for taking prompt action. "As soon as this situation is resolved," the statement read, "exports of fresh beef will be able to resume."
As the fourth largest beef exporter, Argentina expected to sell 350,000 tons of beef products abroad this year. Three months ago, international monitors declared Argentine beef free of foot-and-mouth disease, a finding that officials had hoped would help them increase exports.
"Argentina made the decision to cease meat exports until the sanitary situation is resolved," the Argentine Agriculture Department said in a statement that predicted a resolution of the problem in a week.

HEADLINE: Sales Pick Up With No Sign Of Inflation

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
Retail sales rose in July at the fastest pace in five months, while prices paid to manufacturers, farmers and other producers were little changed, reports released today showed.
The combination of growth and low inflation indicated by the data confirms expectations that Federal Reserve policy makers will leave interest rates unchanged when they meet later this month. 
 "Rapid growth without any inflationary pressures will keep the Fed sidelined for many months," said Richard Yamarone, senior economist at the Argus Research Corporation in New York.
The retail sales data shows consumer spending was off to a strong start this quarter after a second-quarter slowdown, analysts said.
Sales, led by gains at auto dealers, department stores and building supply outlets, rose 0.7 percent in July after a revised 0.4 percent June increase, the Commerce Department said. The July increase in total retail sales was the largest since a 1.4 percent jump in February. Excluding auto dealers, sales rose 0.6 percent in July after a 0.3 percent June gain.
Consumer spending grew at a 3 percent annual rate in the April-June quarter after a 7.6 percent first-quarter pace, which was the strongest in 17 years.
Despite the pickup in spending, there were no signs of inflationary pressures in the Labor Department's report on producer prices.
The producer price index, a measure of prices received by producers for their goods, was unchanged. The core rate, which excludes the more volatile energy and food prices, rose 0.1 percent. In June, the overall producer index rose 0.6 percent and the core rate fell 0.1 percent.
Through July, the overall index rose at a 4.1 percent annual rate, compared with 2.1 percent in the first seven months of 1999. The core index increased at a 1.1 percent annual rate, compared with a 0.1 percent decline for the period a year earlier.
Producer energy prices fell 0.7 percent in July after rising 5.1 percent in June. The cost of gasoline fell 9.1 percent last month after rising 11.8 percent the previous month.
"Energy prices have been the big problem on the price front up until this point," said Vincent Boberski, senior economist with Dain Rauscher Inc. in Chicago, before the report. "The picture looks to be changing."
The Labor Department will release its report on consumer prices on Wednesday.
