HEADLINE: Missionary to England: Pakistani-Born Bishop

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, England

 BODY:
For centuries the Church of England's cathedral here has greeted pilgrims as the next-to-last stop on the road to Canterbury. Signs inside still bid travelers welcome, indicating the route's enduring popularity.
But these days some wonder whether Rochester's bishop might one day go to Canterbury himself -- not as a pilgrim, but as successor to the incumbent archbishop, whose retirement may not be that far off. 
 Such a move would make him the Church of England's spiritual leader, first among equals among bishops of Anglican churches worldwide, among them the Episcopal Church in the United States.
It would be a historic transition, because Rochester's prelate, Bishop Michael Nazir-Ali, is a native of Pakistan. At 50 he already has the distinction of being the only non-Caucasian in the Church of England to head a diocese.
In the last four decades, Christianity has grown rapidly in Africa and Asia, and with it the influence of African and Asian prelates. But if Europeans and Americans are to grasp the significance of the trend, it may have to be personalized through people like Bishop Nazir-Ali.
And there are several like him. There is the Rev. Setri Nyomi, the Ghanaian who is the top official of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, which includes the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.). There is Mr. Nyomi's counterpart at the Lutheran World Federation, the Rev. Ishmael Noko, a Zimbabwean.
And there is Cardinal Francis Arinze, a Nigerian who heads the Vatican's interfaith council. Within the Roman Catholic Church, whose African membership has more than doubled since 1975, the cardinal is considered to be among Pope John Paul II's possible successors.
In an interview in his study -- a room with a fireplace, a window overlooking a garden, and many books -- the Cambridge-educated Bishop Nazir-Ali discussed his rise to influence. "I've never actually applied for anything," he said. "I've always been told to do it. I never thought I would have a ministry outside Pakistan."
His voice is heard well beyond Rochester, which lies east of London. The Guardian, a leading British newspaper, recently published an article he wrote calling attention to the persecution of Christians in some Islamic nations. In it he cited verses in the Koran supporting religious tolerance.
The son of a Christian convert, the bishop has Shiite Muslim relatives. He speaks Arabic, Persian and Urdu, and is often invited to speak in British mosques.
Bishop Nazir-Ali has had an increasingly visible presence among Anglican prelates since 1986, when Robert Runcie, then the archbishop of Canterbury, invited him to help plan the 1988 Lambeth Conference, the once-a-decade meeting of Anglican prelates worldwide.
When the bishops met again in 1998, three years after he was named to head the Rochester diocese, Bishop Nazir-Ali presided over a conference committee concerned with Christian-Muslim relations and spoke about Islam in the world. "It was a very learned talk," said Bishop Henry N. Parsley of Birmingham, Ala.
Last March, Bishop Parsley invited Bishop Nazir-Ali to lecture and preach to Alabama Episcopalians. "People in Montgomery and Birmingham were delighted," Bishop Parsley said. But asked about his colleague's ecclesiastical future, he said, "Who knows, when you're talking about the next archbishop of Canterbury or the next pope?"
Bishop Nazir-Ali has heard the speculation and, not surprisingly, is circumspect. "I carry on with what I'm doing in the way I regard as best," he said. Rochester and Canterbury, neighboring dioceses, share major social work projects.
The archbishop of Canterbury stands at the core of the British establishment, by protocol outranking even the prime minister. To live up to the job description, a prelate must function as local bishop, leader of a diverse and often divided national church, and head of a global religious association. Commenting on the responsibilities, the bishop said, "Nobody in their right mind would seek such a job."
Others mentioned as candidates include Bishop Richard Charters of London, who is considered close to the royal family, and Archbishop Rowan Williams of Wales, who is admired as a theologian.
The successor to the incumbent, Archbishop George Carey, will be chosen by members of a royal commission as well as the prime minister and Queen Elizabeth II. The decision may be years off. Archbishop Carey, who was chosen in 1991, can remain in office until he turns 70, in 2006. But he could step down sooner.
Canterbury's Christian significance dates to 597, when a missionary monk named Augustine arrived to evangelize the Anglo-Saxons. One of his colleagues ventured west to the Medway River, becoming Rochester's first bishop.
The diocese is economically varied, incorporating London's eastern flanks, agricultural areas and new towns. Dickens grew up within its boundaries. Now it contains an emerging religious diversity, with Mormons, New Age spiritualists and others, part of a wide challenge confronting the Church of England, whose problems might have daunted even Augustine.
Church attendance has fallen. Anglican leaders speak of a society awash with "pick and mix" spirituality, in which people choose beliefs and practices to suit their private needs.
To examine the church's place in this, Bishop Nazir-Ali headed a committee that published "The Search for Faith" (Church House Publishing, 1996). The book examined the history of ideas underlying contemporary thinking and suggested that the church find new ways to communicate the Gospel to a postmodern culture.
The bishop has also been quoted as saying that the British might benefit from receiving missionaries.
"Britain is a missionary situation," he said. "There's no question about that. It's a lack of even basic knowledge of the Bible in the population. I was preaching at a Charles Dickens international conference, and I was saying: Dickens was immersed in the Bible. But now when students study Dickens in university, they have to be taught the Bible to understand Dickens."
The church, he said, "needs help, in the sense of inspiration, enthusiasm, new eyes to see its mission."
It may also need self-confidence. At times members of the clergy inviting him to speak have urged him to avoid saying anything that might upset people. But he still feels, as he put it, that "the world is willing to give us a hearing, as long as we're willing to say something."
He knows reactions can be hostile. Earlier this year the bishop, who is married and has two grown sons, touched off a furor by writing that the church should continue to teach "that having children and their nurture is a basic good of marriage and not an optional extra."
One critic, representing an organization for "non-parents," called his message "too offensive for words."
But others were pleased. "That Michael would say that warmed my heart," said Bishop Munawar K. Rumalshah, the head of a London missionary society and a friend for more than 30 years.
Bishop Nazir-Ali's becoming archbishop, his old friend said, would have a big impact throughout the Anglican Communion -- would prove "that there is no black and white in Jesus."

LENGTH: 913 words

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Unconventional Mayor Steps Into Convention Spotlight

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
RICHARD J. RIORDAN is not central casting's idea of a big city mayor. He has no "How'm I doin'?" chutzpah, no big stick. He is no speechmaker and is terrible on television. Even some of his allies refer to him with a mix of affection and exasperation as "Mayor Magoo."
The other day, at a ceremony related to the opening of the Democratic National Convention, which he had worked so hard to lure, Mr. Riordan, a Republican, actually said, "I just want to say those three magic words: Welcome to the City of Angels." He once introduced the actress Tyne Daly as "Tiny." 
 But for seven years, Mr. Riordan, a multimillionaire businessman and lawyer who works for $1 a year, has presided over this city's recovery from riots, fires, earthquake and the worst recession in 50 years with implausible success. With his own money and the help of wealthy friends, he financed successful campaigns to limit the terms of local elected officials, pass a new city charter to restructure government and elect a new majority on the board of education to deal with beleaguered schools in a city where his official powers are weak and political involvement low.
"He does this, 'I'm just a country lawyer' thing, and very slick guys in blue suits screw up because they mistake that facade," said a former chief of staff, Robin Kramer. "Because there's a very capable, highly intelligent and very practical guy behind it."
For about two minutes on the convention podium on Monday, Mr. Riordan will stand in a national spotlight usually reserved for his more colorful counterparts as he welcomes Democrats. When he set out to bring the convention to town more than two years ago, Mr. Riordan had no idea that delegates would arrive in the midst of the worst police corruption scandal in decades and amid fears of disruptive street protests, but he was philosophical this week.
"I feel like a father putting on a wedding for his oldest daughter and being driven nuts," Mr. Riordan said in an interview in the City Hall conference room, surrounded by autographed photographs of President Clinton and photos of the restless, 70-year-old mayor biking and jogging. "And then at the last minute everything comes together and you have a great time. But, really, this has not been easy."
That was a typical understatement. For months, convention planning had been plagued by troubles raising money, infighting and, for a time, Mr. Riordan's inattention. Last winter, Mr. Riordan began making phone calls to raise some $5 million to cover convention costs and spent at least 10 percent of his time on planning. In the end, Terry McAuliffe, the Democrats' most prolific fund-raiser, had to step in to help raise money.
At the same time, Mr. Riordan has had to contend with the worst police corruption scandal in decades, in which rogue officers have been accused of fabricating testimony and, in at least one instance, handcuffing and shooting an unarmed man, then implicating him in a crime and watching him go to prison paralyzed from the waist down. The United States Justice Department, which was already investigating patterns of police misconduct here, has threatened a civil rights lawsuit if the city does not accept a binding agreement to make long-promised changes in officer training.
In the last year of his second term, even some longtime supporters say Mr. Riordan seems adrift. Senior aides have left, and he barely speaks to the man who was once his most trusted confidant, William M. Wardlaw, a Democratic lawyer. Mr. Riordan has not forgiven Mr. Wardlaw for backing the city attorney, James K. Hahn, a Democrat, for mayor next year, while Mr. Riordan, who built an unusual coalition of white suburban homeowners and inner-city Hispanics in the wake of the 1992 riots, favors a fellow Republican businessman, Steve Soboroff.
BUT Mr. Riordan insists he is busier than ever.
"I always say, and I really believe this, that if you start thinking about a legacy, then it takes your eye off the ball," he said.
Mr. Riordan, born in Flushing, Queens, to a father who was an executive at the department store Abraham and Strauss and a mother who was a homemaker, came to politics by a nontraditional route. After graduating from Princeton, and ranking first in his class at the University of Michigan Law School, he made a fortune in the leveraged buyout business in the 1980's. He has a longstanding interest in education, and his private foundation has given away $30 million over 20 years in support of education. He said he would like nothing better when he leaves office than to finance and become the principal of a charter school.
"He's an odd combination, because he's such a restless guy, with a short attention span, and his mind always seems to be jumping to the next thing," said Patt Morrison, a columnist for The Los Angeles Times and one of the members, including the actor Alan Alda and the sociologist James Q. Wilson, of the mayor's book club, which gathers in the 40,000-volume library at Mr. Riordan's house in Brentwood to tackle authors from Stendhal to Raymond Chandler. "And yet he takes on a great deal of serious reading," Ms. Morrison said.
Perhaps Mr. Riordan's biggest failure has been his inability to get along with the 15-member City Council, all but three of whom are Democrats.
"It's more words than reality," he said. "Some of the liberals who would like to be friendly with me are afraid, afraid they'd be thrown out of the liberal cult."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Central Bank In Japan Raises Interest Rates

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 11

 BODY:
Forcefully asserting its view that Japan's economy is now growing firmly after years of false starts, the central bank raised interest rates today for the first time in a decade, defying strong pressure from government officials to keep borrowing costs close to zero.
In what was described as a taxing all-day meeting, the Bank of Japan's nine-member board voted to abandon the zero-interest policy it had adopted in February 1999 as an emergency measure to keep the economy from slipping further into recession. 
 While the move had been widely expected, it nonetheless sent a powerful message about the central bank's view that the Japanese economy, the world's second largest, has now achieved enough momentum to keep expanding. The move also represented an unparalleled display of independence by the central bank, which had been given more autonomy under a change in the law a few years ago but until today had never exercised it.
The central bank said it would steer a benchmark rate known as the overnight call rate -- the interest rate banks charge each other -- to 0.25 percent from virtually zero.
The official discount rate, which is the largely symbolic rate on loans the central bank charges to private banks, was left unchanged at 0.5 percent, a record low.
Today was the first time since 1990 that the central bank had raised rates, which it had lowered repeatedly in response to Japan's seesaw pattern of recession and feeble recovery that characterized much of the decade.
"At present, Japan's economy is showing clearer signs of recovery, and this gradual upturn, led mainly by business fixed investment, is likely to continue," the central bank said in a statement.
The increase in the benchmark rate will lead to higher borrowing costs for consumers and businesses. Even so, the benchmark rate remains extraordinarily low in this country. The comparable rate in the United States is 6.5 percent and in Europe it is 4.25 percent.
The announcement of the rate increase here came after the close of the financial markets. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks was up 141.85 points, or 0.89 percent, to 16,117.50. The yen was little changed against the dollar. The markets were not expected to react much when they reopened on Monday.
But the central bank's decision drew sharp criticism from government officials, political leaders and many economists who have argued that Japan's economy is still too delicate to sustain an increase in interest rates, no matter how small. Many critics of the increase view it more as a statement of independence on the part of the central bank than as sound economic policy.
"I think the Bank of Japan has probably moved too soon in light of the economic situation," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Tokyo. "The onus is on them to demonstrate their decision was correct."
Ronald Bevacqua, senior economist for Commerz Securities in Tokyo, said the rate increase was "a brave move but not necessarily one that the economy justifies."
While Japan's economy grew 2.5 percent in the first three months of 2000 and the government projects that economic growth this fiscal year will be 1 percent, double the rate of a year earlier, Mr. Bevacqua said that Japan's growth was peaking and would slow.
The government, which early this week denounced any rate increase as premature, asked the central bank at its meeting today to postpone a decision on rates until next month, when second-quarter gross domestic product figures will be available to better assess the country's economic performance.
But the board immediately rejected the request by a majority vote, the central bank said.
At a news conference after the meeting, Masaru Hayami, the central bank's governor, stressed that the zero-rate policy had been an extraordinary measure meant to ward off deflation -- a dangerous downward spiral of prices and incomes that can lead to a full-scale depression. But Mr. Hayami said such a policy had to end at some point, and the deflation threat had passed.
Mr. Hayami has long stated the need to raise interest rates, arguing that the zero-rate policy essentially encourages nearly free borrowing that keeps unprofitable businesses from making painful cutbacks. It also hurts the incomes of Japan's growing population of retirees whose savings are barely earning interest.
In recent weeks, Mr. Hayami had conducted a public relations campaign of sorts, proclaiming the necessity of raising rates. Many analysts said he had gone too far to turn back, and one central bank board member who attended today's meeting said that Mr. Hayami had convinced most board members that it was their duty to vote for the rate increase, as a measure not only of their independence but their legitimacy.
"All economic data, ranging from corporate investment to jobs and spending have gotten better in August and July," Mr. Hayami said. "Board members took these data as proof that deflation fears have dissipated."
At its board meeting last month, the central bank had been widely expected to lift the zero-rate policy, but the collapse of a highly indebted retailer, the Sogo Company, sent shudders through the financial system and the bank decided to maintain the policy while it monitored the impact of Sogo's failure.
Analysts said the immediate impact of the rate increase would probaly be tightening of credit available to small and medium-size businesses, which will increase bankruptcies and unemployment.
Particularly vulnerable are the real estate, construction and retail sectors, which are the most heavily indebted. Higher interest rates will also make it more costly for the government to borrow money to feed the extensive spending projects that have helped keep Japan's economy from faltering even further over the last decade.
The rate increase puts Japanese banks in a particularly difficult position. The banks, which have received enormous government aid because of hundreds of billions of dollars of unpaid loans on their books, have promised that they would make more loans to small and medium-size businesses. But they will be hard pressed to keep those promises while raising their loan rates.
Reaction to the rate increase was mixed in the Japanese business community. Takashi Imai, chairman of the Nippon Steel Corporation, told the Kyodo news service that he found it difficult to understand the central bank's decision. "Given personal consumption and prices, it can hardly be said we have come to a point where we can be certain that concern for deflation is gone," he said.
But Yotaro Kobayashi, chairman of the Fuji Xerox Company, welcomed the rate increase, saying: "The Japanese economy is now in a very good shape. The decision is confirmation that concerns about deflation are gone and that the economic recovery is getting on the right track."

HEADLINE: Firestone Scrambles to Meet Demand for Replacement Tires

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
As confused consumers kept phones ringing off the hooks yesterday at dealers across the country, Bridgestone/Firestone struggled to cope with the demand for replacement tires unleashed by its recall of 6.5 million tires for sport utility vehicles.
The company said it planned to double its production of tires in the United States and to step up its imports from other plants run by Bridgestone, its Japanese parent. The domestic increases will not include a plant in Decatur, Ill., to which Firestone has traced a disproportionate number of the tire failures that led to the recall, the second biggest in its 100-year history. 
 Yesterday, dealers were still impatiently waiting for Firestone to give them a definite timetable for when replacement tires will roll in.
"Customers are calling from the time we open until the time we close, and we don't expect the calls to slow down before next week," said Scott McClain, a sales manager at S & S Tire, which runs 22 retail stores in Kentucky and also serves as wholesaler to other dealers.
The recall includes all of Firestone's ATX and ATX II tires for 15-inch wheels, as well as Wilderness tires of the same size with a Department of Transportation 10-digit designation starting with the letters VD; these latter tires are the ones made at the Decatur plant. Because most of the reported incidents involve motorists driving in hot-weather regions -- and because supplies of replacement tires are short -- the recall is being conducted in phases, starting in the Sun Belt states.
The recall, a response to reports of 46 deaths in accidents and hundreds of tire failures, has been extended to Canada and Mexico. Most tires being recalled were supplied as original equipment on Ford Explorers, the most popular sport utility vehicle.
In most cases, even dealers without replacement tires available have told customers to come in, if only to make sure that their tires are properly inflated. Firestone recommends 30 pounds per square inch; Ford has said 26 will do. Most dealers say 30 is a minimum inflation level for safety; many recommend 32 or even higher.
Mr. McClain said he spent two days this week walking through an S & S retail outlet, checking tire pressure on customers' Ford Explorers. Some were as high as 45 P.S.I. -- an overinflation level that could itself cause a tire to eventually burst -- and some as low as 20 P.S.I. "No tire is safe if you are running it underinflated at 100 miles an hour," he said. Many dealers said their customers were expressing wariness about all Firestone tires, not just those being recalled.
"When you find a bad batch of beef, you don't suddenly say that all beef from that store is bad," said Larry Morgan, who owns Morgan Tire and Auto Inc., a large dealership in Clearwater, Fla. "But a lot of people are inappropriately abusing the name Firestone when they should just be thinking of a particular Firestone product line."
Although Firestone is giving California, Arizona and other hot-weather states first priority for replacement tires, dealers in other states are unwilling to make their own customers wait. On Wednesday, when Firestone announced the recall, S & S had 3,500 Wilderness tires -- not counting any being recalled -- in stock. It has already used them up, and is almost out of similar tires from other manufacturers as well. The company has ordered 2,500 more S.U.V.-compatible tires from Goodyear, Michelin and other Firestone competitors.
Wright Tire, a large independent dealership in Anoka, Minn. that derives about 95 percent of its sales from Firestone tires, is getting more breathing room. The owner, Thomas Wright, said he got as many as 300 calls a day on Wednesday and Thursday, but that the volume had tapered off by yesterday afternoon. Mr. Wright, who is also president of the Tire Association of North America, has replaced about 30 sets of tires from stock, and has scheduled another 75 tire replacements for the future.
But in his view, customer panic is misplaced. "Probably 80 percent of the Firestone tires we've sold have gone on S.U.V.'s, many of them on Ford Explorers, and we've never had one reported problem," he said. "If you keep the tire properly inflated, it runs just fine."

HEADLINE: They've Walked a Mile in Their Shoes

BYLINE: By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
Leslie Macpherson fumbled with her tool belt as she walked into the room crammed with wires. She had never seen so many in her life. Blue ones, white ones. Wires as thin as toothpicks, wires as thick as thumbs. Thousands of them.
In her regular management job with Verizon Communications, the country's largest local telephone company, Ms. Macpherson kept track of utilities regulations imposed by state agencies. She wore a suit and sat at a desk. She met with government officials. She wrote reports. She did not carry around pliers or orange telephone handsets. 
 But that was before the union strike began last Sunday. Ms. Macpherson is now temporarily a technician, and a technician must know her wires. In this Verizon office in Midtown Manhattan, the wires are housed in metal frames the size of a mobile home. After several days on the job, Ms. Macpherson now knows how to lay a wire to help set up a dial tone for a new customer. A dial tone! The fundamental product created and sold by Verizon and its 260,000 employees.
"I think that's fed from the switch," she said, waving toward a bundle of wires. "I think."
"These are cables," she said, pointing to a thick gray sheath. "They go underground to the cosmic frame."
Cosmic frame?
"Don't ask me about the cosmic frame," she said.
Ms. Macpherson is one of about 30,000 managers who have been filling in for more than 86,000 unionized workers at Verizon offices from Maine to Virginia, pinch-hitting on union jobs that range from answering 411 calls to fixing aerial cables.
And after several days of the work, many of them said that while they were not siding with the unions, they had a new appreciation for the work of its members.
"I have a great deal of respect for the people who do it, having done it myself," said Diana Barnes, who was transferred from the department that places advertising for Verizon to work as a directory assistance operator. "So some good comes out of bad, if management appreciates the workers more."
Both Ms. Macpherson and Ms. Barnes were sent from Verizon's New York headquarters to work at the company's largest directory assistance center in the city, on 38th Street between Second and Third Avenues in Manhattan. An informal, school's-out atmosphere had descended on the place. Offices usually bustling with a dozen people were staffed by one or two managers. Fill-in workers sauntered in wearing jeans and sneakers. Supervisors who usually sat at desks ran around the hallways with tools, doing double duty as bosses and the bossed.
Of course, union workers have been less than thrilled with managers filling their jobs. They are represented by the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. The police have received reports of egg throwing and vandalism. On a recent afternoon, several people in a picket line outside the 38th Street building yelled at a woman walking in through the front doors.
"No, don't go in there," shouted Arthur Treisman, a telephone operator waving a union placard. "Don't go in there! Scab!"
Miguel Garrido, a technician picketing alongside Mr. Treisman, said he felt insulted that managers were working union jobs.
"I think none of them are qualified to do what we do," Mr. Garrido said. "Most of them were educated in college, but they're not technically inclined."
While union shifts are usually eight hours, most managers have been working 12-hour days to compensate for the short staff. After 13 days, if the strike lasts that long, they are to get a one-day break.
"Realistically, the work out of this office is tremendous, and we do the best we can with what we have," said Deborah Torruellas, who supervised Ms. Macpherson and other frame technicians. "Over the long term, one would see a negative change, because the people here are working 12 hours a day, seven days a week, and it just won't do."
Ms. Torruellas has been with the company for 22 years, working her way up through half a dozen departments to become a manager. When her 38 frame technicians went on strike, she was forced to train eight managers from other parts of the company to do their jobs. The new recruits had to learn in hours what it sometimes took months to master, she said.
The strike has also meant that Ms. Torruellas had to strap on a tool belt and work on the frames herself, something she had not done regularly for a decade. "At least I'm off my desk and on the floor," she said.
Most of the jobs that needed filling were operator positions. Three floors above Ms. Torruellas, about 30 people sat in gray cubicles wearing headsets. The calls for directory assistance came in one after another, an endless stream of questions.
Robert Shapiro was trying to type the word "coronet" into his computer. A caller wanted the number of the movie theater by that name. Mr. Shapiro tapped out the letters slowly.
"Spell it for me," he told his caller. "I'm a manager here. I don't have typing skills."
Mr. Shapiro usually manages computer programmers developing Verizon's e-commerce systems in a White Plains office. But on this day he wore the shackles of the old economy. In his operator's cubicle he would sit for 12 hours, with only three breaks -- 30 minutes for lunch and two 15-minute periods. He had taken his shoes off. On his desk sat an apple, a cookie and a bottle of water.
Mr. Shapiro, who also worked as an operator during the last strike, which lasted for two days in 1998, has been averaging 900 calls in a 12-hour shift. (A trained directory assistance operator takes more than 1,000 calls in an eight-hour shift.) During a recent five-minute period, callers asked Mr. Shapiro for the numbers of a pizzeria, a doughnut shop, a pharmacy, the United Parcel Service and a jeweler in Manhattan named Gumuchjian Fils.
"It really gives you an appreciation of the work that the union folks do," he said. "It's invaluable."
Three floors below, Ms. Macpherson pulled out her pliers and stared at the wires snaking over the metal girders. So many wires! During the last strike, at least, she had been able to hit the road for two days as a delivery driver. But it could be worse, she said, shaking her head as she thought about the managers who had to work as operators.
"I'm O.K. with this," she said. "I'm not complaining."

HEADLINE: Czech Police and Army Get Ready for Protests at I.M.F.-World Bank Meeting

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Aug. 11

 BODY:
Kentucky Fried Chicken and Pizza Hut have already ordered replacement glass. So has Tesco, a British supermarket chain, and it is thinking of shutting down for the duration. McDonald's talks hopefully of its local ownership and wants to keep its outlets open.
The Interior Ministry will have 11,000 police officers on duty, with several thousand troops in reserve. Schools and theaters will close. The ministry has even opened a Web site, warning young people, "The police will have a lot of work on their hands, so they cannot be too tolerant of various childish pranks." It adds, "Do not provoke the police." 
 It advises older people to stock up on food and medicine, and to "relax and trust the authorities."
One might think that these are preparations for the battle in Central Europe that NATO war-gamed for so many years. But it is only the annual autumn meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, a conference that the Czech Republic eagerly sought in 1993 as a millennial symbol of the country's return to capitalism and the West.
The 10-day meeting, which is expected to attract up to 18,000 officials and delegates, opens on Sept. 19. The Communists' old Palace of Culture has been renovated for the meeting at a cost of $60 million and renamed the Congress Center.
But since Prague sought this honor, the monetary fund and the World Bank have become targets of rage against globalization and indifferent capitalism. The fund in particular has for some the same negative connotations that the Federal Emergency Management Agency has for far-right groups in the United States.
Already, on various Web sites critical of the fund and its policies, like www.destroyimf.org -- "a Web resource for all those mobilizing to end the poverty and injustice inflicted by global capitalism" -- there is the cry, "Turn Prague into Seattle!" There, late last November, 40,000 demonstrators paralyzed the city, damaged businesses, clashed with the police and tied up a meeting of the World Trade Organization.
Organizers and Czech officials expect 20,000 to 50,000 protesters -- some peaceful, some not -- to come here. The protests will certainly be the largest here since 1989, and perhaps the largest invasion of foreigners since the Soviets dropped by with their tanks in 1968.
President Vaclav Havel has tried to satisfy and perhaps co-opt some of the more well-mannered groups by offering to meet with them at Prague Castle.
The government has offered designated areas for protest and arranged for a private company, FAM, to equip the old Strahov sports stadium with tents, portable lavatories and food so the protesters will have a relatively clean and safe place to stay.
The tent city will open on Sept. 21, and anyone may stay there for the duration for $37, said Tomas Doubek of FAM. There will be private security guards but no policemen, unless there is significant trouble.
But the conservative party of former Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus objected to the arrangements, saying they looked as if the Czechs "are collaborating with extremists," Mr. Doubek said.
"Some legislators said, 'Let the protesters get a doctorate in finance, learn two foreign languages, work in a bank for a few years, and then they will be qualified to discuss I.M.F. issues,' " he said. "Surprisingly, nobody laughed at this stupidity."
Alice Dvorska, an organizer with the Czech umbrella group Initiative against Economic Globalization, says she is worried about how the Czech police, with a history of aggressive crowd control, will behave.
In May 1998 the police were taken by surprise by protests against the automobile industry and globalization. The police beat some protesters and some bystanders as well.
"We're afraid of violence on the part of the police," Ms. Dvorska said. "The Interior Ministry is purposely demonizing us. If you look at protests around the world, it is always the police who cause most of the violence."
Chelsea Mozen is a 25-year-old American who quit a job in Washington to help organize the initiative's program of nonviolent demonstrations, dance and street theater intended to educate citizens.
"It's not our main aim to shut the meeting down, although we think the I.M.F. and World Bank should be dissolved," Ms. Mozen said. "We want a grass-roots display of our disagreement."
But she says the police have been monitoring the group and its planning, including a meeting outside Prague last month. "We're definitely under surveillance," she said.
On Aug. 2 the group handed out fliers and performed a bit of street theater in Old Town Square, holding a symbolic soccer match between multinational corporations and representatives of the world's poor. The corporations won by bribing the referee, who represented the I.M.F. and the World Bank.
Chuck Reinhardt, a high school teacher from New York, played the part of McDonald's during the match. "The World Bank is not accountable," he said. "They give out loans but don't bear responsibility for what is being done with the money, and most people around the world get no benefits from it at all."
Ragnhild Eide Skogseth, 18, a Norwegian student who played Shell Oil, said the fund and the bank "always say they want to help the poor, but the results are always the opposite."
The Czech police have been training for the meeting and have worked with the American police and with the F.B.I., which has opened an office in Prague, mostly to monitor organized crime.
The F.B.I. trained 24 Czech police officers in crowd control in the United States, said an Interior Ministry spokesman, Stanislav Gross, and the police have paid particular attention to the way the Washington, D.C., police handled the spring meeting of the fund and the bank in April. Hundreds of protesters were arrested there, but there was much less violence than in Seattle.
Still, for the designers of the Web site, the meeting "will be protected by a Czech police operation run by the F.B.I." It says, "The challenge to the workers' movement is to shut down that summit with the biggest international demo Europe has ever seen."
One problem for the police is the location of the old Palace of Culture. The main access from the city center, where most delegates will stay, is by a bridge over a valley that could be blocked by protest.
The two closest hotels, the Corinthia Forum and the Panorama, are on the right side of the bridge, but because they have Libyan ownership, an American embargo would bar Americans from staying there.
Horst Kohler, the fund's executive director, says he has "full confidence" in Prague's ability to handle the meeting. Emphasizing a need for "internal reform," he said the fund was "open for discussions and dialogue."
"We're not hiding" from the protesters, he said.
Mr. Havel emphasizes the symbolism of Prague as the host of the post-Communist world's first annual meeting of the fund and bank. He said he would try to have discussions with the demonstrators as well as the bankers.
The media attention given to security issues "pains me," he said. "It seems as if we are preparing for civil war. We should take this more positively."

HEADLINE: John C. Harsanyi, 80, Is Dead; Won Nobel Economics Award

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
John C. Harsanyi, who won the 1994 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science for his work on game theory, died on Wednesday in Berkeley, Calif.
Mr. Harsanyi, 80, was a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley, for 25 years until 1990. He had Alzheimer's disease and died of a heart attack at home in Berkeley, according to his son, Tom. 
 A Hungarian of Jewish descent, Mr. Harsanyi barely escaped from the forced-labor unit he was drafted into outside Budapest near the end of World War II. While waiting at a crowded railway station to be deported to a mine, Mr. Harsanyi removed his sweater with its yellow star and walked away, his son said.
A guard stopped him and asked him what he was doing there. Mr. Harsanyi, according to his son, said: "I am here to visit one of my Jewish friends who is going to be deported. I think it is important that we stand by our friends in their time of need." The guard let him go. Tom Harsanyi said that of the workers in the forced- labor unit, only his father and three others, who jumped from the train, survived.
Mr. Harsanyi won the Nobel award for his work in game theory, which concentrates on competition among players, using mathematics to forecast the outcome of games, like chess, and also trade wars, hostile takeovers, price wars and other political and economic conflicts. Unlike theories used to explain the interaction in a market of many participants, game theory deals with the fact that when there are just a few players, all of them have to worry about the response of their opponent.
Mr. Harsanyi shared the award with two other economists, John F. Nash of Princeton University and Reinhard Selten of the University of Bonn. Mr. Nash laid out the basic principles of game theory, but he assumed that the players all shared the same information and were driven by self-interest. Mr. Harsanyi made the theory work when rivals did not know much at all about what the other planned to do. He did this, in part, by assigning probabilities to the possible moves of the players and the outcomes.
"He found a way to allow people to think systematically about markets in which there were a small number of players who had access to different information," said John Quigley, a professor of economics at Berkeley and the former chairman of the economics department.
"For a large set of circumstances, game theory is the way people think today," Mr. Quigley said. Mr. Harsanyi's work, Mr. Quigley added, "was instrumental in making economic theory fit the imperfect world in which we live."
Mr. Harsanyi was born in Budapest on May 29, 1920. His parents were Jewish but converted to Catholicism before he was born. He was raised as a Catholic. His main interests were in mathematics and philosophy. But because of the political uncertainty of the time, he earned a degree in pharmacology so that he could work in his father's pharmacy. He was drafted into the forced-labor unit after Germany occupied Hungary during World War II.
After the war, Mr. Harsanyi remained in Hungary, earning a doctorate in philosophy from the University of Budapest. He was an assistant professor of sociology at the univeristy until the late 1940's, when his views clashed with those of the Communist government. He quit his job and returned to work in his father's pharmacy.
In 1950, he escaped over the border to Austria with his future wife, Anne, and traveled to Australia. He married Anne on Jan. 2, 1951, three days after arriving in Sydney.
He went to the University of Sydney at night to earn a master's degree in economics and became a lecturer in economics at the University of Queensland in Brisbane in 1954. But his son, Tom, said that his father felt that he could not be effective in his field from Australia. So in 1956, he enrolled in the Ph.D. program in economics at Stanford University and studied under Kenneth Arrow, a future Nobel winner in economics.
He returned to Australia to teach economics at the Australian National University from 1958 to 1961 and then returned to the United States to Wayne State University in Detroit from 1961 to 1963. He went to the Haas School at Berkeley in 1964 as a visiting professor and became a full professor in 1965. He was appointed a professor in the Berkeley economics department in 1966.
In 1964, before Mr. Harsanyi developed his procedure for dealing with game theory players with incomplete information, he was asked to be one of 10 game theorists to advise the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency on negotiations with the Soviet Union. The 10 advisers said they could not help because both "players" had too little information about the other side.
Mr. Harsanyi is survived by his wife, Anne, of Berkeley, and his son, of Somerville, Mass.

HEADLINE: Bingo, Blood and Burial Plots In the Quest for Food Stamps

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
In California, New York and 27 other states, people applying for food stamps are asked if they own a burial plot. Nebraska and Nevada want to know if applicants have sold their blood, and for how much. Hawaii demands garage-sale receipts, South Dakota wants documentation of bingo winnings, and Minnesota, on Page 20 of a 36-page eligibility application, asks if anyone in the household earns money from a paper route.
Food-stamp applications in most states have become so onerous that they are deterring needy people from applying for the subsidies, a comprehensive analysis by a national network of food banks and advocacy groups has found. Many of the inquiries about income and assets have no connection to legal requirements for stamps but are either aggressive responses to federal mandates to deter fraud or part of recent state and local efforts to cut welfare costs by eliminating recipients. 
 State administrators contend that they are simply complying with federal pressure to be tightfisted with taxpayers' money and properly enforcing the tougher rules passed by Congress in the 1996 welfare overhaul.
But federal officials say the report, conducted by America's Second Harvest, the nation's largest food bank network, adds to their worries that such stringency may be one reason that 12 million people who need the benefits, and are eligible, are not getting them.
Food-stamp use is plummeting at a faster rate than can be explained by economic growth. Since 1996, the number of people using food stamps has declined to 17.2 million people from 23 million, though a growing bipartisan consensus now holds that food stamps, like Medicaid, are supports needed to keep low-wage parents working.
"Sometimes in this program we have not looked at the big picture," Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said in an interview about the survey, which will be released on Monday.
"It's not my goal to keep hungry people out of the program -- that's a disgrace," Mr. Glickman said. "But it's also my job to keep fraud down. It's tricky to balance those things."
The report, he added, "is actually helpful. We are going to continue to work with the states to make sure that the income limits aren't ridiculous," and that antifraud techniques are not "outside the bounds of what we ought to be doing."
Among the new sleuthing methods for countering fraud are parking-lot espionage in Tennessee, computerized credit checks in Delaware and Texas, and calls to employers and landlords in Alaska.
"They don't want you to have nothing," a disabled woman of 56, who asked that her name not be used, whispered as she peered at the question about a burial space in the shabby waiting room of a food-stamp office in Harlem. "It's none of their business. You want to tell the truth, but they make it so if you tell the truth, it don't help."
When the comment was repeated to the sponsors of the study, which examined application forms from all 50 states and a sampling from the nation's 3,143 counties, they said it underlined the unfairness of such questions, though they are not illegal.
"She's afraid she'll go hungry if she's honest," Deborah Leff, president of America's Second Harvest, said of the woman's concern. "Isn't that a mess?"
Though the federal government finances and oversees the food-stamp program, states administer it, with wide variations. The shortest application, in Florida, is only a page, but most are more than 10 pages, and all warn that misleading answers are punishable by a stiff fine and up to 20 years in prison.
Yet, the study found, many questions are unintelligible to the average applicant, and some are mind-boggling even to the researchers.
"Are you or anyone in your household fleeing from New Jersey?" Ohio's eight-page application asks. Researchers nicknamed the query the Soprano Clause, after the television drama about a Mafia family.
"We live in Cleveland," said Sharon Davis, 39, a single mother of three who was laid off last month from her job as a machine operator and had spent most of the afternoon applying for food stamps. "Why would they ask if you're from New Jersey?"
In their defense, state administrators contend that all the questions -- including that one -- reflect local efforts to comply with a stream of federal dictates, including periodic crackdowns on fraud, stiff penalties on states that overpay even by $5, and new rules in the 1996 federal welfare legislation.
To explain the so-called Soprano Clause, for example, Ohio food-stamp administrators pointed to a provision by Congress in the 1996 legislation. It excludes from the food-stamp program any fugitive from prosecution of a felony, which in New Jersey is called a "high misdemeanor." To be safe, said Jon Allen, a spokesman for the Ohio Department of Job and Family Services, Ohio added an extra question just to cover New Jersey's terminology.
By the same token, Nebraska, which was fined $1 million for food-stamp errors in a 1998 federal audit, asks about money from blood plasma donations and counts it against a family's food allotment -- which food-bank analysts say is simply wrong -- because in 1986 an obscure federal policy memorandum defined such money as earned income.
As for burial plots, some state administrators justify questioning elderly applicants about them because a federal provision notes that only one grave per customer can be discounted when calculating a household's assets. To be eligible for food stamps at all, a household cannot have assets of over $2,000, or $3,000 for senior citizens, including checking and savings accounts and the value of any car above $4,650.
Recent studies show that some people seeking food stamps have been turned away or cut off in a push to divert them from welfare -- sometimes illegally, as a federal court found in New York City last year. Many other people either do not know they are eligible or are discouraged by the requirements, especially in states that shortened eligibility to three months instead of a year, which is allowed by federal rules.
Applications take an average of five hours and two visits, Agriculture Department figures show, and the benefit, only $73 a month per person on average, can be as low as $10. Ninety percent of households getting food stamps have income under the poverty line, or $14,150 for a family of three. Three-quarters have no countable assets. A typical family of three leaving the welfare rolls has an annual income of $11,500, according to one study, and qualifies for just under $150 a month in food stamps.
Though many longer applications include questions relating to cash assistance and medical benefits, a recent study in Western and Southern states found that 78 percent of those seeking food stamps were not told when they qualified for the other programs.
Agriculture Department officials are now urging outreach efforts, and this year, for the first time, they are offering modest rewards to states that increase participation. But state administrators see a certain hypocrisy in the new thrust.
"The only message we have heard for years is accuracy; your error rate is what matters," Ann Sessoms, Minnesota's welfare reform manager, said. "If you miss a plasma donation, if you miss a paper route, the state is held liable."
Only last September the Agriculture Department's quality-control arm praised the Tennessee Department of Human Services' "Project Parking Lot," in which Nashville investigators patrol for cars whose blue-book value exceeds the $4,650 limit. They feed the license plate numbers into a computer listing people on the benefit rolls, and have cut off $3 million to $4 million in benefits as a result, according to Larry Evitts, the director of investigations.
"That's crazy," said Stephanie Manning, who oversees a Nashville food pantry that limits aid to three boxes of groceries every six months. "You can't eat your car."
Mike Harris, administrator of food stamps in Nebraska, said the dollar limit on cars, raised only by $150 since Congress set it 20 years ago, shows how states get stuck enforcing obsolete regulations.
"You know what's happened to the price of cars," Mr. Harris said. "It's like, come on, people!"
In the latest enforcement trend, 11 states, including New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, either require electronic fingerprinting of food-stamp recipients or are planning it. Texas has contracted with computer information brokers who provide, among other tidbits, a listing of 10 neighbors who could be asked about an applicant's circumstances. Delaware pays $2 or $3 an inquiry for credit-card histories on applicants whose answers seem suspicious to a caseworker. Though privacy laws make it illegal to use credit information in a criminal case, William Garfinkel, director of audit at the Delaware Department of Health and Social Services, said that nothing barred using it to determine government benefits.
"They count everything," Anna Santana, a divorced bookkeeper in Lincoln, Neb., said, citing a $25 gift certificate from her church for her three children's Christmas presents.
Before qualifying for food stamps, she added, there were times when she fed them first, and ate only if they left something. But her older daughter, then 5, caught on.
"She started cutting back on what she was eating," Ms. Santana recalled. " 'I'm not hungry, Mommy, you need to eat, too.' "
Mr. Glickman said some state actions seemed overzealous, Congressional mandates notwithstanding. "The irony here is that we don't ask farmers to do anything like we do our food-stamp recipients," he added, referring to federal farm subsidies.
A few states stand out in the study as exceptions. Indiana, for example, has a two-page application that does not ask about burial plots, bingo or blood products. Federal audits last year found fewer mistakes in its calculations of benefits than in those of California, which squeezes 120 questions onto 21 pages. Indeed, the study found that there was no correlation at all between the length of a state's application and the accuracy of its payments.
"Some states have shown a lot of good judgment and simplicity in complying with the requirements," Mr. Glickman said. "Other states have gone down a much more complicated route. Our job is to try to help all the states run a simpler system."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE PRESIDENT;
The Gore Balancing Act: Embracing Clinton While Standing on His Own

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE with MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, Aug. 11

 BODY:
For months now, Al Gore has been searching for the proper degree of separation from Bill Clinton. He has used measured words and occasional policy differences both to try to distance himself from the president and to demonstrate that he is his own man, worthy of the presidency in his own right.
At the same time, he has hoped to benefit from his participation in an administration that has presided over the longest economic expansion in history. 
 But in an ultimate twist, it seems that Mr. Gore may have to rely on the very man he is distancing himself from to make his case.
The Gore campaign is planning a multistage separation process over the next few days, although there are still internal debates over some details and how explicit Mr. Clinton should be in talking about his personal behavior and impeachment when he addresses the convention on Monday night.
That process may have begun prematurely with Mr. Clinton's comments on Thursday, when he said in a lengthy public confessional that voters should not hold Mr. Gore accountable for Mr. Clinton's sins.
"Surely, no fair-minded person would blame him for the mistakes I've made," Mr. Clinton said in an interview with a pastor in Illinois.
Gore advisers have been frustrated over the months with some of Mr. Clinton's moves that were intended to be helpful but often upstaged Mr. Gore. But they said today that Mr. Clinton's most recent comments could help the vice president -- because they expected the light to shine brightly on Mr. Clinton at this point anyway.
"We have known for the last four months that the first few days of the ramp-up into our convention was in large measure going to be about Bill Clinton and the last eight years," said a top Gore adviser. "To do it any other way would be frankly ungracious and not politically smart."
But such is the entangled relationship between the president and vice president -- and such is the admiration for Mr. Clinton's political skills -- that questions were raised about whether the White House and the Gore campaign had actually planned Mr. Clinton's remarks as a way for Mr. Clinton to give Mr. Gore some breathing space, even if they dredged up the unpleasantness that led to the impeachment.
Both camps said no. Joe Lockhart, the president's spokesman, said Mr. Clinton arranged the interview with his pastor and did not clear it with the Gore campaign.
The Gore adviser said the same thing. "I have no idea whether Clinton's remarks were spontaneous or premeditated," he said. "But they were not coordinated."
But much of the distancing dance that will take place in the next few days has been planned. Mr. Gore has given Mr. Clinton the starring prime-time role at the convention on Monday. Both sides are envisioning not only a celebration of Mr. Clinton's glory years but a clear signal that his problems are of his own making and should not be used against Mr. Gore.
One Democrat close to Mr. Clinton said the president might have used his confessional interview on Thursday as a kind of rehearsal for the convention speech. "He's trying out the show in New Haven before he gets to Broadway," the Democrat said.
The Gore campaign said Mr. Clinton will not be so explicit at the convention, and White House officials agreed, adding that Mr. Clinton used the forum on Thursday as more of a pre-emptive cleansing so he would not have to do that at the convention. In any case, Gore advisers are focused on other things. "Clinton has great job performance ratings and terrible personal ratings," one aide said. "The whole trick here is to try to be associated with the job performance."
On Tuesday, a symbolic passing of the torch from Mr. Clinton to Mr. Gore has been arranged in Michigan.
The Clinton Question has been swirling around the Gore candidacy for months, and Mr. Gore has dealt with it in various ways. He began his campaign in June 1999 with his strongest comments to date about Mr. Clinton's affair, but he seemed genuinely surprised along the campaign trail to be asked about the president. Finally, he figured out a fairly formulaic answer, which he has more or less followed for months.
He told audiences that his relationship with Mr. Clinton consisted of four parts. As he put it in January to New Hampshire Public Radio: "First of all, we're friends, and that friendship is genuine. Secondly, I have been critical of the personal mistake that the president made, which I've been asked about from time to time in this campaign. Third, I have fought alongside the president for this strong economy and for the other improvements that we've seen during the Clinton/Gore administration. And fourth, I have to win this race on my own."
"Now," he continued, "depending upon the question that's asked or the perspective of the questioner, they may focus on one of those four aspects of the relationship and not really hear the complexity of it with all four, and if they hear only that I'm running on my own, they may say, 'Oh, he's distancing himself.' If they hear I fought with President Clinton for a strong economy, they may say, 'Oh, he's embracing President Clinton.' Well, all of those things are true, but it's not true that I'm either distancing myself from him or that I am trying to run as a derivative candidate. So it's a complex relationship, just as most human relationships are."
Gore advisers acknowledge that this is an important week for the Clinton/Gore relationship. And they acknowledge that Mr. Gore's selection of a running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, who was the first Democratic senator to openly chastise Mr. Clinton for his behavior, was part of the larger process of trying to inoculate himself against Mr. Clinton's behavior.
For his part, Mr. Clinton, who arrived in Los Angeles today for Mr. Gore's nominating convention, is charting his own course in how a president ought to hand off the baton. He has already broken with the tradition of past presidents who arrived just as the conventions for their vice presidents were set to begin.
At Los Angeles International Airport, a reporter shouted to Mr. Clinton that his vice president was concerned that the president was overshadowing him. Mr. Clinton tilted his head back, laughed and said: "I've never heard him say that."
While Mr. Clinton is attending several galas in his honor, aides said the president would spend much of his time polishing his speech. Mr. Clinton intends to give a valedictory address that is shorter than former President Reagan's 53-minute speech in New Orleans but just as focused on making the case for 12 years of one-party rule. As is the custom, the White House has shared early drafts of the speech with Mr. Gore. White House officials have told the Gore campaign there will be no surprises.
Reviewing the hubbub over the day and Mr. Clinton's comments, Gore advisers said all the media's roiling and roar over the Clinton-Gore relationship today was nothing new, at least for the Gore campaign. Said one, "It's just another day at the office."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE ECONOMY;
News on Budgets, Homeownership and Jobs Is Wonderful, but It Isn't Helping Gore Yet

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
With less than three months until Election Day, Vice President Al Gore faces a crucial and perplexing question: why does his presidential campaign not seem to be benefiting from an economy that is as good as it gets?
Heading into the Democratic National Convention next week in Los Angeles, Mr. Gore can point to an array of indicators that would seem to work powerfully to the advantage of the incumbent party in the White House, especially when today's economic conditions are compared with those that the Clinton administration inherited seven and a half years ago. 
Unemployment is down to levels not seen in a generation. Incomes and homeownership are up. Budget deficits have given way to huge surpluses, and the stock market has generated staggering wealth.
It may be too early to count the economy out as a big factor in Mr. Gore's favor. But so far, prosperity's glow has done little for him.
Not only has he trailed Gov. George W. Bush of Texas in nearly every national poll for months, but his efforts to portray himself as a superior steward of the economy have also fallen flat.
A New York Times/CBS News Poll last month found that 75 percent of voters said they believed Mr. Gore was likely to keep the economy strong if elected president, compared with 71 percent for Mr. Bush, a statistical dead heat. Asked which candidate would do a better job of managing the economy, respondents in a Business Week/Harris Poll last month favored Mr. Bush by 51 percent to 33 percent.
"At the moment, the economy is not cutting for Gore as much as I would like," said Al From, president of the Democratic Leadership Council, a group of centrist Democrats.
Political analysts and officials of both parties said Mr. Gore might have hurt himself to a degree by failing to stick to a simple, consistent message about the economy, especially during the spring, when he veered into issues like the Elian Gonzalez case. And they said Mr. Bush had artfully tried to shift the debate from who gets credit for prosperity to what should be done with it.
But they said the real difficulty for Mr. Gore might be that times had been good for so long that voters took prosperity for granted.
"Al Gore's biggest problem on the economy is that this recovery has been going on much longer than any previous recovery," said Robert B. Reich, who served as labor secretary in President Clinton's first term. "It's become almost background noise, and people assume the good economy will just keep on rolling."
Not only do voters show little willingness to grant credit to Mr. Gore, analysts said, but the electorate also does not see either candidate as having much control over an economy that seems increasingly driven by technological advances, globalization and other forces beyond the control of any administration.
"In the economy we're in now, the public doesn't buy the idea that the economy is good because of the Clinton-Gore administration, and they'd be just as disinclined to credit the Republican Congress," said Mickey Edwards, a former Republican congressman from Oklahoma who is now a professor at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.
Still, experience suggests that when Election Day rolls around, a fat and happy electorate is likely to think hard before throwing an incumbent party out of the White House.
Some analysts -- as well as Mr. Gore's aides -- point to the last time a sitting vice president ran for president with a strong economy at his back -- in 1988, when Governor Bush's father faced Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts. For most of the summer, Mr. Bush was behind despite nearly six years of steady economic expansion and an unemployment rate that had been halved, to 5.4 percent, since 1982.
A Gallup poll in June 1988 showed Mr. Dukakis ahead by 52 percent to 38 percent, and when asked which candidate would do a better job keeping the country prosperous, voters ranked the candidates evenly at around 40 percent. But by November, Mr. Bush had a 52-to-35 advantage on economic management in the Gallup poll, and he won the election comfortably.
"History says that people's perceptions of a sitting vice president's capability with regard to the economy can change," said Andrew Kohut, a pollster who is director of the Pew Research Center for People and the Press.
Mark Fabiani, Mr. Gore's deputy campaign manager for communications, said most voters had not yet focused on the election, and that when they did, they would conclude that Mr. Gore had supported and shaped the policies that had brought the economy to where it was and that his approach was more prudent than his rival's.
And he said Mr. Gore would seek to link Governor Bush's economic plans to those of his father, who presided over a recession that contributed to his defeat in 1992.
"People in the end will focus on the economy as the most important issue, and in the end will focus on whether we're on the right economic track and whether they are better off than they were four or eight years ago," Mr. Fabiani said. "The answers to those questions are good for Gore and bad for Bush."
If anything, Mr. Gore is emphasizing the economy more as the campaign progresses, using a message that has two distinct components.
One is unabashedly populist, and is aimed in part at the party's liberal base and at people who do not feel that they have fully benefited from the boom. It is built around the assertion -- challenged by Republicans -- that Mr. Bush's economic platform amounts to tax cuts for the wealthy, an overhaul of Social Security that would leave the retirement security of working people at risk and deference to powerful special interests like oil and pharmaceutical companies.
The other is a promise to continue the policies of fiscal responsibility that helped bring about budget surpluses and reduced interest rates. This portion of his message is intended to emphasize continuity with one of the most successful elements of Mr. Clinton's record and to appeal to moderate swing voters.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE BENEFACTORS;
Moving Heaven and Earth For the City of Angels

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11

 BODY:
He helped lead the charge to lure the Democratic National Convention. He helped finish the fund-raising for a grand new concert hall. He helped recruit the new school superintendent. He founded one art museum and has plans to vastly expand another, and to revive a historically anemic downtown. He's the mayor's best friend, and helped bankroll campaigns to elect a new school board and pass a new city charter. And, oh, did we mention, he's the richest man in town, worth more than $5 billion?
Almost every sphere of civic life in Los Angeles these days bears the fingerprints of one soft-spoken, silver-haired 67-year-old man: Eli Broad, chairman and chief executive of Sun America Inc., the financial services and investment giant that for most of the 1990's was the fastest-growing company on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 The Bronx-born son of Lithuanian Jewish immigrants who began his career at 21 as the youngest certified public accountant in Michigan history, then developed a home-building empire that stretched from Detroit to Los Angeles, Mr. Broad has in the last few years become his adopted city's ultimate go-to guy.
As the Democrats arrive next week, Mr. Broad (rhymes with road) will be front and center to welcome them, though perhaps not as front and center as he wished. He did not get either the speaking slot at the convention or the skybox at the Staples Center that he had asked for. (He will have to share one of three skyboxes with the local host committee, of which he is a co-chairman and to which he gave $1 million while helping raise several times that.)
But Mr. Broad, and his supporters and critics alike, are quick to agree that he has flourished in Los Angeles as he could have in few other cities, if any, where tradition, schools, clubs and old-boy networks matter more and moxie and money matter less.
"It's very simple," Mr. Broad said as the afternoon sun filtered over a broad swath of Beverly Hills outside his office window. "It's a meritocracy. You can come here without the right family background, which I don't have, the right religion, the right political affiliation, and if you're willing to reach out and really work and spend your time, energy and sometimes your money, you're accepted. That's not true of most other cities in the world or North America.
"And that's one of the reasons I love the city, because it's allowed me to do all this."
Former Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor, who has known him since they worked on Alan Cranston's campaign for the United States Senate more than 30 years ago, said Mr. Broad "is making a herculean effort to fill a vacuum" in Los Angeles's civic leadership.
"When he does something, he does it all out," Mr. Kantor said. "Most of the time he succeeds. Sometimes he does not. But the fact is that some people, whether they are threatened by it or resent it, are irritated by anyone who pushes that hard and demands action. He does not sit around and suffer inaction."
Mayor Richard J. Riordan, a Republican businessman who has recruited Mr. Broad, a lifelong Democrat, to help in innumerable civic causes, finds a more mischievous way to describe his friend's bluntness: "Eli knows nothing about foreplay."
The convention is a case in point. Mr. Broad was among a handful of people who wanted the chance to show off the city's recovery from the fires, earthquake, riots and recession of the early 1990's, and was one of the original co-chairmen of the local host committee, which pledged to finance the convention by raising more than $35 million and to use city money only for typically municipal services like transportation and security.
Los Angeles got the convention, but ever since has had trouble raising the promised money. And Mr. Broad has complained publicly and privately that at least one of his fellow co-chairmen, the record and movie mogul David Geffen, failed to put up any of his own.
Andy Spahn, Mr. Geffen's chief political aide, said Mr. Geffen had made clear from the beginning that he would help bring the convention to Los Angeles but intended to direct his fund-raising and contribution efforts to the actual electing of Democrats, beginning with Vice President Al Gore.
"This is a case of no good deed going unpunished," Mr. Spahn said.
But bad blood and embarrassing headlines have lingered for months.
"What happened?" Mr. Broad said of the controversy. "I'll tell you what happened. I got all the press, that's what happened. And why did I get all the press? I was there."
Every city has a cadre of civic leaders who support the elected government, raise money for cultural institutions and charitable causes, and offer private advice to public figures. In the 1950's and 60's, Los Angeles itself had the Committee of 25, a shadowy conclave of businessmen who helped pick candidates for appointment or election to public office and generally set the tone in the city until the Watts riots set off changes in the municipal power structure.
But with a shift in the region's economy from large, home-grown industries like aerospace to multimedia conglomerates, with a wave of mergers and acquisitions that have left downtown Los Angeles lacking a headquarters of a single Fortune 500 company, and with his own considerable ambition, Mr. Broad has emerged as a virtual committee of one, or, as he puts it, a venture philanthropist.
That has not always endeared him to some officials and fellow billionaires here, who complain -- invariably under cloak of anonymity -- that he is too quick to claim credit, too willing to hog the spotlight, too wrapped up in his own pet projects.
"I've got a big ego," Mr. Broad said matter-of-factly in a recent interview in his 38th-floor headquarters in a Century City office tower. "I like to be thought of well."
But Mr. Broad is also something of a rarity in an age of handlers and spin doctors, consultants and retainers. He returns his own phone calls, often flies commercial and still shows up at the kinds of business breakfasts and chicken dinners that most moguls eschew. A few years ago, he used his American Express card to buy a Roy Lichtenstein at Sotheby's for $2.5 million, because he had calculated the interest he could earn by delaying the payment for a month. (He also got 2.5 million frequent-flier miles, most of which he gave away to a local arts college for student travel.)
"Usually, people are visionaries or doers, but not both," said Mr. Riordan, who regularly vacations with Mr. Broad on cruises and bike and ski trips. "He is both a visionary and an incredible doer, who gets onto something like a pit bull and won't let go until he gets it done. To a point that drives you nuts sometimes. On vacation, you want to avoid him. He spent our last vacation, in Sun Valley, on four major topics of what the city needed to do. I just wanted to run the other way."
Asked a couple of years ago what Mr. Broad wanted, one leading Angeleno, a respected graybeard among the city's power players, said, "I think he wants to be the single most influential private citizen in Los Angeles," adding with a chuckle, "And he's got the money to do it."
Mr. Broad has not managed to get everything he wants -- his bid to draw a National Football League team to a revamped Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum failed last year, as did his rivals' -- but it is not for lack of trying.
Associates say that working for him is like working for a jackhammer, that he is fair but relentless, keeping four aides busy in his outer office alone. Golf and other leisure activities hold not the slightest allure; he keeps his perpetual tan by holding long business meetings or reading papers outdoors. His speech, in the flat accent of Michigan, is economical, tending to omit prepositions and definite articles, so that he says, "I was born New York City." Even his passion, collecting modern art, is a business, with a curator and a lending foundation.
His impatience is also legendary. A few years ago, irked that the world-famous architect Frank Gehry was taking too long to finish his new house in the Brentwood section, Mr. Broad hired another architect, with the result that Mr. Gehry disowned the house. (That feud threatened to derail Mr. Broad's later efforts to raise money to finish the Disney Concert Hall in downtown Los Angeles, which Mr. Gehry also designed, but things were smoothed over.) Just now, on the site of two former houses in Malibu, Mr. Broad is building a 4,000-square-foot beach house designed by Richard Meier, who designed the new Getty Center here.
"It's a white Richard Meier house," Mr. Broad said, "and I think white Richard Meier houses look great in beach areas."
Mr. Broad's current projects, both just beginning, are an expansion of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, on whose board he serves, with a new wing and pedestrian arcade (an effort to which he will presumably give millions of dollars) and a public-private undertaking to revive Grand Avenue, the downtown street that is already home to the Los Angeles Music Center and the Museum of Contemporary Art (which Mr. Broad helped found 20 years ago) and that will soon see the completion of the Disney hall and a new cathedral for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles. Just talking about downtown gets him so excited that he pulls out a pad and starts sketching his vision of a new park, pedestrian-friendly sidewalks, restaurants and so on.
"We don't own anything downtown," Mr. Broad said. "All downtown does is cost me a lot of money. But every great metropolitan area needs a core. This city doesn't have any real core. It doesn't have a place where people from different communities can come for free concerts."
Some elected officials have complained that Mr. Broad involves himself in matters, like selecting a new school superintendent, that are none of his business. But he professes pride in such involvement.
"If I think I'm doing what's right," he said, "I think at the end of the day people will appreciate it and I'll feel good about it. And along the way I'm not looking for votes."
