LENGTH: 952 words

HEADLINE: Workouts That Fit the Lives Of Harried Commuters

BYLINE: By ROBERT WORTH

DATELINE: LARCHMONT

 BODY:
EVERY weekday evening, as the northbound train stops at Larchmont and exhales a crowd of weary commuters, a dozen or so head for the New York Sports Club less than a quarter mile away.
This has become a ritual at stations along the suburban lines that fan out from Manhattan near which two major fitness club chains have been building or buying facilities over the last five years. Operating clubs in the city as well as the suburbs, the chains hope to lure commuters by offering a choice of exercise in either spot. 
 "It's definitely an urban-suburban strategy," said Alex Alimanestianu, chief development officer for Town Sports International, the owner of New York Sports Clubs, the largest chain in the New York area. "We've built our cluster of clubs with a view to putting them where people live and work in a defined geographic area."
Town Sports, which operates 70 clubs in the New York metropolitan region, has bought clubs close to the train stations and major highways in Scarsdale, Larchmont, Mamaroneck, White Plains and Croton. Mr. Alimanestianu said that it was hard to find space close to train stations, but the rents were reasonable "because retailers generally want to be on the main street."
Town Sports also owns clubs close to Penn Station and Grand Central Terminal to give commuters the option of exercising before they catch the train.
"That's really been a cardinal principle of our site selection," he said. "In any suburban location we want to be close to the transportation hubs, be they bus or train lines or the PATH train in New Jersey."
Bally Total Fitness, the nation's largest health club chain, has used the same approach. The company owns 40 clubs in the vicinity of New York City, including three in Westchester, and plans to build more.
"We locate clubs where they can fit into the lives of members most naturally," said David Southern, an executive vice president at Bally.
Studies have shown that health clubs draw 90 percent of their membership within a 10- to 15-minute walking distance, said Bill Howland, director of research at the International Health, Racquet and Sports Club Association, a nonprofit group that tracks the industry.
"This club is on my route," said Valerie Kirby, a dark-haired woman in a blue Nike workout suit, as she pumped her arms back and forth on a Lifefitness crosstrainer at the New York Sports Club in Larchmont.
A banker with NatWest, Ms. Krauss said she catches the 5:13 train from Grand Central to Larchmont, then walks down the hill past the club on her way home. "I'd rather go here than in the city, where I'm not sure I'll get to the train on time," she said.
Like most commuters, Ms. Krauss has a narrow window for exercise. She has to be home by 7, when the nanny who takes care of her two children leaves. (The nanny, who is also a club member, then comes the Larchmont club for her own workout.) The club's site near the train station and just off Interstate 95 allows her to exercise without going out of her way.
If her schedule changes and she is left with free time in the city, she can use another of the club's outlets, a few blocks from her office at 41st and Park Avenue. Her husband is also a member, she said, and he prefers to use one of the city outlets.
So many of the Larchmont club's members are commuters that the train times dictate the ebb and flow of people here, the club's fitness manager, Geoffrey Braham, said.
"With the train schedule, you kind of know -- the 6:31 pulls in, and you get a lot of people," Mr. Braham said.
"I can see five or six people who took the train out here with me," said Kermit Patterson, a burly college student from Larchmont who is spending the summer working for an investment bank in the city and spends two hours at the club every day after work.
The Larchmont club is typical in another sense: it was owned by an independent operator until New York Sports bought it and remodeled it two years ago.
Although health clubs remain a highly fragmented industry, several large chains, including Town Sports and Bally, have been aggressively buying up independent clubs and smaller chains. Of the roughly 12,500 commercial clubs in the United States, 30 to 40 percent are owned by chains, up from about 25 percent five years ago, said Rick Devereux, director of operations at the international sports club association.
The expanding suburban market has accelerated the pace of consolidation, because unlike their competitors, the chains can offer members the choice of a workout in any of dozens of regional facilities. All of New York Sports' membership plans, which run from $67 to $83 a month with initiation fees of between $149 and $199, allow members access to all the company's clubs, said Jodie Meltzer, the Westchester area manager for Town Sports.
"It is a leveragable selling feature if you can say we can take care of you in Manhattan and in Rye," Mr. Howland said.
Town Sports built its first suburban club in Great Neck on Long Island in 1986, Mr. Alimanestianu said. "We noticed pretty quickly that people joining in the city were using the Great Neck club and people in Great Neck were using the city locations," Mr. Alimanestianu said. Half of Town Sports' 100 locations nationwide are now in suburbs.
The company's expansion did not take off, however, until the mid- 1990's, when health club membership soared, fueled by the economic boom and the growing popularity of cardiovascular exercise.
Club membership soared to 30.6 million members nationwide in 1999, from 20.7 million in 1990, reported Harvey Lauer, president of American Sports Data of Hartsdale, a company that specializes in sports and fitness research.

HEADLINE: An Artist Whose Canvas Is a Cluttered Taco Stand

BYLINE: By DEBRA WEST

DATELINE: PATTERSON

 BODY:
ROSEMARY JAMISON, a Texan who came to New York in the 1960's in search of a bigger canvas for her art, opened a restaurant here and has been filling it ever since with things like fake shark heads and black lights, bird cages and oil paintings, Life Magazines, pool ladders, armless mannequins and oddities of all sorts.
And, oh yes, she serves tacos, too. 
 Walking into Rosemary's Texas Taco on Route 22 at Haviland Hollow Road is a little like falling through Alice's rabbit hole: it's dark, it's crowded with non sequiturs, and it feels like a flashback.
"Oh, I studied art in college," said Ms. Jamison, 58, her drawl still evident. "But it was like making a little charcoal sketch of a cow skull for days, and I want big."
For about 22 years this restaurant has been Ms. Jamison's art project, first love and home (for nine years she had another spot farther up the road). With Route 22 poised for more development, however, the restaurant building and the land is for sale. The landlord, Janet Hansen, said she wanted to sell now while the economy was good.
"It's a great spot," Ms. Hansen said. "Rosemary has been doing very well here, and she doesn't want to leave.
"I feel heartbroken. I wish she could afford to buy the property herself, but she can't."
Ms. Jamison, who swore off marriage as a girl and calls her art and her waitresses her babies, said the asking price for the property was $324,000, and that it was just too high for her.
"I don't make any money here," she said. "This is a labor of love."
If that is the case, then love must be pink and aquamarine with a hearty dose of glitter.
Everything Ms. Jamison touches she turns to art. Her sidewalk is more Peter Max than Putnam County. Her vehicles are decorative first, functional second.
Her 1961 Chevrolet Apache pick-up truck, no longer used, is intricately outfitted with beads, dolls and various knickknacks.
Her converted small school bus, which she drives to haul her finds back from the Patterson flea market each weekend ("I'm always the first one there"), is also a mass of color.
Her backyard is faux beach club. "It's like you're in the bottom of a pool," she said. "I want people to feel cool and refreshed."
Her bathroom: "Pretend you fell into an aquarium."
But no canvas is more artfully crafted than the 4-foot-11 Ms. Jamison herself.
Twice a week, she colors her hair purple, using a mix of "trench mouth medicine and manic panic" hair dye "to give it more of a violet touch than pure purple," she said.
She bats her three-inch-long eyelashes knowingly, revealing an arc of black eyeshadow, while she talks about her dreams of franchising Rosemary's Texas Taco.
"Don't you think there's room for some competition to Taco Bell?" she asked hopefully, while acknowledging that it might be difficult to duplicate the charms of Rosemary's.
Then she disclosed her true secret hope for the future of her restaurant.
"Maybe nobody will buy it, and I can stay," she whispered. DEBRA WEST

HEADLINE: Putnam's Growth Poses a Threat To the Charms Of a Rural Road

BYLINE: By DEBRA WEST

DATELINE: BREWSTER

 BODY:
THERE was a time when the advertising slogan of the Putnam County Visitors' Bureau, "Where the Country Begins," seemed the perfect description of Route 22, the main road here.
Drivers heading north from New York City and Westchester could jostle with traffic on the parkways and then race up I-684, where no matter how fast they were driving, it wasn't fast enough for the tailgater behind them. But once they crossed the bridge over the Croton River and got onto Route 22, they could relax. 
 The two-lane road, lush with swamp maples, oak trees and untamed shrubs, first forced drivers to slow to country pace, then opened up to a vista of old-time American enterprise. A drive-in hamburger stand, diners, bait and tackle shops, a survivalist's outlet, a cattle ranch, a taco restaurant with more kitsch than kitchen and even a modest ski slope add to the hokey charm of the road.
These days, however, suburbia has caught up with Route 22. Traffic has slowed from a leisurely trot to a frustrating crawl, and the State Department of Transportation, which has been contemplating widening the road for at least 15 years, says that, come fall, it will unveil its plan for expansion at a series of public hearings.
"It's about time," said Celeste Bachrach, 48, an art teacher from Southeast (more commonly known by its mailing address, Brewster). "They should have widened it a long time ago. What were they waiting for?"
Like many in the towns of Southeast and Patterson, Mrs. Bachrach settled in Putnam County because it was a fast drive to Westchester, where her husband works.
"The only reason I got him to move to Brewster was because we could live right off Route 22," said Mrs. Bachrach, who moved from Mount Kisco in 1987. "Now, that traffic just makes me crazy. I will go to any length to avoid 22."
And she means any length.
Instead of going to a Chinese restaurant less than a half mile away on Route 22, for instance, Mrs. Bachrach drives to Danbury, a round trip of 18 miles, for takeout.
"It takes me forever to get there and back," she said. "But I get so aggravated and my level of stress gets so high in traffic, it's worth it to me to take a little longer."
Route 22 was once a main thoroughfare from New York City to Canada, but over the years it has been bisected and marginalized throughout Westchester. In Putnam County, however, it remains a major north-south road. It is also the state's easternmost major road, making it attractive to drivers heading to New England.
The section of the road the state is now considering widening is just 3.1 miles long. It starts at the end of I-684 and goes to Doansburg Road, said Brian J. Doherty the Route 22 project manager for the Department of Transportation.
The proposed $25 million project would widen the road to four lanes and add a median divider from the Interstate to the first stop light, at Milltown Road. The four lanes would continue but instead of having a raised median it would be divided by a center turning lane. The project would end just past the State Police barracks.
The project, which has been discussed since the mid-1980's, has been held up by, among other things, concerns about New York City's water. The section of Route 22 to be widened is bounded on both sides by reservoirs that are part of the Croton Reservoir System. To the east, just beyond the road, lies the East Branch Reservoir. To the west lies the Bog Brook Reservoir.
In the fall the Department of Transportation will complete its environmental assessment. Public hearings will be held, and the state will evaluate comments. If the plan is approved, construction is expected to begin in 2002, Mr. Doherty said.
When construction is contemplated in watershed territory, however, nothing moves quickly. One 1997 proposal involved filling in a portion of the Bog Brook Reservoir.
"When we saw it, we said 'Oh wow!,"' said Geoffrey C. Ryan, a spokesman for the New York City Department of Environmental Protection. "We are certainly not interested in having any incursion in our reservoir."
So the state scrapped that plan.
While the issues are being resolved, traffic continues to grow. Last year, there were about 26,000 cars on the 3.1 mile stretch of road each day. The road averages about 85 accidents a year, Mr. Doherty said.
Traffic is expected to increase by 1 percent every year for the next 20 years, Mr. Doherty said, as a housing boom continues.
In 1990 Putnam County, which has six towns and is the state's smallest county, had 83,941 residents. By July 1998, the population had jumped to 93,358, and demographers expect another big jump in the 2000 census.
In Dutchess County, the next county north, the population rose 3.4 percent from 1990 to 1999, to 268,237. But in Dutchess, new housing permits suggest that the boom is just beginning. There are 106 major residential projects (of 25 residences or more) planned or under construction in Dutchess, said Lindsay Carille, a junior planner in the county's Planning Department.
More houses translate into more traffic.
"The traffic really started to get bad in the 80's with the last economic boom we had," Lois C. Zutell, the Southeast town supervisor, said. "For the amount of commuters we have now, I don't think you have any question that this road has to be fixed. The inconvenience it is causing is just unbelievable. Plus the Friday afternoon traffic with all the New Yorkers going up to the Berkshires is just too much."
But a lot of those weekend commuters like Route 22 for its old-fashioned feel.
Red Rooster, a drive-in that started as an ice cream parlor in the early 60's, is a particular favorite of the country house set. On Friday evenings and again on Sunday afternoons the parking lot fills with Range Rovers, Lexus sport utility vehicles and Mercedes convertibles, whose drivers make a ritual of stopping off during their trips from Manhattan to the Berkshires or Millwood or some other lush country haunt.
"Our clientele is very exclusive," said Jack Sypek, 62, a manager and one-time part owner who has worked at Red Rooster for 29 years. "Doctors, lawyers, movie stars, they all come here. Kevin Bacon, Michael J. Fox, Sam Waterson, James Earl Jones, you name it, they stop here. They like the atmosphere."
There's a lot to like. Red Rooster, which regularly gets good ratings in Zagat's dining guides and has been voted one of the nation's best hamburger havens by those who vote on such things, is steeped in nostalgia.
Clean-cut teenagers in crisp white uniforms serve fast food with manners and enthusiasm straight out of the 50's. Customers squeeze into the tiny vestibule that was added in the 70's and then bring their food out to one of the 25 picnic tables. Adults eat and chat while children climb a graceful apple tree. There's room to walk the dog and a somewhat faded miniature golf course, which features one hole with Porky Pig (par 3) and another with Bugs Bunny (par 2).
Tim Pasik, who lives on 72nd Street and Park Avenue in Manhattan and drives with his three children, his wife and two nannies to his country home in Salisbury on most weekends, looks forward to his weekly stop at the Red Rooster.
"If we get here in time for dinner, we do dinner," said Mr. Pasik, 40, a reinsurance underwriter. "If not, we get ice cream and coffee. We stop here all the time. We wouldn't miss it."
Under the proposed widening plan, Route 22 would have to veer more to the Red Rooster side of the road (the east side) than it does now in order to preserve a pre-Revolutionary War graveyard just a bit north. Red Rooster would lose most of its parking lot and all of its miniature golf course, Mr. Sypek said.
"Don't worry, we have plans," Mr. Sypek said. "We own the land next to us, and we'll rebuild."
But it remains to be seen whether making changes to Red Rooster, which, Mr. Sypek said, is now "doing as much business as we can handle," will affect its fortunes. After all, one of Red Rooster's charms is that it's not something designed to look retro. It's the real thing.
"They don't pay you for loss of business," Mr. Sypek said. "They just pay you for what they take."
Edward R. Heelan, president of Heelan Realty and Development Corporation in Brewster, is skeptical that the road expansion will take place anytime soon.
"I've heard that before," he said. "They've been singing that song for 20 years."
He thinks the state's delay on the road expansion is hurting Putnam County's tax base. Businesses are going elsewhere because they don't like the traffic problem on Route 22. Mr. Heelan represents the owners of 1,000 acres of land that is currently for sale along Route 22.
"You need commercial development to offset all the residential development that's going on," Mr. Heelan said. "Route 22 is a prime avenue for that. I took out a client today who wanted to build a 60,000-square-foot facility. He wouldn't even look at 22. There is a cloud hanging over it. People want to know, Where will the road go, where will the turnarounds be, what will traffic be like?"
He added that the planned expansion doesn't go far enough.
"When they finish up to Doansburg Road, they'll have to start the next section, up through Patterson," he said.
Some people fear that if the road is widened it will begin to resemble Central Avenue in Yonkers and lose its country flavor, green space and mom-and-pop shops.
"Nobody's for that," said Sean Diggin, whose family owns two motels, Heidi's Inn and the Bel Air Motor Lodge.
Heidi's, with 40 rooms, a restaurant and a pool, is old Brewster. It will benefit from road construction because the plan is to move the road away from Heidi's to straighten out a bad curve, Mr. Diggin said.
"It used to be like the Poconos, a summer resort," Mr. Diggin said. "You'd have to make reservations a year in advance."
But the Bel Air Motor Lodge, an unassuming stopover for truck drivers and construction workers, may have to close. The road will take over its parking lot and the land where its well lies.
"They say we can relocate it, but I don't know where," Mr. Diggin said.
It has been a long time since a spot alongside Route 22 was considered a summer resort. Two shopping plazas were built in the last five years, each with its own A.&P., Blockbuster Video and Dollar stores, and the plazas are just eight miles apart.
Edie Keasbey, 70, has lived in Patterson, just down the road from one of the new shopping plazas, since 1938.
She is a member of watchdog organizations like the Croton Watershed Clean Water Coalition, and for decades she has watched as farm lands sprouted housing developments, wetlands were filled in and country roads were paved over.
"Basically, improvements in roads leads to more development and more traffic and more over everything we are trying to put a brake on up here," she said. "It's such a vicious circle."

HEADLINE: Q & A/Daniel C. Esty;
Long-Term Optimist for the Environment

BYLINE: By ALAN BISBORT

 BODY:
DANIEL C. ESTY, director of the Yale Center for Environmental Law and Policy, thinks the environment will not be taken seriously around the world, until it is given a number. "What is important gets measured," Mr. Esty said, but that kind of analytical approach is rarely focused on the natural world.
Mr. Esty proposed to change all that to include the environment in the equation and the result is called the Pilot Environmental Sustainability Index. The purpose of the index, which grew out of a February workshop at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, is to "measure the ability of economies to achieve environmentally sustainable development," Mr. Esty said. In other words, it is a report card on the state of the environment in a number of countries. 
 The numbers he has crunched, obtained through the Center for International Earth Science Information Network at Columbia University, have already generated the sort of heated but healthy dialogue he had anticipated.
To create the index, Mr. Esty, his Yale colleagues, and members of the World Economic Forum's Global Leaders of Tomorrow (a select group of promising young people who, in the past, have included Bill Gates, the Treasury Secretary Larry Summers and Mr. Esty), took data from 57 countries and looked at 65 variables. The countries who were graded and then ranked were those for which reliable data existed. .
The resultis what Mr. Esty calls "something like a batting average or cumulative grade- point average."
The index hasn't been perfected, which is why it's a "pilot," said Mr. Esty, who plans to expand the survey next year to 100 countries.
A one-time administrator at the Environmental Protection Agency, Mr. Esty has put his global perspective to work locally, having served on Cheshire's Planning and Zoning Commission for five years. Describing s himself as a "short-term pessimist but long-term optimist," he said he was committed to the long haul of reversing the havoc of the "experiment" on the earth. Mr. Esty was interviewed at his New Haven office. Here are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. Your index has the United States ranked 16th. Why isn't it closer to the top?
A. If there was a direct correlation between economic wealth and environmental health, the U.S. would be tops in both. A significant percentage of reaction is "Oh my goodness, the U.S. is doing so poorly, what's going on?" But there's another reaction, particularly from Europeans who perceive us as foot-dragging on critical issues like climate change, that we are ranked as high as we are. Both myths get burst. The U.S. is riding high and everything is fine is not true, and this puts numbers to that reality. But, also the perception that the U.S. is abominable is also unveiled as not true.
Q. Were there any surprises in the results things you never suspected?
A. The biggest single surprise is how high Russia ranks at 22. We know their performance is terrible, and yet what has saved them is that they have a vast open space in Siberia. So that on certain criteria they rank high simply as a function of having Siberia. But if one looked at pollution control in Russia's cities, it's horrible. They rank at the bottom. The opposite is true in Singapore, a country we know is sophisticated in its environmental management. But Singapore is a city state that sits at the edge of sustainability on a number of issues. It has no place to put garbage, it doesn't have adequate water, it's up against critical limits. So, even excellent management does not produce a high score on the index.
Q. Can't a number of these countries with low scores be said to have inherited their problems, in that much of the worldwide environmental awareness rose only after the damage was done?
A. Some countries are still on the industrialized trajectory. One wants to get to China, Thailand, Vietnam, before they deepen their hole. One chart in the index plots competitiveness against environmental performance and what you see is that there is no trade-off; countries doing well economically take necessary environmental steps. But the chart also shows, clearly, that you don't get rich by getting dirty. That whole theory of development is strongly disproved.
Look at Sweden and Belgium. They're roughly the same on competitiveness, but look how much better Sweden does than Belgium on the environment. Given an equal economic success, a country can do different things to their environment. Belgium is riddled with dioxins, and it shows up on the index. Sweden is fifth, Belgium 23rd, below Russia.
Q. Isn't this is one of the more optimistic aspects of the index, that it is an ongoing thing?
A. Exactly. The truth is that as we move forward this can only improve, because we discard shaky data sets and replace them with more systematically gathered data. And we broaden the number of countries included as these countries develop the data we need. One of the positive things that came out of this were the number of countries that called, mailed, or e-mailed, saying "Why didn't you include us?" Our answer was simple: "We just don't have enough data from you." People are upset about being ranked low but it's worse to not be ranked at all, because it takes you off the list of countries taken seriously.
Q. Doesn't it sometimes feel like the human genome project of the environment?
A. It's very complex, and there's a tendency in politics and media to simplify. We're saying go the other way, accept the complexity. This index only begins to tell the story. The question it doesn't answer, yet, is "which policies matter?"
Q. What is the reaction to the index from business leaders around the world?
A. We know that a significant percent of business community takes the environment seriously. For those who do, the index is not a surprise. The brighter companies today understand that investing in the environment does not undermine their economic position. One of the things we hope to do with this index is to show that those old attitudes are not in touch with the current wisdom about how you want to promote economic development.
Think about what the developing countries' representatives were saying at the World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle: "Don't hold us to environmental standards, it'll hold us back." That's based on old, disproved economic misconceptions.

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 5; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: LAW ENFORCEMENT;
Is Putnam the Safest County? Uh, Not Exactly

BYLINE: By AL BAKER

 BODY:
AS the parting shot in a one-page news release, it almost went unnoticed: "Putnam County is considered the safest county in the state of New York."
But from the cornfields of Tioga County, in northwest New York, to the bedroom neighborhoods of Madison County, in the geographic center of the state, the words drew a surprising response. 
 "That seems kind of braggadocio," Peter L. Ward, the chairman of the County Legislature in Tioga, said of Putnam's declaration.
The sheriff of Putnam County issued the statement in June, citing 1999 statistics in four crime categories. But in a follow-up interview, the sheriff, Robert Thouborron, admitted that his comments might have been made hastily. The state's Division of Criminal Justice Services has yet to issue its 1999 report, so Putnam's crime data cannot be compared with other counties.
"If the headline is, 'Sheriff Misleads Public,' then you got me," Mr. Thoubboron said. "We should have said we are one of the safest."
Taking credit for cutting crime is nothing new. Everyone from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to President Clinton has done it. The political and economic benefit of a perceived sense of safety is often the motive, criminologists say.
But tiny increases or decreases in statistics, especially in counties or cities where the crime rate is already low, can cause dramatic swings in percentages that render them meaningless. For example, an increase of one violent crime a year would double the crime rate in Hamilton County but would barely be felt in a place like Yonkers.
It's not that Putnam is lying.
"When you deal with smaller jurisdictions like this, the numbers can fluctuate from year to year, quite wildly," said James Alan Fox, Lipman professor of criminal justice at Northeastern University in Boston. "You have to take not just with a grain of salt but with the whole shaker of salt claims by a county saying that they are the safest."
According to the state's most recent report in 1998, four counties in New York had lower rates of violent crime per 100,000 people than Putnam: Hamilton, Madison, Schuyler and Tioga.
Thomas M. Gifford, the chairman of the Schuyler County Legislature, said that he has known people who have moved to Schuyler from Putnam for safety.
Michael J. Maloney, the Schuyler County sheriff, said he has not studied the numbers but believes "we probably have the lowest amount of violent crime," in the state. In fact, its rate is the second lowest, after Hamilton.
"You can walk around the streets here at night all by yourself and you don't have to worry about anybody driving up to you doing bodily harm," Mr. Gifford said.
Of course, Schuyler County is so rural (it has 18,500 residents) that, as Mr. Gifford said, "a lot of the streets here don't have lights, sidewalks or pavement."
In Putnam County, with a population of 93,000, Mr. Thoubboron said robberies were cut in half, to 7 last year from 14 in 1998. That is less than the number of robberies that can occur in one night in one police precinct in the Bronx.
Burglaries, Mr. Thoubboron said, dropped by 32 percent in Putnam, to 232 last year from 302 in 1998. Motor vehicle thefts went down 53 percent in the same period, he said.
Those drops were on top of crime rates already among the state's lowest, according to the state's 1998 report on crime.
Among counties with populations between 50,000 and 100,000, Putnam had the lowest index crime rate that year, a rate calculated by adding the total number of violent crimes to property crimes, dividing by the county population and multiplying by 100,000.
Mr. Thoubboron ended his June 8 statement by saying Putnam's decrease "is in large part due to the professional and dedicated law enforcement officers in the various departments that serve our community." Translation: good cops.
But experts say crime often runs in cycles, its rates more a product of sociological trends than enforcement strategies. If a county wants to claim to be the safest, it must be safe in all areas of crime, not just four or five categories, said Alfred Blumstein, a criminologist at Carnegie Melon University.
"The one I find most reliable is homicide rates," Mr. Blumstein said.
Putnam County had four homicides in 1999, according to the records provided by Mr. Thoubboron. One case, on New Year's Eve, was memorable for its horror: a Carmel woman killed her two sons, her husband and herself.
When asked to recall the last homicide in Madison County (population 70,000) Rocco J. DiVeronica, the chairman of the county's Board of Supervisors, conceded he was stumped.
"You mean just a regular outright murder?" Mr. DiVeronica said. "I don't know. About 13 years ago we had a brother killed a brother.
"Boy, I know there's been some suicides," he added, pausing to think for a moment. "That's an interesting question."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1510 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Using the Internet to Lower Costs and Sell Houses

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
IT didn't take long for DeLanee J. Collins to decide to sell her house in Tinton Falls through an Internet brokerage company rather than a traditional one. For the technologically savvy Ms. Collins the reason was simple: to save money.
That was the promise of the company she used, Your Home Direct.com, based in West Long Branch. The company began operations in March under the premise that by linking the Internet with a range of real estate services it could make the process of buying and selling a home more efficient and less costly. 
 Depending on the services provided through its licensed real estate agents under three different sales programs, Your Home Direct charges 2 to 3.9 percent of the sales price. This compares with the 6 percent commission that has become the industry standard for traditional brokerage companies. The Web addresses for Your Home Direct are www.yhd.com or yourhome direct.com.
Ms. Collins listed her home with Your Home Direct after hearing its ad on the radio and calling for a demonstration. "It seemed like a win-win situation," Ms. Collins said, without "any greater risk than I would have with a traditional brokerage." Ms. Collins, 36, a single parent with two sons, is an international project manager at Avaya Communications in Holmdel, formerly Lucent Technologies
Jason and Jennifer Walk bought Ms. Collins's contemporary with three bedrooms and a loft. "I saw a virtual tour of the house and fell in love with it," Mr. Walk said. "From my perspective I wasn't gaining or losing anything by buying this way."
There are a handful of traditional discount brokerages in New Jersey, including Lake Realty in Brick. Since the agency's founding in 1993, Sherif Selim, the owner, said he had been charging commissions ranging from 0.75 percent to 3.75 percent to sellers in Ocean and Monmouth Counties.
But Your Home Direct bills itself as the first full-service licensed Internet-based company in the state.
Internet real estate sites have been around for several years and have evolved from offering bare-bones property listings to providing lots of features, including data on neighborhoods as well as links to lenders and house inspectors. While such sites can save home buyers and sellers time by enabling them to narrow their search for houses and services online, many ultimately steered prospective buyers to traditional brokerage companies.
With Your Home Direct, Glenn E. Cohen, a 38-year-old lawyer, has expanded the concept of e-brokerage by combining the Internet's time-saving features with flesh-and-blood brokers. Earlier, Mr. Cohen worked for his family's brokerage company in Shrewsbury, selling subdivision sites to developers.
Initially backed by $2.8 million from investors, including the state's largest home builder, K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, Your Home Direct secured an additional $8 million in venture capital and established five offices in the state. It has 70 employees, 50 of them licensed agents. Since it started, the company has listed about 1,000 houses, mostly resales but a few new homes, Mr. Cohen said. Buyers have signed contracts on 275 and closed on 85, he said.
The company says its fees are low because its overhead is low, its brokers spend far fewer hours than conventional brokers in showing property, and they work on a salaried rather than on a commission basis. They don't attend closings or home inspections, as many conventional brokers do, and in some cases they don't accompany the buyer on visits to the houses. In May the company added a mortgage subsidiary, yhd Capital.com.
Conventional brokers questions whether services like Your Home Direct maintain large enough staffs of knowledgeable brokers to keep customers up-to-date about local market conditions. The suggestion is that a conventional broker might be able to get a better price for the seller.
Your Home Direct replies that the time-saving feature of the Internet used in combination with real brokers serves customers well. "Without the efficiency of the Internet we don't exist, and without the services we don't exist," Mr. Cohen said.
THE company joins a growing number of e-brokerage companies that have sprung up across the nation in the last two years as a "bricks and clicks" alternative to the conventional "bricks and mortar" way of buying and selling homes.
Others include zipRealty.com in Berkeley, Calif.; eRealty.com in Houston; and Homebytes in Richmond, Va. Last month, Homebytes became the first e-brokerage company to be licensed in every state; it intends to be fully operational in New Jersey by the end of September.
While some companies like Your Home Direct offer a range of fees based on the services the sellers want, others charge a set price. Homebytes, for instance, charges sellers a one-time fee of $499, which includes listing the home on the local Multiple Listing Service, the bible of available properties, and establishing a sales price. The company's agents also advise sellers on how to sell their houses via telephone and the Internet.
Referring to discount e-brokerage companies generally, Dennis R. Cronk, the president of the National Association of Realtors in Washington, said: "If they fit some consumers' needs, they will be utilized. But in the past discount brokerages have never reached any level of success in the business."
Walter Baczkowski Jr., the executive vice president of the New Jersey Association of Realtors in Edison, said that a "good real estate market hides many evils." The test "is how well these business models can withstand a bad economy," he said, adding that "there is only so much venture capital to go around.'
Under each of Your Home Direct's three sales programs it offers such basic services as listing the houses, with digital pictures and computerized tours on real estate Web sites, and marketing the houses through tradition print advertisements and "for sale" signs. The company prequalifies all prospective buyers and provides online links to a network of professionals.
The lowest commission Your Home Direct charges in 2 percent. For that, sellers get the basic listing services but must show their homes themselves.
For a 3 percent percent commission, an agent will provide the seller with a marketing plan and with help on setting a realistic price, will show the house and will handle all negotiations.
For a 3.9 percent commission the company will also list the home with the local Multiple Listing Service. Under this plan if the house is sold through the buyer's broker, that broker gets 2.5 percent of the 3.9 percent commission; the Your Home Direct agent gets the remaining 1.3 percent.
To sell her Tinton Falls house, Ms. Collins selected the 3 percent plan, and the house was shown to five prospective buyers, including the Walks. After negotiating to have some minor repairs done, the Walks offered to pay Ms. Collins's full asking price of $229,900. She, in turn, paid Your Home Direct a $6,897 commission, compared with the $13,794 she would have paid a broker charging the standard 6 percent. "Along with the savings," Ms. Collins said, "it was a relatively hassle-free experience."
A recent survey of 20,000 buyers conducted by the National Association of Realtors showed that 37 percent of the home shoppers used the Internet as "as search tool," up from 18 percent in 1997 and from 2 percent in 1995, said Mr. Gronk, the group's president. But he added that 49 percent of the respondents said they actually found their homes through a local Multiple Listing Service, compared with 4 percent who found their homes through the Internet.
"The industry is changing, and Realtors have to prove they add value," Mr. Gronk said. "But today and in the past, sellers have migrated to full-service real estate brokerages." If commissions "are ridiculously low, they ultimately must ask, 'What am I getting and not getting,' " he said.
But Nick Karris, a real estate analyst for Gomez Advisors, an Internet research firm in Lincoln, Mass., said that e-brokerage companies are changing the way business is done.
"These are not fly-by-night companies that just put up fancy Web sites," he said. The consumer "is no longer at the mercy" of the traditional real estate agent or of the traditional 6 percent sales commission.
Executives at many established real estate firms in New Jersey acknowledged that by challenging the conventional pricing of brokerage services, e-brokerage companies like Your Home Direct would appeal to some but certainly not all consumers.
"There are certain things that can't be done unless Realtors rub elbows with buyers and sellers in the field," said Jack Waters, a regional vice president, in the Matawan office, of Weichert Realtors, one of the state's largest residential brokerage companies. "That's where the business is done, not on a laptop."
For his part, Mr. Cohen said that Your Home Direct would not overtake traditional full-service real estate companies. "But we will take a piece of the market," he said.

HEADLINE: Port Norris, One Bead on a String of Isolated Coastal Hamlets

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: PORT NORRIS

 BODY:
JOHN LAWS'S service station, with two pumps, is the last one in town, now that the Mobil station has closed. Mr. Laws, who is 63, can remember when there were seven, and he can remember the two clothing stores, the barber shop, the movie theater, the hardware store, the pool hall and the A&P. And those were just some of the businesses on Main Street.
"You didn't have to leave to do anything," Mr. Laws said as he stood outside Laws & Laws service station and hardware store, the busiest place in town on this hot weekday morning. 
 Now, you have to leave Port Norris to do practically everything. There is just Laws & Laws and Newcomb's grocery across the street, and a small pizzeria. There is no pharmacy, no laundry, no library, no liquor store, no diner. The two doctors in town just gave notice that they will be moving to Millville, 12 miles away.
From its docks on the Maurice River, this settlement in Commercial Township used to send Delaware Bay oysters north by the boxcar. But since a blight devastated the beds in the 1950's, Port Norris has been emptying. An industry that once had 4,500 workers has fewer than 200 today, and nothing has come to take its place.
And now Port Norris, with 1,000 to 1,500 residents, is just the biggest bead on a string of tidewater hamlets -- Dividing Creek, Turkey Point Corner, Cedarville -- on the edge of the vast bayside marsh, their clapboard buildings peeling, their commercial centers an occasional grocery with a wooden floor and their residents separated by miles of lowland farms from any sign of New Jersey's labor-hungry suburbs.
Unemployment rates are not broken down by municipality, but the Commercial Township mayor, George Garrison, said joblessness here was "in the double digits, and I'm sure of that much."
Commercial Township is not the poorest municipality in Cumberland County -- average incomes in Bridgeton and Fairfield and Maurice River Townships are lower -- but it cannot support itself.
The township's chief financial officer, Judson Moore, said the biggest tax-paying industry was sand mining, which provided few jobs. The biggest employer, Mr. Moore said, is the school district, with 70 to 80 employees.
Otherwise, the jobs are in Millville and Vineland, at least 20 minutes away. The nearest supermarket is in Millville, too.
Port Norris's ambitions now center on its future as a site for development as part of a federal empowerment zone for distressed areas. The designation brings many forms of aid, which local officials want to use for a wastewater treatment plant, among other things, needed to draw business back to the waterfront.
They also want to bring tourists to the waterfront, consisting of the fishing villages of Shellpile and Bivalve, with its marinas and its unspoiled view across the river's mouth.
But sometimes development presents a bind, too. "If we ever get a water and sewer treatment plant down here, people have to start paying fees," Mr. Moore said. "But there are a lot of poor people in this town. I've talked to senior citizens who have an income of $7,600 for the whole year."
Nor are people clamoring for strip malls and entertainment parks, although Port Norris could use bus service -- to Millville, or anywhere.
"This is a pretty isolated corner of New Jersey," said Stephen Kehs, the director of economic development for Cumberland County. "Most of the people I've spoken to in these little bayshore towns and villages like it that way."
Isolation has its advantages for Port Norris. "There's not a lot to spend dollars on," Mr. Moore said. "But we're hoping people rediscover it."

PUB-DATE: August 13, 2000

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2714 words

HEADLINE: To Sprawl, or Not to Sprawl

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: MILLVILLE

 BODY:
SOME things down here refuse to change. In the 1980's, anticipating the completion of Route 55, speculators from the north bought 38 acres next to Roger Ruske's farm here, paying $2,800 an acre. The highway arrived, but not much else. Last year, Mr. Ruske bought the property -- for $1,100 an acre.
If sprawl is New Jersey's most persistent blight, then the south of South Jersey is its last unscarred territory. Largely beyond the reach -- or consciousness -- of Philadelphia, and in no way commutable from New York or North Jersey, Cumberland and Salem Counties have a life apart from the rest of the state. 
 These two counties contain 2.5 percent of New Jersey's population of eight million and about a quarter of its agricultural production, which was $800 million in 1998. Between them they have three movie theaters, a dozen farm equipment dealers and not one Starbucks.
The biggest private school is the Cumberland Christian School. Roadside churches have lawns full of cars on Sunday morning. Some families sell garden produce by setting it on a card table in the front yard and leaving a coffee can for payments.
Most people want these things to stay this way. But everybody wants some other things to change:
Both counties have fewer jobs than they did 10 years ago. Per-capita income is barely two-thirds of the statewide figure of $31,265 -- or about the level of Georgia's.
While 25 percent of all adults in New Jersey are college graduates, the proportion in Salem and Cumberland is 10 to 12 percent.
In the big city, the old manufacturing and farm-market center of Vineland, the main street is strung with nail salons and dollar stores. In the smaller cities -- Bridgeton, Salem, Penns Grove -- many buildings wear plywood and for-rent signs.
The south seems to illustrate a principle of economic development: to be unspoiled is to be left behind. James W. Hughes, the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy, said: "It's a classic rural dilemma. What type of growth do you want?"
Once, the growth was industrial. And to be sure, some industry is contemporary and prospering, especially in a band along the Delaware River from the DuPont laboratories in northern Salem County to the three nuclear power plants clustered in the south. But the glass industry has withered, and the canneries and textile factories are largely abandoned.
In the last decade, not much has changed, including the population. From 1990 to 1998, according to census estimates, Salem County lost a few hundred residents, slipping to 64,912 from 65,294, and Cumberland County had gained a few thousand, to 140,341 from 138,053.
People down here -- and they call it "down here" -- are always weighing the tradeoffs they make. As the glass and canning industries departed, the south welcomed prisons (Cumberland County has four) and nuclear plants and sent residents to casino jobs an hour or more away. The towns along the Delaware Bay are peaceful, untrammeled by urbanites in search of vacation homes -- and they are disturbingly poor. Agriculture is healthy, but as a tax base farms cannot compare with office buildings.
In his office at Cumberland Nurseries, Mr. Ruske, for one, readily allowed that "Cumberland County is the poorest county in the state; we're on the top of all the bad lists and at the bottom of all the good lists."
But he added: "We are the richer part of the state, if you consider the quality of life. Do you want open spaces or million-dollar houses that you have in Monmouth County? We're left out, but I still think that's good."
In Shiloh, about three miles west of Bridgeton, where a few weathered stores cluster around a single blinking traffic light, Frank Noyes considered the problem from the counter of his auto repair shop, a business his father started in 1942. "This area is probably as depressed as any area around, but it's a great place to live," Mr. Noyes said. "I don't think in New Jersey you could find a better place."
In Fortescue, Shirley Fonash said the visitors to the tiny village on Delaware Bay and to her waterfront restaurant, the Charlesworth, came because "they've heard we're a step back in time."
But her daughter, Cindy Fay, a computer programmer who lives in Vineland and waits tables on weekends, said she could stand to see Cumberland County's quaintness compromised by some four-lane highways. "Why should we have to drive an hour, be it to Cherry Hill or Wilmington, to get a decent-paying technical position?" Mrs. Fay asked. "We are not just tomato pickers."
Indeed, if it seems that a local economy cannot thrive without an outbreak of office parks and mini-mansions, planners and economists say that is probably the case. The gap between north and south has been a fact for decades, if not centuries. But in the last 30 years, at least in terms of income, it has grown: In 1969, per-capita income was 28 percent higher in the five northeastern counties than in Salem and Cumberland; in 1997 it was 47 percent higher.
Mr. Hughes of Rutgers said the disparity would most likely grow as the inner cities and truly rural areas were left farther behind. In the south, below what he calls "the commutershed" of Philadelphia, Mr. Hughes said, "You're not going to get office development, and for manufacturing you don't have the highly skilled labor force you need."
Thomas Hamer, a professor of economics at Rowan University in Glassboro, said that "at the risk of being one in favor of sprawl, to get development we've got to extend the sprawl into those two counties.
"The only way to do that is pave a freeway," Professor Hamer said. "Until that happens, they'll continue to be remote because of the transportation time and cost."
There are many people, especially in Salem County, who say they would rather be remote.
John A. Kugler, a Salem County freeholder, said that when local officials convened four years ago to redraw the county's master plan, they intended to deflect development to I-295 and the turnpike and the nearby industrial band on the Delaware River -- and for the rest of the county to be left alone.
On a drive through Aldine, just above the Cumberland County line, Mr. Kugler paused where the cows take their 250-yard daily walk down the main thoroughfare to the milking barns.
Proceeding north into Gloucester County, he nodded toward a giant clot of town houses and scattered subdivisions looking raw on the treeless terrain.
"This is what we're trying to avoid," he said. "It's choking the school system."
And while Salem County has helped finance an industrial park and an office complex on I-295 that will employ thousands of workers, "we don't want them to live here," Mr. Kugler said. "We want them to come in from someplace in Pennsylvania."
So far, Salem County has had its wish: last year, a total of 144 new housing units were authorized by building permits. (Cumberland had 370; by contrast, Gloucester had 1,539, Burlington 2,933 and Ocean 4,155.)
"The county is a real throwback," said Patricia DiMatteo Knobloch, the director of economic development. "It hasn't stopped in time, but it's been able to preserve the best of what was in New Jersey. It's one of the few places where you can write a check without having to show the history of your life."
This is hardly a preserve of gentleman farmers. The county ranks 18th of the state's 21 in per-capita income, down from 13th 30 years ago. Prices for the main crops, soybeans and corn, have plunged. The city of Salem is poorer than Trenton or Asbury Park.
Still, Salem County's unemployment rate is a respectable 3.8 percent, and it ranks near the top in average wage for nonfarm workers, thanks to high-paying jobs in the nuclear power plants on the river and in chemical manufacturing and research.
"We don't have to be pro-development," Ms. Knobloch said. She added that the area's farmers, many from families who settled here 200 or 300 years ago, were unusually reluctant to sell; it took her 11 years to persuade one to part with a parcel for an industrial park at an interchange.
If Ms. Knobloch is gingerly trying to find places for development, her counterpart in Cumberland County, Stephen Kehs, is simply trying to find development. "We've got plenty of land around Millville and Vineland and Bridgeton," Mr. Kehs said. "We have to be looking for new jobs. We've still got an unemployment rate of 7.2 percent."
That rate is a big improvement from the bleak 1980's, when unemployment approached 20 percent, but it is still by far the highest in New Jersey.
The economic recovery in the 1990's saw more and more Cumberland County residents go to work in the four prisons, which now employ about 5,000 people, or one in 12 workers, and casinos in Atlantic City, employing about 2,000.
Cumberland is celebrating its recent designation as a federal empowerment zone, giving the county millions of dollars in aid and enabling it to offer tax credits and other incentives to businesses. "For better or worse," Mr. Kehs said, the county was eligible because the poverty rate exceeded 20 percent in parts of Vineland and Bridgeton.
"Everybody leaves," said Shirley Spencer of Vineland, on a stroll with her husband, Cleo, at the Cumberland County Fair. Mrs. Spencer said of their six children, all of whom went to college, "They couldn't stay in Vineland because there's nothing for them."
"One of my daughters graduated from law school, and for all the places she looked for work here, she couldn't find anything."
Mrs. Spencer said she suspected something more than economic stagnation -- "in my opinion it was because she was black and she was a woman" -- but she also doubted that Vineland would ever recover.
"When the plants were open, everybody was working," said Mrs. Spencer, who retired as a cook in the public schools. "Now, there are so many people without jobs and no transportation to get people to where they are."
Many of those who manage to stay have been buffeted.
"If you want a good job, you've got to travel an hour, an hour and a half," said Ira Morris, a boat builder at Silverton Marine Corporation in Millville. For a while, Mr. Morris had to commute to Atlantic County for a job, almost two hours each way.
Sean Tomlin is trying to stay here, too, starting his own Web-design business, Loaded Media, in a commercial building on High Street in downtown Millville. At 24, Mr. Tomlin has already ridden the employment seesaw in his hometown, which is always seeing jobs come and go.
His employer, until it laid off most of its staff last winter, was Camanco Communications, an ambitious start-up that provided Internet access to computers in hotel rooms. Mr. Tomlin said about 250 people lost their jobs, including many people who had relocated from as far away as Nebraska and California.
"It was great," Mr. Tomlin said as he took a break on a July afternoon when High Street was looking tidy but ghostly. "Stock options, competitive pay. There were some very talented people working there. That's what I miss the most."
Mr. Kehs hopes the county can draw some more information-technology employers, but he also wants ware housing, food processing and other industries that can absorb what he calls the "hard-to-reach remnant" of the work force stranded when the glass and textile factories closed.
And in that market, the competition is not New York or Bergen County but the south. "We're beginning to market our part of the state as an alternative to the Carolinas," Mr. Kehs said. "We have the same kinds of affordable land, labor and economic opportunities."
Mr. Kehs can also advertise one advantage unknown in the rest of New Jersey: affordable housing. Last year, the National Association of Home Builders named the Vineland-Millville-Bridgeton area the nation's 11th most affordable market, a measure comparing home prices and median income.
And while local governments chase ratables, the lag in development is good for agriculture, still crucial to the economy here. Wesley Kline, an agricultural agent for Cumberland County, said that "if agriculture is going to survive in New Jersey, it's going to survive here in Cumberland County."
Mr. Ruske, the nursery owner, agrees, even while he says the state's farmland preservation program is of little use to local growers because their development rights command so little. "I've heard for the 35 years I've lived here that things are going to get better, and it hasn't," he said. "Yet agriculture has gotten better."
"We don't have the impediment of housing," he said, "and agriculture is important to the right people -- the freeholders, the planning boards." At the same time, he said, the growers here have become some of the most proficient and productive in the country.
Mr. Ruske, who just stepped down as president of the state board of agriculture, is a third-generation nurseryman, having moved from Connecticut in 1967 in search of land that someone just out of college could afford. His is a family farm, in that his 31-year-old son, Chris, plans to take it over, but Mr. Ruske is impatient with the sentimental image of farm life.
"Most people's picture of the family farm is 'American Gothic,' " he said. "It's subsistence farming. That's absolute nonsense."
His own sector of the agricultural economy is burgeoning along with the suburbs from Maine to Virginia; on his 275 acres are yews, holly and viburnum for the fresh landscapes of office parks and subdivisions. "It's the right industry with the right product at the right time," he said, "which is why we make money."
The farm lobby points out at every opportunity that New Jersey's farmland is the most expensive and highly taxed in the nation, and that dairy and grain farmers are under siege here, as everywhere. But the old-fashioned South Jersey family truck farm is getting along.
"I bought my farm as a farm, and this is how I want to make a living," said Andrew Buzby, who grows fruit and vegetables in Salem County. He has 13 laborers this summer, but also relies on his wife, his three sons and his 73-year-old father.
"It's a real good way to make a living if you can do it," Mr. Buzby said.
There's another promising industry here -- or at least one without a downside -- and that is marketing the beauty here in the southern part of the state. Mr. Kehs said, for example, that in the fishing and birding season there were more than 100,000 vehicle trips just to the tiny bay village of Fortescue.
Mrs. Fonash, at the Charlesworth Restaurant and Hotel, has seen many of the visitors, fishers on the boats and birders in the reeds, who make the 10-minute drive from the nearest through road.
A jumble of cottages and mobile homes with about 300 year-round residents, Fortescue is decidedly unpolished. But that's why people like it, Ms. Fonash said: "People are looking for the hidden away, less exploited places. And we are hidden away."
Fortescue was not always so undiscovered. The Charlesworth, built in 1924, once looked out on a beach and a boardwalk, which led to a pavilion for dancing for summer crowds. But storms obliterated beach, boardwalk and tourism, and the Charlesworth, which had been the height of elegance, closed nine years ago.
When she and her husband, Jim, bought the business two years later and reopened it, "some kind of higher power was directing us, or else it was a total stroke of idiocy," Mrs. Fonash said. But now their dining room, an everybody-knows-everybody kind of place with a table of Europeans or New Yorkers here and there, is usually full, and their five guest rooms usually booked.
"We haven't made a nickel on it, to tell the truth," Mrs. Fonash said while the accordion player set up and the kitchen clanged on a recent Friday night. "But we've come so far in seven years."
Her daughter, Mrs. Fay, paused on her way to the kitchen to continue a conversation. "And I want a four-year college that's less than a 45-minute commute," she said.
Then Mrs. Fonash continued, too, remarking on the boats that dot the bay on summer weekends. "It looks like somebody threw out confetti," she said. "We'd love to expand because the potential is here. It's here. Last year I wouldn't have said that, but this year I know."
