The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: August 13, 2000

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 3289 words

HEADLINE: On 14th Street, Less Grit, More Glamour

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
IN a city where the names of some neighborhoods bestow cachet and some addresses are dropped like royal titles, 14th Street has probably never achieved even a minor peerage.
Never mind, says Gary Gaines, an importer who is about to trade in an apartment off Sutton Place for a loft in the Greenwich, a cavernous former department store at 14th Street and the Avenue of the Americas. He has bought 2,150 square feet of finished but unpartitioned space on the third floor. 
 Mr. Gaines's neighbors at the Greenwich will include other migrants from uptown, among them Brian Brooks, who sold his apartment at the venerable Beresford on Central Park West, and Joel Solomon, who lives on the Upper East Side at 80th Street and Third Avenue. Mr. Solomon bought a loft for his 25-year-old son, Stephen, and a penthouse for himself.
"I will miss the seclusion and seeing Bobby Short in my elevator," Mr. Gaines said, "but I like living in the new, being part of something happening. Fourteenth Street is on the threshold of a major transformation, and this building is at its center."
People already living on or near 14th Street would probably say that it has already crossed that threshold, starting with the city's $3.6 million reconstruction of Union Square Park in 1983 and the 1987 opening of the Zeckendorf Towers, a 652-apartment condominium and office complex.
But subsequent and future projects give weight to Mr. Gaines's notion that another threshold has been reached.
The signs of change are noticeable from the western end of the street at least as far east as First Avenue, where Stuyvesant Town dominates the landscape. (Even there, new fencing and ornamental gate posts are planned, and new trees are to be planted.)
These changes are giving 14th Street a new persona as a residential boulevard, a booming retail thoroughfare and a mecca for high-tech enterprises.
At the western side, near 10th Avenue, art galleries, trendy restaurants, late-night clubs and one of the city's highest-fashion emporiums are bringing elegance and verve to the gritty meatpacking district.
From Eighth to Fifth Avenues, new technology and dot.com companies are clamoring for space, joining the publishers, photographers, graphic designers and advertising agencies already encamped there. An eyesore was removed recently when the long-empty 14th Street Armory was torn down earlier this year to make way for two new apartment towers and a Y.M.C.A.
On the east side of the street, further improvements are planned for Union Square Park. The city has earmarked $2.5 million to expand the park by 20,000 square feet at its southwest corner between 14th and 15th Streets.
East of the park, New York University is expanding its domain, constructing a 16-story dormitory on the site of the old Palladium nightclub. The new building is two doors away from a 19-story N.Y.U. dorm completed two years ago. The university has also signed a lease for a 14-story building being put up by Alex Forkosh, a developer, on the site of former Sahara Hotel, once a notorious single-room-occupancy hotel and drug haven at 14th Street and Third Avenue.
David Gmach, the executive director of both the 14th Street-Union Square Business Improvement District and the 14th Street-Union Square Local Development Corporation, considers the conversion of the Sahara and the demolition of the 14th Street Armory, both of which were symptomatic of decay, to be hallmarks of the changes that have swept across the entire street.
Where the armory stood between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, two residential towers will be developed by the Orda Management Corporation and the Related Companies. One will contain 60 luxury condominiums for N.Y.U. faculty members; the other will be a rental with 225 units, 20 percent of which will be reserved for low-income tenants. The McBurney Y.M.C.A. will occupy two floors at the base of the building.
"I would be surprised if you could find another single street with that much going on in a two-to-three-year period," Mr. Gmach said during a recent walk from 10th Avenue to Avenue B. "There is at least one million square feet of development that has either been recently completed or is under way."
As much as any artery in the city, 14th Street, which is the dividing line between Chelsea and Greenwich Village and also borders the Flatiron district and the Ladies Mile Historic District, has flourished and withered and then flourished again.
A century ago, it was the cultural and political epicenter of the city: the Academy of Music, vaudeville theaters and Tammany Hall were all thriving. Before the rise of Fifth Avenue as a commercial hub, 14th Street was a retail center, housing the early quarters of Macy's, Tiffany's and Best & Company. When those stores moved uptown, bargain emporiums like S. Klein and J. W. Mays set the tone for the area.
Then about 35 years ago, the area began to slide into deterioration, its middle-class shops shuttered or replaced by cut-rate stores with flashy merchandise displayed on the sidewalk. Union Square became a magnet for drug dealers and derelicts.
"Mays went out, the recession came in, and so did the junkies," said Alex Barbagianis, an owner of Ariston Florist, which moved to 14th Street and Fifth Avenue nine years ago after 16 years in a location a block to the west. "You could buy any kind of dope here, and we had a tough time."
Then, several significant changes took place, and a turnaround seemed possible. The Union Square Greenmarket was established in 1976, the city refurbished the park, and Zeckendorf Towers opened on the site of the former S. Klein store at Union Square East.
As Chelsea became gentrified, lower Fifth Avenue acquired national retailers and chic shops, and stores like Bed Bath & Beyond and Barnes & Noble moved to the southern end of the Avenue of the Americas, it became all but inevitable that 14th Street would be upgraded.
"If Times Square is the crossroads of the world, then 14th Street is the crossroads of New York, because it's where uptown and downtown come together as a 24-hour community where people both live and work," said Mr. Gmach, the BID executive. "Everything New Yorkers could want is at their fingertips. There is a blend of activities and diversity here."
Although that assessment is widely shared, many would also agree that 14th Street is a work in progress, and more remains to be done to elevate it to first-class status. Some developers of residential property, for example, still insist on giving their buildings addresses on 13th or 15th Streets. Mosbacher Properties, the developer of the Greenwich, for example, plans to put the entrance on 13th Street.
"Fourteenth Street is one of the last major crosstown streets in the city to undergo improvement," said David Schore, the president of Mark Holdings, which recently bought the building at 25 West 14th Street. "Fifty-Seventh Street was always great, and 42nd and 34th now have a lot of new retailers."
If he were to measure, he said, "Forty-Second Street is 90 percent done, 34th is 50 percent done, and 14th is 50 percent done. There are still a lot of 99-cent and electronics stores, and those will be squeezed out by higher rents and hopefully higher-rent retailers. It will never be an upper Madison Avenue, but it could be a healthy extension of lower Fifth Avenue with a lot of national chains."
MR. SCHORE is in the process of turning his building into a combination retail and office space with a total of 70,000 square feet. "Even before I closed, and it was public that I was the buyer, I was getting constant calls from brokers," he said. "I have seen both new and traditional office users come in."
Lucille Strider, a broker who moved to 14th Street 11 years ago, contends that the street has already arrived. "I do retail and apartment rentals and apartment sales, and this area is hot as a pistol," she said. "Prices just keep going up. There is no cap. There seems to be constant need, and some days are like a feeding frenzy."
"Two years ago we were lucky to get $30 a square foot for retail space," she said. "Now it is between $75 and $100."
Ms. Strider has had a front-row seat for the evolution of her neighborhood. "I moved into a building between Fifth and University Place in 1989 that had a large OTB parlor downstairs," she said. "At 6 p.m. everything closed and shuttered, and it was like living in the Third World."
About seven years ago, OTB moved out and its premises were divided in half, with Radio Shack taking part of it and the rest remaining vacant. Now a day spa will move into the other half. The Garden of Eden, a specialty food shop that offers everything from charcuterie to caviar, has also recently moved into the building.
Andrew Rasiej, the chief executive and president of the Digital Club Network, an Internet company that cybercasts live concerts, in many ways typifies the kind of businessman who would not consider the more traditional Wall Street or Midtown areas for his office.
The founder of Irving Plaza, the music club on nearby Irving Place, he is negotiating a lease for a two-story former furniture store between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.
"I am in a Silicon Alley business, and it is important for my company and my employees to feel that they are in the middle of a network of Silicon Alley," he said. "There is no better place to feel like you're in the middle of the New York technology community than 14th Street because of its proximity to the Flatiron district and easy access to transportation."
Like many of his peers, Mr. Rasiej said lifestyle considerations were as important a part of his decision as the quality of the working space.
He noted that his 60 employees, soon to be expanded to 75, range in age from 22 to 35. "Most people in dot.coms work 10- to 12-hour days," he said. "For them to have any personal time, they need to be near home and near their social life. Nobody wants to commute an hour to get home or to a party. Being in the center, you have restaurants, bars, clubs, theaters, and good transportation is a recruiting asset." Fourteen subway lines and 14 bus routes converge on 14th Street, and so does the PATH line.
While there remain plenty of small and medium-sized buildings in the area, it is large complexes that have more dramatically changed its flavor.
Probably the most visible example is the Related Companies' building at 1 Union Square South. Situated between Broadway and Fourth Avenue across from Union Square Park and made distinctive by its giant steam-puffing sculpture, the building houses 240 apartments, a Virgin Megastore, a Circuit City Superstore and a 14-screen movie theater.
"That development with its mix of retail and residential has been a cornerstone of the revitalization of the area," said Mr. Gmach, the BID executive.
Another landmark on Union Square but one whose future seems unsure is the former Mays store, now occupied by a Bradlees. The Bradlees discount chain, which has declared bankruptcy, sold its lease back to the landlord, Vornado Realty, but obtained an agreement allowing it to remain in the building until March 2002. Wendi Kopsick, a spokeswoman for Vornado, would not comment on plans beyond that date.
But 14th Street is not only a commercial thoroughfare. With 100,000 students enrolled at N.Y.U., the New School University, Pratt Institute, Baruch College, Cooper Union and Cardozo Law School, all near 14th Street, it is an academic hub. "That's bigger than Ohio State and Notre Dame combined," said Jeffrey Roseman, the executive vice president of Newmark New Spectrum Retail, which is leasing and marketing several projects in the area.
Two years ago, N.Y.U. put up a $55 million dormitory on the old Luchow's site between Third and Fourth Avenues, to accommodate 600 students, and now it is building another dormitory for 1,000 students two doors away. This dorm, on the site of the former Palladium, will cost $120 million. The dorms flank P. C. Richards, one of the first chain stores to venture as far east as Third Avenue. At the back of the buildings, the Genesis Robert F. Kennedy Apartments, a complex of 94 apartments on 13th Street for formerly homeless and low-income people, offers on-site social services. "This shows the neighborhood will continue to have a diverse population," Mr. Gmach said.
LYNNE P. BROWN, the associate vice president for government and community relations at N.Y.U., said: "Twenty years ago with the problems in Union Square Park that drove everything else out, we wouldn't have considered putting students there. Now we are happy to be part of the mix not only out of self-interest, which means finding a congenial area for students, but we also like to think we're helping to move it one more step to its renaissance."
Pratt Institute has bought seven stories in a converted factory at 142-144 West 14th Street because it has outgrown its space in the Puck Building in SoHo. Administrators and trustees of Pratt, whose main campus is in Brooklyn, spent two years scouring Lower Manhattan for a new site before choosing the one on 14th Street.
"It had about 80,000 square feet, it was in a superb location in regard to transportation, and it is in an area with a number of educational institutions with whom we interact," said Thomas F. Schutte, the president of Pratt. "We felt there was a buzz here, and we are just plain excited about it."
The street is also home to several major medical institutions, including the Beth Israel Medical Center's Phillips Ambulatory Care Center; the Elizabeth Seton Childbearing Center, which is affiliated with St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center; and New York Eye and Ear Infirmary.
One stretch that has been spruced up without losing its Old World charm is the tree-lined block between Second and Third Avenues, which has a variety of small shops and restaurants ranging from Jamaican to Filipino to Mexican.
"This block was one of the worst blocks and one of the last to change," said Daphne Mahoney, the owner of Daphne's Caribbean Express, known for its Jamaican meat patties. "There are more people working in the block, more security guards and more sanitation. And it is great to see N.Y.U. moving in here. I cater their students' end-of-exam parties."
John F. Mazzola opened a restaurant that bears his nickname, Johnny Mozzarella, four months ago. "I saw this was an up-and-coming area, but they needed a little Italian flair," he said.
Sprinkled from one end of the street to the other is a growing residential population, ranging from artists, who populated lofts in meatpacking buildings for years, to families and elderly people in Stuyvesant Town, whose southern border is 14th Street. In between are the renters and buyers in larger, sometimes more luxurious buildings.
Though it is residential conversions like the one in the stately landmark Bank Building at Eighth Avenue and 14th Street that are getting most of the attention, "not every development is a luxury condo," Mr. Gmach said, "and we now have buildings available that have never before been utilized as residential buildings."
In some of those, rents remain reasonable, but more often than not, they are escalating. For example, Charles Blaichman, a developer and builder, bought three rather nondescript mixed-use buildings at 18 and 20 East 14th Street and at 60 West 14th in a package deal for $7 million three years ago. He has turned the two buildings on East 14th into 62 apartments, ranging in size from 500-square-foot studios to 900-square-foot two-bedroom units for which he is charging $1,750 to $5,000 a month. He is now converting the West 14th building, which will have 65 apartments at comparable rents.
"I saw a real shortage of rental apartments downtown, so I never thought of selling condos or lofts," he said. "We rented very quickly, and we think there is still a big demand. They are well located, and things will only get better."
Whatever prosperity is to be found in the rental market is more than matched in the sales arena.
At the Greenwich, the former store at 14th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, where finished but unpartitioned lofts ranging in size from 766 square feet to 3,100 square feet are under construction, contracts have been signed for 69 of the 79 units. Prices range from $465,000 for the one studio in the building to $3.425 million for a penthouse with a giant terrace.
The average price per square foot is $692, and buyers have the option to configure rooms with their own architects or, for additional fees, to leave that to the building's designers, Franke Gottsegen Cox Architects in Manhattan. Many buyers have purchased more than one loft, including one who bought the entire seventh floor, said Michele Conte of Brown Harris Stevens, the building's director of sales.
Ms. Conte described her job as "having to guess what will sell two to three years ahead." "We have known for several years that a lot of uptown people would be moving downtown," she added.
Asked why buyers were willing to give up park or river vistas for views of the traffic on 14th Street, she said, "It is the lifestyle, the vibrancy of the street, the youthfulness, the creative electricity in the air," she added.
"The people who are buying are, by and large, new money, but they are people with a very down-to-earth attitude," she said. "They don't wear three-piece suits but jeans to work, and 80 percent of them are between 30 and 35 years old. This is smart money. It is not out to flash."
Indeed, Mr. Brooks, 44, the chief human resources officer for WPP, the marketing and communications conglomerate, who has lived in the Beresford for three years, said: "I am not leaving because of the building but because I concluded that I really want to live downtown. This is mostly about my perception that the old East Side-West Side divide in New York in terms of defining neighborhood characteristics is disappearing and is being replaced by an uptown-downtown dichotomy.
Mr. Solomon, who owns a moving and storage company, bought an apartment in the Greenwich for his son in October. Happily ensconced at Third Avenue and 80th Street after moving to the city from Great Neck, N.Y., he had no thought of uprooting himself again.
T HEN I began to think it's time to move," he said. "The East Side is very homogenous. If you've eaten in one Italian restaurant, you've eaten in them all."
Now he and his wife, Suzette, will move into a 2,661-square-foot penthouse loft at the Greenwich with a 2,057-square-foot terrace. "In our previous apartment I felt that though we lived in the city, we hadn't really moved in," he said.
Still, not everyone with ties to 14th Street views its evolution with unmitigated glee. Marcia Garcia-Starkey, a co-chairwoman of the 14th Street Special Committee that represents two community boards, worries that diversity will be engulfed by a tidal wave of chic.
"We don't want to turn 14th Street into an urban mall," she said, citing the loss of Dizzy Izzy's, a bagel store across the street from Markt, the Belgian bistro of the moment. "He was there for at least 20 years, but he couldn't afford the rent when the lease ran out," she said. "Dizzy Izzy's was a place where transgendered people gathered. When neighborhoods become upscale like Chelsea has, diversity goes out the window."
"At the corner of Seventh Avenue, there is a Cuban restaurant where you can get rice and beans, chicken or pork for $5," she continued. "Those are the kind of things that could disappear, and we don't want to see a 'white bread' 14th Street."

HEADLINE: Responding to Responses On 'What Would You Do?'

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The answers last Sunday to Peter Applebome's request for responses to his July 23 column about his decision not to confront a black man about loud rap music with X-rated lyrics he was playing in the presence of Mr. Applebome's young daughter revealed much about the respondents. Nowhere in evidence was there concern for the daughter in permitting her to be exposed to such vulgarity -- or to the display of cowardice and ignobility implicit in failing to oppose it -- or, for that matter, for all the other little daughters who will, likewise, eventually be exposed by the failure to act now.
The reasoning behind most of the respondents was the same ethic-less selfishness displayed by Mr. Applebome. "We have to put up with more and more thoughtlessness from others and really can't fight back," says Marian Parker. The thought of righteous opposition to indecency evidently never crosses her mind. "Why risk an altercation with someone you'll never see again?" asks Gene Busnar. Someone will see that man again; are their rights not to occupy some portion of your philosophy? "There is just too much rage floating around in society to make it worth any risk of your well-being, or even your life," observes Phyllis Lutzker. What kind of "life" is it to perpetually ignore evidences of inhumanity? 
 The responses that did not depict overweaning absorption with one's own survival alone displayed a penchant for embracing the insipid and meaningless. Austin J. Maher describes his wife as "lightheartedly" offering that she "really likes the beat of the music, but doesn't know about the lyrics." Truthfulness about her opinion of the music apparently takes a back seat to simply defusing the incident. D. Grace Challoner states that she resorts, simply, to rolling up the window and having a sing-along with her child -- inculcating the notion that evil is not to be countered, only run away from, leaving others to face it. Terrence Ripmaster offers only the observation that the makers of the rap music "generate billions of dollars into our economy."
The respondents all come from high-priced enclaves of the sort Mr. Applebome inhabits. Mr. Applebome speaks of "a sense of suburban politesse that trumps everything else." Such "politesse" appears to be to sacrificing ethics and principle just to cut someone not from the suburbs some slack. One detects feeling that, having skewered the public in so many other ways, the least the snotty rich can do is to allow those they see as their beasts of burden to act like the animals they perceive them to be, once in a while.
Mr. Applebome does, after all, conjure the image of a "working-class white kid" playing the rap music in a car next to him. Evidently, Mr. Applebome divorces himself from the working world. With the remuneration he is provided through the thought control articles he seems to perennially submit to the media, he seems in no hurry to consider himself part of the same masses he seeks to pattern the morality and manners of.
We all are responsible for making the civilization better, and the only way it can get better is if we do not just sit back and let the world overtake us. You have to be a participant in the world.
 
JULIAN PENROD
West Caldwell 
http://www.nytimes.com

LENGTH: 776 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
U.S. Remains Destination Of Choice For Investors

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE United States has been living through extraordinary economic times for so long now that fresh milestones sometimes pass with a yawn. With growth rates over 5 percent, subdued inflation, low unemployment, high productivity and strong corporate profits -- all with the expansion already a decade old -- it is hard to surprise people with good news.
But here is another sweet nugget to chew on: The unusually large gap between the performance of the United States economy of those of its main peers, Europe and Japan, is proving more sustainable than many economists expected. And the strong dollar that helped make it all possible continues to defy gravity. 
 Months after the sharp correction in the Nasdaq began last April, the dollar has not only failed to plunge against the yen and the euro as was once widely expected, but it has actually retouched its record highs against the euro and held steady against the yen.
Indeed, stock market nervousness aside, foreigners have arguably never had as much faith in the future of the American economy as they do today. The dollar's value is determined, in the simplest sense, by the confidence that the world has in the United States. And nothing that is happening here has persuaded foreigners that they would do better to put their money elsewhere.
The old economic laws suggest that this cannot go on indefinitely. In a sense, the United States has been living on borrowed money, running the largest trade and current account deficits in its history. That makes it more vulnerable to the whims of foreign trading partners. Fortunately, they seem to be as smitten by America's technology revolution as Americans are.
"They are not flinching," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Bank Securities in New York. "In terms of the new economy, Europe is still somewhat behind and Japan is seriously behind, and they cannot afford not to be here."
Perhaps the most popular script for a so-called hard landing of the American economy begins with a stock market correction, followed by a plunge in the supercharged dollar, reflecting the world's lowered hopes for growth and profits here.
If this country's major trading peers -- Europe, Japan, Canada and Mexico -- stopped recycling the dollars they earn by selling goods here into productive investments here, the dollar would quickly lose its strength. That would make imports more expensive, contribute to inflation, cause the Fed to raise interest rates and further undermine the stock market.
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers has been sufficiently concerned about such an outcome for the past year that he traveled the globe urging the country's economic peers to prod their economies to grow faster so that the world could "balance up," not "balance down." Europe has been growing only half as fast as the United States, and Japan's economy is flat, worsening the already severe American trade deficit.
A HARD landing could still happen if the stock market takes another dive. But the 30 percent correction in the Nasdaq was no minor blip, and it only slightly unnerved dollar investors, who have since sent the United States currency higher.
Exactly why is speculative. But the consensus is that foreign investors view America's technology prowess as far more resilient than a stock market bubble. And they are willing to keep investing in what is essentially a seller's market -- the high dollar making assets here very expensive.
One way that shows up is through mergers and acquisitions of American companies by foreigners, which have quickened this year from the already extraordinary rate of 1998 and 1999. Through early August, foreign companies had announced 1,202 deals to buy American companies, with the purchases valued at $266 billion. For all of 1999, there were 1,701 deals valued at $305 billion.
If that enthusiasm continues, it is not inconceivable that the record current account deficit could continue to expand without jeopardizing the dollar and the economy.
Rudi Dornbusch, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, says the United States, with its younger population, has long had lower savings rates and higher investment rates than Europe and Japan. That was true even when Japan seemed to be years ahead in manufacturing efficiency. But it is still true today, when both Japan and Europe lag far behind in technological innovation, he said.
"People who were worried about our deficit were wrong because they underestimated the appeal of our new economy," Mr. Dornbusch said. "It's as though there's both an oil and a gold rush, and it's all happening here."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Kenya Johnson, Michael Johnson

 BODY:
Kenya Latrell Johnson, a daughter of Josephine and Walter Johnson of Brooklyn, and Michael George Johnson, the son of Nancy and George Johnson of St. Albans, Queens, were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard J. Lawson performed the ceremony at the New Canaan Baptist Church in Brooklyn.
Mrs. Johnson, 29, works in Manhattan as the project manager in marketing for Discovery.com, the Web site for Discovery Communications, a media company. She graduated from Clark Atlanta University in Georgia. Her mother retired as a traffic enforcement agent with the New York Police Department. Her father, also retired, was a porter for the New York City Transit Authority. 
 Mr. Johnson, 27, is a senior planner with the New York City Economic Development Corporation. He graduated from the University of Virginia at Charlottesville. His mother is a real estate sales representative with Greene Team Realty in St. Albans. His father is a custodian with the New York City Board of Education.
The couple met the old-fashioned way: at church, specifically the New Canaan Baptist Church, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. They had grown up in that church together but over the years had exchanged no more than a polite "How are you?" They didn't even know each other's names.
In the fall of 1997, the bride, who had been working as a promotions coordinator at various Atlanta television stations, made the church one of her first stops after returning to Brooklyn. She had taken a job at a pay-per-view television service in Manhattan and was re-establishing her social life in New York.
Mr. Johnson was putting away his trumpet after playing for the Sunday morning service when she approached him. He, too, had recently returned to Brooklyn, after receiving a master's degree in city planning from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "I had recognized him from the church," Mrs. Johnson said.
The two commiserated about the task of finding jobs, and he took her business card. He was about to move to Maryland but called her a couple of times just to chat. About a week later, when job prospects in Maryland didn't pan out, he returned to New York and made a date.
By the end of the evening, Mr. Johnson said, he was seeing her "in a different light." She didn't have stars in her eyes yet, but she agreed to get together again.
"I liked his warmth," Mrs. Johnson remembered. "He was easy to be with. He loved his family and was intelligent." By the third or fourth date, he had won her over.
By December 1997, things were serious enough to make both sets of parents check to see if branches of the two family trees were somehow entwined. (They aren't. His roots are in Virginia, hers in North Carolina.) After he proposed last Christmas Eve, the jokes began.
"The whole church refers to us as Johnson & Johnson," the bride said. "They say, 'Here comes Johnson & Johnson -- not the baby powder, but the love crew.' "

HEADLINE: Reviving Hospitals' Health

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Hospital Chain's Critics Call Recovery Incomplete" (Aug. 6), which looked at the performance of the Tenet Healthcare Corporation:
As the hospital industry has undergone a remarkable transformation caused by Medicare cuts, managed care and new technology, Tenet has managed to build successful hospital networks in major markets that preserve access to local care for millions of patients. The company has accomplished this as many other hospital operators have suffered huge losses, dozens of hospitals have closed and thousands of workers have been laid off. 
 The article contains little of this important context. Much of the article seems drawn from controversy that surrounded Tenet's acquisition of not-for-profit hospitals in Los Angeles, Philadelphia and St. Louis two years ago.
Certainly, there were concerns raised then by community leaders and others unfamiliar with Tenet about how it would operate these facilities and whether it would continue to provide care for the poor. Yet there was little in the article to suggest how those acquisitions have turned out.
In 1998, Queen of Angels-Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Center in Los Angeles and St. Louis University Hospital in St. Louis joined Tenet in order to meet the tough economic challenges that threatened their future viability. Today, under Tenet ownership, both are stronger than ever. They have added services and, importantly, they have continued to provide the same level of care to the underserved in their communities. The controversy of two years ago has given way to a general recognition that Tenet has strengthened these important health care facilities that otherwise faced an uncertain future.
Two years ago, Tenet stepped in to rescue a network of venerable hospitals in Philadelphia that was within days of closing down after years of losses. Today, thanks to Tenet and the millions of dollars that it has invested, these local health care assets are very much on the mend. Recently, in fact, former President Gerald R. Ford was treated for a mild stroke at Tenet's Hahnemann University Hospital -- a facility that might not even still be open if Tenet had not saved it.
Tenet has achieved its current financial success by investing in its hospitals, making them efficient, emphasizing quality and service, and meeting the needs of the communities that it serves.
 
HARRY ANDERSON
Santa Barbara, Calif., Aug. 9
 
The writer is senior director of corporate communications at the Tenet Healthcare Corporation.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Wall St. and the Politics of the Status Quo

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON

 BODY:
WALL STREET'S political views are usually summed up with the simple logic that is a staple of junior high math. If all wealthy people are Republicans, and all bankers and traders are wealthy, then all bankers and traders are. . . .
To be sure, there are plenty of exceptions, most notably Robert E. Rubin, who jumped from running Goldman Sachs to become President Clinton's Treasury secretary and is now chairman of Citigroup's executive committee. But for both personal reasons (cut my taxes) and ideological ones (competition is good, except on investment banking fees), most financial professionals prefer the Republican mantra of smaller government programs, less regulation and, of course, lower taxes. 
 This year would seem to be no exception. The Republican candidate, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, is offering enough treats to warm even Gordon Gekko's heart. Mr. Bush wants to end the estate tax, cut income taxes and give people a chance to invest some of their Social Security taxes in the stock market. Vice President Al Gore, on the other side of the aisle, prefers tough environmental regulations and adding a prescription drug benefit to Medicare, a step that the drug industry opposes.
Yet Wall Street remains strangely tepid about Mr. Bush. What gives?
Just this: The last five years have been the best in the history of the United States capital markets. Since the end of 1994, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has more than tripled, and the value of United States stocks has risen by more than $10 trillion, to $16 trillion. The Street may be too conservative to thank Bill Clinton explicitly for its good fortune, but it is well aware that the federal budget surplus has played an integral role in powering the market higher.
To finance deficits, the government must sell bonds to investors, competing for capital that could otherwise be used to invest in stocks or corporate bonds. Government borrowings raise long-term interest rates, stifling economic growth.
But in the last five years, thanks to tax increases in 1990 and 1993 and relatively restrained government spending, the federal budget has gone from deficit to surplus. As a result, long-term interest rates have fallen from 8 percent to less than 6 percent, after dipping as low as 5 percent in late 1998. With lower interest rates and lots of capital available, companies of all sizes have been able to raise the money they need to grow. In turn, strong economic growth has stimulated consumer spending, raised tax revenue and increased the government's surplus, making even more capital available for private companies.
Sure, the surplus is not the only reason that the economy has performed so well lately. Information technology and the explosion of the Internet have probably been even more important. But investors are not interested in a return to deficit spending.
"Wall Street likes it just as it is and doesn't want to see any big policy changes," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer of the First Albany Corporation.
But both Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush are eager to get their hands on the surplus for new spending programs and tax cuts. Either move would be a mistake, said Byron Wien, chief United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. In fact, if the new president is able to spend the surplus, the Federal Reserve will probably raise short-term interest rates, Mr. Wien said. That's because the Fed is already worried that the United States economy is growing too fast and increasing the risk of inflation, and that deficits (or lower surpluses) will further stimulate the economy in the short run.
"I don't want either party's program to pass," Mr. Wien said.
Mr. Johnson agreed. While the Street has a slight preference for Mr. Bush, it would be happiest if neither party controls both the White House and Congress next year, he said. "I'd like to see a Republican president neutralized by a Democratic Congress," he said. "Give us policy gridlock."

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
Speaking of Success, In a Woman's Voice

BYLINE: By ALECIA SWASY; Alecia Swasy, assistant managing editor for business at The St. Petersburg Times, is the author of "Soap Opera: The Inside Story of Procter & Gamble."

 BODY:
INSIDE our newsroom in St. Petersburg, Fla., is a filing-cabinet drawer emblazoned with a yellow smiley face. We call it the Happy Drawer -- home to the good stuff.
No, it's not where we keep the Belvedere vodka. We're talking chocolate. Hershey's Kisses, Snickers bars and Reese's peanut butter cups. 
 When the chocolate stash runs low, people get cranky. No small problem, considering that there is a correlation between chocolate served and articles produced. The average 1,000-word article might require a handful of Kisses, while a 300-page nonfiction book might mean 27 1/2 pounds of peanut M & M's.
So what a treat to come across the management tricks of fellow chocolate aficionado Ellen Gordon, the chief executive of Tootsie Roll Industries. At 68, Mrs. Gordon presides over production of 49.5 million Tootsie Rolls and 16 million lollipops a day, generating a net profit margin of 17 percent, far ahead of her competitors at Hershey. She merits a place among the profiles of "Why the Best Man for the Job Is a Woman" (Harper Business, $24), by Esther Wachs Book, a former reporter at Forbes magazine who knows how to put a human face on a business story.
My eyes tend to cross at most management texts, but this one is different. It's not a generalized, predictable tome on how and why women should become leaders. Ms. Book's book is like a series of comfy chats inside a corporate suite. We hear the voices of the women who have broken into the boys' club.
It's lonely there, and the statistics are truly pathetic. In 1999, women held just 12 percent of the senior posts in Fortune 500 companies. And women chief executives are as scarce as pandas. But in broader terms, women still represent power and money -- they control 85 percent of all personal and household spending.
The profiles offer plenty of lessons. For starters, these women never forget their roots.
Marcy Carsey, who developed "The Cosby Show" and "Roseanne," then pitched them to the networks, is the daughter of a shipyard worker and a homemaker from Quincy, Mass. A self-described nerd, Ms. Carsey endured the gray, slushy winters by watching television. Clearly, she understands the untapped market of female viewers. "Roseanne," for instance, portrayed the absurdity of everyday life for working moms.
Ms. Carsey's shows became huge hits: her production company is worth an estimated $1.2 billion and she is now a partner with Oprah Winfrey in Oxygen Media, whose chief executive is Geraldine Laybourne, a former chairwoman of the Nickelodeon cable channel.
Several of these successful women knew hard and dirty work in their childhood. Rebecca Mark slopped hogs in Missouri; she is now chief executive of Azurix, a global water supplier started by Enron. Her Escada blazer and Ebel watch belie her modest farm roots, but the work ethic has remained. After her hotel was bombed during a visit to Bombay, she worked by candlelight to develop a new power plant for the city of Dabhoi. But that probably wasn't as tough as raising her twins while earning her Harvard M.B.A. with distinction. Just reading about her workweek made me want to take a nap.
All of these women also demonstrate the importance of establishing confidence at an early age. Researchers have found that self-esteem for many girls plummets at about the age of 13. One survey cited in the book found that 60 percent of girls are happy in elementary school, but that drops to 29 percent in high school. Boys maintained a higher level of self-esteem.
Sports were important confidence-builders for many of the women, including Meg Whitman, chief executive of eBay, who was a swimmer.
Along with self-confidence, of course, comes the courage to take chances. Ms. Carsey, for instance, quit a comfortable job at the networks, took out a second mortgage and started her company.
MANY of the women lead by example and know how to balance work and family. They go to school plays and don't miss birthday parties. That sends a clear message to their colleagues: "I trust you to get the work done. You don't have to account for every minute of your time."
The book has a couple of flaws. First, the editors could have shown us some mercy by deleting every other use of the word "paradigm." A far greater problem is the excessive fawning over unsympathetic characters like Darla D. Moore. The book chronicles Ms. Moore's time at Chemical Bank, where the bankruptcy and reorganization unit she ran earned millions a year before she joined her husband, Richard E. Rainwater, the billionaire investor, as president of his investment firm.
In her Upper East Side condo, the book says, she displays a floor-to-ceiling oil painting of herself, decked in burgundy taffeta. And the book acknowleges her reputation as a manager who motivates by fear. One of her mantras to employees: "So, what are you wasting your time on today?"
But for my money, the single fat paragraph given to Ms. Moore's and Mr. Rainwater's woes in the Columbia/HCA Healthcare scandal falls short. The two were slow to catch on to Richard L. Scott's management problems at the chain, which Mr. Rainwater founded with Mr. Scott. Eventually, Ms. Moore pushed for Mr. Scott's ouster, but it took a federal investigation into allegations of Medicare fraud to get her attention. Columbia paid hefty penalties in settling the case, and shareholders saw their investment dwindle. But, hey, Ms. Moore wants to be a role model for young M.B.A.'s attending the Darla Moore School of Business, a result of her $25 million contribution to the University of South Carolina. This might not be someone I want my nieces to admire.
But back to the good stuff -- chocolate. Mrs. Gordon's family has controlled Tootsie Roll for 65-plus years. Her grandfather had sold paper to the company and noticed that management was late in paying its bills. Enter Grandma, who saved a bit of her teacher's pay to buy up Tootsie Roll stock. Other relatives did likewise, and the family bought a controlling interest after the Depression.
Her father took young Ellen along with him to work, and she wrote a high school essay on how she wanted to become a businesswoman, a laughable notion in that era.
After college, she and her husband took over the company. She watched General Motors and other American manufacturers lag behind foreign competitors because they failed to invest in new technology. So she invested in high-speed machines and listened to employee feedback.
"As a manager, you really don't know all the answers," she said.
At meetings, many people may drop by to offer their points of view. "That's why my chairs have wheels on them," she said.
The company doesn't even track turnover; most employees have been there for more than 20 years.
PUSHING 70, Mrs. Gordon still gets calls from headhunters with job offers; she rebuffs them. She has no plans to retire but hopes to pass on the Tootsie Roll business someday to one of her daughters or a top manager. "I love the game," she said.
Must be all that chocolate.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN -- UPDATE;
Tennis Justice: Court at South St. Seaport Gets a Reprieve

BYLINE: By DENNY LEE

 BODY:
The tennis courts on Piers 13 and 14 below the South Street Seaport were to close in May, because the city, which owns the property, was hoping to redevelop it for other uses.
But after inquiries from the Manhattan borough president's office and Community Board 1, the Economic Development Corporation, the landlord for the property, extended the lease on the courts to Michael Del Prete, who took over from the previous tenant, the New York Health and Racquet Club. 
 Tennis players were ecstatic.
"Elation is not an overstatement," said Samuel P. Sporn, 69, a lawyer. Mr. Sporn, an avid player, collected more than 300 petition signatures to save the courts.
Mr. Del Prete, who owns several other courts in the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn, has renovated the courts and renamed them the Wall Street Racquet Club. He is expected to sign a one-year lease, renewable for three years. He said he planned to improve programs for children.
"We are going to give scholarships through E.D.C. on an as-needed-basis to children who can't afford to play," he said.
Hourly rates for others will be $30 to $60 for members and about twice that for nonmembers. The city will get $20,000 a month in rent.
Janel Patterson, a spokeswoman for the corporation, said the lease would include a 30-day cancellation notice.
The 30-year-old courts were seen in Woody Allen's film "Annie Hall." The city is still considering plans to replace the courts with a hotel or a Guggenheim museum designed by Frank Gehry. DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: Investing;
A Buyer's Market in Cars and Car Stocks

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
CHARLES DICKENS did not have Detroit in mind when he wrote, "It was the best of times, it was the worst of times." But it sums up the situation for the nation's auto industry.
With the American economy strong and unemployment at near-record lows, automakers are selling all manner of four-wheeled vehicles at a record pace. Profits are good. The companies are flush with cash. Labor disputes look remote. 
 Yet Wall Street has looked at these fundamentals and effectively scoffed, "Big deal." Auto stocks, which peaked during the spring, are down, in some cases substantially. The stock market, analysts say, is expecting a slide in demand -- though it may be many months away and may not come at all.
"The good news is that sales have never been better," said Stephen Girsky, an auto industry analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "The bad news is that with slowing employment, rising interest rates and rising gasoline prices, sales are going to fall. And the pricing environment is just terrible."
At a seasonally adjusted annual rate of around 17 million vehicles, sales remain at record levels. But they were higher six months ago, and inventories are rising. All these factors have combined to send the stocks skidding.
General Motors, which was trading in the low $90's in May, closed on Friday at $63.25. DaimlerChrysler, which peaked at just over $68 in early April, is now at $56.375. Ford Motor, which most analysts see as the best stock of the lot, has taken only a modest hit. Its shares, which peaked at just over $31 in mid-April, are now at $29.125.
"In a rising interest rate environment and a moderating vehicle sales environment, these stocks tend to perform poorly," said Nicholas Lobaccaro, who follows auto companies for Lehman Brothers. "And you are looking at much heavier supply of the most profitable vehicles and major inroads by foreign manufacturers in trucks and sport utility vehicles."
Indeed, the long-term worry is that worldwide supply of vehicles is far outstripping demand. That is great news for consumers, because it suggests that prices will probably remain under pressure. But it is not positive for corporate profit margins.
"We estimate there are 40 excess assembly plants around the world, which probably means the industry has 100,000 extra employees," said John A. Casesa, an auto analyst at Merrill Lynch.
And more supply is coming. Japanese manufacturers, seeking bigger market share, are committed to bolstering production of light trucks and S.U.V.'s in the North American market, Mr. Casesa said.
An increase in light-truck capacity, which some analysts estimated at 15 percent, would almost certainly threaten profits in the product line that has been Detroit's biggest money-maker.
Some analysts, however, say the worst may be past for the stocks. They contend that that interest rates may have peaked, that the economy is slowing but is not likely to stall, and that gasoline prices are off their highs. And auto stocks are trading much lower than they were three months ago.
David Bradley, an auto industry analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities, turned negative on the stocks in mid-May, when the economy was growing rapidly and the Federal Reserve seemed intent on raising interest rates for the foreseeable future.
He has not changed his view entirely since then, but he says he is feeling a bit better. "I have gone from being quite bearish to a slightly more positive posture," he said. "We are advocating putting a toe in the water where we see opportunity."
But with the economic outlook still muddled, few analysts are sanguine about what will happen on Wall Street.
"I think the stocks will be choppy for the rest of the year, but I think they are undervalued," said Wendy Beale Needham of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. She is recommending Ford and G.M. for purchase.
Indeed, most analysts say Ford seems the best investment. "We have been very cautious on DaimlerChrysler and General Motors, but think Ford can create shareholder value, mainly because of their product pipeline," said Mr. Lobaccaro at Lehman.
Mr. Bradley also likes Ford, but as a short-term play. This month, Ford shareholders approved a proposal to distribute a special $10 billion dividend. Ford, which has already distributed $5.7 billion to investors, could pay for the balance by buying back its stock, he said.
"Even though the stock has popped in the last week or so, Ford clearly has short-term potential," he said. "I think the buyback is worth another 5 percent on the stock."
MR. BRADLEY said investors with longer time horizons might consider G.M. -- not because of its prospects in the motor vehicles sector, but because it still owns 30 percent of Hughes Electronics. Chances are that the company will spin out that remaining portion or split it off in the second half of 2001, he said. "Another spin of Hughes could be worth $20 a share on General Motors stock," he said.
Generally, analysts are less than positive about DaimlerChrysler, which they say has yet to realize the potential of its megamerger nearly two years ago. "Clearly, the merger hasn't gone as well as Daimler would like," Mr. Girsky said.
Mr. Lobaccaro added: "If you look at the current earnings growth rate of DaimlerChrysler, it is hard to reconcile how low it is, if all the synergies they claimed would be realized were actually hitting the bottom line. From a near-term and medium-term perspective, the merger has been a disappointment."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
Yes, the Euro Will Rebound. Someday.

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
WILL the euro ever rally?
That is a fair question, given the currency's tumble this summer. Despite predictions that it was time for a rebound in the euro, the unified currency of 11 European nations, it is back within striking distance of new lows, bedeviling American investors by erasing gains that they may have made in European equities. 
 After a rally of 8.5 percent from its record low of 88.95 cents on May 4, the euro has fallen 6.4 percent from its recent peak of 96.49 cents, on June 16. It dropped below 90 cents on Wednesday and finished the week at 90.33 cents. That is down 22.6 percent from its debut value of $1.1667 in January 1999.
"It's embarrassing to be a currency forecaster these days," said Anne Mills, senior foreign economist at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. She is not alone. There is no easy answer to why the euro remains so weak.
The economies of the countries behind the euro are now growing at 3 to 4 percent a year. They are at an earlier stage in their expansion cycle, compared with that of the United States, so they should be able to keep perking along. Their stock markets, while not taking off, are doing better than American equities so far this year. And the European Central Bank has moved to support the euro and to keep inflationary pressures in check, raising its benchmark interest rate by 1.75 percentage points since November. Many analysts expect that inflation and euro worries will prompt another rate increase late this month or in September.
"I find it very difficult to explain the softness of the euro from the European side," said Nicholas P. Sargen, global market strategist for J. P. Morgan's private clients.
The euro has also received help from the United States in the last year, as the Federal Reserve has lifted its benchmark interest rate by 1.75 points, aiming to put a brake on American economic growth. A slowing United States economy should make a rebounding Europe more attractive, especially in a year when the American stock market indexes are in negative territory.
But all that came of this was a six-week rally that started in early May and got its real lift when the Fed raised its target for the federal funds rate by half a point, to 6.50 percent, on May 16.
So what happened? While analysts are not confident of their explanations, they put most of the blame on the strong performance of the United States economy and investors' consequent unwillingness to bet on Europe when American has given them so much.
Rather than worrying that the American economy will slow sharply, investors seem to be betting that the Fed can direct the economy to a soft landing, with growth remaining relatively robust and inflation continuing to be restrained. German jobs data, released last week, may have also created concern; the number of unemployed fell by 9,000 in July, but that was below the predictions of 10,000 to 25,000. The unemployment rate slipped to 9.5 percent, from 9.6 percent.
"What has made us wrong," Ms. Mills of Brown Brothers Harriman said, "is the appetite of Europeans for direct and portfolio investment in the United States."
Karen E. Parker, director of currency research at Chase Securities, pointed out that European companies were still behind their United States competitors in restructuring and in productivity gains. That, too, is probably undermining the euro, she said.
Even the euro pessimists have been surprised. Ms. Parker has been bearish on the currency since its inception. But she had predicted that it would rally this year, in part because the Fed was pushing interest rates higher and the American economy's rapid growth was expected to slow. Last December, she forecast that the euro would be at $1.10 by the end of this year.
Now she predicts that the best the euro can do is 92 cents by year-end and 95 cents by next June. "The most that we are counting on is that the euro has bottomed out," she said. But she is not ruling out a brief side trip to a new low.
"This is one of those major moves that simply take longer to turn around than people think," Ms. Mills said.
She said she felt sure of one development -- although, wisely, she declined to forecast the timing: "Sometime in the next five years, we will be doing the same search for reasons why the dollar is so weak."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1266 words

HEADLINE: Business;
In a Humming Economy, A Rising Din of Defaults

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
WITH the economic expansion setting records for longevity, much of American business is reveling in prosperity. But all is hardly well. For reasons that include profligate lending and underwriting in the second half of the 1990's, many large businesses, and even entire industries, are suffocating from their debts.
A major portion of the health care industry is in shambles. In retailing, competition from category killers has contributed to huge consolidation. And some auto parts suppliers, already beleaguered despite record car sales by Detroit last year, seem to have no place to go but south. 
 That's not all. Household names like Pathmark Stores and United Artists Theatre Company defaulted on bonds this spring and are contributors to a total of $15 billion in defaulted debt across corporate America for the first half of 2000 -- a rate that could smash last year's record of $23.5 billion.
Though the financial disruption at Pathmark and United Artists is nearly invisible to their customers, it is very visible to the bankruptcy lawyers and other people -- please don't call them vultures -- who make their living from corporate distress. For them, business has rarely been better. And judging from the agony in the market for high-yield bonds, probably the best predictor, it is likely to get better still.
"The restructuring industry is in an expansion phase right now," said Al Koch, managing principal at Jay Alix & Associates, a leading specialist in the category. Its staff has nearly tripled in size over the last five years as more companies have needed help in fixing operations and recasting notes and bonds. "Insolvency attorneys are all very, very busy," Mr. Koch added.
Deryck A. Palmer, a partner and restructuring specialist at Weil, Gotshal & Manges, can vouch for that. He points particularly to the bounty that awaits those involved in refinancing hospitals, which he believes are only beginning to feel the crunch that has affected other businesses.
"What's amazing is you have this much activity in a robust economy," Mr. Palmer said.
Whether these exceptions to the boom will lead to a full-fledged credit crunch depends on whom you ask. But there is no doubt that a rising number of companies, running out of financing options, are having to default.
And with nearly all economists agreeing that the Federal Reserve will succeed, sooner or later, in slowing the nation's growth, the corporate distress will probably widen. If the Fed's tightening brings on a recession, as a few analysts now predict for next year, the defaults could intensify the contraction.
As Henry S. Miller, vice chairman of Wasserstein Perella & Company and head of its restructuring business, put it, "Most people who play in this business believe there is a lot more to come."
Moody's Investors Service calculates that 6.2 percent of high-yield, or junk, bonds are now in default. It projects that the rate will rise to 7.1 percent by year-end, and to 8.4 percent by July 2001. Globally, the United States, which has the world's most accessible capital markets, accounts for 75 percent of the defaulted bonds by amount and 85 percent by number of companies.
Most economists doubt that the soured debt will cause more than a blip in the nation's overall economic performance. But Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, watches the figures on distressed loans. And his staff has made inquiries recently about the ill health of the market for high-yield debt, defined as securities rated no higher than Ba-1 by Moody's or BB+ by Standard & Poor's.
HOME casualties are in long-ailing businesses like steel. Others are in highly cyclical ones like heavy equipment. Harnischfeger Industries, a maker of mining equipment, survived the Rust Belt vicissitudes of the 1980's only to be driven into Chapter 11 bankruptcy by overwhelming fixed costs and falling prices in 1999.
Borrowing for what analysts regard as ill-conceived acquisitions has also caused problems. Safety-Kleen, for example, tried to combine such fundamentally different businesses as hazardous-waste disposal with the more routine collection of used motor oil and recyclable materials. In still others, companies fell prey to rapid technological change or, as with hospitals and nursing homes, to new restrictions on government reimbursements.
With a few exceptions, Internet companies have not made much use of the bond market, because of a ready supply, at least until this year, of equity capital. As a result, few have defaulted.
Analysts say bad strategies or bad execution, or sometimes both, could not have occurred without a severe relaxation in standards that allowed weak companies to borrow freely from banks and bond investors.
From 1996 to 1999, said Edward Altman, a finance professor at New York University and a consultant to Salomon Smith Barney, "you had a huge number of low-quality issues coming to market." As proof, Dr. Altman said, defaults showed up within a year or two of the financings, instead of the more typical three or four years.
Mr. Hamilton agreed that the ease of raising money in the bond market in 1997 and 1998 "sowed the seeds for the current crop of defaults."
As the cash flows necessary for repaying bonds and loans failed to materialize, banks began to tighten their credit standards, even more so in the wake of Russia's 1998 default. The Fed put pressure on the banks to acknowledge their mistakes by using some of their profits to increase reserves to cover dubious loans. Also, lenders and debt markets became far less hospitable to companies needing to refinance.
"Credit standards have tightened up and they've got nowhere to go," Mr. Koch said. "Three years ago, you could go to the bank across the street but you can't do that anymore. And the bond markets are closed to them."
In the past, Mr. Koch said, companies could routinely be rescued with fairly straightforward financial fixes like persuading investors to swap their bonds for freshly issued stock. But companies now find that they need to make their operations far more efficient, too. He cited Trans World Airlines as a company that still needed to improve operations if it is to head off its third descent into bankruptcy.
In a report published last month by Salomon Smith Barney, Dr. Altman found not only that the default rate on bonds jumped to 1.58 percent in the second quarter, from 1 percent in the first quarter, but also that so-called distressed debt had reached "somewhat ominous" levels. Distressed bonds have yields to maturity at least 10 percentage points above those of similar Treasury securities.
Some 17 percent of high-yield debt was in this category on June 30, compared with 9 percent at the end of last year and just 3 percent at the end of 1998. And Moody's downgraded the debt of twice as many companies as it upgraded in the first half of this year, the highest ratio since 1991, when the last recession ended.
STILL, the cumulative total of defaulted and distressed debt, estimated at 23 percent of the amount outstanding at midyear, remains far below the 43 percent in 1992. In fact, some analysts contend that prices on high-yield debt have fallen to bargain levels, with the average yield at 13 percent.
"We feel the Fed is basically done with interest-rate increases," said Steven A. Ruggiero, director of high-yield research at Chase Securities. He calls high-yield debt a "good place to be" for investors, provided that they are in a mutual fund or closed-end fund and that it constitutes no more than 10 percent of a portfolio.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Oil Prices Falling? Don't Count On It

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
AFTER a sharp run-up, which helped put gasoline back onto front pages in the spring after a long absence, oil prices have subsided and politicians rail no longer about supposed industry gouging.
Investors seem unshaken in thinking oil prices can only slide further, following the pattern traced after the 1973-74 Arab embargo, the 1979-82 period that included revolution in Iran and the 1991 Persian Gulf war. 
 But Charles T. Maxwell, regarded as the dean of Wall Street's oil analysts, contends that things are different now. Mr. Maxwell, with Weeden & Company, made the case on Thursday for his against-the-grain view. Here are excerpts from the conversation.
 
Q. You're predicting that oil will average $24 a barrel through 2003 in contrast to a Wall Street consensus that it will return to $18 to $20 within the next year or two. Why?
 
A. Excess world capacity, what could quickly be brought into production, has ranged between about 7 and 10 percent over the last 50 years. It reached 18 percent in 1986, when prices collapsed. Today it's around 5 percent, and we need 2 to 2 1/2 percent as a cushion against emergency, such as weather or strikes. So we are as tight now as I have seen in my 44 years studying the industry. It's not political maneuvering by OPEC -- the oil physically isn't there.
 
Q. Is this a result of reduced supply or higher demand?
 
A. Both. Low prices until recently not only created disincentives to invest, but they've also limited the capital available to invest because earnings collapsed. And then demand rebounded in the Far East and Europe, and we've got unprecedented prosperity in America.
 
Q. But profits are now pretty robust, right?
 
A. It takes as much as four years from the time a major development project gets approved to the time when oil begins to flow. Besides, national oil companies in Venezuela and elsewhere must compete for budget money, and the Exxon Mobils of the world are sensitive to stockholder values and their own options. Every dollar they put into buying back shares because they're cheap is a dollar that doesn't go into the drill bit.
 
Q. Is the tight market what caused the price of gasoline to jump recently, to as much as $2.50 a gallon in the Midwest?
 
A. It may have been a modest contributor, but what happened there was basically an environmental issue -- making reformulated gasoline. They brought in supplies from other areas, and the problem quickly dissipated.
 
Q. So will the government investigation prove to be fruitless?
 
A. No investigation we've had yet has found a conspiracy of the oil companies. I'm not going to say there weren't individual operators or terminals that were gouging.
 
Q. If profits are good and you think oil will stay above $20, why are most industry stocks, except for the oil-field service and exploration companies, in the dumps?
 
A. Investors have "learned" from experience that a high price elicits an investment cycle, which creates an expanded supply, which drops the price quickly and leaves them hanging. And while I think the process this time will be gradual, irregular and stretched out, the business is regarded as more cyclical than 20 years ago, when people saw growth in it.
As the price of oil holds in the mid-20's, I expect people to realize what good value these stocks are. The stocks have suffered from being "old economy."
 
Q. Hasn't Chevron, for one, been bragging about becoming a high-tech company?
 
A. Let's be serious. They're going to do a little Internet purchasing, but I think it's laughable. When Internet P/E's get low enough, they won't even mention it again.
 
Q. Will the industry continue to consolidate?
 
A. The game's not over. Chevron probably won't merge, but Texaco is likely, with Royal Dutch the most logical candidate. Conoco, Amerada Hess and Phillips would be perfect for takeover. Phillips, which doubled reserves when it bought ARCO's Alaskan assets, is most appealing, selling for 9 times earnings, compared with 15 1/2 for its peers.
 
Q. Do oil companies stand to gain if George W. Bush and Dick Cheney, both of whom worked in the industry, win in November?
 
A. When push comes to shove, the parties would make geopolitical decisions about such things as imports and subsidies pretty much the same way. But Bush's would be a looser environmental policy, on offshore drilling, say, than Gore's.
 
Q. How did Mr. Cheney do as chairman of Halliburton, whose stock has a P/E of 65 and has jumped 30 percent this year?
 
A. I wouldn't call him a brilliant businessman, but he did a workmanlike job organizing the company, putting a face on it and winning business. He certainly met the expectations of the people who put him in.
