HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
A Space Detour for Streaming Internet Traffic

BYLINE: By THERESA FOLEY 

 BODY:
Listening to NetRadio.com's Woodstock 69 music channel or KBAC-FM, Santa Fe's jazz and eclectic radio station, or some other music program over the Internet is gaining popularity among people who spend lots of time online. But delivering simultaneous streams of music to thousands or even millions of listeners over an ever more clogged Internet has become increasingly frustrating. If the audio stream hits too many traffic jams, the listener may find his Internet radio program stuttering or stopping midway through a song.
One promising remedy involves sending the stream up to a satellite, hopping over most of the jam ups on the ground and landing the music stream at a network hub closer to the listener. 
 That is how Viacom's MTV Networks is helping move the feed from SonicNet.com -- one of 18 MTV Web sites -- to the ears of its Internet audience. SonicNet beams its audio stream to the Loral Skynet Telstar 7 satellite from a station in Tulsa, Okla.
The satellite feeds SonicNet's programming to antennas around the country, converting it back to an Internet signal that is distributed to 135 network hubs operated by America Online, Excite@Home and other Internet service providers. Those providers then pass it along through conventional cables or telephone lines to people at their PC's.
"We don't care if it's delivered by satellite, fiber or carrier pigeon; we care about cost," said Nicholas Butterworth, president and chief executive of the MTVi Group, MTV's Internet unit. He made clear, though, that he was still monitoring the results. "So far the satellite service has proven valuable," Mr. Butterworth said, "but over the long term, who knows?"
MTVi is using competing ground-based distribution services from companies like Akamai Technologies and Digital Island to improve the reception of its Internet music and video programs.
The iBeam Broadcasting Corporation, which provides the satellite service to MTVi, said it had signed up 250 Internet content providers the last nine months, since it started operating its network of satellites and fiber to bypass traffic jams on the terrestrial Internet.
Entertainment and news providers like MSNBC Cable News, another iBeam customer, want to see their Web content delivered to users in the fastest, most efficient way possible and are willing to pay for such service. IBeam charges the companies monthly fees of $4,600 or more.
IBeam, which had a public stock offering in May, reported a loss of $33.1 million for the second quarter on revenue of $3.4 million. The company has several competitors that offer -- or plan to offer -- satellite service as a way for Internet content companies to rise above the network fray.
For several years, some overseas Internet service providers have used satellite links as a way to connect to the United States' Internet backbone. But the use of satellite distribution by American Web content companies as a way to gain speed and efficiency is still a new business, though it is an approach similar to the way cable and broadcast TV networks have distributed programming to cable operators and local stations for more than two decades.
IBeam and its rivals, including Cidera, InterPacket and NetSat Express, contend that the Internet is a hostile network environment for streaming media, the Internet term for video and audio that is viewed or heard as it is transmitted, rather than being received and stored on the user's PC before being played.
"The Internet was not designed to do what we're asking it to do -- to distribute something that looks like TV or sounds like a CD," said Peter B. Desnoes, iBeam's chief executive. He notes that a three-minute video stream requires a total data transfer of nearly 10 million bytes -- roughly 800 times more than a typical Web page.
"The way to solve it is to go around the Internet itself," Mr. Desnoes said. "We have built a very complex private network that includes satellite elements that sends content out to the edge."
The public Internet architecture is simply not designed to handle large audiences of simultaneous users who, for example, might tune into Internet Webcasts. Nor are the built-in backup systems. If a few packets of data are lost in the transmission of an e-mail message or a Web page, the Internet's software automatically finds them and replaces them. But in the case of a video transmission, resending packets to replace lost data can make for a choppy picture.
For video traveling from a single point to many, "nothing beats satellite," said Robert Fagin, Internet, infrastructure and services analyst at Bear, Stearns.
Bear, Stearns forecasts a $48 billion market for streaming media by 2010, up from $1.3 billion today, with perhaps 30 percent of the flow being delivered by third-party service providers -- whether satellite players or companies that offer land-based route-around solutions.
Cidera, a satellite-delivery company based in Laurel, Md., predicts that audience demand for streaming media will be so strong that content providers and Internet service companies alike will be willing to pay companies like Cidera to ensure a smooth and steady flow of streaming media.
Ramachandran Viswanathan, Cidera's vice president for marketing, said Internet service providers recognized that "streaming media is like a tsunami wave about to break on them."
Even when people have high-speed Internet connections like the DSL service available through telephone companies, they can find that streaming media can be slowed or disrupted by bottlenecks on the Internet, said Bill Collatos, a venture capitalist.
Mr. Collatos is a founding managing general partner of Spectrum Equity, a $3 billion firm in Boston that has invested in Orblynx Inc. of Fairfax, Va., a company that, with the help of Intelsat, has developed technology for distributing Internet content by satellite.
For the public, investment opportunities are still limited. IBeam shares were offered at $10 in May, and reached nearly $28 in early June, before falling back. They closed at $10.1875 on Friday.
Cidera, InterPacket and NetSat Express have all registered for public offerings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, but have not set dates for proceeding. Meanwhile, competition is on the way from several big, established satellite companies, including Intelsat and PanAmSat, which are putting their own Internet-content delivery networks into service.
IBeam appears to be ahead of the others in its service concept, which goes beyond delivery and includes flourishes like adding other material to the information stream. For MTVi, for example, iBeam can insert advertising into the live streams, tailored to individual subscribers.
"If you are a cat owner, you will get a cat commercial," Mr. Desnoes said. "We provide those services."
The economics of the business models are still to be proved by iBeam and the other start-ups, which lease satellite capacity rather than operate their own spacecraft.
Roger Stanyard, the principal consultant at the British firm DTT Consulting, has studied use of satellites with the Internet for more than three years. He said the most that a company like Cidera could expect to charge an Internet service provider was $250 a month -- a figure that he said in some cases might not cover the cost of providing the service. "It becomes difficult to get your money back," Mr. Stanyard said.
But Mr. Collatos, the venture capitalist, remains guardedly optimistic about the Internet satellite companies. "All are early stage and they will miss their plans; it's inevitable," he acknowledged. "But fundamentally, the concept they have is sound."

HEADLINE: New Economy;
The Internet in Japan is riding a wireless wave, leaving phone-line companies in the dust.

BYLINE: By John Markoff 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
TO understand how different the development of the Internet has been in Japan than in the United States, consider the plight of Hiroaki Kobayashi.
A veteran telecommunications entrepreneur who started one of the first modem companies in Japan and then sold it to AT&T, Mr. Kobayashi is now the president and founder of Tokyo Metallic, a struggling Japanese provider of high-speed, or broadband, Internet access lines. 
 His company is trying to jump start the development of a type of broadband telephone-line technology known as digital subscriber line, or DSL. But while Internet access through DSL is booming in the United States, Mr. Kobayashi's business is barely sputtering. There are fewer than 1,000 DSL customers in Japan, split between his company and one lone competitor.
In the United States, the incumbent Bell phone companies and their start-up competitors, known as CLEC's, are now closing in on a million DSL subscribers nationally, according to the Cahners Instat market research group. And Internet access by high-speed cable television lines is quickly reaching even higher numbers in the United States.
But here in Japan, Tokyo Metallic's tiny band of entrepreneurs is facing many obstacles, not the least of which is the giant Japanese telephone company Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, which currently has a competing strategy for wiring Japan with high-speed fiber optic cables.
Moreover, the Japanese telephone industry invested heavily in an early version of a digital technology known as ISDN -- a type of phone service much slower than DSL and only slightly faster than modem data sent over a standard, analog phone line that many people in the United States still use for Internet access.
Although NTT has recently made overtures to the American DSL companies, industry executives said that the telecom giant was in no rush to invest in DSL -- in part because it is still anxious to retrieve its investment in ISDN.
For all the landline forces working against him, though, the biggest challenge to Mr. Kobayashi's vision of wiring Japan has nothing to do with wires at all. Just the opposite, in fact. The Japanese are heading onto the Internet in droves -- by wireless means.
Currently, according to InfoCom Research, there are between 20 million and 27 million Internet users in Japan, or approximately one of every five people in the nation. Of that number, nearly half -- some 10 million -- are connecting to the Internet wirelessly. Of these wireless customers, 7.5 million are using a service called i-mode, offered by NTT DoCoMo, NTT's wireless division. For nearly two of three i-mode users, this wireless link is their only method of access to the Internet.
InfoCom forecasts that the percent of Japanese population connected wirelessly to the Internet will increase to more than 85 percent by 2003, compared with only about 60 percent connected by fixed-line networks.
That trend suggests that people here are likely to use and experience the Internet much differently than they do in the United States, where so far only a fraction of Internet users have wireless access.
Japan's wireless Internet explosion was set off last year by the introduction of NTT DoCoMo's i-mode cellular phones, which are capable of sending and receiving data. And now competing with the i-modes are an increasingly popular type of cellular phone known as PHS that supports data speeds of 64,000 bits a second -- as fast as the wired, ISDN digital phone lines here.
What's more, Japan is now moving quickly to a second generation of wireless Internet technology, which promises higher data speeds and a variety of location-sensing commercial services that are likely to be embraced by business customers.
But this is far more than a business revolution. One has only to sit in a Japanese subway car watching teenagers communicating via the Internet cell phones, or wander the stores of the Akihabara, Tokyo's electronics district, where there are literally hundreds of different voice, data and data-voice handset models on display, to grasp the momentum of the wireless Net in Japan.
In advertisements and in interviews, Keiji Tachikawa, chief executive and president of NTT DoCoMo, has been sketching out his vision of a next-generation digital cellular network to be initiated early next year, when DoCoMo plans to offer five types of wireless Internet access devices that will further blur the line between cell phones and computers.
It is a prophecy that has led many observers of the Internet in Japan to conclude that the wired world may increasingly become an afterthought for most Internet users here.
"Japan is more mobile and less people are home," said Joichi Ito, an Internet pioneer in Japan who now heads Neoteny, a Tokyo-based Internet business incubator. "Most people don't have living rooms here, and wiring is very high-cost."
There are also other cultural factors that explain the wireless versus wired split. Andrew Seybold, an American wireless expert who visited here this summer to study the Japanese wireless market, points to a variety of reasons that the wireless Internet has taken faster, firmer root in Japan than in the United States: better wireless coverage, pricing on par with prices for wired service and the fact that for many people, particularly teenagers, the wireless phone is their only phone.
Mr. Seybold also noted the strong cultural factors that have driven the success of the i-mode phone in Japan, particularly popular "killer applications," like train schedules, wireless banking and games.
Japanese designers seem to have understood the user interface issues in a way that American designers have not, Mr. Seybold said. "In Japan you can get to the train schedule with two clicks," he said. "When I try to find a plane flight on a U.S. cell phone, I have to go through seven menu levels before I can even enter the flight number."
One likely consequence of the diverging approaches to the Web is that Japan, and by extension Asia, may be reaching the next generation of the Internet far sooner than the United States.
Whether that means that the next generation of technology innovation and competitive advantage will follow the Web westward across the Pacific Ocean remains to be seen. Meanwhile, Hiroaki Kobayashi can only hope that Tokyo Metallic doesn't become completely swamped by the wireless wave.

HEADLINE: Murdoch Deal Could Revamp New York TV

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER and GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
Media analysts and network executives said over the weekend that the sale of TV stations owned by Chris-Craft Industries to the owner of the Fox network, the News Corporation, was likely to create a host of opportunities for the News Corporation -- and raise almost as many questions.
The questions will affect the News Corporation and Viacom, which until Friday had also been bidding to acquire the stations. 
 The sale, expected to be announced formally this week, is valued at $85 a share, or about $3.5 billion. It will add 10 stations owned by Chris-Craft and present the News Corporation's leader, Rupert Murdoch, with a competitive edge -- ownership of two powerful TV stations in a number of major cities, including New York and Los Angeles. It will also give him extended control over dissemination of local news in New York, where he would own both Channel 5 and Channel 9 as well as The New York Post.
The deal, however, raises questions about how the News Corporation will deal with current Federal Communications Commission restrictions. They include a limit on how much reach one broadcasting company can attain and a ban on cross-ownership of newspapers and TV station in the same city, which Mr. Murdoch won a waiver for when only Channel 5 was involved.
The deal especially throws into question what may happen to UPN, which is now owned by Viacom but will become the Paramount Network in January.
No network has ever succeeded without owning stations in the two largest media markets of New York and Los Angeles. Viacom, which also owns CBS, finds itself in the position of running a network whose two biggest stations will be owned by a company that also owns a rival network. And the affiliation agreement between the Chris-Craft stations and the Paramount network expires in January.
Some network executives are already predicting the Viacom president, Mel Karmazin, will simply decide that the UPN Network, now losing between $100 million and $150 million a year, is an asset not worth keeping. Faced with some CBS cable TV assets that had little prospects of turning a profit in the next five years, the Eye on People channel and Tele-Noticias, Mr. Karmazin chose to shut down both of them.
But the UPN Network had shown recent signs of growth, having found a hit in a weekly wrestling franchise. One media analyst said that Mr. Karmazin, in recent private conversations, said "UPN will be profitable in a year."
"He was very much of a mind to keep it," the analyst added.
Whether that will still be true with the News Corporation owning the most important stations broadcasting the network is far from certain. But the analyst, who spoke on condition of anonymity, cautioned against any facile predictions that Mr. Karmazin will quickly pull out of UPN.
"There are too many advantages to owning two networks," the analyst said. "You could put a CBS News nightly newscast at 10 p.m. on the alternate network and amortize so much more of the costs of an expensive news division. You can cross-promote to your second network when your main network may have a show that has a totally different appeal."
It is similar opportunities on the local level presented by dual ownership of stations in the same city that are at the center of News Corporation's plans for the Chris-Craft stations. Michael J. Wolf, who heads the media department at Booz Allen & Hamilton, said: "There are cross-promotions that can take place, similar to the way that companies are able to drive viewers from one cable network to another. The same thing can work in local television markets."
Two stations in the same city can also achieve great economies of scale, Mr. Wolf said, by combining news operations and advertising sales staffs. "This would let News Corp. get a bigger piece of an advertiser's budget," Mr. Wolf said. And it could open up possibilities in sports, he added, by allowing the News Corporation to place a team's games on two channels. For example, Channel 5 carries Yankees games. But because that is the flagship station of the Fox network there are many nights when Fox cannot pre-empt entertainment programming for a game. Now it might be possible to move some games over to Channel 9.
Dual ownership is certain to be most noticed in New York because of Mr. Murdoch's ownership of The Post. Presumably he will have to gain an additional waiver from the F.C.C. to add Channel 9 if he intends to retain The Post because of the continuing restriction on cross-ownership of newspapers and stations.
But Fox will be much more aggressive in seeking to overturn another F.C.C. restriction, the one that limits a broadcasting company to owning stations that reach no more than 35 percent of the nation's homes. Fox was already at that cap before this acquisition. With the Chris-Craft stations, the network will be far above the cap. Fox has already filed suit in federal court to challenge the regulation and analysts and executives said this weekend that Fox would surely step up its lobbying efforts in Congress to have the limits either raised or eliminated.
Even if the restrictions stay in place, Fox is not likely to simply sell off stations to get down to the limit. "You may see a lot of station swapping take place," a Fox executive said. Another network executive compared what might take place to "a game of go fish, where you take one card and I take another." The point of the game: match up stations and cities to create dual ownership.
But all this presumes that owning stations will continue to be good business, a point many broadcast executives disagree on. One senior executive with experience at two networks said many family-owned companies with long histories running TV stations had recently decided to quit the business, sensing that the future was too unpredictable. "It's not like by adding Channel 9, you now have two of seven stations in New York. With all the cable channels out there, it means you have two of 100."
Most recently, one News Corporation acquisition, the Family Channel, which Mr. Murdoch bought for $1.9 billion in 1997, has struggled to find an identity and to make money.
Still, David Londoner, a media analyst with ABN Amro, said there was a prospect that coming digital technology would expand the reach of local stations by multiplying their signals from one channel to as many as four. "More channels in big cities? You should be able to do something with that," he said.

Ford Releases Data on Tires That Firestone Recalled
Ford Motor released documents showing that Bridgestone/Firestone had received for years an unusually large number of claims on the tires that were recalled last week.
The highest numbers of claims by a wide margin were for tires produced at Bridgestone's factory in Decatur, Ill., in 1994 and 1995, when the factory was operated by replacement workers. Until now, Ford and Firestone sought to present a united front. But several disclosures indicate that their relationship is being strained by the tire recall. Page A1. 

Venture to Offer Video-on-Demand
Intertainer and Akamai Technologies plan to announce a partnership today to deliver video-on-demand to the computers of consumers with high-speed Internet connections. The service, which is now available in Cincinnati and Denver, will be broadly available by the end of the year, the companies said. C5.
 
Jobs Finds Fault With New Book
"The Second Coming of Steve Jobs," a book by Alan Deutschman, portrays Steven P. Jobs, the co-founder and chief executive of Apple Compute, as an abusive, insecure narcissist who, through a "reign of terror," turned around the company and reclaimed his authority. Last week, Mr. Jobs called the chief executive of Random House, the publisher's parent, to complain about the book, referring to it as a "hatchet job." C9.

NBC has also acquired the rights to a hidden-camera show called "Sweet Revenge," in which a contestant will be offered a chance to get back at a friend or family member by setting him or her up for embarrassment on a hidden camera. C9.
 
A Space Detour for Web Traffic
Delivering simultaneous streams of music to thousands or even millions of listeners over an ever more clogged Internet has become increasingly frustrating. If the audio stream hits too many traffic jams, listeners may find radio programs stuttering or stopping in the middle of a song. One promising remedy involves sending the stream up to a satellite and landing it at a network hub closer to listeners. C4.
 
Networks' Convention Role Shrinks
The three main broadcast networks are likely to continue to play a role at political conventions, and the parties are likely to continue to covet every moment on these high-visibility networks. But the scaling back in prime time that occurred this year is expected to only intensify the next time. Media. C9.
 
Japan Heads to Web Without Wires
While Internet access through high-speed lines is booming in the United States, the business in Japan is barely sputtering. The Japanese are heading onto the Internet in droves -- but by wireless means. There are at 20 million to 27 million Internet users in Japan, or one of every five people in the nation. Of that number, nearly half are connecting to the Internet wirelessly. New Economy. C4.
 
Web Entrepreneurs Stepping Aside
Anecdotal evidence suggests that a changing of the guard is under way in the Internet industry, as the early proponents of the Web are stepping aside for the mainstream business people who have migrated to the new medium. Analysts say the executive shift could have broad implications for e-commerce.Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C7.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Bill's Third Acceptance

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD

 BODY:
My Fellow Democrats:
After that rousing eight-minute demonstration, I accept your love. I accept your appreciation for triangulating you out of the Carter-Mondale-Dukakis wilderness and back into the White House for eight glorious years. And were it not for that damnable two-term amendment the Republicans put through to get even with F.D.R., tonight I would be saying, "I accept your renomination!" 
 That's how I'd like to start my valedictory speech. And then there are a few other things I wish I could say.
On the contrition business, I'd like to tell Bush and Cheney where to get off with all their barbs about "restoring honor and dignity" and other code words condemning my private life. But that line of attack from me would play into their hands.
So I'll choke back my feelings and pretend to be grateful to Joe Lieberman for calling me to moral account on the Senate floor. That'll get a big hand; we can't let the Pat Robertson crowd out-God us. And at least Joe voted right on acquittal.
I showed the other day how I can smother my detractors with gratitude. My best line to my pastor in Illinois: "If I hadn't been knocked down the way I was, and forced to come to grips with what I'd done and the consequences of it in such an awful way, I might not ever have had to really deal with it 100 percent." Thank you, Ken Starr and Henry Hyde, for forcing me to deal with it. Beautiful.
And the convention will tear the place apart if I thank the two-thirds of the American people for sticking by me in my toughest time. My personal purging process is not a subject Al wants me to touch on at a convention that is supposed to be all about him, but I know what's best for me. And what's best for me is best for him because this election is about me.
I won't let on about that, of course; I have to say every election is about the future. But I'll look back, bragging on the good times, claiming my tax increase in '93 was responsible for all the prosperity and surpluses today. I'll blame the Democrats' loss of the House on that unpopular party-line vote, even though everybody in the hall who lost will know the reason was our health-care fiasco.
My theme will be the tried-and-true "You Never Had It So Good," backed up with a pile of facts and figures -- 22 million jobs! Crime down! Stock market up! -- followed by the fearsome "Don't Let Them Take It Away." Look, maybe we had nothing to do with prosperity, but if we were in a depression, who would be getting the blame?
Looking into my own soul, I confess I'm torn. The good part of me wants Al Gore to win because it would validate my eight years and show the American people saying, "We want to give Bill Clinton a third term." On the other hand, the bad boy in me wants him to lose, to show the Democrats how much they needed me personally to drag them in and keep them in.
Even more conflicted are my feelings about Hillary's New York bid. I want her to win because I owe her for all that forgiving and because she's a backup for my validation in case Al can't make it without me. But my bad side says if she loses, she'll realize who the only winner is in this family. Plus which, she wouldn't be able to get on her high horse and have all that fun in the Washington I brought her to.
No -- get thee behind me, Satan -- I want Hillary to beat that pushover unknown, really I do. For six years, ever since her health-bill fiasco, we've been assuring everybody she hasn't been affecting presidential policy, especially about the Palestinians. But the new line is that the opposite was true, that she was deeply involved in all sorts of big decisions. Look, whichever she wants -- strictly first lady or co-president -- I can teach it either way.
So I'll stand up there for my Third Acceptance and wow 'em by taking full credit for everything good that's happened in eight great years. Let Al play Mr. Nice Guy if he likes; I'll be that old lovable rogue who can make a centrist waffle look like red meat. I'll make the Democrats miss my charm. I'll scare the viewers with the prospect of Bush, backward economics and back-alley abortions, and I'll stupefy my enemies with great globs of gratitude.
Clinton fatigue? Not when I'm finished. Tonight is the first night of Clinton nostalgia.

HEADLINE: THE DEMOCRATS: THE REPUBLICANS;
Bush Defends Settlement For Cheney

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas this weekend defended the generous retirement package that his running mate, Dick Cheney, received from his former employer as a standard practice for a company executive.
But senior Democrats today derided Mr. Bush, the Republican presidential nominee, for standing behind the settlement when the Republican-led Congress has resisted increasing the minimum wage. 
 After accepting Mr. Bush's offer to join him as the vice-presidential candidate, Mr. Cheney resigned as chairman and chief executive of the Halliburton Company, a Dallas-based energy services company. Halliburton awarded him a financial settlement worth an estimated $20 million after five years of service during which he received about $12.5 million in pay and stock options currently worth $39 million.
In an interview with The Los Angeles Times that was published today, Mr. Bush said he was aware that Mr. Cheney would receive a retirement package, as any successful chief executive would. Mr. Bush said: "I think what you ought to do is ask, 'Does the board of directors know what they are doing? Are they expert? And let the experts make the decision as to what's fair.' "
Chris Lehane, a spokesman for Vice President Al Gore, said the size of the retirement package and Mr. Bush's approval reflects the close relationship between the Republican Party and big business that working families might find troublesome.
Dirk Vande Beek, communications director for Mr. Cheney, said critics were making too much of the matter, "especially when no one complained about the $200 million compensation package Bob Rubin got after leaving Goldman-Sachs."
Juleanna Glover, press secretary for Mr. Cheney, said Halliburton planned to disclose details of the retirement package on Wednesday. Details of the package Robert E. Rubin received after leaving the firm he headed to become chairman of President Clinton's National Economic Council in 1992 could not be independently confirmed.

HEADLINE: Some Progress in Phone Strike, But Agreement Proves Elusive

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
A quick end to the strike by more than 86,000 employees of Verizon Communications, the nation's largest telecommunications employer, appeared out of the grasp of negotiators yesterday after unions rejected parts of the company's latest proposal.
Verizon made a new contract offer at 1 a.m. yesterday that did not overcome the unions' objections. 
 "It is old wine in new bottles," said Robert Master, a spokesman for the Communications Workers of America, which represents the majority of the striking workers.
The communications workers' union and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, which represent Verizon employees in 12 Eastern states and Washington, D.C., are still at odds with the company on issues like mandatory overtime, stress levels and the movement of work resulting from Bell Atlantic's $72 billion acquisition of GTE, which formed Verizon.
Still, progress was made in establishing a framework for a contract for several dozen employees of Verizon's wireless unit. And both sides agree that perhaps the main stumbling block was overcome last week in an understanding that would allow unions to organize more easily at Verizon Wireless.
If anything, the strike illustrates an effort by organized labor to find its footing in the high-technology industries that are reshaping the economy. Instead of wages and benefits, the main objectives of the strike involve an effort to gain a union foothold in new areas and secure concessions for a work force weary of long hours and the concern that mergers might translate into fewer jobs.
Optimism over Verizon's concession in the wireless area gave way over the weekend to feelings among negotiators that a fast resolution to the strike, which is entering its ninth day, has become more remote.
The main difference remaining between the two sides concerns the movement of work resulting from the Bell Atlantic-GTE merger.
The unions are seeking to limit the movement of jobs or tasks by agreeing on a flat percentage of Verizon's work force of 260,000 employees that would be subject to such movement, similar to the half a percentage point agreed upon with Bell Atlantic after it bought Nynex in 1997.
Verizon, though, wants a more flexible agreement that would limit movement of work by measuring it in net additions or subtractions within a given region.
In one part of Verizon's offer, the company proposed limiting the number of employees who could transfer from stressful jobs at call centers to other parts of the company. The unions said this proposal would actually make matters worse, but the company said it was only part of the way it would address the issue.
In addition, the union reiterated concern over Verizon's move to expand in the high-speed Internet access business by acquiring NorthPoint Communications. Verizon told the unions that about 300 union-represented jobs would be shifted into the NorthPoint operation, but details involving the outsourcing of related tasks remained blurry, a person close to the talks said.
Although an overall agreement is within reach, both sides acknowledged that little progress was made over the weekend. If the walkout drags on, the communications workers' union said it would start using its $400 million strike fund on the 15th day of the strike. The fund would pay its members $200 a week, which would rise to $300 a week if the strike were to last a month.
Verizon said it had 90,000 repair requests yesterday, up from about 80,000 during most days last week, although the company attributed the increase to rainstorms that knocked out service in parts of several Eastern states. Meanwhile, the number of pickets thinned to about 750 yesterday, down from the thousands at Verizon sites each day last week.

LENGTH: 1118 words

HEADLINE: Destin Journal;
New Economy Eclipses A Sliver of Old Florida

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: DESTIN, Fla., Aug. 11

 BODY:
The sand dunes of Okaloosa Island, like snowbanks, line both sides of U.S. Highway 98 between Fort Walton and Destin, and they are so pretty that people weave off the road, looking at them. The golden sea oats waft in the summer breeze, and gnarled pines, blasted by hurricanes that hit or barely missed, lean from sand so purely white that the sun flashes off it like a mirror and hurts the eyes.
To the south, beyond the dunes, is the Gulf of Mexico, an emerald green when the sun is out and a deep, deep blue on cloudy days. And across the spit of the sand, to the north, is a wide bay, its water darker, a place where wading birds prowl the shallows, spearing fish and crabs. 
 But at 55 miles an hour, this three-mile stretch of protected, mostly undeveloped federal land flashes past in an instant. In the amount of time it takes a tourist to tune his car radio, the little oasis is gone.
And looking around at what has become of the rest of this part of the Florida Panhandle on each side of that stretch of sand, part of Eglin Air Force Base, it is enough to make some visitors wonder if what they saw was even real.
Concrete condominiums, as imposing as anything in Miami or Fort Lauderdale, line the beachfront on both ends of this paradise, blocking views of the Gulf. Tower cranes in the distance promise more.
Thick traffic on 98 moves like syrup on a cold day, and turning left against the gridlock, to one of the gigantic new seafood emporiums that look almost like amusement parks with their expanse of neon, can be hair rending. The real estate people have a term for this kind of growth: "Turning sand into money."
Fort Walton, to the west, is "built out," the locals like to say, but to the east, at Destin and beyond, the building boom is still raging. Destin, which had long been regarded as one of the last little jewels of coastal old Florida, has been transformed into a coastal city of condominiums.
"We have been discovered," said Commissioner Nick Nicholson of Okaloosa County.
It didn't happen overnight, it just seems like it to people who come only every few years. The Panhandle has been a prize for developers for decades. Destin, once known as the World's Luckiest Fishing Village, has been growing and changing for years.
Now the village is gone, at least the village that older people here remember.
The fishing is no longer so lucky.
"It's kind of heartbreaking to see it turn into a concrete jungle," said Dewey Destin, 47, great-great-grandson of the town's founder, Leonard Destin.
"It's a bittersweet feeling," said Mr. Destin, a part-owner of Destin Seafood Market and a city councilman since 1985. "There are more jobs, and the properties are worth more money.
"And it has destroyed our community. It has destroyed the local natural fishery. We now have much dirtier water. But this is what you get when you exchange nature for economic well-being."
People used to saunter across 98 in their bathing suits. Now, they wait for a break in the traffic, and run as if a mean dog were after them.
"If I had a choice, I would have restricted the development to have low density," said Mr. Destin, who points out that most zoning during the early boom years was handled by the county, not the city. "I would have done it much differently."
The population statistics show growth, but do not show the true changes in Destin and the surrounding coast. In 1970, the population of Okaloosa County was 88,188, according to state statistics. By 1990, it had climbed to 143,776, and by 1999 it had climbed to almost 180,000.
But the tourists and the part-time residents have truly altered the landscape, real estate figures show.
In 1990, there were 194 sales of new condos in southern Okaloosa County, which includes Destin, and in rapidly developing southern Walton County, to the east.
In 1999, there were 937 sales of new condos, many of which will be vacant for part or even much of the year, or leased to tourists.
The boom shows no sign of stopping. Sales of condos and town houses here almost doubled in just the past year.
Real estate developers say Destin and much of the rest of the Florida Panhandle have become a playground of the new, fat economy.
"Because of the boom, baby boomers and e-commuters are purchasing places as second homes or working from their homes here," said Dave W. Hubbard, a broker. "The younger generations are getting their money early on and coming to play on the water. Condos are starting at $300,000 and going to $1.4 million. That's about average for a Gulf view."
Some residents say it had to happen sooner or later, and make no excuses for the transformation.
"We knew that we weren't going to be able to keep this beauty secret for a long time," said Michael Beaubien, who owns Born to Boogie Charter Boat Fishing. "How could we put a fence around us and say, 'No, get out'?"
"Developers are not going to sit there and say, 'We'll take care of this land and leave it as a habitat for the redheaded woodpecker,' " Mr. Beaubien continued. "It's just not realistic to think that."
But people who loved it for what it was hate what it is.
"Storm water runoff has affected the bay, and all the fertilizers they put on the golf courses are killing it," said Jacquelyn L. Tatjes, a secretary at Sexton's Seafood, a place where locals and tourists have gone for years to get fresh shrimp and crabs to boil.
Ms. Tatjes has lived here 25 years, after fleeing the building booms in California. Here it is, she said, all over again.
"There's no way a local can even go to the beach," she said. "They say there's public access, but there's no parking. You can't even see the beach anymore."
And the new people have no connection to the place, beyond their time-share agreement or deed, longtime locals say.
"They're rude. Instead of accepting our heritage of a small town, they just want to change it," Ms. Tatjes said. "They want it to be just like where they came from. It's lost all its charm."
As soon as the value of her property peaks, she said, she is moving.
Others have already left.
Evan Bergwall is now a senior vice president at a bank in Neosho, Mo., a small city outside Joplin. Mr. Bergwall and his family left Destin this year, for good, after living here 10 years. "What I went there for disappeared," he said.
"As a place to get away," he said, "it isn't, anymore."
Like some exotic animal in a cage, the undeveloped stretch of land between Destin and Fort Walton is fenced off on the Gulf side. But people regularly cross the fence, climb the dunes and look at the water, and run or roll back down them.
They commit a small disobedience, just to see what, once, this was all like.

HEADLINE: A Small Case Of Identity Crisis;
Overlooked Rockland Divides Over Question Of Growth vs. Quiet Charm

BYLINE: By WINNIE HU 

DATELINE: RAMAPO, N.Y., Aug. 12

 BODY:
Upstate New Yorkers think of Rockland County as downstate, while downstate New Yorkers think of it as upstate, if they think about it at all. Many know it simply as the first rest stop after crossing the Tappan Zee Bridge: Rockland, New Jersey.
At just 176 square miles, Rockland is the smallest county in the state (after the five boroughs of New York City) and one that is often slighted because of its precarious foothold west of the Hudson River above New Jersey. Even some of its own residents say that Rockland is just the county that you have to go through to get somewhere else. 
 Yet geography is only partly to blame for this identity crisis. Although Rockland has pockets of wealth, it has never wielded the political muscle of Nassau, or enjoyed the same cachet as Westchester, its better-known neighbor across the Hudson. It has never produced a governor, and its most honored native, James A. Farley, the postmaster general under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, moved to Manhattan and was buried in Westchester. "It's another thing to be chagrined about," said Thomas F. X. Casey, the Rockland County historian.
Now, an increasing number of Rockland's citizens are seeking recognition and respect through a surge of civic activism: protests, town meetings, even bold threats to withhold tax money from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority if more local trains and buses are not provided. But at the same time, many other citizens are fighting to preserve the serene landscape and quiet charm that have long defined their county. Like so many places in the Hudson River Valley, Rockland seems caught between two contradictory impulses as it tries to decide whether it is ready for a larger role in the world and the headaches that come along with growth and visibility.
"There are people who preferred when Rockland was forgotten," said Craig H. Long, a police detective and historian for the town of Ramapo. "They were content, and didn't seek that recognition, because it was like a well-kept secret here. When you open up the county, you invite more problems. Some residents feel the worst thing that ever happened was the Tappan Zee."
Rockland -- the name is thought to have been inspired by the rocky soil -- was carved out of Orange County more than two centuries ago by British colonists and thrived for a time as an outpost for shipbuilders and manufacturers. But most of the county remained farmland until the Tappan Zee Bridge was built in 1955. "The opening of the Tappan Zee changed everything," said Mr. Casey, the county historian. "It changed Rockland from a semirural, sleepy county to a much larger county."
Nearly two-thirds of the county is now covered with industries, subdivisions and roads, while much of the rest has been preserved as parks or open space. In the past fiscal year, those industries created 3,100 new jobs, mainly in services and sales. This gave Rockland the second-highest job growth rate in the state, after Putnam County. Most of Rockland's citizens earn a comfortable living; the median income for a family of four is $82,400 a year, compared with $56,200 in New York City.
Yet desspite its growing affluence and visibility, Rockland continues to be dwarfed by its neighbors. The county has 284,022 residents, compared with 7.4 million in New York City, 1.3 million each in Nassau and Suffolk, and 905,572 in Westchester.
Frustrated Rockland residents say their concerns and issues are routinely ignored by numbers-driven media organizations and government agencies. "Let me put it to you this way," said Paul Adler, a real estate agent who is chairman of the county's Democratic Party. "One of the biggest thrills in Rockland is when the Channel 2 weatherman mentions we're going to have rain. Unlike Westchester or Long Island, the only time we make the news is when there's a murder or a flood."
They are still seething, for instance, over being assigned an 845 area code in June while Westchester was allowed to keep the longstanding 914 prefix. Though Rockland officials protested loudly, the Public Service Commission in Albany decided that more people would have been inconvenienced by changing the area code in Westchester. "Obviously, the common goal was to minimize any disruptions," said David Flanagan, a spokesman for the commission. "Westchester had a greater number of businesses and cellular phone users that would have been disrupted."
Rockland loyalists saw this as yet another affront. "I'm pretty upset," said Ron Javer, a media account executive from Ramapo, who likened it to being stuck away in a corner all over again. "Where is 845?" he asked. "Montana?"
Such complaints are nothing new, of course, in a sprawling state where 62 counties compete for the same resources. And for all its grumbling, Rockland actually fares better than many other counties because it is viewed as a swing district in state elections. Albany's political leaders actively court its voters -- 70,912 enrolled Democrats and 40,900 enrolled Republicans -- because they are known to stray across party lines.
State Senator Thomas P. Morahan, a Rockland Republican who is running for re-election this fall, said Gov. George E. Pataki and other Republican leaders had been very helpful in supporting county projects. He pointed to $840,000 in state funds this year to refurbish downtown areas in the villages of Suffern, Spring Valley and Haverstraw. "While we don't get as much as Westchester, we're not totally abandoned here," he said. "We are not the poor cousin."
State and county officials say it is nearly impossible to pinpoint Rockland's total portion of the state budget because it receives money under various programs and grants. But federal money is tracked more easily, and many county leaders contend that they have been shortchanged in that. Ryan S. Karben, a Democratic county legislator from Ramapo, said his research found that Rockland received only 1 percent of the federal dollars spent annually in New York even though it had 1.5 percent of the state's population.
"There is a need for a much more aggressive style of leadership," he said. "I think a new generation of leaders are going to demand that Rockland get better. I'm not content with crumbs."
One long-running skirmish has been over what county leaders see as a chronic shortage of bus and train service. After years of complaints, Rockland legislators passed a resolution in May that sought state approval to drop out of the M.T.A., which coordinates public transportation for New York City and seven downstate counties. C. Scott Vanderhoef, the county executive, said that Rockland contributed $33.6 million in taxes to the authority in 1998 but received only $11.7 million worth of service and capital improvements.
"They pay attention to enormous numbers," said Mr. Vanderhoef. "For them, this is a small issue; for us, it's big. If you're doing bottom-line stuff, Rockland has to fight harder and yell louder."
Christopher Boylan, the M.T.A.'s deputy executive director, said Rockland's size had not been a factor in decisions. The M.T.A. has continued to improve its services, he said, including pledging $41 million over the next five years to expand and refurbish train service west of the Hudson in Rockland and Orange. In addition, the M.T.A. has contributed $53 million to New Jersey Transit for a train station in Secaucus that will be used as a transfer point by Rockland residents commuting to New York City. "There are periods when member counties may get more than they put in, and some periods when they may put in more," he said. "When they put in money, it's for the benefit of the mobility of the entire region."
Rockland's citizens have not always defended their local interests so vigorously, and they say their county has suffered for that. First, the Tappan Zee Bridge ushered in traffic and pollution. Then, industries created environmental problems.
The federal Environmental Protection Agency has designated 4 Superfund sites in Rockland (compared with 2 in Westchester and 15 in Nassau) over the last two decades. While one of the Rockland sites has been fully cleaned, the others remain hazardous. At the newest site in Hillburn, Hudson Technologies spilled 7,500 pounds of freon last year that made its way into the drinking-water supply. Four wells had to be closed.
"I feel like I'm at ground zero again," said Geoff Welch, a musician who moved to Ramapo in 1981 to escape the pollution and crowds of Manhattan only to spend his free time researching Rockland's environmental issues. "That's why I'm standing my ground and fighting. I could move further out, but the same thing would happen all over again."
Mr. Welch and many others have banded together to preserve their way of life from the dual threats of development and the ambitions of fellow Rockland citizens. In the villages of South Nyack and Nyack, many residents are fighting a proposed expansion of the Tappan Zee Bridge in their backyard. But elsewhere in the county, others say it would help alleviate congestion. A state task force appointed by Governor Pataki has advocated replacing the aging structure with a wider, $4 billion bridge and rail system to accommodate the growing traffic.
In Ramapo, a dozen community groups are trying to block construction of two power plants that they say would drain their water supply and ruin their view of Torne Mountain, a spot immortalized by the Hudson River School painters. Yet, at the same time, two other power plants proposed for the town of Haverstraw have received a much different welcome. Many residents there say the plants will generate more jobs and income from taxes.
Such contradictory impulses have divided Rockland's citizens and perplexed outsiders who do not know what to make of the mixed signals. Does the county want growth and more transportation links to New York City? Or does it really want to hold on to the last vestiges of a rural life that once thrived here? There seems to be no consensus.
On a recent afternoon, Mr. Welch and his neighbors in Ramapo showed off a billboard warning: "Stop the power plants. Once it's up, it's over." But several of the neighbors hastened to add that they were not trying to stop economic growth, just the problems that come along with it.
"People zip by on the highway and they don't realize the history and the wildlife in this county," said Mr. Welch as he pointed with pride to the craggy peak of Torne Mountain rising above low-lying buildings. "We have a lot of work to do to bring it to their attention and give it the respect it deserves."

HEADLINE: THE DEMOCRATS: THE FORMER PRESIDENT;
At Clinton's Twilight, Memories of Reagan's Farewell

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13

 BODY:
When you watch President Clinton at the Democratic convention, it may look as if he is stealing President Ronald Reagan's script from 1988. As Mr. Reagan did then, Mr. Clinton plans to bless his No. 2 officially on Monday evening. As Mr. Reagan did then, Mr. Clinton is expected to implore Americans to build on the triumphs of the current administration.
As was the case 12 years ago, members of the party faithful are a bit edgy about their ticket and grouse that their new standard-bearer is not nearly as dynamic as the man he wants to replace. While Mr. Reagan savored a 54 percent job approval rating in the New York Times/CBS News Poll on the eve of his party's convention in 1988 -- impressive for a lame duck -- Mr. Clinton's stands even higher, at 61 percent. 
 Yet for all the apparent similarities, the two presidents' approaches toward their valedictory appearances could not have been more different. While Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton have been roundly accused of hogging the spotlight from his vice president, Mr. Reagan drew plaudits for how he choreographed the passing of power in his party.
While Mr. Clinton popped up in Los Angeles on Friday for fund-raisers and appearances that drowned out the attention -- and complicated fund-raising -- for Al Gore, Mr. Reagan did not arrive in New Orleans until the Sunday before the convention 12 years ago.
Mr. Reagan pulled off what was widely described as a sentimental, nostalgic and certainly graceful journey. He was greeted at a rally in New Orleans to shouts of "Four more years! Four more years!" Delegates wiped tears from their eyes as the president at the convention hailed the party for lighting "a prairie fire" that he said transformed the nation. He promised never to bid a final goodbye.
By contrast, the gossip among delegates, lobbyists and hangers-on here was whether Mr. Clinton would ever -- or even should -- say goodbye.
Even as they acknowledged that Mr. Clinton is dominating the ramp up to the convention, many delegates sounded wistful about his leaving the White House. Some said they did not view Mr. Gore as alluring a leader.
"We all know that if there were not term limits, Bill Clinton would be running for president again," said Martha Aasen, a delegate from Westport, Conn. "Gore doesn't turn me on. He's different. He's sincere. He knows the issues, but he's different." She was glad, she said, that Mr. Gore was not speaking until three days after Mr. Clinton, so there will not be back-to-back comparisons.
Roger Short, a delegate from Detroit, took issue with those who are eager for Mr. Clinton to leave. "He's still the president and has every right to be here," he said. "He raises a lot of money that other Democrats are certainly willing to take. Let's not beat the guy up for his mistakes in the White House."
The difference, of course, between the Clinton and Reagan models is that while Vice President George Bush tried to distance himself from Mr. Reagan on the Iran-contra case, he did not have to worry about being connected to anything approaching the embarrassment of Mr. Clinton's personal scandals. So Mr. Gore is faced with the far more confounding task of trying to take credit for the booming economy encouraged by the current administration but not wanting to be linked to the baggage.
Joe Andrew, the Democratic national chairman, said the party studied Mr. Reagan's approach in 1988 but decided that Mr. Clinton had a different place in his party.
"Most people would see the transfer in 1988 as being successful; it was gracefully done," Mr. Andrew said. "But there was a very different goal. They wanted George Bush to be Ronald Reagan."
Asked then if the Democratic Party did not want Al Gore to be Bill Clinton, he demurred, saying, "We want Al Gore to simply be Al Gore."
It is especially striking that Mr. Clinton has been ridiculed for pulling attention from Mr. Gore given that he has been much more aggressive in helping his vice president than was Mr. Reagan. In fact, Mr. Reagan's endorsement of Mr. Bush was so feeble -- almost like an afterthought -- that he had to clarify his comments the next day.
Robert M. Teeter, who was a top strategist for Mr. Bush, said Mr. Clinton's transgressions are a horrible burden for the vice president. "We had the challenge of Bush having to establish himself in his own right," he said. "In Gore's case, it's a very difficult strategy because the economy's in pretty good shape but people want a change. There's real tension."
David Leland, the chairman of the Ohio Democratic Party, said he understands the political need for Mr. Clinton to depart on Tuesday to leave the stage for Mr. Gore. That doesn't mean he is happy about it.
"I'm in the same hotel as Bill Clinton and I'd love to have him stay around," Mr. Leland said. "We can go out and shoot pool, go have steaks. Whatever."

HEADLINE: How an Illinois County Cleared the Welfare Rolls

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: RUSHVILLE, Ill., Aug. 11

 BODY:
Holly E. Cain, manager of the local welfare office, used to post job openings for welfare recipients just inside the front door of her agency here. She nearly put herself out of business. Welfare disappeared from this county. For more than a year, there have been no new cases, no old cases, no one on the rolls receiving cash assistance.
Mrs. Cain still clips and posts help-wanted advertisements from local merchants, schools and hospitals. But the notices are no longer intended for welfare recipients. All sorts of people stop by to check what jobs might be available. 
 "That's new," said Mrs. Cain, who has run the four-person Schuyler County office of the Illinois Department of Human Services for 20 years. "It's a very positive change."
Schuyler, on the prairie west of Springfield, Ill., was the first county in the state and one of the first in the nation to be "welfare-free." As other counties have approached that status, they have found that the last cases are among the most difficult.
This county, with a population of about 7,500, illustrates in microcosm some of the profound changes that have transformed much of the nation's welfare system since President Clinton signed a landmark welfare law on Aug. 22, 1996.
The elimination of cash assistance here resulted not just from a strong economy, but also from hard work by local welfare officials, who gave lots of personal attention to each case -- and who have many lessons to teach the rest of the country. With practice, they became adept at matching welfare recipients with jobs.
Virtually all the former welfare recipients in Schuyler County have kept their jobs or moved on to higher-paying jobs, Mrs. Cain said.
But poverty has not disappeared here, and life is not easy for the former welfare recipients, some of whom take home less than $1,000 a month from their jobs. But they say they have more self-confidence and self-esteem because they are earning paychecks and not getting cash assistance any more.
"It was scary," said Karen J. DeMoss, 46, describing her transition to work after 12 years on welfare. "But I have more confidence now. And I wish I had gotten off public aid a long time ago."
Ms. DeMoss once held factory jobs, but in her years on welfare she got into a rut. Tears welled up as she recalled how she had to explain to her two teenage sons that the family was poor. That was three years ago. Now, she said, the boys are proud of her because she caters banquets and wedding receptions. "They think it's nice their mom can cook for 300 people," Ms. DeMoss said.
Likewise, Deanna D. Zeisler, 34, who now works in a restaurant and does cleaning, said: "I didn't feel good when I was on public aid. I feel good about myself now. I'm working. It feels good to have a paycheck in my name. It may be a tiny paycheck, but I earned it. It wasn't just handed to me."
Life is still austere for Ms. Zeisler. "I can't afford to go to the movies," she said. She volunteers at the local theater, taking tickets and selling popcorn, in return for the privilege of seeing a film with her three sons.
The goals of the 1996 law and the intent of Congress are understood by Mrs. Cain and her colleagues at the welfare office here. Drawing on their experience and their contacts in the community, they devised a strategy to carry out the law by matching workers with jobs.
"We didn't wave a magic wand," Mrs. Cain said of her effort to whittle down the welfare rolls. Her supervisor at the regional office in Springfield, Gregory Matarelli, said "it's not happenstance" that Schuyler County was the first to eliminate welfare, though that was never an explicit goal.
The welfare office here went about its work methodically and systematically. Whenever a welfare recipient got a job, Mrs. Cain or her caseworkers would call the person every two or three weeks for five months, to make sure the person kept the job.
"We pretty well know most of our clients, or their family members," Mrs. Cain said. (In 1995, the last year for which Census Bureau estimates are available, Schuyler County had a median household income of $27,370, about 80 percent of the comparable figure for the nation as a whole.)
Of the 102 counties in Illinois, four others -- Cumberland, Hardin, Putnam and Washington -- had no welfare cases in July. A total of 53 had fewer than 20 cases each.
State officials pay close attention to those counties. They receive a monthly report describing the circumstances of each family on welfare in any county with fewer than 50 cases. Supervisors like Mr. Matarelli want to know if the families are working, and if not, why not. They discuss each case with local officials, suggesting techniques that have proved effective in other counties.
As the number of cases dwindled, Mrs. Cain formed a "5 o'clock club" for those who remained on welfare -- the cash assistance program officially known as Temporary Assistance for Needy Families. They met on Monday evenings to share their job-hunting experiences.
"They gave support to one another," Mrs. Cain said. "They listened to one another much more readily than they'd listen to me standing up there saying the same thing."
Ms. DeMoss said caseworkers prodded her to start looking for work. "They made it sound like a positive thing, not like it was doomsday and we'd be out on the street with nothing," she said.
The number of families on welfare in Illinois has fallen below 100,000 this year for the first time in three decades. State officials say 86,600 families are receiving cash assistance, down from a peak of 247,800 in 1994. More than two-thirds of the cases are in Cook County, which includes Chicago, but even in that county the number of families receiving cash assistance has declined by 50 percent in the last three years.
Illinois differed from many other states in one crucial respect. It encouraged people to hold on to Medicaid and food stamps after they took jobs and lost cash assistance.
The number of people in Schuyler County receiving Medicaid or food stamps rose to 418 in July of this year from 368 in July 1997, even as the number of people on cash assistance dropped to zero.
In many states, people were inadvertently dropped from Medicaid when they lost cash assistance. But in Illinois, state and local officials saw Medicaid as an indispensable form of assistance that could help tens of thousands of welfare recipients take low-wage jobs offering no health insurance benefits. Indeed, Mr. Matarelli and Mrs. Cain said they had audited the records of closed welfare cases to make sure families were receiving the medical and food assistance to which they were entitled.
Linda Renee Baker, secretary of the Illinois Department of Human Services, said, "We are aggressive about letting families know they may still be eligible for food stamps and Medicaid." In addition, she said, the state increased spending on child care by 30 percent this year, to $648 million.
The staff at the Schuyler County welfare office has not been reduced, despite the absence of welfare recipients since April 1999. Mrs. Cain said the four employees still had plenty of work to do, arranging Medicaid, food stamps, child care, transportation and other services for needy county residents, including former welfare recipients. Mr. Matarelli said those services helped welfare recipients "get some traction in the economic mainstream."
Cumberland County, in east central Illinois, had 143 welfare cases in September 1994 and has not had any in 8 of the last 12 months. Asked why the numbers were so low, Paul D. Marti Jr., manager of the local welfare office, said, "It's a combination of good case work, a good economy and good follow-up."
If trends continue, Mr. Marti said, many more counties may become welfare-free. "That would mean that everyone has gotten work or has been assisted in some way to get beyond welfare," he said. But, he added, "State officials discourage talk of that goal," for fear that caseworkers might improperly limit access to welfare if they focused too much on caseload statistics rather than on serving clients.
Mrs. Cain and Mr. Marti said the last cases were the most difficult because these welfare recipients often had mental or physical disabilities, alcohol or drug abuse problems, little work experience, few job skills and limited education.
"But," Mr. Marti said, "because the numbers are so low, you have a lot more time to work with clients, and you can focus on them quite a bit. They're the toughest cases, but they're also the most gratifying when you're able to help them."

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 789 words

HEADLINE: The Indispensable State

 BODY:
Seemingly overnight, California has become for Democrats what the South once was in national elections -- their indispensable electoral building block. So it is fitting for them to celebrate in Los Angeles what they hope will prove a seamless transition from the Age of Clinton to the Age of Gore.
In no other state has the triumph of Clintonism been greater. The magnitude of this triumph was evident at the Republican convention in Philadelphia. Not a single power broker hailed from the nation's largest state -- a state without which no Republican presidential candidate won the presidency in the 20th century. Among the throngs of Congressional leaders and governors assembled in Philadelphia, the only statewide Republican officeholder from California was Secretary of State Bill Jones. And he had endorsed John McCain. 
 Things have gotten that bad for Republicans in the state of Earl Warren, Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan -- a state that was represented on more than half the G.O.P.'s postwar presidential tickets. Lest his party's delegates forget they are reveling in what was once called Reagan Country, President Clinton may want to remind his hosts this evening that in 1992 he was the first Democratic presidential candidate since Lyndon Johnson to carry the state.
The contested center of Californian politics has long been fiscally conservative and socially liberal, and President Clinton helped break the Republican dominance in the state by catering to these affinities. Positioning his as the party of balanced budgets and free trade left Republicans to wallow in the morass of immigration, abortion and guns.
Democrats may want to pay homage to the special role of Pete Wilson, the former Republican governor, in the state party's reversal of fortunes. His anti-immigrant crusade, a political blunder of epic proportions, may keep the state in the Democratic column long after the adopted son from Arkansas (this is the president's 55th trip to California while in office) leaves the scene.
Governor Wilson fashioned his anti-immigrant pitch in the throes of a devastating recession early in the 1990's, one made more severe than elsewhere in the nation by the post-cold-war downsizing of the state's defense industry. At the time, appealing to disgruntled middle-class whites seemed like a winning strategy. Indeed, Governor Wilson was re-elected in 1994 while backing Proposition 187, an initiative to deprive illegal immigrants of access to education and other social services.
But the long-term damage to the party proved devastating. Along with other Republican-backed measures aimed at overturning bilingual education and affirmative action, Proposition 187 drove a whole generation of Hispanics into the Democratic fold. Mr. Wilson garnered 44 percent of the Hispanic vote when he first ran for governor in 1990. By 1998, however, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, Dan Lungren, received less than 20 percent.
Worse, the G.O.P.'s is a shrinking slice of a rapidly growing pie. Hispanics make up about a third of the state's population and are expected to become the majority in the next half-century.
Meanwhile, many of the less-educated, disgruntled Anglos who may have applauded the state Republican Party's drift to the right have left the state. The recession triggered a massive migration, well over a million of them, in the first half of the decade. To those who remained in California to experience the current tide of prosperity, the party leadership's view of immigration as more of a threat than an opportunity seemed bizarrely defeatist. Where once Ronald Reagan rhapsodized about America being a shining city on a hill, Pete Wilson now wanted to build a moat around it.
But a word of caution is in order for California Democrats as they uncork the Champagne bottles this week. Independents, not Democrats, are the only growing category of registered voters. Recent polls suggest the race could be closer in California than previously thought, and Vice President Al Gore's choice of Senator Joseph Lieberman as his running mate could dampen the enthusiasm of the party's Hollywood backers.
Democrats would also be foolish to take the votes of Hispanics, those Americans most likely to still live in a traditional family, for granted. This is particularly true if Gov. George W. Bush succeeds in his effort to broaden his party's voting base. In his book "Cadillac Desert," Marc Reisner called California a "beautiful fraud," referring to how much of the desert state was transformed into a verdant mirage. It may yet prove that to political analysts too eager to read permanence into the current political snapshot. Things change, especially in Reagan Country.

HEADLINE: THE DEMOCRATS: LOS ANGELES DIARY;
Lieberman Injects Bit of Yiddish, Clintons Stay Late and Connecticut Is Noticed

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB and ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Maybe Jackie Mason should worry. After all, the Democratic vice-presidential candidate seems to enjoy using Yiddish words like "chutzpah" and Jewish-style phrases that have not often been heard on the national campaign trail.
Just this morning, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman was asked by Tim Russert on NBC's "Meet the Press," what would happen if the Gore-Lieberman ticket won the presidency. The inauguration date is Jan. 20, 2001, a Saturday. As an Orthodox Jew, Mr. Lieberman strictly observes the Sabbath, from sundown on Fridays to sundown on Saturdays, which ostensibly prohibits working, riding in vehicles and other activities. 
 Mr. Lieberman smiled. "Well, as my mother would say, Tim, if she were here, 'Sweetheart, we should have such a problem.' "
He went on to say that he would probably stay near the Capitol on Friday night, to avoid having to travel by car. And, if the Secret Service agreed, he would walk from the Capitol to the White House to participate in the events.
Mr. Lieberman said that he has driven on the Sabbath in the past if important issues were at stake.
The senator has talked about his religious roots and convictions repeatedly -- an issue intertwined with his negative views about Hollywood morality and what he has termed the avalanche of films, television and music that are excessively violent or sexual.
Today, the senator said he would not back down on those views, even though many Hollywood executives and performers are Democrats and are contributing heavily to the campaign.
Privately, several prominent Democrats in the entertainment industry have said that contributors like Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen, two of the owners of the film company DreamWorks, have been called by Vice President Al Gore, who is sensitive to Hollywood's uneasiness with Mr. Lieberman, and asked their opinion of his running mate and that they not publicly criticize the choice.
Mr. Gore got what he wanted. Criticisms have been muted. The moguls got what they wanted. A call from the presidential candidate asking for a favor.
Mr. Lieberman's Jewish roots, of course, are the talk of Hollywood. At a fund-raiser on Saturday night, the comedian Red Buttons came onstage to the music of "Hava Nagilla." Mr. Buttons grinned, calling the song, "The Democratic Party's new campaign song."
 
And the Clintons Hung On
It was not a Bill Clinton record for partying late, but it came close.
The president who loves Hollywood did not leave a Brentwood fund-raiser top heavy with the B list -- Cher, Paul Anka, Milton Berle, Diana Ross, Michael Bolton -- until 1:45 this morning, and did not get back to his hotel until 2:10 a.m.
Maybe that was because the president's wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, who is running for the Senate in New York, was having a good time sitting at dinner next to Brad Pitt, who came with his new wife, Jennifer Aniston.
Or maybe it was because Mr. Clinton was intent on clinging to every moment of his waning presidency.
"I was thinking how quickly it all passed and what an absolute joy it was," the president told the 1,400 people who raised, depending on the estimate, from $1 million to $4 million for his wife's Senate campaign and the Democratic Party.
The president added: "I used to tell people in some of the dark days, when they'd say, don't you sometimes regret that you ever got into this -- I'd say, Lord, no. Just a few twists in the road and I could be home doing real estate transactions in a musty loft."
Hollywood, which also billed the event as a "gala salute to William Jefferson Clinton," fell over itself with sometimes bizarre accolades.
From Stan Lee, the Marvel Comic books publishing tycoon, the creator of Spider-Man and a host of the party: "I'm a guy who's dealt with super heroes most of my life, and sir, you have great potential. I think you would learn to climb the side of buildings and wear spandex tights. I think I could make you famous."
From John Travolta, who, in the movie "Primary Colors," played a Clinton-like president: "If I were hungry, you'd sit right down and eat a cheeseburger with me, not even suggesting holding the fries. But now, if I were president, what would I miss? Well I would miss flying around in that classic 707. Now, I happen to own one of those puppies. And if you and the missis ever need a ride."
It was not until the very end of the party -- held under the lemon and grapefruit trees on the estate of Ken Roberts, a radio and real estate magnate -- that anyone even got around to mentioning the name of the Democratic presidential nominee. And that had to come from the president himself. "He understands the future," Mr. Clinton said of Vice President Al Gore. "He was talking about global warming when we ran in '92, and people were still making fun of him."
Mr. Clinton got teary-eyed several times during the evening, but tried to reassure the audience: "I'm not going anywhere except to a different line of work. I'll try to be a useful citizen and I'll try to hang around."
 
A Republican in the Crowd
Democratic revelers at the Century Plaza Hotel, the convention home for the New York delegation, were somewhat startled to see Bruce J. Teitelbaum turn up.
Mr. Teitelbaum, a Republican, was the aggressive Senate campaign manager for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani until the mayor withdrew from the race in May and left him unemployed.
So just what was he doing at the hotel? Gathering intelligence, perhaps?
"I'm going to relax a little bit," said Mr. Teitelbaum, whose wife, Suri Kasirer, a Democrat, is a Gore fund-raiser and a delegate from New York. Ms. Kasirer was staying at the Century Plaza, Mr. Teitelbaum said, while he was staying at the Peninsula.
"She has her hotel, I have mine," he said. "We visit each other."
 
For Connecticut, Star Power
The Connecticut delegation suddenly finds itself with new cachet and the selection of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman has suddenly infused the small state's Democratic delegates with star power.
Connecticut Democrats allowed that their state does not exactly have a reputation for Bacchanalian revelry. Nobody comes to Trumbull for Mardi Gras, as one delegate dryly noted. And until a week ago, the only official event the delegation had scheduled in Los Angeles was a reception last night sponsored by the natural gas industry.
Now, however, all people and things connected to Connecticut are in demand, and the gas party was something of a hot ticket, though Mr. Lieberman was not arriving in town until Monday night.
"People have been calling me wondering how to get into it," said William Curry, a onetime gubernatorial candidate and former White House official, who sat next to Mr. Lieberman in the State Senate years ago. "I would flatly say, the number of inquiries I would normally receive for something like this would be close to zero."
"If such things could run to negative numbers, chances are I'd be getting calls from delegates saying, 'How can I get out of this?' "
