SECTION: Section C;Page 1;Column 2;Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1784 words

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Shuffling the Deck at Pearson;
But Are the Moves Too Fast to Follow?

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
The folks back in Texarkana, Tex., should be proud of Marjorie Scardino. True to her Lone Star State roots, Mrs. Scardino, the chief executive of Pearson P.L.C., thinks big.
Since January 1997, when she took charge of Pearson -- a British publisher whose holdings include Penguin Books, The Economist magazine, The Financial Times newspaper and a major educational publishing operation -- Mrs. Scardino has overhauled the formerly sleepy company, engineering numerous major acquisitions and asset sales as well as many smaller deals. 
 The result, Mrs. Scardino contends, is a media company poised for growth by extending its books, newspapers and magazines into online, interactive communications. But the dizzying pace of change has made it difficult for even some sophisticated financial analysts to gauge the impact of the makeover.
"Analyzing how the existing businesses are performing is very difficult, which makes it tough to evaluate management," said Michael Nathanson, a publishing industry analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
So far, investors in Britain seem to love Mrs. Scardino's attempt to propel a stodgy company into the new economy. Since she took the reins, the stock, which trades on the London Stock Exchange, has nearly tripled the performance of Britain's main index, the Financial Times Stock Exchange 100.
"There is a Marjorie factor," one analyst said. "They think she can do magic."
And the company is so confident of investor support that Pearson has secured a listing on the New York Stock Exchange, where its shares will begin trading in September.
Just last month Mrs. Scardino announced Pearson's purchase of National Computer Systems, based in Minneapolis, for $2.5 billion in cash. The purchase is meant to let Pearson expand its electronic educational business to include testing services and the connection of schools to homes.
Pearson is raising the money for the deal through a rights offering that creates roughly 25 percent more shares -- a move that worried some investors because the shares were sold at below-market prices. Nonetheless, investors and analysts generally supported the deal. And despite some concerns that Pearson was making yet another high-priced acquisition, analysts generally found it a good strategic fit.
"We really think education will change, and technology has given people the way to change it," an enthusiastic Mrs. Scardino said in a telephone interview last week. "It gives us the way to integrate the assessment portion of education in our school programs."
Worthy as the deal may be, though, it goes on a Pearson plate already heaped with acquisitions still waiting to be digested -- including the educational book division of Simon & Schuster, which Pearson bought for $4.6 billion in 1998.
Mrs. Scardino has, meanwhile, been unflinching in selling high-profile, but peripheral, operations, like the group that owns Madame Tussaud's wax museum, Pearson's stake in various Lazard Freres investment arms, and its holdings in the BSkyB satellite broadcasting business. But at some point, analysts say, Pearson's chief will need to demonstrate her ability to manage the company she has recast in her image.
Michael Picker, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, wrote last week in a report that recommended holding, but not buying, the stock that "management is increasingly important, as publishers attempt to shift from a preservation focus to a growth focus."
Evaluating management skills is particularly difficult at a company that is undergoing change at such lightning speed. Even a key measurement -- profits or losses from continuing operations -- tends to be a floating figure on such a fluid ledger.
Profits and losses generated by one-time transactions have accounted for an unusually large -- and varying -- chunk of operating profit before taxes. In 1998, for example, the company reported 250 million, or $376.2 million, in operating profits. That represented 37.4 percent of profits before taxes and interest. Last year, it posted 318 million in operating profits, which accounted for about 50 percent of the 627 million in profits before taxes and interest. The balance was asset sales that included 348 million from the sale of Pearson's stake in the BSkyB satellite broadcasting business.
This year, analysts' estimates vary, but a new Morgan Stanley report projects Pearson's profits from continuing operations at 357 million, or 62 percent of profits before restructuring charges and interest.
To reduce it all to the simplest numbers: net per-share earnings rose from 6 pence in 1997 to 74.1 pence in 1998 and fell back to 48.2 pence last year.
"A company whose financials change so dramatically with acquisitions and sales, as evidenced by the huge percentage of profits generated by transactions, makes it impossible with any certainty to see what is happening to the performance of the underlying operations," said Bruce Greenwald, a professor of finance and economics at Columbia University's business school. "That issue is crucial to the future because acquisition activity only makes sense if supported by strong operating abilities."
In any acquisition, a buyer has some flexibility about writing down costs in the year of the purchase. With publishing companies, for example, those costs may include a portion of the expenses of creating educational reading programs, paying writers' advances and carrying inventory. Depending on how the numbers are recorded, future profit projections can look better than they might have otherwise.
Pearson's publishing operations represented 52 percent of its $5.37 billion in 1999 sales. But while the company provided pro forma comparisons for sales between 1998 and 1999, to reflect the acquisitions, it did not provide pro forma numbers for 1998 operating profits.
Mr. Nathanson of Bernstein expressed his frustration over this issue in a recent report. "Pro forma historical comparisons are difficult to make, to say the least," he wrote.
Even some bottom-line estimates are particularly complex. For example, Pearson releases three different per-share earnings figures -- earnings per equity share, earnings after removing one-time charges but before Internet investments, and earnings per share after one-time charges and after Internet investments.
A Pearson spokesman, John Phallon, contends that such numbers illuminate, rather than obscure, its financial performance because they distinguish performance before and after acquisitions. Still, Mr. Nathanson and a second analyst who insisted on anonymity said that separating out Internet spending implied that Pearson wanted outsiders to view it is a mere extra. "The reality is that Internet spending is not an option," Mr. Nathanson said. "It is a necessity, given their businesses."
Mr. Phallon added that the company also provided "underlying sales growth, trading margins" and other measures to help investors. And he said that providing 1998 pro forma figures for the Simon & Schuster unit would have been difficult since its former owner, Viacom, treated costs in a different way than Pearson. Still, Mr. Nathanson said those comparisons would have been helpful.
Several other analysts said they too found the numbers exceedingly complex. But they said they were leery of being critical for fear that Pearson could make access more difficult. Mr. Phallon contends he has found no difficulty among analysts "in understanding how we present our financial results."
Some deals, experts acknowledged, have been extremely clever. Mr. Nathanson cited Pearson's television programming units, which were worth about $1.5 billion before Mrs. Scardino formed an alliance with Bertlesmann and CLT-UFA, the big European broadcaster, to create Audiofina. Pearson's 22 percent of Audiofina currently has a market value of $4.84 billion.
And yet, the premium prices paid for some recent acquisitions have put extra pressure on Pearson's management to make them pay off. Pearson paid $466 million, or about 1.6 times annual sales, for the small children's book publisher Dorling Kindersly -- a high multiple by traditional standards, according to industry executives. The price for National Computer Systems was 50 times annual profits, which analysts have also generally characterized as top dollar.
And while Pearson's expansions may bring many advantages, size alone is not magical. Even after combining Pearson's existing educational businesses with the Simon & Schuster unit, the company has had mixed results in persuading schools to use its books. Though Pearson has done well in California, for example, its performance in Texas has been mediocre.
Peter Jovanovich, president of Pearson Publishing, said he was pleased that educational sales were up 15 percent, but added, "I wish we had done better in Texas."
And not all publishing experts are impressed by Pearson's heavy investment in the education market. "Why couldn't Pearson have done a joint venture with N.C.S.," one industry expert said of the National Computer deal. "Why did they need to buy it?"
Mr. Jovanovich said that National Computing's software programs for helping parents and teachers assess students' classroom performance could be complementary to Pearson's textbook business and online testing operations.
And while Pearson says that it can find $50 million in cost savings by combining with National Computer, gaining additional revenues could be a far trickier route to increased profitability. To one expert in the educational technology field, the issue will be getting two different cultures to work together.
"Creating educational content is different from building and testing administrative software for the schools," this person said, speaking on condition of anonymity to avoid riling Pearson in a field in which the company holds increasing power. "The question is whether they can integrate the educational experience and combine it with the assessment business."
Pearson itself had initially considered only an alliance with National Computer and had even discussed that possibility with the company. But when National Computer's chairman, Russ Gullotti, said he was going to retire, he approached Mr. Jovanovich about assuming his position. Mrs. Scardino -- always on the lookout for a deal -- chose to buy the company, perhaps, in part, because she was concerned about losing Mr. Jovanovich.
Now, while Mr. Jovanovich and other Pearson managers toil to incorporate this latest acquisition, investors and analysts will have their work cut out for them, too -- trying to get a fix on Mrs. Scardino's ever-changing company.

An article in Business Day on Aug. 15 about business deals by Pearson P.L.C. of Britain misstated the title of an executive and the unit he runs. Peter Jovanovich is chief executive of Pearson Education, not president of Pearson Publishing. The article also misspelled the name of a Pearson spokesman. He is John Fallon, not Phallon.
The article also referred imprecisely to the reporting of Pearson's financial results. The company's financial statements include one-time gains and losses in profit before taxes and interest, not in operating profit.

HEADLINE: Australians Pushing Away From the Table

BYLINE: By BECKY GAYLORD 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia

 BODY:
Chalk up another victim of America's eat-on-the-run workplace culture.
First it was the French. Traditionalists watched in horror as white-collar drones in the homeland of haute cuisine, caught up in the pressures of the global economy, began abandoning the wine-soaked three-hour lunch in the 1980's. 
 But who would have thought Australians -- that independent-minded, fun-loving lot Down Under -- would also succumb to the capitalist credo that productivity and profit-making constitute a higher calling than a leisurely midday meal?
Alas, the evidence of the Australian office worker's apostasy is everywhere. Start with the upscale rotating Summit restaurant, situated atop a skyscraper in the heart of the business district, where lunchtime business bustled a decade ago. "They used to fill the buffet from 1 to 3," said Jenny-Lee Stefas, who took over last year as sales and marketing manager.
How times have changed. By 1999, even after a refurbishment that included funky red carpet, sleek white chairs and a minimalist "Space Odyssey" theme, business had dropped off so much that on some days only three or four customers showed up, Ms. Stefas says. That left room for 347 more.
To lure more business people, the restaurant took aim at their weak spot and advertised a rich repast in one hour flat. Business has tripled, to an average 75 diners. They are able to sit down at noon and order, say, warm chili prawns with mango and cucumber relish followed by crisp-skin Tasmanian salmon with green-pea puree, tomato provencale and olive oil, all of it washed down with a good wine, and be out the door by 1. And if the Summit fails to deliver on the one-hour guarantee, customers win a one-night stay at a country resort.
Other top-flight restaurants have begun speeding things up. Late last year, the highly regarded MG Garage restaurant put together a quick-lunch special for 25 Australian dollars, or $15. "You can come here with a main course and a glass of wine already chosen to go with it, and that alone cuts the time of having to look at the menu and decide," said Janni Kyritsis, MG Garage's head chef.
For years, American business people have eschewed wine at weekday lunches. In Australia, the trend is newer, but growing. "If you go out for a boozy lunch, you write your whole afternoon off," said Leigh Anderson, a manager at Morgan & Banks, an executive recruitment firm here. "People can't afford to do that."
Not that Mr. Anderson is a stranger to the long lunch. He said that at the company he worked for six years ago in London it "was almost a condition of your employment to take people out for lunch."
And they could be fairly liquid affairs, he confessed. Now, at Morgan & Banks, he said, "we tend to discourage that."
Harland Koops, a partner at the law firm of Henry Davis York, has also weaned himself of long lunches, though he says he was never a regular player on the lunch circuit. "Calvinistic instincts seem to be reasserting themselves," Mr. Koops said.
Clients, he added, "really have their heads down making money, and they're not playing as much as they used to."
Ah, the good old days, Australian business people claimed a leisurely lunch of several courses and accompanying wines, followed by dessert and coffee, as a national privilege.
Until late last year, even the bond market closed for a respectable hour and a half -- one of only a handful in the world to cease business in the middle of the day. Throughout the 1980's and into the early 90's, that shutdown created the occasional phenomenon known as the claret run. "That's when a market would go on a seemingly inexplicable rally," one money market dealer explained. "And it was based on the fact that a few people would come back from lunch all liquored up and decide they liked the market and start buying it."
Sometimes, they would not come back at all, and the business lunch would slide into dinner. Such epicureans were known as F.T.R.'s, for "failed to return."
So what happened? What drove Aussies toward midday temperance?
Time-poor, cholesterol-rich executives cite not just the global economy and the competitive pressures it has unleashed, but also fitness concerns. An increasing number are heading out for a lunch-hour jog or a session with a personal trainer. Or else they are eating at their desks so they can leave early for some surfing or golf.
There was also the government's elimination of tax-deductible lunches in two stages -- the first in the 1980's, the second in the mid-1990's. Tony Bilson, director of the chic Ampersand Restaurant, called that change a "body blow." It was followed by a new 10 percent tax on restaurant meals, that began on July 1, presaging even harder times to come. The trade at midday is so thin on some days that Mr. Bilson occasionally mulls shutting Ampersand for lunch.
The same gastronomic drama has been playing itself in other parts of the world, notably France, where long, liquid lunches were for years a sacred ritual. No more. Listen to Capucine Favet, 26, a designer of street events for W.M., an outdoor-event company in Paris. "Everyone goes out to the boulangerie, and comes back with bread, or cheese or something, and eats together as a group," Ms. Favet says.
The trend toward faster midday meals has been long in the making in France, but got a fresh nudge in January with a law that bans salaried employees from putting in more than 35 hours a week. In response, many companies have stopped counting lunch hours in the figure, said Patrick Lenain, an economist with the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. "Now people who take two or three hours are executives, and it's business lunches with clients," Mr. Lenain said.
In Australia, though, all the changes put together are not likely to deter die-hard diners. "I work with a fellow who's known as Sir Lunch a Lot," Mr. Koops said. "They're still out there, mate. They're just lunching on."
Indeed, at 3:30 on a recent afternoon, Mr. Koops's colleague could not be reached at his office. He was, his secretary said, still at lunch.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 4; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1061 words

HEADLINE: CRITICS NOTEBOOK;
The Case of the Elusive XO

BYLINE: By William Grimes 

 BODY:
DINING out has its pleasure and its mysteries, and XO sauce is both.
Those two cryptic letters flitted around for years in the storage area of my brain taken up by old B-movie actors whose names elude me, books I intend to read but have never gotten around to and unsolved historical puzzles like the origin of bouillabaisse, which a faithful correspondent demands that I credit to the Greeks. (He's Greek.) 
 A few weeks ago, XO moved directly to my frontal lobe. It is one of the star attractions at a Hong Kong-style restaurant in Manhattan, Ping's Seafood, and on repeated visits I developed an infatuation with it. It came with a simple dish of steamed scallops, showing up as a small, viscous puddle on each shell. The flavor was intriguing: salty and sweet, hot and sour.
I put my nose right down to table level and studied the situation. I could see tiny bits of dried shrimp, garlic, chilies and scallop. There were very thin chopped-up noodles, too, and nearly microscopic chips and flecks of unknown ingredients. If this was XO, I had to get to the bottom of it.
A chance remark by a fellow diner heightened my curiosity. He mentioned in passing that when he grew up in Hong Kong, in the 1960's, XO sauce did not exist. All cuisines change, of course, but Chinese cuisine seems almost immutable, an endless list of classic dishes codified eons ago. The very idea of a new sauce on the block made the search for XO that much more compelling. Unfortunately, no one seemed to know very much about it. Even knowledgeable Sinophiles drew a blank when XO came up in the conversation. Books on Chinese cuisine failed to mention it. I began calling and e-mailing experts around the world. I queried the very diligent Hong Kong Tourist Association. I did not turn up a lot. XO, I was told, was born in Hong Kong fairly recently and usually involved dried scallops. That was about it.
Finally, I reached Ken Hom, the cookbook author, at his home in southwestern France. XO was music to his ears. It turned out that he, too, had embarked on the same quest, about 20 years ago when he was giving cooking classes in Hong Kong and kept encountering a strange new sauce with an odd name. XO.
Accompanied by Willie Mark, an expert on Hong Kong cuisine, Mr. Hom began eating his way around Hong Kong and quizzing chefs and owners. What was this XO, exactly? Where did it come from? Who invented it? The two detectives never found the smoking wok -- the world of food seldom yields clear-cut answers -- but they narrowed their circle of inquiry tightly enough to make an informed guess.
"There is a group of very expensive restaurants called Sun Tung Lok, owned by the Yuen family, that specializes in shark's fin dishes," Mr. Hom said. "I think they were the first." Then Fook Lam Moon, a celebrated seafood restaurant in Kowloon, began making it, too. "They actually started bottling and selling their sauce," Mr. Hom said, "which is very rare."
An alternative theory comes from Tian-Sak Wong, who edited the Hong Kong magazine Food World at the time. Mr. Wong credits two innovative seafood restaurants for the sauce, East Ocean and Tsui Hang Village.
The motivation for developing the sauce seems beyond dispute. "I think it's one of those things where restaurants thought, 'How can we squeeze more money out of the customers?' " Mr. Hom said. There was a lot of money to be squeezed in Hong Kong at the time. Why not take a basic chili sauce, add some expensive ingredients like dried scallops, give it a marketable name and charge a premium for it? At the time, wealthy diners were ordering the expensive, aged XO-grade Cognac at dinner and drinking it by the bottle through the meal. "XO" had just the right splurgy connotations of luxury, like Rolex or Rolls-Royce.
In Hong Kong, trends spread quickly. Although connoisseurs derided XO as inauthentic, and impractical to boot, it caught on as a status marker. Soon, restaurants all over town were making XO, often throwing in a little twist to establish their own brand, so to speak. The Regent Hotel, for example, added lemon grass to the basic recipe of dried scallops, dried shrimp, Yunan ham, shrimp roe, garlic and chili peppers. Even critics had to concede that the sauce was getting better. Diners began throwing XO on everything. A well-known sauce company, Lee Kum Kee, bottled its own version for the retail market.
In Vancouver, which probably has more Hong Kong-style restaurants per capita than any city in North America, XO is more or less standard at Chinese restaurants. Most of them charge a supplement of $2 to $5 for the sauce, and at some of the better restaurants it is bottled and sold for use during major holidays, like Chinese New Year. "Quite a lot of restaurants serve it," said Alan Yung, the manager of Sun Sui Wah Seafood, one of Vancouver's highest-rated Chinese restaurants, "although the quality depends on the what grade of dried scallop you use." His version uses dried garlic, dried chilies and uncured Virginia ham.
At Hon's Wun Tun House, a noodle restaurant, XO is sold on the side, like a condiment. It also appears in beef tenderloin with wide Shanghai noodles.
"It's terrific with any simple stir-fried seafood, like scallops or prawns with snow peas," said Stephen Wong, a Vancouver food writer, who grew up in Hong Kong. "It's also great with har-gow, the shrimp dumplings that come with dim sum."
I have never been to Vancouver, so I can only guess at the XO there. I did manage to find, at a shop across from the Manhattan Bridge market, a four-ounce bottle of Lee Kum Kee's XO, which is regarded as the best of the commercial versions. "Very good," the man behind the counter told me as he took my $6.75. "Very good, very hot."
It was neither. The sauce tasted excessively fishy, and the heat was nowhere to be found. It made me appreciate once again the Ping's version, a baroque creation whose seemingly endless list of ingredients includes fresh scallops, dried scallops, dried shrimp, shrimp roe, salted fish, dried ham, fresh green chilies, garlic, shallots, bacon, noodles and minced chicken. It takes the XO formula, already a newfangled, gaudy creation thrust upon the world by an overheated, fast-money economy, and works so many changes on it that surely a new name is required for this gilded lily. May I suggest Trump sauce?

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES

 BODY:

THE EURO GAINS. The euro rose as traders bet that the European Central Bank will raise interest rates in the coming weeks. In New York, the euro settled at 91.32 cents, up from 90.49 cents on Monday.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Industrial Output Advanced 0.4% in July

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Industrial output rose in July, as production of computers and productivity-enhancing business equipment offset declines for automobiles, appliances and electricity, Federal Reserve data showed today.
Overall industrial production increased 0.4 percent last month, as expected, after gaining 0.2 percent in June. The details suggest that higher borrowing costs imposed by the Fed are slowing the market for expensive consumer goods without stalling efforts by companies to become more efficient. 
 "The Fed is probably seeing what it wants to see happen: a modest slowdown on the consumer side, but growth on the business investment side, which will improve productivity and keep inflation under control," said Clare Zempel, chief investment strategist for Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee.
The Federal Open Market Committee meets next week to decide whether six increases in the overnight bank lending rate since June 1999 have been enough to cool the economy and keep inflation in check. At 6.5 percent, the rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans is at a nine-year high. The rate helps determine what banks charge their customers.
The plant-use rate, which measures how much of capacity factories put to work, rose to 82.3 percent from 82.2 percent in June. Analysts had expected a rate of 82.1 percent.
Production of consumer goods fell 0.5 percent after showing no change in June and falling 0.1 percent in May. Output of autos and related products fell 6.6 percent.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
High Court Urged to Hear Microsoft Appeal Quickly

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Declaring that the outcome of the Microsoft antitrust case could affect nearly every person who uses a computer, the Justice Department urged the Supreme Court yesterday to hear the company's appeal quickly so "that justice is not denied through delay."
The Supreme Court can hear direct appeals in civil antitrust cases brought by the federal government if it thinks the expedited review is in the national interest. 
 In its filing yesterday, the Justice Department argued forcefully that the Microsoft lawsuit is surely such a case. "A lengthy appeals process," the government stated, "could irreparably harm competition in a vital and rapidly evolving sector of the national economy."
Last month, Microsoft asked the court to let its appeal go first to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, which had ruled for the company in a related case. Microsoft said the appeals court was the proper place for an initial review because the company's appeal raised many technical issues and argued that the trial judge made a series of procedural errors.
Microsoft will file a legal brief with the Supreme Court on Tuesday, seeking to undermine the arguments the government made yesterday.
With its filing, the Justice Department essentially tried to make it more difficult for the Supreme Court to decline a direct review. It characterized Microsoft's arguments as all but an insult to the court's competence. Microsoft, the government stated, "overstates the complexity of this case" and "underestimates this court's capabilities."
The government also suggested that if the court declined, it would leave the antitrust Expediting Act of 1903, which was amended in 1974, as a dead letter.
From 1903 until 1974, all appeals of civil antitrust cases brought by the government went directly to the Supreme Court, but the 1974 amendment gave the court more discretion in which appeals it heard directly. The standard, under the 1974 amendment, is that the case should be of "general public importance in the administration of justice."
In pointed language, the government told the court: "The stakes in this case for the national economy are immense. If this case does not qualify for direct review under the Expediting Act, it is difficult to imagine what future case would."
Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who heard the lawsuit in Federal District Court, ruled this year that Microsoft was a monopoly that had repeatedly violated the nation's antitrust laws. And he ordered that the company be split in two, an order he later shelved pending appeals. Microsoft is appealing both Judge Jackson's ruling and his breakup order.
The votes of four of the Supreme Court's nine justices would be needed for the court to hear an expedited appeal. If the case went directly to the Supreme Court, it could be resolved in a year. If it went first to the appeals court, the resolution could take up to two years.
The Supreme Court's decision on whether to hear the appeal directly could well be crucial to the outcome and the impact of the Microsoft case, legal experts say.
If the court proceeded with a direct appeal, they say, it would be a favorable sign for the government. The government would avoid a federal appeals court where Microsoft has done well in the past. And a move for expedited treatment would suggest that the court wanted to resolve a pressing problem quickly.
"If the Supreme Court's instinct is that Microsoft is a monopoly whose activities are costly to society, it will be more likely to take the case directly," said Herbert Hovenkamp, a professor at the University of Iowa law school. "But if not, then the cost of lingering is not so high, and then it will be more likely to let the appeals court review the case first."
The effect of any sanctions against Microsoft, assuming it lost the case on appeal, would probably be dulled by an additional year of delay. "For that reason, this is a decisive moment in the litigation," said William Kovacic, a professor at the George Washington University law school.
In its filing, the government addressed that issue, noting, "Delay will postpone, and likely complicate substantially, the restoration of competition in the affected high-technology industries, which evolve at an extraordinary pace."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Stocks Head Mostly Lower on Weakness in Retail Shares

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks declined yesterday on weakness in retail shares after Home Depot reported earnings that fell short of the most optimistic expectations.
That dragged down the Dow Jones industrial average and snapped a three-day winning streak. 
 "You've got weakness in some retailers after Home Depot reported its results," said Chuck Carlson, co-manager of the Strong Dow 30 Value Fund. Mr. Carlson said the Dow was poised for a decline after gaining in 10 of the last 11 sessions and climbing 6.3 percent in that time.
The Dow dropped 109.14, or 0.98 percent, to 11,067.00. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.00, or 0.2 percent, to 1,488.56, with retail and financial shares the biggest losers. Four stocks fell for every three that rose on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Nasdaq composite index was up 1.97, to 3,851.66, as gains in semiconductor stocks including Intel and Rambus offset a decline in Network Appliance.
Chip stocks are benefiting from investor optimism that the Federal Reserve has finished raising interest rates, said John Forelli, portfolio manager at Independence Investment Associates in Boston. The last significant economic report before Fed policy makers meet next week is the Consumer Price Index, which will be released today. Analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News expected the report to show that retail inflation rose 0.1 percent in July.
Retail shares fell after several companies reported earnings at or near estimates. Home Depot dropped 51 5/16, to 53 3/4. Home Depot, the nation's largest home-improvement chain, reported fiscal second-quarter profit that met analysts' estimates while missing the most optimistic forecasts. The stock had jumped 7 percent in the last two sessions.
"They just did what was expected of them," Mr. Carlson said. "That may sound weird, but investors want to see these types of companies do better than expectations."
Target, the third-biggest discount retailer, fell 3, to 26 15/16. It reported second-quarter profit that matched analysts' estimates.
Wal-Mart Stores, the world's largest retailer, fell 3/4, to 51 3/4. It reported its results last week and warned of lower-than-expected earnings growth in the third quarter.
Brokerage stocks also fell, including Morgan Stanley, down 2 9/16, to 101 1/2; Goldman Sachs, down 2 5/8, to 118 3/16; and Lehman Brothers, down 6 5/8, to 130 3/4.
Network Appliance slid 51 3/16, to 841 5/16. The company reported profit that matched expectations, though new-order growth was not as strong as some analysts had expected. The shares have risen 80 percent in the last four months.
Intel rose 1 5/16, to 67 7/8, Rambus jumped 31 3/16, to 80 3/4. Texas Instruments advanced 2, to 65 3/4, extending Monday's 11 percent gain. Micron Technology rose for a third day, gaining 6, to 86 1/2.
Semiconductor stocks "should be able to enjoy a strong rally here through the end of the year," said Mark Edelstone, a Morgan Stanley Dean Witter analyst.
Ivax dropped 13, to 29 5/8, after the company said United States approval of its generic version of the Bristol-Myers Squibb cancer drug Taxol might be delayed by a new patent related to the drug, held by an undisclosed third party. Ivax's drug was expected to be approved no later than this month. Bristol-Myers rose 1 7/8, to 52 1/2.
Red Hat Inc. gained 2 3/16, to 24, leading a rally among companies that develop and distribute software based on the Linux operating system. International Business Machines, the world's biggest computer maker, said it would sell computers bundled with Red Hat software. VA Linux Inc., a maker of Linux software, climbed fell 3 1/16, to 381 5/16, and Corel, which distributes Linux software with its own suite of software, advanced 1/16, to 3 21/32.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Treasury Prices Drop
 
Treasuries fell as the price of oil climbed to a 10-year high.
The 10-year note fell 3/16, to 99 21/32. Its yield rose 3 basis points, to 5.80 percent from 5.77 percent. The 30-year bond fell 3 1/4, to 107 3/4 while its yield rose 2 basis points, to 5.71 percent from 5.69 percent.
The 30-year bond has returned 14.6 percent this year, including reinvested interest, while the 10-year note has gained 8 percent.
The Treasury is expected to announce today it will repurchase $1.5 billion in long-term debt this week.

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
Still a Baby Boom

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
America's economic miracle -- which Bill Clinton claimed as vindication in his Monday speech, but George W. Bush insists was an act of God -- didn't begin when Mr. Clinton took office in 1993. And no, it didn't begin with Ronald Reagan either. In fact, it didn't really start until 1996 or so. In other words, this boom is still in its infancy; and like all infants, it remains vulnerable. Mr. Clinton's greatest achievement is that during his second term he avoided the fiscal irresponsibility that might have strangled our "new economy" at birth -- irresponsibility that his opponent in the 1996 election would have practiced. Will his successor emulate his example?
Of course, Mr. Clinton prefers to think that everything good that happened these past eight years was his own doing. You can see why: Republicans confidently predicted that his 1993 tax increase would produce disaster -- a recession, an even worse budget deficit. So Mr. Clinton has an understandable urge to crow over the fact that even in his first term things turned out pretty well. 
 But we're talking analysis here, not poetic justice; and the truth is that growth from 1992 to 1996 -- like growth from 1982 to 1989 -- was just an ordinary business cycle recovery, with no sign of an upturn in the economy's sluggish long-term trend. And business cycles have very little to do with the administration that happens to be in office; they are determined mainly by the actions of the Federal Reserve, not the president. Jimmy Carter and George Bush got blamed for the recessions that happened on their watches, Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton got credit for the recoveries that happened on theirs; but neither the credit nor the blame was deserved.
It was only in 1996 -- even as the right was comparing Mr. Clinton's recovery unfavorably with Mr. Reagan's -- that things really began to change. Productivity, which had grown at a snail's pace for two decades, began to accelerate -- and accelerate, and accelerate, with recent numbers so high they take one's breath away. Unemployment began falling to levels not seen since the inflationary years of the late 1960's -- but this time without inflation. And from these fundamentals many other good things flowed, from falling poverty and plunging crime rates to a record budget surplus.
Did the Clinton-Gore administration create this miracle? Of course not. The best guess is that a long process of technological innovation finally reached critical mass, creating new opportunities that American business was uniquely ready to exploit. But the right question isn't whether the policies of this administration gave birth to the new economy; it is whether different leadership would have killed it. Not to put too fine a point on it: What would have happened if Bob Dole had won?
I've been going back over Mr. Dole's economic program -- which, remember, was centered on huge tax cuts -- and trying to calculate what today's economy would look like if those tax cuts had been enacted. One clear conclusion is that even if the economy had grown as fast as it actually did, the federal budget -- certainly the non-Social-Security budget, and probably the whole shebang -- would still be in deficit. And it seems to me that our morale, not to mention business confidence, would be a lot lower if that budget were still out of control.
Anyway, the economy surely wouldn't have grown as fast as it did. Our soaring productivity didn't come out of thin air; an important, perhaps crucial ingredient was an amazing surge in business investment, especially in information technology. And this surge didn't have to happen. In a full-employment economy like that of America in the late 1990's, budget deficits mean that the government is borrowing money that would otherwise have been invested. This drives up interest rates, depresses asset prices and crimps business plans. Had Mr. Dole's tax cuts been enacted, the resulting deficits would surely have crowded out a lot of investment -- and quite possibly have crowded out the productivity boom.
Not long ago America faced a choice between sober, sensible fiscal discipline and huge, irresponsible tax cuts. We chose discipline, and were rewarded with growth beyond our wildest dreams. So why would anyone today propose exactly the kind of irresponsibility we were lucky to avoid four years ago? 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Earnings Rise At Brazilian Plane Maker

BYLINE: By JENNIFER L. RICH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Benefiting from vibrant demand for regional jets, Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica S.A. reported a 35 percent gain in second-quarter earnings today on a 54 percent surge in sales.
The company, known as Embraer, is Brazil's largest manufacturing exporter and an emblem of Brazilian corporate success. In the recent quarter, it earned 112.9 million reais, or $62.6 million at current exchange rates, compared with 83.6 million reais in the period a year earlier. Quarterly sales rose to 1.2 billion reais, or $665.4 million. 
 The results reflected the demand for Embraer's short-haul jets, the fastest-growing segment of the commercial aviation market. The planes seat 30 to 110 people, with a range of about 1,500 miles, and are more profitable to operate on many routes than larger aircraft.
In the first half of the year, Embraer delivered 72 planes in the 30- to 50-seat ERJ-135/145 family to airlines around the world, up from 38 in the first half of 1999. In an effort to meet increasing demand, Embraer has accelerated its production to 14 aircraft a month and plans to speed that up further, to 16 planes a month by year-end.
Embraer valued its current backlog of undelivered planes at nearly $21 billion, of which $8.6 billion is in firm orders and $12.2 billion represents options on future purchases.
The company's president, Mauricio Botelho, has said that it plans to invest about $1.4 billion between 2000 and 2004, with $1.1 billion going into the development of new models and $300 million into construction of a new plant and research center. Embraer recently introduced the 44-seat ERJ-140, and is developing a family of jets in the 70-to-110-seat category.
For the first half of 2000, Embraer's earnings more than doubled, to 210.4 million reais, or $116.66 million, on a 62 percent increase in sales, to 2.2 billion reais, or $1.22 billion.
The strong financial results helped divert attention from a recent decision against Brazil at the World Trade Organization in a case involving an Embraer rival, Bombardier of Canada. The W.T.O., which arbitrates disputes between member countries, is expected to rule in the next couple of weeks on the value of sanctions that the Canadian government can levy on Brazilian imports.
In New York trading today, Embraer's American depository receipts fell 81.25 cents, to close at $23.6875. They began trading on July 21 at $18.50.

HEADLINE: Chancellor Blames Albany For Shortage of Teachers

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Further straining his relationship with State Education Commissioner Richard P. Mills, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy filed court papers yesterday that forcefully blamed Mr. Mills for the shortage of certified teachers in the city's 99 lowest-performing schools.
Specifically, Mr. Levy's lawyers charged, Mr. Mills has not made good on promises to provide financial incentives for certified teachers who agree to work in hard-to-staff schools; to improve programs at teaching colleges and attract strong candidates into those programs; and to finance a "master teacher" program, which would help outstanding teachers get advanced degrees and counsel less experienced teachers. 
 Mr. Levy was responding to a lawsuit that Mr. Mills filed on Aug. 1 to block the city from placing uncertified teachers in the 99 schools, designated as failing by the state. Mr. Mills went to court because the city had violated a new state policy that requires that only certified teachers be hired for those schools after September 1999.
In his lawsuit, Mr. Mills is demanding that the city not only replace nearly 600 unlicensed teachers assigned to the 99 schools last year, but also fill any additional vacancies with certified teachers. Mr. Levy has tried to comply by introducing several recruitment initiatives, including an alternative route toward obtaining certification and an increase in the starting salaries that private and parochial school teachers can earn if they transfer into the failing schools.
With Mr. Mills judging those actions inadequate, lawyers for Mr. Levy filed papers yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn that denounced the commissioner's demand as "arbitrary and capricious," not to mention "unreasonable and irrational." Since the State Board of Regents created the ban on uncertified teachers in failing schools, they said, it is the state's responsibility to find enough certified teachers to replace them.
"The Regents policy is a call to action for the state and the commissioner to drastically increase the pool of qualified teachers in New York State," Daniel McCray, a lawyer for the city who is representing Mr. Levy, wrote in the court papers. "However, the commissioner and the state have not come close to fulfilling their obligations."
In addition to failing to provide a financial incentive for certified teachers who agree to work in hard-to-staff schools and taking other promised steps, Mr. McCray wrote, the state had failed to fulfill its pledge to "initiate a campaign to encourage students to choose teaching as a profession."
Alan Ray, a spokesman for Mr. Mills, declined to comment on Mr. Levy's response to the lawsuit. He said the state would formally respond on Tuesday, in a hearing before Justice Joseph F. Bruno.
But in recent weeks, Mr. Mills and his aides have repeatedly said that the state has not only poured money into teacher recruitment, but also removed barriers that had hindered New York City's recruitment efforts. For example, the Board of Regents voted last month to allow alternative certification programs. And in March, the board voted to allow credentialed teachers from most other states to begin teaching here immediately rather than waiting to pass New York's certification exams.
Mr. Mills has maintained that the disproportionate number of uncertified teachers working in New York City's failing schools is the biggest obstacle to their improvement. But Mr. Levy, who faces the task of bringing the city's 1,100 public schools in line with the tough new standards he championed as a state regent, also has to face an array of local constituencies -- especially the powerful teachers' union, which has insisted that it will not allow Mr. Levy to force veteran certified teachers to transfer into failing schools against their will.
But pressure from the union is apparently not the only factor in Mr. Levy's refusal to take drastic measures. The court papers suggest that he is philosophically opposed to the idea of forcing teachers to work in troubled schools, especially now that the system is struggling to attract new teachers and retain older ones who are nearing retirement age.
Mr. Levy's lawyers also suggested in the court papers that uncertified teachers are not necessarily incompetent. They said that in recent years, the city has invested $50 million in on-the-job training for uncertified teachers in the 99 failing schools. The training has emphasized teaching practices "tailored for at-risk children," the court papers say.
"Many newly certified teachers fresh out of school, or veteran teachers who have worked only in high-performing schools, would not be familiar with these teaching methodologies," Mr. McCray wrote.
Student test scores have sharply improved in some of the schools, even though they have large numbers of uncertified teachers, Mr. McCray wrote. In particular, he pointed to P.S. 212 in the Bronx, where the percentage of students who scored in the lowest category decreased to 19.1 last year, from 53.2 percent in 1998. Yet nearly 40 percent of the teachers at that school are uncertified, according to the court papers.
The court papers suggested that Mr. Mills was being unrealistic in rigidly enforcing the new policy in light of the current teacher shortage. The ban on uncertified teachers in failing schools even extends to those in the Teach for America program, many of whom graduated from "the finest universities," the court papers say. Teach for America places recent college graduates in urban schools.
In a separate affidavit, Mr. Levy listed 13 recruiting strategies that the school board had used in recent months in an attempt to comply with the policy, and suggested there was nothing more that he could do.

HEADLINE: Navistar Cuts 1,100 Jobs, Citing Truck Order Drop

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Responding to a slowdown in heavy-truck orders in North America, the Navistar International Corporation said today that it would lay off 1,100 employees, or about 15 percent of its white-collar work force.
The company, one of the world's largest makers of heavy trucks, buses and diesel engines, said that after several years of spectacular growth, orders for big trucks in North America had been falling steadily, largely because of higher interest rates, soaring fuel prices and a glut of used trucks. 
 The announcement by Navistar, which is based in Chicago, comes just a day after Freightliner, a unit of DaimlerChrysler A.G. and the world's biggest maker of heavy trucks, said that it would cut 3,475 jobs, or about 19 percent of its work force.
Earlier this month, Paccar, the world's No. 2 truck maker, based in Bellevue, Wash., said that it would lay off 430 workers at a big-truck plant in Tennessee.
Though the economy remains strong, and demand for diesel engines and buses is robust, Navistar and other truck makers are trying to head off a cyclical downturn after what some industry experts said were two years of "excessive demand" for heavy-duty rigs. Higher interest rates have made it more expensive to finance the purchase of a new truck, and higher diesel prices have forced some trucking companies to park their rigs.
As a result, over the last year, orders for heavy-duty trucks -- which often cost $80,000 to $100,000 -- fell nearly 30 percent. Freightliner said yesterday that it expected heavy-duty truck sales in North America to drop about 25 percent from 1999.
And earlier this year, Navistar laid off 800 employees in Canada, where its heavy-duty trucks are made, and the company says it may cut 500 more jobs. The company, which markets its big trucks under the International brand name, has 19,000 employees worldwide.
The Navistar announcement was contained in its third-quarter earnings release, which reported profits excluding special items of $76 million, or $1.27 a share, compared with $77 million, or $1.17 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue edged up to $1.92 billion from $1.88 billion. The results slightly beat Wall Street projections of $1.24 a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
Shares of Navistar, which have been weak for much of the last year, fell $1.9375 yesterday, to $37.125.
John R. Horne, the chairman and chief executive of Navistar, said in a statement that the company was working to become less cyclical.
"The steps we plan will allow us to continue to build a healthy business in the downturn," he said, "and come out even stronger when the market turns up again."
The company said it would also take a charge in the fourth quarter related to the 1,100 job cuts.
Though heavy-truck orders, which make up about a quarter of Navistar's sales, are in decline, orders for medium-sized trucks are more stable, and sales of Navistar's diesel engines, which are used in U.P.S., U-Haul and pickup trucks, continues to grow. The company is also supplying diesel engines to the Ford Motor Company, which uses them in its sport utility vehicles. The company also said its school bus division was strong.
Analysts said today that they were not surprised by the Navistar announcement. Many investors have been warned about a drop in orders going back more than a year, and the stock prices of many of the big truck and engine makers have fallen.
"We're in the ninth inning in the stock prices," said Tobias M. Levkovich, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. "This news has all been discounted, and we think we might see a recovery by next spring in the order patterns."

HEADLINE: Deere Profit Up, But Stock Falls

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MOLINE, Ill., Aug. 15

 BODY:
Deere & Company said today that earnings more than doubled in its fiscal third quarter as a result of a rebound in farm machinery sales, more efficient manufacturing and the contributions of a recently acquired forestry equipment maker. Yet the company's shares fell more than 10 percent.
Deere reported income of $172.4 million, or 72 cents a share, in the three-month period ending on July 31, up from $68.9 million, or 29 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $3.63 billion from $3.04 billion. 
 The results exceeded the consensus forecast of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial, of earnings of 59 cents a share.
But Deere's shares lost $3.75 today, closing at $33.25. Even as it reported the profit increase, the company said that "weakness in the fundamentals of the farm equipment economy is likely to continue next year," with industrywide sales of farm equipment in the United States and Canada likely to be flat to 5 percent lower.
It recently acquired the Timberjack Group for $600 million to create one of the world's largest producers of forestry equipment.

HEADLINE: Program Recognizes Teachers' Extra Efforts

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
John Caffrey had been teaching English for 31 years when he heard about a new way to gain recognition for his skills, one available to teachers nationwide. The hitch: applicants had to pass a rigorous and time-consuming assessment that included videos of their teaching, samples of their students' work and essays analyzing their classroom techniques.
Mr. Caffrey, who was teaching middle school in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was not the type to mind the extra work. He already had two master's degrees and was eager for another credential, even if it did not mean higher pay or career advancement. 
 "I simply wanted to be recognized as an expert in my field," Mr. Caffrey said last week. "I wanted the confidence that affirmation like that could bring."
So in 1995, Mr. Caffrey became one of the first New York City teachers to earn advanced certification from the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, an independent panel that sets standards for experienced teachers. The board, created in 1987, was recommended in a landmark report, "A Nation Prepared: Teachers for the 21st Century," by the Carnegie Forum on Education and the Economy. National board certification does not replace state certification, which remains an entry level requirement for all teachers. Instead, it helps teachers with at least three years of experience measure their skills using benchmarks set by the panel, which is mostly made up of teachers but also includes school administrators, union officials, lawmakers and business leaders.
"It recognizes people who go beyond what is expected," said Karen Zumwalt, a professor at Columbia Teachers College, "and it motivates people who want to grow professionally but aren't sure how to do it."
Last year, a record 2,967 teachers earned national board certification, bringing the total to 4,804 nationwide since 1995. But only 62 teachers in New York State have earned the credential, and of those, only 25 work in New York City. Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, said the program has been slow to catch on here because there were few financial incentives attached and because city teachers were overextended as it is.
But as education has become a crucial election issue and states have scrambled to attract teachers in the face of a shortage, New York has joined several dozen other states in creating incentives for teachers to get national certification. The state now pays the $2,300 application fee for most teachers. And starting this year, the state plans to give $10,000 a year for three years to teachers who earn the advanced certification and agree to work in low-performing schools. In New York City, that means the 99 "schools under registration review," which have been designated by the state as failing.
City teachers who earn national certification also can get a $3,700 raise. But those with 30 credits beyond master's degrees -- about 44 percent of the city's teachers -- have already received that increase and cannot get more. Ms. Weingarten said this lack of an additional incentive was the main reason so few city teachers have gone through the process.
The new incentives may be working. This spring, 100 teachers in New York State submitted applications to the national board, up from 59 in 1999. Those teachers will find out in November whether they passed the assessment. Meanwhile, about 50 city teachers are applying for national certification in the coming school year, up from 20 this spring. Typically, slightly more than half of each year's applicants are certified .
During the school year, applicants videotape their classroom instruction, submit lesson plans and student work samples, and write essays reflecting on how they help students learn. They also have to write extensively about their work outside the classroom with colleagues, parents and the community. In the summer, they finish the process with written exams on the subject they teach, as well as teaching techniques.
"It takes up all the extra time that you possibly have," said Beverly Tinort, who teaches first grade at C.S. 21 in Brooklyn and earned national board certification last year. "But it's so worth it. Teachers in New York are so burdened, we never get a chance to stop and reflect on how we're doing our job. This is a blessing because it forces us to stop and reflect."
As part of the assessment, Ms. Tinort had to sit with colleagues and watch a video she had made of herself teaching sixth graders. Her colleagues picked apart everything from her body language to why girls seemed more engaged in the lesson than boys.
"Early on it was very painful to watch yourself with that critical eye," Ms. Tinort said. "But you pick up so many things that you never would have realized."
She said, "You really pick up on your weaknesses."
Others, like Mr. Caffrey, said the national certification process did not improve their skills but simply affirmed that their teaching methods were on the mark.
"When I go into classrooms now I have a sense of accomplishment," said Mr. Caffrey, who now runs a union-sponsored teacher training center in Brooklyn's District 14. "I always felt teaching was a noble profession and I worked so hard every day, and it just didn't seem to me that people in the management system recognized that. Now I have some recognition."
Skeptics question whether nationally certified teachers are really better. Chester E. Finn Jr., an assistant secretary of education under President Reagan, said there was no data on how the students of these teachers performed compared with their peers.
"After 10 years and gazillions of dollars and an awful lot of states being wooed to give bonuses to these folks, all we know is that other teachers admire their teaching," Mr. Finn said. "I need to see some proof that these teachers are more effective in terms of student learning."

HEADLINE: Tire Deaths Are Linked To Rollovers

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Government data released this evening showed that virtually all the recent deaths linked to Firestone tires now being recalled occurred when sport utility vehicles, most of them Ford Explorers, rolled over after the tires failed.
Federal regulators said tonight that they had received more than 750 complaints about the failure of Firestone tires, involving 62 deaths. That is significantly more complaints and more deaths than previously announced, and more deaths than for any other safety recall involving autos or any kind of auto parts. The only recall of a comparable number of tires, another Firestone recall in 1978, followed far more complaints to regulators -- 14,000 -- but fewer deaths -- 41. 
 Why have the recent tire failures been unusually deadly? The tires recalled in 1978 were on cars; the tires at issue now are on sport utility vehicles and a few pickup trucks, which are harder to control when a tire fails.
Safety groups and lawyers representing crash victims are urging automakers to make changes, like redesigning the tires and the suspensions, so that sport utilities will be less likely to go out of control and roll over when a tire fails. But automakers have mostly rejected these ideas as they try to satisfy customers.
For example, putting nylon coatings inside would help hold the tires together when the tread peels off, as has happened with the Firestone tires. But that produces a bouncier ride, which few drivers choose at showrooms, so automakers seldom request the nylon from tire makers, said Brook Lindbert, the General Motors engineering director for tire and wheel systems.
Recommending a high inflation pressure for tires, which the Ford Motor Company did not do for the Explorer, reduces the likelihood of a tire failure. But more fully inflated tires produce a bumpier ride, said Tom Baughman, Ford's engineering director for North American trucks. If the recommended pressure is fairly low to begin with, there is less of a safety margin to protect against leaks that may cause tire pressure to fall to dangerously low levels, he acknowledged.
Most sport utility vehicles still use the stiff suspensions of the pickup trucks on which they were based. These shared suspensions hold down the cost and improve performance on rough terrain, a feature many drivers cherish even if they never leave the asphalt.
Balancing these often conflicting demands is difficult. The question now in court cases and for regulators is whether too much safety has been compromised, and whether automakers have set a balance too far in the direction of customer desires and too little in the interest of safety.
Led by Ford, which installed most of the recalled Firestone tires on its Ford Explorer vehicles, automakers say that they have set an appropriate balance between customer satisfaction and safety. Even with the deaths attributed to Firestone tires, Explorers have a 22 percent lower death rate in rollovers than competitors' midsize sport utilities and a 24 percent lower death rate in crashes over all, said Ernie Grush, Ford's manager of safety data analysis.
While sport utility occupants have high death rates in rollovers, their overall death rates are no higher than for car occupants. This is because sport utilities fare well in collisions with lower-riding cars, he said, adding that, "Customers should look at and consider the overall accident rate in all types of circumstances."
While the deaths now being attributed to tires might seem numerous to Explorer owners and are large for a recall of tires or auto parts, they represent a smaller problem by traffic safety standards.
The tire-related deaths spread over the last several years are just a tiny part of the much bigger problem of rollovers, which kill 9,500 Americans a year. Rollovers, in turn, are just part of the overall problem of automobile crashes, which claim 41,000 lives annually.
The high incidence of rollovers in the tire incidents could, however, focus attention on a move by Senate Republicans and the auto industry to block publication by the government of rollover ratings for cars and for light trucks, a category that includes minivans and pickup trucks as well as sport utilities.
After 27 years of study and numerous objections by the auto industry, federal regulators announced plans on May 25 to begin the ratings this autumn. But after strenuous auto industry lobbying, the Senate inserted a little-noticed provision in the transportation budget this summer barring regulators from issuing the rules and ordering the National Academy of Sciences to conduct a one-year study of the regulators' technique for the ratings. The House version of the transportation budget does not contain this provision, and House and Senate conferees are scheduled to work out the differences in the budgets early next month.
Michael Stanton, the senior lobbyist for the Washington-based Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers, said the regulators' proposed rating system was too imprecise. The system compares a vehicle's width to the height of its center of gravity. The system does not take into account high-technology features like roof-mounted air bags, or the computerized vehicle stability systems that Ford plans to offer.
But Ricardo Martinez, the administrator until last autumn of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which regulates vehicle safety, said that the rating system was reliable and should be adopted quickly. The system assigns vehicles one to five stars, like government crash test ratings.
Sport utilities are more prone than cars to roll over if they lose a tire, although rollovers also depend on variables like driver skill, Mr. Lindbert of G.M. said. The higher a vehicle's center of gravity, the more the vehicle and its occupants tend to lean forward during braking, and this makes it important to retain as much traction as possible on the rear tires to keep the back end of the vehicle under control, he said.
If a rear tire develops problems, Mr. Lindbert said, "in many regards you have the potential to get sideways on the road," which tends to produce rollovers.
Tonight's government data showed that while front and rear tires are subject to failure, rear tire failures caused all but 2 of the 131 rollovers reported to regulators. Not all rollovers resulted in death. Calculating the frequency of rollovers when tires fail is almost impossible because no one knows for sure how many tire failures there are. The government does not collect the data and tire makers do not share their data on their own brands.
An analysis of federal data on deaths in tire-related accidents from 1990 to 1997, the most recent year available, shows that 91 percent of the deaths of occupants in Ford Explorers involved rollovers. Only 28 percent of the tire-related deaths in cars involved rollovers, said Leon Robertson, a retired Yale University epidemiologist who analyzed the data and who has also worked for plaintiff lawyers over the years.
Tonight's government data included public complaints of 52 deaths in Explorers that rolled over after Firestone tires failed, and five more deaths in Explorers for which the complaints did not mention whether rollovers occurred. Only two Explorers did not roll over. The remaining deaths also involved rollovers, notably a Chevrolet Blazer and GMC Suburban. G.M., Nissan and Toyota use Firestone tire sizes that have not been recalled, and DaimlerChrysler does not use Firestone tires.
Even before the Firestone tire problems, automakers had begun to make changes to their sport utilities. The next generation of Ford Explorers, which will go on sale in January, has a softer, car-like suspension of coiled springs instead of a truck suspension of steel bars that flex when the vehicle goes over bumps.
With the new suspension will go new tires. Ford decided several years ago that the new Explorers would no longer use 15-inch tires but would have 16-inch tires instead. The 16-inch size has not been recalled -- although some plaintiff lawyers have called for this -- and is already used on the more expensive Explorers now. The tire has a recommended inflation pressure of 30 pounds per square inch, four pounds more than the 15-inch tires being recalled.
Wes Sherwood, a Ford spokesman, said tonight that even before the current problems, Ford was considering a pressure of more than 30 pounds for the next generation of Explorers, particularly for the rear tires.
But safety experts caution that the biggest safety gains will come not from tire changes but from motorists' buckling their seat belts. Government statisticians say that halving the frequency of unbuckled motorists, to one-sixth of front-seat occupants from one-third, would save several thousand lives each year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Ford Explorer in Arlington, Tex., after the casing of its Firestone tire pulled away, causing the driver to lose control of the vehicle. This particular tire, a Firestone FR680, is not one of those being recalled. (Associated Press)(pg. C21)
 
Charts: "Tire Trade-Offs"
Safety groups and plaintiffs' lawyers disagree with automakers over how to make sport utility vehicles safe while preserving their market appeal. The debate has centered on the recall of Firestone tires installed mainly on Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles, but is part of a broader controversy over tire and sport utility design.
 
TIRE INFLATION
 
Safety Groups and Lawyers
Sport utility tires should be inflated to at least 30 pounds per square inch, because underinflation strains the tire and can cause blowouts.
 
Automakers
Underinflation is a safety problem only below 20 p.s.i. Inflating cold tires to 26 p.s.i. at the service station provides an adequate margin of safety against leaks. Higher pressures cause a bouncy, truck-like ride unpopular with buyers who have recently switched to S.U.V.'s from cars.
 
SUSPENSIONS
 
Safety Groups and Lawyers
S.U.V. suspensions are stiff because they come from pickup trucks, so automakers call for soft tires to compensate.
 
Automakers
For off road use, S.U.V.'s need stiff truck suspensions to carry heavy loads. In any event, more S.U.V.'s are being equipped with car suspensions, because few S.U.V. buyers go off-road.
 
TIRE DESIGN
 
Safety Groups and Lawyers
The steel belts on radial tires for S.U.V.'s should have nylon coatings to keep the tires from coming apart. Tire makers do not install the nylon coatings to save pennies per tire.
 
Automakers
Nylon coatings are unnecessary, except on high-speed cars like the Chevrolet Corvette. The coatings produce a bumpier ride that few S.U.V. buyers want.
 
ROLLOVERS
 
Safety Groups and Lawyers
In general, S.U.V.'s roll over too readily.
 
Automakers
While S.U.V.'s roll over more often than cars, overall death rates are similar, because S.U.V. occupants are less likely than car occupants to die in collisions with other vehicles.
 
(Sources: Public Citizen; C. Tab Turner, plaintiffs' lawyer; Ford; General Motors)(pg. C21)
 
"Most Likely To Roll Over"
Cars and sport utility vehicles have similar overall death rates (about 145 deaths per million registered vehicles a year), but the cause of death in an S.U.V. accident is more likely to be from the vehicle rolling over.
 
PERCENTAGE OF CRASH DEATHS FROM ROLLOVERS
 
Sport utility vehicles -- 62%
Vans and pickups -- 40%
Cars -- 22%

HEADLINE: Warring Populisms

 BODY:
Depending on your point of view, it was either old-time religion night or dinosaur time at the Democratic National Convention. Two of the party's great roarers, Senator Ted Kennedy and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, were on hand to remind the faithful of the party's traditional New Deal values. John F. Kennedy's only surviving child, Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg, reminded voters of that golden era when Democrats like her father could depend on a solid base of blue-collar voters. Earlier in the day Vice President Al Gore was in Michigan, the heart of union country, to warn that "the powerful interests are going to fight against us with everything they've got" to prevent the Democratic ticket from defending working families.
Even before Franklin D. Roosevelt's politically productive attacks on financial "royalists," economic populism was a staple of Democratic campaigns. For years, when Democrats turned to their venerable themes of economic justice and fairer income distribution, the Republicans accused them of promoting class warfare, but to little avail. Then under the tutelage of Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan, the G.O.P. learned to trump the Democrats' appeals to middle-class financial solidarity with their own appeals to Main Street in the form of a cultural populism built around a powerful set of patriotic, religious and racial symbols. Now both Mr. Gore and his Republican opponent, Gov. George W. Bush, seem eager for a renewed clash centered on their competing brands of populism. 
 Although the apostate Clinton strategist, Dick Morris, argues that Mr. Gore is making a mistake to revive "liberal" economic themes, both Mr. Gore and President Clinton seem confident the Democratic ticket can win an argument over who gets the fruits of what Mr. Gore calls "unprecedented economic abundance." In one sense, the target presented by Mr. Bush, with his old-money pedigree and his oil-patch running mate, is irresistible. He would spend billions on tax relief for investors, top earners and inheritors of large estates. His plan is a perfect setup for Mr. Gore's favorite pitch that he "fights for working families" while the G.O.P. remains the party of "the wealthy, the well connected and the powerful."
Mr. Gore's rhetoric, like that of Mr. Kennedy and Mr. Jackson, has a root system that dates back to William Jennings Bryan. Populism in its original form arose as a protest against the ability of agricultural, railroad and industrial interests to buy influence over government policy. Today's soft-money game is a lineal descendant of that form of corruption -- a fact that undercuts the purity of Mr. Gore's claim to be an opponent of special interests. In fact, the Democrats have been lapping up soft money from corporations and wealthy donors, having already passed $120 million before starting the fund-raising events associated with their convention. As John Broder and Don Van Natta Jr. reported in yesterday's Times, corporate donors and lobbyists play the money game at both conventions in what Senator Russell Feingold calls a "system of legalized extortion and legalized bribery." The inescapable conclusion is that Mr. Gore, no amateur exaggerator, grossly exaggerates his party's independence of special interests.
Even so, the convention oratory reflects an underlying reality that the Democrats do offer a fairer approach to parceling out the benefits of the Clinton boom. Mr. Gore's promise to take on the drug companies and health management organizations does have more credibility than Mr. Bush's less aggressive proposals. Moreover, should he carry out his campaign promise to outlaw soft money contributions that have tainted both conventions, Mr. Gore will have put some real muscle behind the Democrats' quadrennial exercise in ringing the century-old chimes of economic populism.

HEADLINE: THE DEMOCRATS: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Grabs Torch From Clinton, Hoping to Avoid Burns

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: MONROE, Mich., Aug. 15

 BODY:
With a bear hug and a slight nudge, President Clinton pushed his understudy, Al Gore, to center stage today, relinquishing the limelight to the man he hopes will succeed him.
It was a metaphoric ceremony that Vice President Gore has longed for as Mr. Clinton has effortlessly dominated news coverage and captured public attention -- and overshadowed Mr. Gore's efforts to present himself as a leader in his own right. 
 Mr. Clinton tried today to pass that torch to Mr. Gore here before a crowd of more than 15,000 people, the largest audience Mr. Gore has seen since he officially announced his candidacy more than a year ago.
"The nominee of the Democratic Party," Mr. Clinton said, "my partner and friend for the last eight years, understands where we are, where we're going and how it will affect ordinary citizens more than any other public figure in this country over the last 20 years."
Vouching for Mr. Gore, Mr. Clinton, who was operating on three hours of sleep after delivering his valedictory speech in Los Angeles on Monday, added: "I hope you'll take my word for this, because I spent most of my adult life studying economics and the development of our country. The things that have happened in the last eight years -- the good things -- are nothing compared to the good things that can happen in the next eight years. Nothing!"
Mr. Gore, who had been standing ramrod straight behind the president with Mrs. Clinton and Tipper Gore, Mr. Gore's wife, embraced Mr. Clinton and shed his jacket as he moved to the lectern.
"I want to thank you, Mr. President, for giving me a chance to serve my country for the last eight years," Mr. Gore said, "by working to help strengthen your hand."
He introduced his wife as "the woman I love," and went on to tell the stories of several people whose lives had been improved by Clinton administration programs. He said that Mr. Clinton had built a strong foundation for the nation and that the election was about whether voters wanted to build on that foundation or allow it to erode. Mr. Gore did not mention his Republican opponent, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, but he did refer to the governor's proposal for an across-the-board tax cut of $1.3 trillion over 10 years. Mr. Gore has proposed tax cuts of about $500 billion.
"You know, Bill Clinton worked hard to get this economy right," Mr. Gore said. "And I'm pledging to you here today, I am not going to let the other side wreck it and take it away from us. We're going to keep the prosperity going."
It was not clear whether this ceremony would usher in for Mr. Gore a transfer of attention -- and an enhancement of his standing with the electorate -- or whether Mr. Clinton would continue to steal the show.
As it was, Mr. Clinton upstaged Mr. Gore as soon as the symbolic "passing of the torch" was over . (No object was actually passed, as producers of television news programs had been led to believe might happen.) As Mr. Gore began speaking, eyes were diverted to Mr. Clinton who was draping his arms around Mrs. Clinton and Mrs. Gore.
After they left, the Clintons stopped at a McDonald's, an event that made a huge splash with local residents.
Mr. Clinton marked the moment with a crispy chicken sandwich and fries. Whether he was anticipating one of the advantages of being an ordinary citizen or downing some comfort food to soothe his angst over the dimming of the limelight, he seemed cheerful enough.
"If I'm going to be a citizen again, I'm going to have to start getting used to it," the president said as he shrugged and then slipped a $20 tip to the teenage waitresses, telling them to "go out and have some fun."
Monroe, a town of 22,600 people near Lake Erie, was chosen because it represents the challenge ahead for Mr. Gore. It is a swing district that includes both rural and suburban voters, both high-tech and low-tech workers and an equal number of Democrats and Republicans.
It is a bellwether area of the state, having voted for winners in most presidential elections in modern history. A survey from earlier this month, after Mr. Gore picked Senator Joseph I. Lieberman as his running mate, showed Governor Bush winning the support of 45 percent of those likely to vote and Mr. Gore 37 percent.
"If Gore can win here, he can win the state" and the national election, said Ed Sarpolus, a pollster in Lansing. "This is one of Gore's toughest audiences. His problem is still Bill Clinton, the person."
